I've been informed that there is some misunderstanding about something which was transcribed from my "Conversation with a disciple." I did not take any time to check and edit that transcription as I sometimes do with transcriptions. Hence, I decided to take the responsibility myself to clarify a point which may not be clear.

When I said, "The sin can apply to many people. It's not just those sins which are inflicted upon us.", I was responding particularly to the person sitting before me who was admitting that her perspective was jaded. She was suggesting that she was hating the sinner as much as the sin and she went on to explain how she was suffering from their sin.

I was therefore specifically addressing the tendency to hate the sinner when the sin causes our own suffering. In other words, when it causes pain to ourselves (unless, of course, it's the pain which comes from genuine Vaisnava compassion for other's sufferings…. which was not the case in this case) we tend to lose our objectivity and hate the sinner and not just the sin.

If our anger towards the sinner is based on pure Vaisnava compassion, then according to our Vaisnava siddhanta, it's justifiable to become angry with the sinner when the sinner willfully causes pain to other Vaisnavas. But that was not the case in this case either.

But even the Vaisnava anger mentioned above has to be closely looked at within one's own heart, much in the same way Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur has described in "Amrita Vani" in a quote I oftentimes speak from (cited at the end of this explanation):

Therefore, I said, "the sin can apply to many people" simply to emphasize this point, that it's better to not hate the sinner based solely on sins committed only to ourselves, much in the same way as Dharma the bull did not hate the personality of Kali for breaking his legs.

In this regard, Srila Prabhupada explained the following point in his purport to SB 1.17.18:

"Although the bull, or the personality of religion, and the cow, the personality of the earth, knew perfectly well that the personality of Kali was the direct cause of their sufferings, still, as devotees of the Lord, they knew well also that without the sanction of the Lord no one could inflict trouble upon them. According to the Padma Purana, our present trouble is due to the fructifying of seedling sins, but even those seedling sins also gradually fade away by execution of pure devotional service. Thus even if the devotees see the mischief-mongers, they do not accuse them for the sufferings inflicted. They take it for granted that the mischief-monger is made to act by some indirect cause, and therefore they tolerate the sufferings, thinking them to be God-given in small doses, for otherwise the sufferings should have been greater."

It was on this basis that I said, "The sin can apply to many people."

I realize that this may not fully address whatever questions arose on this topic, but at this point in time, it's the most I can offer given all of the other matters I'm currently dealing with.

I sincerely hope, however, that at least some of the confusion has been cleared by this explanation.

I will not be able to go any further than this, neither now nor in the immediate future.

Hare Krsna

Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's quote:

Is anger toward those envious of devotees a limb of devotional service?

We should display anger toward those who are envious of devotees. This is a particular limb of devotional service. A lack of anger against blasphemers is unjustified. But we need to understand who is actually envious of devotees. Those who do not serve the Supreme Lord, the Supersoul and most blissful friend of all living entities, do not benefit themselves but instead invite trouble by their envy of Kṛṣṇa and the Vaiṣṇavas. Such people are branded as envious, and we should not show them mercy. These people become intoxicated by worshiping materialists. We should both ignore them and display our anger toward them.

But before that, we have to see whether we ourselves are envious of devotees, whether we ourselves are actually serving Kṛṣṇa. Or are we serving something else on the pretext of serving Kṛṣṇa? How much are we attached to Kṛṣṇa? Are we trying to enjoy the objects meant for Kṛṣṇa’s enjoyment?

I think my enjoyment-prone material body is fiercely envious of Kṛṣṇa and His devotees, because instead of thinking constantly of Kṛṣṇa’s lotus feet and happiness, I am busy worrying about my own happiness, blaspheming others, and looking for faults. I do not look at myself at all. I am such an offender at the feet of devotees that I should first learn to display anger toward myself. I am so envious of devotees that I should beat myself with shoes simply to purify myself. Then I can set an example for others and sincerely engage in the service of Hari, guru, and the Vaiṣṇavas. I must remember that everyone is worshiping Hari but me. I am unable to do so. I should also remember that I may die at any moment.

So first we should show anger toward our own sinful propensities, such as our desire for profit, adoration, and distinction and our propensity to cheat others. We must correct ourselves first. Otherwise, we cannot correct others. Then we have to correct those who are related to us, who are envious of the spiritual master and Kṛṣṇa and who are pulling us toward material enjoyment by tempting us. This is the secret of success.

data.title: Bada Haridas Prabhu's Bhajans
data.blurb: Last night I was chanting bhajans with the devotees assembled in the Towaco community both before and after Dhirasanta Maharaja's wonderful talk from Bhagavad-gita about the importance of controlling the mind.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last night I was chanting bhajans with the devotees assembled in the Towaco community both before and after Dhirasanta Maharaja's wonderful talk from Bhagavad-gita about the importance of controlling the mind.

When devotees were asking me to chant certain bhajans, most of which I had learned from Bada Haridas Prabhu, I felt I should give credit where credit is due.

Before chanting the next bhajan, I decided to ask permission to tell a short story about how I came to learn bhajans from Bada Haridas Prabhu.

After telling my story, which I won't repeat here due to time limits, I told everyone that I was holding on to many recordings of my first visit with Bada Haridas Prabhu in the late 1990's when I spent several evenings together with him and Panca Tattva dasa (also from Alachua) just chanting different bhajans with him and recording them for the purpose of learning them from him.

It was during those recordings, that I realized that the Alachua community was in possession of a very valuable jewel which needed to be shared with the rest of the world. So I invited Bada Haridas Prabhu to come to Ukraine.

The rest is history… again, another story too long to repeat here.

I promised the devotees attending the Towaco program that I would make the bhajans Panca Tattva dasa recorded for me during those evenings in Alachua available for everyone if they wished to download them.

I told everyone that I had approximately sixty recordings, which is true, but after looking at the files I realized that a good part of those recordings were done at a time other than when I was personally with Bada Haridas Prabhu. Before making all those additional recordings available, therefore, I should first check with Bada Haridas Prabhu and ask him if it's OK to release them.

Meanwhile, I will post 16 of those recordings. These are the only ones I can find right now from the ones we chanted together in Alachua in the late 90's. Bada Haridas Prabhu was leading, I was drinking the nectar of his association and was also playing the mrdanga because there were only three of us present. Panca Tattva dasa was playing kartals.

You can download the files by clicking HERE.

Hare Krishna

data.title: Conversation with a disciple
data.blurb:
Disciple:

I would like to discuss the same topic we discussed in our last conversation… about the devotees who are disturbing me.

Niranjana Swami:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Disciple:

I would like to discuss the same topic we discussed in our last conversation… about the devotees who are disturbing me.

Niranjana Swami:

I don't remember all of the details of our conversation but I thought I said that if you accept them as they are, that the problem would go away. What I meant, I'm almost sure, is that if you just accept them as they are, it meant that you were accepting that however they dealt with you was for your own purification. If you see things in that way then you see Krishna's hand, that Krishna has arranged for you to be in this situation and this situation is meant for your own purification, and if you accept it in that way then you will no longer see them as problems anymore. I might have also given my own experience, that I oftentimes talk about, the time when my temple president was insulting me. Did I?

Disciple:

Not completely. But I remember.

Niranjana Swami:

You remember the story? Because I was speaking to you based upon my own experience, that it was very difficult for me to tolerate the way I was being dealt with by this particular temple president. And you know the story how I was asked to give SB class, and I was speaking, with references of the Bhagavatam about Maharaja Rahugana. And then I was getting such wonderful realizations that I realized that I could have never possibly gotten these realizations if my president hadn't treated me that way. And I became grateful. And then when I thanked him, in my heart, for the way he treated me. I really changed. The problems went away. And he stopped treating me that way. So it was based on my own realization.

Disciple:

Did you have any bad feelings toward him?

Niranjana Swami:

No.

Disciple:

OK. Our situation in asrama. Ekadasi Night. Kirtan on the roof. I cannot sleep. I cannot go on harinama. And I'm tired and I want to sleep but the kirtan is very loud… mrdanga kartals etc. I cannot rest. The next day I feel completely broken. I do not have any desire to do anything. And I feel that they must not do that. It's not correct. I know. Kirtan is OK but  there is time and circumstances. I mean when devotional service of someone disturbs my own devotional service, what should I do?

Niranjana Swami:

What else can you do but tolerate?

Disciple:

Of course I had to tolerate.

Niranjana Swami:

Yes. Because you tried to get them to change and they don't. I remember you telling me that also. You appealed to them. You appealed to others, and nothing changed. What else can you do?

Disciple:

I'm ready to tolerate, but I'm not ready to forgive them and to feel some good feelings towards them.

Niranjana Swami:

So, but then that means that your mind is disturbed by their presence. So keep you distance from them. Otherwise you're going to have to be disturbed.

Disciple:

It's one building. No way to keep a distance. In our society we practically never speak about good manners, at least to be sensitive to other people.

Niranjana Swami:

We speak about this all of the time, but maybe they don't hear about it in your asrama, that's all. But I wouldn't say "in our society". That's a pretty broad generalization… in our society. Maybe in _________  they don't speak about it in the women's asrama. But it is definitely talked about in many places. I certainly speak about it.

Disciple:

You do. You always say that all of your good qualities are not your credit. But I can see that from the very beginning in your Krishna consciousness, you had many good qualities. And those qualities which you have now, you just developed your qualities which you had from the very beginning. Or you developed different qualities?

Niranjana Swami:

To tell you the truth, I don't remember a time when I deliberately decided to develop good qualities.

Disciple:

It seems that you have good qualities.

Niranjana Swami:

But the point is that I don't remember a time when I deliberately decided, "I'm going to develop this quality." It's just something that evolved through my own experiences of interacting with other people. And chanting Hare Krishna and praying to my spiritual master. But I can't remember a time when I was thinking, "Well I have to think about developing."...I can remember thinking, "I have to be tolerant." That I can remember. I had to learn tolerance a lot in the beginning. But it's something that I've had to learn for forty-five years. Tolerance.

Disciple:

But when I see your example. For me it's a perfect example because you love people, and you do not discriminate against them and you do not see their faults. And you do not criticize them. I am an example of the opposite. And how can I learn this?

Niranjana Swami:

Well I always answer that question, when it's asked, not directly about me, but just in general, that if you want to develop the qualities that you see in others, the best way to develop their good qualities is by serving them. Consciously serving them, in the way I spoke about the other evening. I don't know if you were there? That's why I attribute that whatever good qualities others may see in me is only because I tried to consciously serve the person who was the embodient of all good qualities.

Disciple:

What can I do for you? Because my service during my service during your visit is so insignificant.

Niranjana Swami:

Well there are many other ways to serve me in the same way I have found in service to Srila Prabhupada. Telling others about Krishna is the way to serve me. Telling others about your own realizations in Krishna concsiousness is a way to serve me.

Being a good example. I oftentimes emphasize that the wrong act committed by the servant leads people in general to blame the master, and the opposite of that is that whatever good behavior there is in a disciple, always brings credit to the spiritual master. That's a way to serve me. And these are ways that disciples can serve in separation.

When I am not present there are ways that you can serve me. I mean that there are also ways my disciples serve me who don't see me. For instance, transcribing my lectures. Or helping with printing of my books, or distributing the books, and these are also different ways disciples serve me when they are not physically with me. But these opportunities are available to anyone who wants to do it. But as far as direct personal service? You can't get much more personal than those services which I just described.

These are the services that mean the most to me. [Not serving my body.] These are the things that I speak about all of the time. These are the things that I try to invest so much of my energy and time in trying to teach others that when I see somebody reciprocating with my efforts to help them in that way, it gives me life. It gives me a purpose for being here. I feel reciprocation that I'm actually doing something to share what Prabhupada gave me with others. It just gives me life.

We all have to feel a sense of purpose. That gives us life. We then feel like, "I have some purpose for being here. Some purpose for being on this planet. I have some purpose to be recognized by others. That's the best way to be recognized, by service. Serving in the ways I just described is a powerful way to be recognized. Because it's not only simply by the recognition, as I told in my story. Prabhupada never recognized [externally] the rooms that I prepared for him. But he did recognize. Nobody will tell me that he didn't. He did.

Disciple:

Of course he did because you had a big desire to satisfy him. And in this age of Kali very often Krishna punishes us because sometimes it's the only way to strengthen our intelligence. How can we strengthen our intelligence in another way without punishment?

Niranjana Swami:

Without being punished?

Disciple:

Yes.

Niranjana Swami:

You don't like being punished..? Prabhupada, I think you must have heard me say this many times, because I quote Prabhupada on this. Prabhupada said that to strengthen our intelligence means that before we do anything, we compare it to the instructions we received from guru and Krishna. And by building everything that we do on those higher instructions, our intelligence becomes stronger. Prabhupada even said that for the disciple, intelligence means… the instructions of the spiritual master. Therefore before we do anything we should be thinking, "Is this what I should be doing?" And compare it.

Disciple:

In the very beginning I had this feeling. I always before I do something, I always thought, what would you think about it. But then I lost this feeling. And I would like to restore it. And one time you spoke about sin and sinner, how to separate them.

Niranjana Swami:

Hate the sin and not the sinner, you mean?

Disciple:

Yes. And I don't understand, because sin does not exist without sinner. How to separate that.

Niranjana Swami:

The sin can apply to many people. It's not just those sins which are inflicted upon us. But it can be those sins which have been inflicted upon anybody. So you hate the sin. Even when it happens to others, and you see others who are suffering as a result of that sin, including the sinner. So that's how you distinguish. Usually we put them together seeing the sin is that which has caused "me" suffering. But no. We have to learn how to distinguish between the sin and the sinner. The sin, in of itself, is universal. We can see another person committing a sinful act and the object of their sinful act suffers. The person who commits the sin, we think, "That person is going to suffer." So we can hate the sin. But the sinner we feel compassion for. Why should they suffer. And why should the person who will be the object of their sin suffer also? So let me help this person so that they don't have to suffer.

Disciple:

I meant devotees.

Niranjana Swami:

You meant devotees? Well. What's the sin? Devotees are supposed to be sinless.

Disciple:

When they behave unfair and disrespectfully. But they are quite satisfied and pleased with themselves. So I cannot think about how they will suffer, because it doesn't look like they will suffer.

Niranjana Swami:

But it seems like you're the one who suffers.

Disciple:

Uh-huh. Yes. I do.

Niranjana Swami:

So.

Disciple:

Because my parents, I was raised with the thought that we should take into consideration other people and we should not disturb them. And I don't do all of these things which they do. But they still do not like me. And they don't like that. And you may remember, that you said many years ago that if I do not learn how to associate with devotees I will never reach the spiritual world because Krishna is always surrounded by His devotees. So there is no hope.

Niranjana Swami:

By why does it have to be only those devotees. The ones who disturb you so much. Aren't there any other devotees who don't disturb you?

Disciple:

Yes. There are.

Niranjana Swami:

So why don't you increase your association with them?

Disciple:

I do. But still I have to go to my place and I have to suffer. Because mostly I spend my time in my room. But I try to work on it, although not very successfully.

Niranjana Swami:

I can understand the difficulty. Familiarity breeds contempt. You have to live with that constantly. The same manner of dealings with you. They don't change. Your same attitude towards them. It doesn't change. And nothing changes. So usually under those circumstances when you are forced into a situation that can't be changed but you have no other choice but to accept it, it becomes more difficult to tolerate and that's the kind of living situation that you're in.

I can't sit down and talk to these people. Obviously you're not asking me to sit down and talk to these people, whoever they may be. And I'm grateful that you don't ask me to speak with them. I'm sure that you wouldn't even think of it. But what can I do? I don't even know who they are. And I don't even know if they have a potential to change. I don't even know if it's them. Or if it's something that you're doing that's provoking them to behave in that way. It doesn't sound to me like you are. From what you tell me, there's nothing you are doing to provoke them to deal with you in that way. It sounds to me that it's just a situation, or circumstance that you're all familiar with each others shortcomings and nobody is willing to make the changes required to make the relationships more harmonious. Everybody has reached their limit... including yourself.

Disciple:

Sometimes I'm in despair.

Niranjana Swami:

I can see that. I have no other way to try to help you except to help you internalize because I can't help you on the external platform.

Disciple:

Yes. That's what I need from you. An internal change.

Niranjana Swami:

Internal changes can only come by learning how to accept the situation that Krishna has put you in and to see that it's Krishna's will. "There is no other reason to explain why I'm here? Why I'm doing this?  It's been sanctioned by Krishna and if it's been sanctioned by Krishna, and if it's His will, I have to learn to accept it. And if He wants a different situation for me, then He'll arrange it."

The more you keep on hearing about Krishna and learning how Krishna is such a loving friend…. Krishna knows what's going on in our hearts. And Krishna will never do anything that's bad for us. And when we increase our hearing about Krishna, the more we see His presence in our life, and the more we become grateful. And then the more we become grateful, the more Krishna massages our hearts and we actually feel his presence more and more in our life, and we become peaceful. But it takes time for the whole process to take place. Somehow this place, this place, this ashram, these women, these circumstances, it's what you are being given right now as your test. And when you can actually accept it, it will become an opportunity for you to move on and then there will be more tests. But it's all because Krishna wants you, more than anything else, to come back to Him. He wants to make this your last visit to the material world. And he's going to make sure that every test that you get, He'll do His best to help you and give you the strength to overcome it so that you can remove all of these obstacles on your path, and go back to Godhead. You're so fortunate.

Disciple:

It's not so quick.

Niranjana Swami:

It may not be so quick. It may even not happen in this life. But you have a very auspicious opportunity to make it in this life.

Disciple:

If I do some devotional service in my room, for example, listen to a lecture, and another mataji does the same thing very loudly and I cannot hear the lecture which I'm listening to, but instead of this, I'm listening to the cacophony from the corridor, what should I do in this case. I don't know. I become very angry in this case. Because they don't understand. I want to do something.

Niranjana Swami:

There is nobody who is responsible for this place where you stay. Is that what you're telling me?

Disciple:

Two matajis… ________ and ___________.

Niranjana Swami:

But they don't listen to you?

Disciple:

They don't listen to me. So for them it's not a problem at all. If I complain to someone who is in charge, I mean above them is it correct or not?

Niranjana Swami:

To complain is not the best approach. The best approach is to not come forward with a complaint demanding that someone should do something about it. The best approach is to very humbly come forward and ask the person, "Is this the right situation. I'll describe it. Do you have time for me to describe it? If you don't have time for me to describe it, can I write it down, and will you read it? And then just give me an answer? Is this the right situation that I should tolerate? Or maybe do you see that there's something that could be done to improve the situation because I've been living like this for so long and I've been trying to tolerate but it's been very difficult for me." That's the best way, rather than to complain. Because people don't like it when somebody comes just to complain.

Disciple:

Maybe it's not the right word?

Niranjana Swami:

I'd say, "making them aware." There's a difference between making somebody aware and complaining. A person who complains is usually somebody who wants somebody to do something about it. That's a complaint. " I have a complaint. You do something about it. It's your resopnsibility."

Disciple:

I tried to do it one or two years ago.

Niranjana Swami:

To make somebody aware.

Disciple:

Yes. Because they wanted to throw me out of the ashram. And there was some conversation between ______, ________, and _______  who is above them.

Niranjana Swami:

Oh _________? He's the person who is above them?

Disciple:

He was at least one year ago.

Niranjana Swami:

_________ is a very reasonable person.

Disciple:

Yes. He is. When we talk with each other. Yes he is very reasonable. But when we talk together, he was on their side. Unfortunately very often I can see in our society that if you are an ordinary devotee and do not have any position, any title, then they will not listen to you. I don't want to think in such a way. But that's what I see.

Niranjana Swami:

I don't know what "ordinary devotee" means.

Disciple:

Ordinary devotee means not a Prabhupada disciple, not a scholarly brahmana, I don't know what. Sorry for this but that's what I think. One more question? How to realize that Krishna's name is not different from Krishna so that we would not ignore Him when we chant Hare Krishna?

Niranjana Swami:

To realize Krishna's name is nondifferent from Him, is not a mechanical process. It's not something that you can do and immediately see Krishna in His name. Like anything in spiritual life, Krishna always has the choice and final decision in how He will reveal Himself to every individual. He has the final decision. What works for one to achieve that decision may not be the exact same situation that works for another. But what works for everyone is love. And love is something very difficult. It's not so easy, it's not so cheap to have. To take lust which is "for me" and to completely turn it to love "for Krishna" requires a cleaning of the heart.

Without ceto darpana marjanam, without a cleaning of the heart, you will not be able to see Krishna in His name. So it begins with cleaning the heart, which you are doing. But you have to continue the cleaning process. And to continue the cleaning process means that whatever obstacle you are facing right now in your spiritual life, you need to be able to overcome it. And if you don't overcome it, it will hinder your progress in being able to experience Krishna in His name. He won't reveal. He only reveals Himself to those whose hearts are clean.

So what do we do? How to get a clean heart? We get clean hearts by approaching Krishna in His name, approaching Him through prayer.

I was speaking to somebody the other day and I was saying how powerful prayer is. That prayer is something that we have a tendency to minimize because it takes a lot of hard work to pray. Usually it's more comfortable for the mind to just kind of gravitate to the easier things to think about than to really go deep within our own hearts and to actually reveal something that Krishna already knows. But to reveal and speak to Him personally and saying, "Krishna this is who I am, but I want to be "this" person, who is higher than I am. But I know that I can't be this person who's higher than I am without Your help.

So let me tell You all these things about who I am now, that's preventing me from becoming the higher person who I want to be. This is the type of person I want to be, but I'm telling all of these things because I can't come to that level of a "higher person" without Your help. And I'm suffering. Because I always see the person that I don't want to be, but I'm living with that person every day. And every day I'm living with the person I don't want to be, it causes me pain because I would really like to be the person who's higher.

But how do I get to that higher point unless You, Krishna, help me? Because I have no other way."

That's prayer. It takes work. It actually takes work. But that's what is required to become purified. It's work. And you're capable of doing it.

Disciple:

Actually I never pray.

Niranjana Swami:

But you're capable of doing it.

Disciple:

I hope so.

Niranjana Swami:

You have my blessings.

Disciple:

For praying? I repeat only one prayer from Ayurveda. It's not for the health. It's just very nice prayer. But I'm not sure that I can translate it into English. Maybe Prabhu can help?

Niranjana Swami:

He's putting together my Ayurvedic medicine for me.

Disciple:

Yes. I know. It sounds so nicely in Russian. I don't know how to translate it properly into English.

“Dear Krishna, you are inside of me, within my very breath, within each bird, each mighty mountain. Your sweet touch reaches everything and I am well protected.
Thank you Krishna for this beautiful day before me. May joy, love, peace and compassion be part of my life and all those around me on this day. I am healing and I am healed.”

Niranjana Swami:

That's your prayer?

Disciple:

My only prayer.

End of recording.

Disciple:

I would like to discuss the same topic we discussed in our last conversation… about the devotees who are disturbing me.

Niranjana Swami:

I don't remember all of the details of our conversation but I thought I said that if you accept them as they are, that the problem would go away. What I meant, I'm almost sure, is that if you just accept them as they are, it meant that you were accepting that however they dealt with you was for your own purification. If you see things in that way then you see Krishna's hand, that Krishna has arranged for you to be in this situation and this situation is meant for your own purification, and if you accept it in that way then you will no longer see them as problems anymore. I might have also given my own experience, that I oftentimes talk about, the time when my temple president was insulting me. Did I?

Disciple:

Not completely. But I remember.

Niranjana Swami:

You remember the story? Because I was speaking to you based upon my own experience, that it was very difficult for me to tolerate the way I was being dealt with by this particular temple president. And you know the story how I was asked to give SB class, and I was speaking, with references of the Bhagavatam about Maharaja Rahugana. And then I was getting such wonderful realizations that I realized that I could have never possibly gotten these realizations if my president hadn't treated me that way. And I became grateful. And then when I thanked him, in my heart, for the way he treated me. I really changed. The problems went away. And he stopped treating me that way. So it was based on my own realization.

Disciple:

Did you have any bad feelings toward him?

Niranjana Swami:

No.

Disciple:

OK. Our situation in asrama. Ekadasi Night. Kirtan on the roof. I cannot sleep. I cannot go on harinama. And I'm tired and I want to sleep but the kirtan is very loud… mrdanga kartals etc. I cannot rest. The next day I feel completely broken. I do not have any desire to do anything. And I feel that they must not do that. It's not correct. I know. Kirtan is OK but  there is time and circumstances. I mean when devotional service of someone disturbs my own devotional service, what should I do?

Niranjana Swami:

What else can you do but tolerate?

Disciple:

Of course I had to tolerate.

Niranjana Swami:

Yes. Because you tried to get them to change and they don't. I remember you telling me that also. You appealed to them. You appealed to others, and nothing changed. What else can you do?

Disciple:

I'm ready to tolerate, but I'm not ready to forgive them and to feel some good feelings towards them.

Niranjana Swami:

So, but then that means that your mind is disturbed by their presence. So keep you distance from them. Otherwise you're going to have to be disturbed.

Disciple:

It's one building. No way to keep a distance. In our society we practically never speak about good manners, at least to be sensitive to other people.

Niranjana Swami:

We speak about this all of the time, but maybe they don't hear about it in your asrama, that's all. But I wouldn't say "in our society". That's a pretty broad generalization… in our society. Maybe in _________  they don't speak about it in the women's asrama. But it is definitely talked about in many places. I certainly speak about it.

Disciple:

You do. You always say that all of your good qualities are not your credit. But I can see that from the very beginning in your Krishna consciousness, you had many good qualities. Niranjana Swami:

To tell you the truth, I don't remember a time when I deliberately decided to develop good qualities.

Disciple:

It seems that you have good qualities.

Niranjana Swami:

But the point is that I don't remember a time when I deliberately decided, "I'm going to develop this quality." It's just something that evolved through my own experiences of interacting with other people. And chanting Hare Krishna and praying to my spiritual master. But I can't remember a time when I was thinking, "Well I have to think about developing."...I can remember thinking, "I have to be tolerant." That I can remember. Disciple:

Without being punished?

So.

But it's all because Krishna wants you, more than anything else, to come back to Him. He wants to make this your last visit to the material world. And he's going to make sure that every test that you get, He'll do His best to help you and give you the strength to overcome it so that you can remove all of these obstacles on your path, and go back to Godhead. You're so fortunate.

Disciple:

It's not so quick.

Niranjana Swami:

It may not be so quick. It may even not happen in this life. But you have a very auspicious opportunity to make it in this life.

But you're capable of doing it.

I hope so.

Disciple:

Yes. I know. It sounds so nicely in Russian. I don't know how to translate it properly into English.

data.title: Thinking about a "Conversations with disciples" series
data.blurb: I have just posted a transcription of a conversation I had not long ago with a senior disciple. The recorder on my phone was somehow left on from a recording I had made shortly before the scheduled meeting with this disciple. I discovered the recording on my phone some time later.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I have just posted a transcription of a conversation I had not long ago with a senior disciple. The recorder on my phone was somehow left on from a recording I had made shortly before the scheduled meeting with this disciple. I discovered the recording on my phone some time later.

When I listened to the recording, I thought that this is something others may benefit from hearing as well. So it was transcribed.

Then, through another disciple, I asked this senior disciple if she would mind if the transcription was posted. I was told that she was fine with it being posted, "as is". But I chose to remove a few details which I felt did not have to be included.

I generally do not record my meetings with disciples. I do not want them to be intimidated by the presence of a recorder. But, after some thought, I realized that there are many disciples who ask if they may record their conversations with me. Rarely, at least that I can remember, have I ever denied somebody's request to record their private conversation with me.

The thought then occurred to me, "Maybe there are more private recordings in the possession of disciples and/or aspiring disciples, which may be of similar value?

Hence, I am now thinking about beginning a "Conversations with a disciple" series for my blogs. They wouldn't be frequent. It would take time to transcribe them, edit them, and post them. But it could begin by asking my readers if they have such a recording in their possession which they feel could be of benefit for others to hear?

If there are personal parts which the possessor of the recording prefer not be transcribed and posted, they could be edited out. In fact, I would personally edit them out. Anonymity could also be kept, much in the same way that my books of letters have been presented.

Additionally, confidentiality would be maintained, much in the same way that complete confidentiality is kept by those who translate letters both to me and from me.

If you, or anyone you know, have a recorded conversation which you (or they) would like to share, these recordings can be uploaded, along with editing requests , here on the Fileshare page of this site:

https://www.niranjanaswami.net/en/fileshare

Hare Krishna

data.title: A Nice Quote
data.blurb: I was reading Bhurijana Prabhu's book this morning entitled, "Japa, Nine Keys from Siksastakam", and came across the following reference quoting Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur on the SB 2.1.11 verse:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I was reading Bhurijana Prabhu's book this morning entitled, "Japa, Nine Keys from Siksastakam", and came across the following reference quoting Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur on the SB 2.1.11 verse:

etan nirvidyamananam
icchatam akuto-bhayam
yoginam nrpa nirnitam
harer namanukirtanam

TRANSLATION
O King, constant chanting of the holy name of the Lord after the ways of the great authorities is the doubtless and fearless way of success for all, including those who are free from all material desires, those who are desirous of all material enjoyment, and also those who are self-satisfied by dint of transcendental knowledge.

I thought I would share (Everything within quotes is Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur)….

data.title: The Temple of the Vedic Planetarium
data.blurb: Two days ago, I was taken on a tour of the "Temple of the Vedic Planetarium" by Sadbhuja dasa, the managing director of the TOVP, Prema Avatara Gauranga dasa, the construction manager, and several other devotees who are intimately connected with the project.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Two days ago, I was taken on a tour of the "Temple of the Vedic Planetarium" by Sadbhuja dasa, the managing director of the TOVP, Prema Avatara Gauranga dasa, the construction manager, and several other devotees who are intimately connected with the project.

One of the many realizations which came to me from the tour was that although there are so many temple projects going up all over the world, there is no project like the "Temple of the Vedic Planetarium."

The TOVP was directly Srila Prabhupada's vision. Of course Srila Prabhupada had a vision that temples would be established all over the world in every town and village. But with the TOVP, Srila Prabhupada gave so many details, from the significance of the temple down to the details directly related to its design.

I left my tour with renewed conviction that devotees throughout the world should continue to give their support to the TOVP so that we may realize Srila Prabhupada's complete dream for the TOVP within our lifetime. So much work is yet to be done, and so many funds are still required for the work to continue.

I laud the efforts of the TOVP team, headed by my godbrother, Ambarish Prabhu, the Chairman of the project and I pray that more and more devotees will become inspired to help realize the temple opening in the year 2022.

Devamrita Maharaja came along with me for the tour. Some photos were taken of us with the tour group. Once they are submitted they will soon thereafter be posted here on the site.

Meanwhile, Savyasaci dasa sent some photos he took yesterday from "the cage" which is a small cage designed to carry the TOVP workers so that they can inspect the structural work currently going on with the chakra. Those photos will be posted here on the site and one of the videos can be seen below (it may take a little longer to load than normal).

Hare Krsna

data.title: Readings in the GBC Meetings
data.blurb: Whenever the GBC Body meets with members of the Strategic Planning Team (SPT), my godsister, Laxmimoni dasi, usually reads something from Srila Prabhupada for the benefit of all those who are present before anything else is discussed.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Whenever the GBC Body meets with members of the Strategic Planning Team (SPT), my godsister, Laxmimoni dasi, usually reads something from Srila Prabhupada for the benefit of all those who are present before anything else is discussed.

One of Laxmimoni's services is to go through the Vedabase and to pull out inspirational quotes in order to put all of us into the right mindset for discussing the topics on the agenda for each day.

However, Laxmimoni doesn't just extract quotes. She stitches them together in a way to keep the topic and mood nicely flowing and so that she can stay within the time allotted to her before the start of the meetings. Then she reads it with such relish that any sincere follower of Srila Prabhupada cannot help but be moved with inspiration. I've also found myself moved to tears quite often.

Unfortunately, I cannot replicate the exact experience for my readers here in this blog. In order to fully understand what I'm saying, one has to be present, listening to Laxmimoni dasi read.

But before I left Ujjain, I asked Laksmimoni if she would share her readings with me so that I could share it with others.

The following is one of the many references she sent to me. It is from a room conversation in Tokyo, in 1974. I will gradually share more of these in the future.

Hare Krsna


These symptoms of love mean one must give and take. One must disclose his mind and take instruction. One must give him to eat, and one must take something from him to eat. These are the six symptoms of love. Give and take. Just like you have given me this flower, so you have given. So if I instructed, “You take it,” that is give and take. If I offer you prasadam, you should bring some foodstuff. You should disclose your mind, and you should say that “This is my problem; you should hear me.” This is a symptom of love. Everything is there.

dadati pratigrhnati    guhyam akhyati prcchati
bhunkte bhojayate caiva   sad-vidham priti-laksanam
[Upadesamrta 4]

So our only request is that our business is we are in this old age traveling four times in a year. What is material benefit out of it? I am old man. I cannot move. I am eighty years, and two years less. Naturally this is not the age for traveling, retirement. But why I am traveling? Because I wanted to satisfy my Guru Maharaja. That is the only reason. I wanted to satisfy the desire of my Guru Maharaja, the desire of Lord Caitanya Mahaprabhu. And therefore at night I don’t sleep; I dictate. I publish this book. I go from country to country, village to village, town to town. And they also reciprocate, these boys. They’re helping me, how to publish these book, these boys. That boy is editing twenty-four hours; he is typing. Do I pay them anything?

… This is love. “I go away from Guru Maharaja and live four hundred miles away, and I love Guru Maharaja.” … Nonsense. You show some symptoms of love, that “My Guru Maharaja wants to do this. Oh, I must help him.” Just like Caitanya Mahaprabhu wanted, prithivite achhe yata nagaradi gram: “As many towns and villages are there, everywhere must there be…broadcasting My missionary activities.” ... … Just like a Christian, if he is real Christian, if he is actually following Lord Jesus Christ, Christ says, “Thou shalt not kill.” He must propagate, “You shall not kill.” But where is that Christian who is propagating? They are killing…

… It is clearly said in the first commandment, “Thou shalt not kill.” So every Christian, they must preach this cult. That is Christian. And he’s helping killing, and he’s a Christian? Similarly, Lord Caitanya Mahaprabhu’s mission is prithivite achhe yata nagaradi gram: “As many towns and villages are there, you must preach this cult.” That is really devotee, one who is doing this. He may not be very successful preacher; that doesn’t matter. Because he is doing that, he is first-class devotee.…that is real love. That is real follower. What his predecessor has ordered, that must be done. At any risk. It doesn’t matter whether it is being nicely done or not nicely done—because he is attempting to do that, that is sufficient. That very attempt will make him successful. This is the principle. You see?... Vyavasayatmika buddhih. Unfortunately, you do not read. What for we are publishing so many books, for the enlightenment of the people?

vyavasayatmika buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana
bahu-sakha hy anantas ca buddhayo 'vyavasayinam

“Those who are on this path are resolute in purpose, and their aim is one. O beloved child of the Kurus, the intelligence of those who are irresolute is many-branched.”

… “Who are irresolute.” Now, our only resolution was that “Guru Maharaja wanted this. Let me try it.” And with resolute purpose, I tried it. And therefore, I do not know, but people say that I have done very wonderful. People say that. … But what is the secret of this success? That resolution, that “My Guru Maharaja wanted this. I shall try my best to do this,” that’s all. I have no other secrets. Rather, I was doubtful, that “What I have got position, how people will understand? Still, let me try my best,” that’s all.

data.title: A Few Words from Mayapura
data.blurb: I'm not sure where to begin. As most of you may have noticed, there's been a long lapse since the last time I posted a blog. The months of September and October were like a blur for me. There was just too much going on for me to think about blogs.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm not sure where to begin. As most of you may have noticed, there's been a long lapse since the last time I posted a blog. The months of September and October were like a blur for me. There was just too much going on for me to think about blogs.

I arrived in Mayapura a few days ago after the GBC mid-term meetings in Ujjain. Needless to say, after another very intense summer, I've been longing for this opportunity.

I decided to not follow the same nama vrata I followed last year. My reasoning was that I had already lost half of Kartika in GBC meetings. Since I was not the only one disappointed with the way the mid-term meetings were scheduled this year (during Kartika), next year the meetings have been scheduled to finish three days before Kartika begins. Hence, I decided to wait until next year for the full Kartika nama vrata.

Meanwhile, since my stay in Mayapura will be relatively shorter than in previous years, I decided to arrange my schedule accordingly. My room is open for anyone who wants to chant japa together from 6:00 AM – 7:30 AM. I've also scheduled 5:00 – 6:00 PM daily (until early November) as the times I'm available for personal meetings. My daily readings with Sivarama Maharaja (and soon, Devamrita Maharaja) begin at 6:00 PM and continue until 7:30 PM. At 7:30 PM, we're chanting Damodarastakam and a short kirtan until approximately 8:15 PM.

At all other times, I have a long list of projects I need to work on, including some personal reading projects I would like to fulfill. I also plan to resume writing occasional blogs. With the limited time available to me before I must leave, I have doubts that I will be able to complete all, or even most of the projects. But for now, all I intend to do is to, at least, start.

Yesterday, Srila Prabhupada's Disappearance Day, was a special day. In the morning I watched the last few chapters of the "Following Srila Prabhupada" series, with Srila Prabhupada in Vrndavana, London, and then back in Vrndavana. In the early evening, I attended Radhanath Maharaja's pandal program along with the 6,000 devotees who were attending his yatra. Maharaja greeted me when I arrived and asked me to speak about Srila Prabhupada, which I did, for about a half-hour. I then visited Sivarama Maharaja where we read "The Final Lesson", the last chapter of "Srila Prabhupada Lilamrita, together. After that the two of us chanted Gurvastakam and I then proceeded downstairs where the devotees were waiting for me to begin the Damodarastakam prayers.

By Srila Prabhupada's grace, I finished the day filled with thoughts of my eternal master and well-wisher, Srila Prabhupada.

Hare Krsna

data.title: My Vyasa Puja Offering (Written Yesterday on Janmastami)
data.blurb:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,
 
Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,
 
Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.
 
Today I am observing your appearance day for the forth-fifth time. After standing before you like this annually for forty-five years, offering homage to your divine lotus feet, I'm thinking that I need to take a serious look within my heart and pray that my attempt to glorify you will some day become worthy of your attention.
 
When you were with us, you once told us:
 
"So my Guru Maharaja used to say that 'Instead of seeing Krsna, you serve so faithfully that Krsna will see you.' That should be the process. Krsna is omnipresent. He can see you; He can understand you, what are doing. So we have to execute devotional service in such a faithful way that Krsna will see us. Then you will be successful. 'Don't try to see Krsna. Try to become seen by Krsna.' That was my Guru Maharaja's instruction."
 
How can I ever expect Krsna to look at me unless you ask Him to look favorably upon me? My only hope is for capturing your merciful glance along with your benevolent smile of approval. I live for that. Without hope for it some day, there is no value to my life.
 
Krsna remains passive with me as upadrasta and anumanta, the overseer and permitter. There is no reason for me to think that other than through your mercy, He will respond to me in any way other than that. I have no love for Him. I cannot therefore invoke His divine intervention. But you love Krsna and surely He listens to you.
 
It is my greatest fortune that you magnanimously accepted me as your servant almost forty-four years ago when I promised you that I would faithfully execute devotional service to your divine lotus feet for all of eternity.
 
Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur has instructed how a faithful sadhaka must think:
 
"'Krsna must be merciful to me either today or after one hundred years or in some other birth. I will take shelter of His lotus feet with determination and never leave.' This type of dhairya, patience, is most desirable for the practitioners of devotional service."
 
My dear Srila Prabhupada, on this most auspicious day of your divine appearance, I humbly submit that I have complete faith that you will be merciful to me, either today, after one hundred years, or in some other birth. I have firmly taken shelter of your lotus feet and will never leave them. Please keep me as your servant birth after birth, and continue to engage me, as you see fit, in service to the Lords of your life.

Your eternal servant,
 Niranjana Swami

He can see you; He can understand you, what are doing. So we have to execute devotional service in such a faithful way that Krsna will see us. Then you will be successful. 'Don't try to see Krsna. Try to become seen by Krsna.' That was my Guru Maharaja's instruction."
 
How can I ever expect Krsna to look at me unless you ask Him to look favorably upon me? My only hope is for capturing your merciful glance along with your benevolent smile of approval. I live for that. Without hope for it some day, there is no value to my life.
 
Krsna remains passive with me as upadrasta and anumanta, the overseer and permitter. There is no reason for me to think that other than through your mercy, He will respond to me in any way other than that. I have no love for Him. I cannot therefore invoke His divine intervention. But you love Krsna and surely He listens to you.
 
It is my greatest fortune that you magnanimously accepted me as your servant almost forty-four years ago when I promised you that I would faithfully execute devotional service to your divine lotus feet for all of eternity.
 
Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur has instructed how a faithful sadhaka must think:
 
"'Krsna must be merciful to me either today or after one hundred years or in some other birth. I will take shelter of His lotus feet with determination and never leave.' This type of dhairya, patience, is most desirable for the practitioners of devotional service."
 
My dear Srila Prabhupada, on this most auspicious day of your divine appearance, I humbly submit that I have complete faith that you will be merciful to me, either today, after one hundred years, or in some other birth. I have firmly taken shelter of your lotus feet and will never leave them. Please keep me as your servant birth after birth, and continue to engage me, as you see fit, in service to the Lords of your life.

Your eternal servant,
 Niranjana Swami

data.title: Questions for Disciples' Retreat
data.blurb: One of the events planned for the July Disciple Retreat in Magdalinivka will be daily question and answer gatherings similar to that which was held during the "Bhakti Sangama Festival" in Svityaz last year.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
One of the events planned for the July Disciple Retreat in Magdalinivka will be daily question and answer gatherings similar to that which was held during the "Bhakti Sangama Festival" in Svityaz last year.

In preparation for this event the opportunity is being given to disciples and aspiring disciples to submit up to three questions in the form below. Your questions will be translated into English (if necessary) and compiled into the list of questions which we will attempt to answer during these four days.

In order to have your question included in the list, you must provide your name and city of residence in the form.

However, it is important to note that your name will be known only to the devotees assigned to receive, compile, and translate the questions as they are submitted. No one's name will be read together with questions at the disciples' retreat.

Questions will be prioritized in the following order:

1) Relevancy - based upon lectures and themes I have been speaking on in 2017.

2) Disciples and aspiring disciples present at the retreat. (The term "disciples" includes initiated devotees who have formally accepted a siksha relationship.)

3) Disciples not present at the retreat.

4) Aspiring disciples not present at the retreat.

5) Those who are not in categories 2 – 4 listed above, may submit questions, but since the retreat is for disciples and aspiring disciples, these questions are less likely to be answered.

Please forward this blog (which can be downloaded below) to any disciple or aspiring disciple you know who you believe may be interested in submitting a question.

However, please also inform the same devotee that questions can be submitted only from within this blog. Questions from any other source will not be accepted.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Moscow and Gauranga Festival including Health Update
data.blurb: I had another intense session with the doctor this morning, with the last session scheduled for Wednesday, May 31st.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I had another intense session with the doctor this morning, with the last session scheduled for Wednesday, May 31st.

I was told very firmly (and more than once) that I must take two weeks for full rest and recovery after I'm finished with his treatments. His main criteria for rest was "no lectures and no traveling," emphasizing that the two positions best for me for the next couple of weeks would be walking and lying down. Sitting was not considered a favorable option, although it seemed that short periods of sitting would be a concession he would reluctantly agree to.

When I resisted a little, his response was that I will risk losing all of the benefit from the work that's been done if I did not heed his warning.

Of course, I have a different understanding. I'm not convinced that everything would be lost. I sense that he was trying to make his point strong, knowing my tendencies. But I did not argue that point any further with him.

I will say this, however… four hours sitting on the train, each way between Moscow and St. Petersburg this weekend, immediately had a noticeable impact on my back. The spine seems overly vulnerable from the work that he's done. He said that I will need to resume exercise to remove that vulnerability, but that's also not allowed until the two week recovery period is over.

Needless to say, I did not expect this, which means neither did I plan for this.

However, I've decided to look for some middle ground between my plans and the doctor's recommendations.

Here are the plans I will likely stay with:

Moscow:

Saturday, June 3 – Srimad Bhagavatam class at Kuuseenina
Sunday, June 4 – Srimad Bhagavatam class at Kuuseenina
Sunday, June 4 – Sunday Feast Lecture at Kusseenina

Tuesday, June 6 – Departure from Moscow to Gauranga Festival

Gauranga Festival – June 8 – 13.

Regarding my participation at the Gauranga Festival, it will be limited and spontaneous (depending on factors which will have to be determined on a day-by-day basis). I will likely not be able to attend most of the morning program. I will attend some events during the day and will give talks, although I will likely not speak publicly every day. My participation in the evening programs will also have to be significantly cut back from previous levels of participation.

The above, in itself, is a significant compromise with "no lectures and no traveling". But it is a plan and, as already stated, it is a plan which I will likely stay with unless there are strong indications that I should not.

Hare Krsna

data.title: When "Genuine Meets Genuine"
data.blurb: During my travels in South Florida two months ago, my godsister, Visakha dasi, asked if I would be willing to read her book and to write a review if I felt so inclined. Eager to read anything written about Srila Prabhupada, I unhesitatingly accepted her offer.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During my travels in South Florida two months ago, my godsister, Visakha dasi, asked if I would be willing to read her book and to write a review if I felt so inclined. Eager to read anything written about Srila Prabhupada, I unhesitatingly accepted her offer.

One of the many projects I've been working on during these past two weeks here in Moscow was to read Visakha's book and to offer her my review.

For those of you who listen to the many lectures I give about Srila Prabhupada, I'm sure you've noted that I speak often about his ability to inspire people because he was so genuine. Reading Visakha's book, I discovered that her book was a powerful testimony to this quality I so much adore in my spiritual master.

Visakha dasi asked if I would direct my review to non-devotee readers since, as she told me, the book is intended for them.

I believe that my review (as follows) speaks for itself. I encourage everyone to acquire a copy of her book, to read it, and to experience for yourself what inspired me to write this review.

My review:

"Whether you are a spiritual seeker of sorts, fixed on a particular path, or just someone who wants to know more, Visakha dasi herein reveals, through deep introspection, what it means to be genuine in one's quest for the right answers.

This inspirational memoir reveals Visakha's unexpected encounter with her guru, his method of teaching, and the transformation that took place in her heart by weighing his words with his actions.

In a world filled with great potential for disappointment, it's comforting to see what happens when 'genuine' meets 'genuine.' This book is a compelling look at both."

Hare Krsna

Please click on the book cover to go to the book on Amazon.com
