March 14, 2017 - Kiev - SB 5.25.13-15

“There is no end to the great and glorious qualities of that powerful Lord Anantadeva. Indeed, His prowess is unlimited. Though self-sufficient, He Himself is the support of everything. He resides beneath the lower planetary systems and easily sustains the entire universe.”(SB 5.25.13)

“My dear King, as I heard of it from my spiritual master, I have fully described to you the creation of this material world according to the fruitive activities and desires of the conditioned souls. Those conditioned souls, who are full of material desires, achieve various situations in different planetary systems, and in this way they live within this material creation.” (SB 5.25.14)


PURPORT by Srila Prabhupada

In this regard, srila Bhaktivinoda thakura sings,
anadi karama-phale, paḍi’ bhavarṇava-jale,
taribare na dekhi upaya

“My Lord, I do not know when I commenced my material life, but I can certainly experience that I have fallen in the deep ocean of nescience. Now I can also see that there is no other way to get out of it than to take shelter of Your lotus feet.”

Similarly, sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu offers the following prayer,

ayi nanda-tanuja kinkaram
patitam mam visame bhavambudhau
kṛpaya tava pada-pankaja-
sthita-dhuli-sadṛsam vicintaya

“My dear Lord, son of Nanda Maharaja, I am Your eternal servant. Somehow or other, I have fallen into this ocean of nescience. Kindly, therefore, save me from this horrible condition of materialistic life.” (Sri Siksastaka, verse 5)

“My dear King, I have thus described how people generally act according to their different desires and, as a result, get different types of bodies in higher or lower planets. You inquired of these things from me, and I have explained to you whatever I have heard from authorities. What shall I speak of now?”(SB 5.25.15)

Purport by Niranjana Swami

This verse and commentary is summarizing that which has been previously described... how a living entity wanders in the material universe throughout different planetary systems and how the material universes have been formed to facilitate the movements of the living entities from the various higher to lower forms of life for the fulfilment of their fruitive desires.

This is  the purpose of the material creation... to give  facility to a living entity to fulfill his fruitive desires.

Prabhupada would oftentimes quote the verse,

visṇu-saktiḥ para prokta
ksetra-jnakhya tatha para
avidya-karma-samjnanya
tṛtiya saktir isyate (Visṇu Puraṇa 6.7.61)

“There are three potencies of Krsna – the superior energy which is full of knowledge, the living entity who belongs to the superior energy, but although he belongs to that superior energy he can come under the influence to the third energy, which is ignorance and which is visible in fruitive activities.”

This whole material nature has been designed for the living entity to pursue fruitive activities.  It is a very effective design. Those who are intelligent enough to see the power of the illusory energy can understand that it is very powerful. It is designed in such a way to keep the living entity trapped according to his desires.

Fruitive desire means desire for one’s own  enjoyment. Therefore Krsna describes this in Bhagavad-gita as karma-bandhana. These desires are the cause of bondage of the living entity in the material world.

There are either fruitive desires or desires aimed for Lord’s pleasure. Those living entities whose desires are pure, exclusively for the Lord’s pleasure are not bound by the laws of fruitive activities or by material nature. Those who have independent desires are under the influence of the three modes of nature which, Krsna very clearly states, are very difficult to overcome.

Why is it difficult to overcome? Because the material nature or the illusory energy has two types of potencies – one is called avaranatmika-sakti, or the potency to keep the living entity feeling satisfied in this world, the other is called praksepatmika-sakti, which is the potency of the Lord that thrusts one down into the material world, even those who make an effort to get freed from it. One is thrust back down. And then one is rocked back and forth into deep sleep, or ignorance, again, thinking that the material world is not such a bad place.

Therefore Krsna says that this material nature is very difficult to overcome. Until one can become free from fruitive desires, one’s status in life will be in the higher, middle or lower planetary system, accordingly-- the living entity is given a suitable body and a suitable facility to enact his fruitive desires.

We see that even great devotees of the Lord can come under the powerful influence of this illusory energy.  The power of avaranatmika-sakti is perfectly displayed in the story about Indra oftentimes told from Mahabharata.

I was looking through Vaktrtavali, a compilation of little stories from Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura. He tells the story about Indra when he was cursed to become a pig. He once lived at Manasa sarovara with his piglets.  Brahma went there and said, “What are you doing here? You belong in heaven.” I am paraphrasing.

But here Srila Bhaktisiddhanta says,
“'O, you! You go to heaven and  sit on the throne of Indra. There, are many servants and maidservants who are waiting to serve you.' Hearing this, Indra was blinded by rage and tried to attack Brahma.”

That was Brahma who was coming down and telling Indra, “What are you doing in this place? You may have been cursed but you don’t have to stay there. You have got a throne on the heavenly planets. You have so many people waiting to serve you. You have so much opulence and enjoyment. And here you are in stool!”

Avaranatmika-sakti. He was thinking that stool was nice. Therefore he was actually opposed to Brahma who was trying to come and rescue him. He considered Brahma an enemy and out of anger and lamentation he became very restless.

Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur then continues,

“Then one by one, Brahma killed Indra's piglets, and as a result, Indra in pig form screamed so loudly that the four directions shook. Then he killed his dear wife. Thereafter, bereft of his relatives, the pig-shaped Indra began to think about Brahma’s instruction and slowly remembered his actual position.”

Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura’s commentary of that is,

“The pig understood, 'I am actually Indra. I am not a pig. The pig body is not my original form. By nature I am the servant of the Supreme Lord, serving as Indra.'

As a result of hearing about one’s constitutional position the living beings can understand their actual identity. At present if we tell people mad after family life about their constitutional position, the way Mahaprabhu taught it, reminding them that they should give up all other activities and simply worship Lord Hari, then like the pig-shaped Indra, they too will reply, 'Eating stool, or in this case, material enjoyment, is our sanatana-dharma and we are happy with it. We do not want to hear about Lord Hari. We have so much work to do. We have to eat stool and we have to have more children.'

Such people think that saints are their enemies. They do not know that:

yasyaham anugrhnami
harisye tad-dhanam sanaih (SB 10.88.8)

“The Supreme Lord has said that to whomever He shows His mercy, He quickly takes away all that person’s possessions.”

I decided to read it rather than paraphrase it so that everybody will understand that these are not my words. These are the words of the previous Acaryas, so that nobody comes and tries to attack me, “Why are you saying this? We do not want to hear these things.”

I do not think anybody will do that. Hopefully, all of you present here understand that the material world is a place of suffering. If that realization is not there, it is very difficult to take to spiritual life, because as Srila Prabhupada states here in the commentary of the verse today, quoting Bhaktivinoda Thakura, “I do not know when I began my material life but I can certainly experience that I have fallen into a deep ocean of nescience.”

Then he quotes Lord Caitanya - ayi nanda-tanuja kinkaram. “Somehow I have fallen into this ocean of nescience. Kindly save me from this horrible condition of materialistic life.” (siksastaka 5)

In other words, in order to break free from this praksepatmika-sakti, one has to be convinced that this material place is no place for any gentleman. One has to at least admit,, “I'm suffering.”
Indra could not even realize that when he was a pig. He was so overwhelmed by the powerful illusory energy that he thought that being in the stool with his pig-wife and his little pig-children was a great place.

This is the power of the illusory energy because sometimes people suffer in the material world but they think, “Let me overcome suffering by fruitive activities.” It is not that people do not realize they are suffering. A lot of people get it, they understand, but they form different philosophies of life on how not to suffer.

One philosophy of life is fruitive activities. The best way to avoid suffering is to enjoy. If I can make a nice arrangement to enjoy, then I can overcome my suffering condition. And if I can maintain hope that this nice arrangement I am making to enjoy will overcome my suffering condition, I am ready to accept whatever difficulties I have because at least I can have hope that I will not suffer like this anymore... And that gives me a sense of happiness. It is close enough, the enjoyment is close enough for me to realize that I can keep going until I get it.

Prabhupada gives the example on the way they keep the race horses running in a race. They put a little carrot in front of the horse’s nose. The horse thinks, “It's close! I know I’ll get it. It is close.” The horse is ready to run to any lengths to get that carrot. “It is there! I am almost there! I am almost there!” Fruitive activity does just that. Then we finally bite into the carrot and think, “Yay! I finally got it.”

The nature of fruitive activities is, as an intelligent person knows, it produces further suffering.

tasyaiva hetoḥ prayateta kovido
na labhyate yad bhramatam upary adhaḥ
tal labhyate duḥkhavad anyataḥ sukham
kalena sarvatra gabhira-ramhasa (SB 1.5.18)

Bhagavatam states that “persons who are actually intelligent and philosophically inclined, do not endeavor for sense enjoyment which is available from the highest planets like Brahmaloka down to the lowest planets like Patala.”

In other words, they have enough brain substance to understand that the material world is a place of suffering. “It does not make any difference if I get some sense enjoyment; I know it is not going to be the permanent solution to my problems.”

There it is. This is the definition what this universe is created for. The universe is created for sense enjoyment from the highest planet to the lowest planet. That is what is being stated here, “Thank you for telling me about what this universe has been created for – for fruitive activities to enjoy from the highest planet to the lowest planet.”

These intelligent persons know that as far as this sense enjoyment is concerned, it comes automatically in due course of time, just as in due course of time suffering comes without asking for it.

This universe is a complete whole. It is a system perfectly designed by perfect intelligence to keep those conditioned souls entrapped. It is such a perfect design. Avaranatmika-sakti and praksepatmika-sakti are perfectly designed. So many facilities to think “I can be satisfied here.” That is what makes it so hard to get out.

Someone may say, “Why did Krsna make it so hard? It is His fault.” It is another challenge sometimes people come up with. “It is His fault, it is not my fault.” But actually the material universe was created as we just read in the verse.

“… I have fully described to you the creation of this material world according to the fruitive activities and desires of the conditioned souls. …” (SB 5.25.14)

It is according to the desires of the conditioned souls. Someone may say, “Well, why am I allowed to have those desires? Krsna should not have allowed me to have those desires. It is His fault.”

Sometimes people get so absorbed in whose fault it is. But here we read today Lord Caitanya says, “Somehow or other I have fallen.” Bhaktivinoda Thakura says, “I do not know when I commenced my material life but I can certainly experience that I have fallen in this deep ocean of nescience.” An intelligent person will try to understand. “I am suffering.”

Prabhupada gives the example when a house is burning down, you do not run and ask, “Who lit the fire?” The house is burning down. You run downstairs, knock on the door and ask, “Who lit the fire?” “What difference does it make? The house is on fire.” “I need to know who lit the fire.” “What do you need to know who lit the fire for? It is burning down.” “At least if I know who lit the fire, I will be careful not to be in a house that's burning down again.” Meanwhile the house is burning down and we get into all these arguments about who lit the fire. It is very difficult to understand.

I oftentimes refer to this quote of Bhaktivinoda Thakura. It is one of my favorite quotes for mental speculators who think that unless they can pierce the covering of the inconceivable potency of the Supreme Lord and fully understand it with their intelligence; they will not surrender to Krsna.

They think, “I have to first understand everything. And only when I can understand everything with my powerful, powerful intelligence. My powerful intelligence will reveal everything to me. Then I will be able to reduce this entire cosmic manifestation to one little simple formula.” Although Krsna can never be reduced to one little simple formula – He is inconceivable, and one has to accept that if one wants to get out of this material world.

Unless one accepts the inconceivable potencies of the Lord, he will never be able to get out of maya. With our puny little brains we try to reduce Krsna to someone who we can so fully understand that we can predict everything.

But Krsna always has the upper hand. That's what makes Him different from us. He is God and we are not.
ekale isvara kṛsṇa, ara saba bhṛtya
yare yaiche nacaya, se taiche kare nṛtya (CC Adi 5.142)

Krsna is the Supreme and all living entities are subordinate to Him.

‘mayadhisa' ‘maya-vasa' -- isvare-jive bheda as described in Caitanya Caritamrita. Krsna is mayadhisa, which means He is the controller of maya. And living entities are maya-vasa; they are under the control of maya. Krsna says,

mayadhyaksena prakrtih
suyate sa-caracaram (B-g 9.10)

Maya works under My direction. These things living entities can understand by hearing from a superior source but Krsna’s powers and potencies are always inconceivable.

Just like the story of Lord Brahma. There are so many stories about Lord Brahma, like Brahma vimohana-lila. In Brahma-vimohana-lila he tried to play a trick on Krsna but Krsna had to show him that He has the upper hand.

“Do you think you can play a trick on Me and steal all my cowherd boys and cows? I have the upper hand. I will become all the cowherd boys and cows. Why have you taken them away?”
Then Brahma comes back and sees all the cows and cowherd boys. Then Krsna reveals His four-armed form to Brahma and all the cowherd boys and cows are Him. And Brahma says, “Oh, forgive me. I can never fully understand Your glories.” Brahma offered his prayers to the Lord. “Forgive me. I tried to reduce You to a little formula and You showed me that it's not possible.”

When Brahma went to see the Lord, the gate-keeper came and Brahma said, “I have come to see the Lord.” Then the gate-keeper went in and said, “Brahma wants to see You.” The gate-keeper goes back to Lord Brahma because the Lord asked the gate-keeper to ask him, “Which Brahma is it?” So he goes back to Brahma and says, “The Lord wants to know which Brahma is here.”

“Which Brahma? It is Brahma. He knows who I am. I am Brahma with four heads.” Brahma thought he was the original creator of the universe. “He should know who I am.” That is power of the Lord’s energy that one thinks oneself to be important. Then Krsna has to reveal His inconceivable potencies for those who may temporarily forget.

Lord Brahma was allowed in and the Lord said, “You asked which Brahma you are.” Then all of a sudden all the other Brahmas were called by the Lord – Brahmas with eight heads, sixteen heads, thirty-two heads, sixty-four heads, millions of heads. Then Brahma felt like a little insignificant insect in presence of all these other Brahmas.

The inconceivable potencies of the Lord have to be accepted. The difference between a devotee and empiricists is that they cannot accept submission to the inconceivable potencies of the Lord. But when a devotee sees the inconceivable potencies of the Lord, he thinks how wonderful Krsna is. “Krsna is so wonderful.” That is the difference between a devotee and an empiricist – a devotee accepts that Krsna is so wonderfully inconceivable.

“The more I hear about Him, the more I want to serve Him.” The more one wants to serve Him, the more Krsna becomes satisfied with the devotee’s desire to serve Him that He reveals more and more of His inconceivable nature into the heart of that devotee, because a devotee always wants to serve the Lord. He does not look for excuses not to serve the Lord. He knows that under all circumstances the Lord is worthy of my service now and forever. He is happy to hear the inconceivable pastimes of the Lord, because the more he hears about the inconceivable pastimes of the Lord, the more his love for the Lord increases. The more he remembers the Lord, the more he desires to serve the Lord and the more he becomes qualified to become an eternal associate of the Lord. By the inconceivable potencies of the Supreme Lord, even that which is inconceivable can be understood. Even that which is inconceivable can be understood if one accepts the inconceivable potencies of the Lord.

athapi te deva padambuja-dvaya-
prasada-lesanugṛhita eva hi
janati tattvam bhagavan-mahimno
na canya eko ’pi ciram vicinvan (SB 10.14.29)

Lord Brahma said this. He said that after Brahma-vimohana-lila. “Unless one gets a drop of mercy from Your lotus feet, one can never understand Your inconceivable greatness.”

That is what Brahma got when he tried to fool the Lord, and the Lord revealed His inconceivable nature. That was his realization. “Unless one gets a drop of mercy from Your lotus feet, one will never be able to understand Your inconceivable pastimes.”

In those same prayers Brahma says to the Lord, “Those who are accustomed to speculate about You are like persons who beat the empty husk of rice to get grain. They do not get Your mercy but they do get something. They get their hard labor”... because if they beat the empty husk of rice to get grain, there is no rice in there. It is empty.  But they keep on beating. They get something – their hard labor, but no rice.

Brahma says that in the same prayers in Brahma-vimohana-lila when he is praying to the Lord. That is what he says to Krsna. “We need Your mercy. Somehow or other I simply want to be qualified for Your mercy.” That is what Brahma also said in the same prayers. He said to the Lord, “O my Lord, please count me as one of Your devotees. Let me take birth as Brahma in any planet. Wherever I go, it does not make any difference. Just look at me and count me as one of Your devotees.” That was his prayer, the same prayer after Brahma-vimohana-lila. That is all he wanted. Just please accept me as somebody who wants to serve You. That is a devotee. He is happy to know that the Lord is inconceivable, and he never blames the Lord for his suffering.

tat te 'nukampam susamiksamaṇo
bhunjana evatma-kṛtam vipakam
hṛd-vag-vapurbhir vidadhan namas te
jiveta yo mukti-pade sa daya-bhak  (SB 10.14.8)


That is also described in the prayers in Srimad Bhagavatam. “One who seeks Your compassion and tolerates all kinds of adverse suffering due to one’s own past misdeeds, who goes on serving You with his body, mind and words, certainly he becomes a bona fide candidate for Krsna’s mercy.” He does not blame Krsna, “Oh, why did You always let me suffer?! It is Your fault. I cannot surrender until I know why Krsna did this.”
Now I am going to go back to Bhaktivinoda Thakura. This is all an introduction to Bhaktivinoda Thakura. I did not forget. I am going to read it. I am probably going to end with it. This is Sri Bhaktyaloka.

“The Amnaya says that the living entities are minute particles of the spiritual sun, Krsna, and they are innumerable. As the spiritual world is manifested by Krsna’s cit, or spiritual potency, and as the material world is manifested by the inferior illusory energy, similarly the living entities are manifested by a portion of the spiritual energy.”

visṇu-saktiḥ para prokta
ksetra-jnakhya tatha para
avidya-karma-samjnanya
tṛtiya saktir isyate (Visṇu Puraṇa 6.7.61)

This is actually the three potencies of the Lord (we quoted it right in the very beginning) –  the superior, the inferior and living entities.

“Krsna’s spiritual form has all qualities in full. And those qualities are naturally present in the living entities in minute quantity.”

Krsna’s qualities are unlimited and are manifested in minute particles but in a limited way.

“The independent nature of Krsna is found insignificantly in the living entities.”

Krsna is supremely independent. We are minutely independent.

“Why? Why am I minutely independent? Why did He let me be independent?”
“Because we are part and parcel of Krsna. Krsna is unlimitedly independent. We are minutely independent.”
“I do not want to be minutely independent.”
“Oh, you do not want to be minutely independent? So, that means you want to be dependent, huh?”
“No, I am not ready to be dependent. But I do not want to be minutely independent either.”
“Oh, that means you don’t want to exist, right?”
“Maybe that’s what I am saying.”
“Sorry, you exist. And nothing is going to change.”
“I don’t want to be dependent, I don’t want to be minutely independent either.”

Anyway, let’s continue.

“The independent nature of Krsna insignificantly found in living beings. For this reason the living entities claim to be independent. As a result all living entities have developed different propensities. By one propensity the living entity searches for his own happiness.”

Fruitive activities... karma... avidya karma samjnana... from to topmost planets lowest planets.

“By one propensity the living entity searches for his own happiness. By another propensity he searches for Krsna’s happiness. Thus living entities are divided into two groups – those searching for their own happiness and those searching for Krsna’s happiness. Those who search for Krsna’s happiness are called nitya-mukta and those who search for their own happiness are called nitya-baddha. In this regard all inconceivable natures are under the subordination of spiritual time.”
“In this regard all these inconceivable nature are subordinate to spiritual time.”

Those who are still trapped in the material world cannot understand it.  Think of something that has no beginning …

Go ahead! Start! Let me know when you are finished. At some point you have to accept Krsna has no beginning. But if you try to get there by using  the limited mind, you cannot get there, because everything in our experience has a beginning.

Somebody may say, “Krsna has created the material world. It has a beginning.”

Well, that’s what you think, but the material world has always existed. And its creation and annihilation has been going on eternally, because Krsna’s energies are eternal. Not only Krsna is eternal but His energies are eternal. His energies have no beginning because Krsna has no beginning also. Just as you cannot conceive of somebody who has no beginning, His energies also have no beginning.”

“You mean to tell me that there was never the time when Krsna created His energies!?”

Here we go.

They have no beginning. They are always eternally manifest or unmanifest. And the complete understanding of the Supreme Being cannot be understood unless one accepts that Krsna and His energies exist simultaneously. One has to accept it.

Never was there a time when they are not created. Krsna says to Arjuna that “Never was there a time when I did not exist. Never was there a time you did not exist. You see all the kings assembled here on the battlefield. Never was there a time they did not exist. Nor in the future will any of us ever cease to be.”

Go ahead, start, and think about it! Let me know when you finish. We are still trapped by time.
I am explaining this to help you understand what Bhaktivinoda Thakura is about to say. Because when I finish reading this, this class is over. I want to make sure when I finish reading this, you have the greatest opportunity to accept it. Not that you are going to jump up and say, “Wait a minute! I have to ask this question. You cannot go now.”

Accept it. Just accept it. That’s my humble appeal. It will carry you a long way if you just accept it. Let us continue.

“In this regard all inconceivable natures are under the subordination of spiritual time. The time factor of the spiritual nature is a state of eternal present. But in the inferior illusory energy there are three states of existence – past, present and future.”

“Spiritual time – eternal present, material time – past, present and future; creation, maintenance, destruction. But what was created first? Time because without time there can be no creation, maintenance and destruction. First time is created.”

“When was time created?”

“Accept my dear prabhu.”

“Whatever considerations arise in this regard if related with the spiritual time factor,  then no doubts will remain; but if seen otherwise, then doubts will remain. Why did a pure spirit soul search for his own happiness? If one puts forward such a question, then doubt arising from material time factor will manifest. If one can give up such doubts, then he can perform devotional service, otherwise there will only be a series of arguments. If arguments are related to inconceivable nature, then anarthas arise.”

End of quote, end of class. Hare Krsna. All glories to Srila Prabhupada and our previous Acaryas.

Fruitive desire means desire for one’s own  enjoyment. Therefore Krsna describes this in Bhagavad-gita as karma-bandhana. These desires are the cause of bondage of the living entity in the material world.

There are either fruitive desires or desires aimed for Lord’s pleasure. Those living entities whose desires are pure, exclusively for the Lord’s pleasure are not bound by the laws of fruitive activities or by material nature. Those who have independent desires are under the influence of the three modes of nature which, Krsna very clearly states, are very difficult to overcome.

Why is it difficult to overcome? Because the material nature or the illusory energy has two types of potencies – one is called avaranatmika-sakti, or the potency to keep the living entity feeling satisfied in this world, the other is called praksepatmika-sakti, which is the potency of the Lord that thrusts one down into the material world, even those who make an effort to get freed from it. One is thrust back down. And then one is rocked back and forth into deep sleep, or ignorance, again, thinking that the material world is not such a bad place.

Therefore Krsna says that this material nature is very difficult to overcome. Until one can become free from fruitive desires, one’s status in life will be in the higher, middle or lower planetary system, accordingly-- the living entity is given a suitable body and a suitable facility to enact his fruitive desires.

We see that even great devotees of the Lord can come under the powerful influence of this illusory energy.  The power of avaranatmika-sakti is perfectly displayed in the story about Indra oftentimes told from Mahabharata.

I was looking through Vaktrtavali, a compilation of little stories from Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura. He tells the story about Indra when he was cursed to become a pig. He once lived at Manasa sarovara with his piglets.  Brahma went there and said, “What are you doing here? You belong in heaven.” I am paraphrasing.

But here Srila Bhaktisiddhanta says,
“'O, you! You go to heaven and  sit on the throne of Indra. There, are many servants and maidservants who are waiting to serve you.' Hearing this, Indra was blinded by rage and tried to attack Brahma.”

That was Brahma who was coming down and telling Indra, “What are you doing in this place? You may have been cursed but you don’t have to stay there. You have got a throne on the heavenly planets. You have so many people waiting to serve you. You have so much opulence and enjoyment. And here you are in stool!”

Avaranatmika-sakti. He was thinking that stool was nice. Therefore he was actually opposed to Brahma who was trying to come and rescue him. He considered Brahma an enemy and out of anger and lamentation he became very restless.

Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur then continues,

“Then one by one, Brahma killed Indra's piglets, and as a result, Indra in pig form screamed so loudly that the four directions shook. Then he killed his dear wife. Thereafter, bereft of his relatives, the pig-shaped Indra began to think about Brahma’s instruction and slowly remembered his actual position.”

Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura’s commentary of that is,

“The pig understood, 'I am actually Indra. I am not a pig. The pig body is not my original form. By nature I am the servant of the Supreme Lord, serving as Indra.'

As a result of hearing about one’s constitutional position the living beings can understand their actual identity. At present if we tell people mad after family life about their constitutional position, the way Mahaprabhu taught it, reminding them that they should give up all other activities and simply worship Lord Hari, then like the pig-shaped Indra, they too will reply, 'Eating stool, or in this case, material enjoyment, is our sanatana-dharma and we are happy with it. We do not want to hear about Lord Hari. We have so much work to do. We have to eat stool and we have to have more children.'

Such people think that saints are their enemies. They do not know that:

yasyaham anugrhnami
harisye tad-dhanam sanaih (SB 10.88.8)

“The Supreme Lord has said that to whomever He shows His mercy, He quickly takes away all that person’s possessions.”

I decided to read it rather than paraphrase it so that everybody will understand that these are not my words. These are the words of the previous Acaryas, so that nobody comes and tries to attack me, “Why are you saying this? We do not want to hear these things.”

I do not think anybody will do that. Hopefully, all of you present here understand that the material world is a place of suffering. If that realization is not there, it is very difficult to take to spiritual life, because as Srila Prabhupada states here in the commentary of the verse today, quoting Bhaktivinoda Thakura, “I do not know when I began my material life but I can certainly experience that I have fallen into a deep ocean of nescience.”

Then he quotes Lord Caitanya - ayi nanda-tanuja kinkaram. “Somehow I have fallen into this ocean of nescience. Kindly save me from this horrible condition of materialistic life.” (siksastaka 5)

In other words, in order to break free from this praksepatmika-sakti, one has to be convinced that this material place is no place for any gentleman. One has to at least admit,, “I'm suffering.”
Indra could not even realize that when he was a pig. He was so overwhelmed by the powerful illusory energy that he thought that being in the stool with his pig-wife and his little pig-children was a great place.

This is the power of the illusory energy because sometimes people suffer in the material world but they think, “Let me overcome suffering by fruitive activities.” It is not that people do not realize they are suffering. A lot of people get it, they understand, but they form different philosophies of life on how not to suffer.

One philosophy of life is fruitive activities. The best way to avoid suffering is to enjoy. If I can make a nice arrangement to enjoy, then I can overcome my suffering condition. And if I can maintain hope that this nice arrangement I am making to enjoy will overcome my suffering condition, I am ready to accept whatever difficulties I have because at least I can have hope that I will not suffer like this anymore... And that gives me a sense of happiness. It is close enough, the enjoyment is close enough for me to realize that I can keep going until I get it.

Prabhupada gives the example on the way they keep the race horses running in a race. They put a little carrot in front of the horse’s nose. The horse thinks, “It's close! I know I’ll get it. It is close.” The horse is ready to run to any lengths to get that carrot. “It is there! I am almost there! I am almost there!” Fruitive activity does just that. Then we finally bite into the carrot and think, “Yay! I finally got it.”

The nature of fruitive activities is, as an intelligent person knows, it produces further suffering.

tasyaiva hetoḥ prayateta kovido
na labhyate yad bhramatam upary adhaḥ
tal labhyate duḥkhavad anyataḥ sukham
kalena sarvatra gabhira-ramhasa (SB 1.5.18)

Bhagavatam states that “persons who are actually intelligent and philosophically inclined, do not endeavor for sense enjoyment which is available from the highest planets like Brahmaloka down to the lowest planets like Patala.”

In other words, they have enough brain substance to understand that the material world is a place of suffering. “It does not make any difference if I get some sense enjoyment; I know it is not going to be the permanent solution to my problems.”

There it is. This is the definition what this universe is created for. The universe is created for sense enjoyment from the highest planet to the lowest planet. That is what is being stated here, “Thank you for telling me about what this universe has been created for – for fruitive activities to enjoy from the highest planet to the lowest planet.”

These intelligent persons know that as far as this sense enjoyment is concerned, it comes automatically in due course of time, just as in due course of time suffering comes without asking for it.

This universe is a complete whole. It is a system perfectly designed by perfect intelligence to keep those conditioned souls entrapped. It is such a perfect design. Avaranatmika-sakti and praksepatmika-sakti are perfectly designed. So many facilities to think “I can be satisfied here.” That is what makes it so hard to get out.

Someone may say, “Why did Krsna make it so hard? It is His fault.” It is another challenge sometimes people come up with. “It is His fault, it is not my fault.” But actually the material universe was created as we just read in the verse.

“… I have fully described to you the creation of this material world according to the fruitive activities and desires of the conditioned souls. …” (SB 5.25.14)

It is according to the desires of the conditioned souls. Someone may say, “Well, why am I allowed to have those desires? Krsna should not have allowed me to have those desires. It is His fault.”

Sometimes people get so absorbed in whose fault it is. But here we read today Lord Caitanya says, “Somehow or other I have fallen.” Bhaktivinoda Thakura says, “I do not know when I commenced my material life but I can certainly experience that I have fallen in this deep ocean of nescience.” An intelligent person will try to understand. “I am suffering.”

Prabhupada gives the example when a house is burning down, you do not run and ask, “Who lit the fire?” The house is burning down. You run downstairs, knock on the door and ask, “Who lit the fire?” “What difference does it make? The house is on fire.” “I need to know who lit the fire.” “What do you need to know who lit the fire for? It is burning down.” “At least if I know who lit the fire, I will be careful not to be in a house that's burning down again.” Meanwhile the house is burning down and we get into all these arguments about who lit the fire. It is very difficult to understand.

I oftentimes refer to this quote of Bhaktivinoda Thakura. It is one of my favorite quotes for mental speculators who think that unless they can pierce the covering of the inconceivable potency of the Supreme Lord and fully understand it with their intelligence; they will not surrender to Krsna.

They think, “I have to first understand everything. And only when I can understand everything with my powerful, powerful intelligence. My powerful intelligence will reveal everything to me. Then I will be able to reduce this entire cosmic manifestation to one little simple formula.” Although Krsna can never be reduced to one little simple formula – He is inconceivable, and one has to accept that if one wants to get out of this material world.

Unless one accepts the inconceivable potencies of the Lord, he will never be able to get out of maya. With our puny little brains we try to reduce Krsna to someone who we can so fully understand that we can predict everything.

But Krsna always has the upper hand. That's what makes Him different from us. He is God and we are not.
ekale isvara kṛsṇa, ara saba bhṛtya
yare yaiche nacaya, se taiche kare nṛtya (CC Adi 5.142)

Krsna is the Supreme and all living entities are subordinate to Him.

‘mayadhisa' ‘maya-vasa' -- isvare-jive bheda as described in Caitanya Caritamrita. Krsna is mayadhisa, which means He is the controller of maya. And living entities are maya-vasa; they are under the control of maya. Krsna says,

mayadhyaksena prakrtih
suyate sa-caracaram (B-g 9.10)

Maya works under My direction. These things living entities can understand by hearing from a superior source but Krsna’s powers and potencies are always inconceivable.

Just like the story of Lord Brahma. There are so many stories about Lord Brahma, like Brahma vimohana-lila. In Brahma-vimohana-lila he tried to play a trick on Krsna but Krsna had to show him that He has the upper hand.

“Do you think you can play a trick on Me and steal all my cowherd boys and cows? I have the upper hand. I will become all the cowherd boys and cows. Why have you taken them away?”
Then Brahma comes back and sees all the cows and cowherd boys. Then Krsna reveals His four-armed form to Brahma and all the cowherd boys and cows are Him. And Brahma says, “Oh, forgive me. I can never fully understand Your glories.” Brahma offered his prayers to the Lord. “Forgive me. I tried to reduce You to a little formula and You showed me that it's not possible.”

When Brahma went to see the Lord, the gate-keeper came and Brahma said, “I have come to see the Lord.” Then the gate-keeper went in and said, “Brahma wants to see You.” The gate-keeper goes back to Lord Brahma because the Lord asked the gate-keeper to ask him, “Which Brahma is it?” So he goes back to Brahma and says, “The Lord wants to know which Brahma is here.”

“Which Brahma? It is Brahma. He knows who I am. I am Brahma with four heads.” Brahma thought he was the original creator of the universe. “He should know who I am.” That is power of the Lord’s energy that one thinks oneself to be important. Then Krsna has to reveal His inconceivable potencies for those who may temporarily forget.

Lord Brahma was allowed in and the Lord said, “You asked which Brahma you are.” Then all of a sudden all the other Brahmas were called by the Lord – Brahmas with eight heads, sixteen heads, thirty-two heads, sixty-four heads, millions of heads. Then Brahma felt like a little insignificant insect in presence of all these other Brahmas.

The inconceivable potencies of the Lord have to be accepted. The difference between a devotee and empiricists is that they cannot accept submission to the inconceivable potencies of the Lord. But when a devotee sees the inconceivable potencies of the Lord, he thinks how wonderful Krsna is. “Krsna is so wonderful.” That is the difference between a devotee and an empiricist – a devotee accepts that Krsna is so wonderfully inconceivable.

“The more I hear about Him, the more I want to serve Him.” The more one wants to serve Him, the more Krsna becomes satisfied with the devotee’s desire to serve Him that He reveals more and more of His inconceivable nature into the heart of that devotee, because a devotee always wants to serve the Lord. He does not look for excuses not to serve the Lord. He knows that under all circumstances the Lord is worthy of my service now and forever. He is happy to hear the inconceivable pastimes of the Lord, because the more he hears about the inconceivable pastimes of the Lord, the more his love for the Lord increases. The more he remembers the Lord, the more he desires to serve the Lord and the more he becomes qualified to become an eternal associate of the Lord. By the inconceivable potencies of the Supreme Lord, even that which is inconceivable can be understood. Even that which is inconceivable can be understood if one accepts the inconceivable potencies of the Lord.

athapi te deva padambuja-dvaya-
prasada-lesanugṛhita eva hi
janati tattvam bhagavan-mahimno
na canya eko ’pi ciram vicinvan (SB 10.14.29)

Lord Brahma said this. He said that after Brahma-vimohana-lila. “Unless one gets a drop of mercy from Your lotus feet, one can never understand Your inconceivable greatness.”

That is what Brahma got when he tried to fool the Lord, and the Lord revealed His inconceivable nature. That was his realization. “Unless one gets a drop of mercy from Your lotus feet, one will never be able to understand Your inconceivable pastimes.”

In those same prayers Brahma says to the Lord, “Those who are accustomed to speculate about You are like persons who beat the empty husk of rice to get grain. They do not get Your mercy but they do get something. They get their hard labor”... because if they beat the empty husk of rice to get grain, there is no rice in there. It is empty.  But they keep on beating. They get something – their hard labor, but no rice.

Brahma says that in the same prayers in Brahma-vimohana-lila when he is praying to the Lord. That is what he says to Krsna. “We need Your mercy. Somehow or other I simply want to be qualified for Your mercy.” That is what Brahma also said in the same prayers. He said to the Lord, “O my Lord, please count me as one of Your devotees. Let me take birth as Brahma in any planet. Wherever I go, it does not make any difference. Just look at me and count me as one of Your devotees.” That was his prayer, the same prayer after Brahma-vimohana-lila. That is all he wanted. Just please accept me as somebody who wants to serve You. That is a devotee. He is happy to know that the Lord is inconceivable, and he never blames the Lord for his suffering.

tat te 'nukampam susamiksamaṇo
bhunjana evatma-kṛtam vipakam
hṛd-vag-vapurbhir vidadhan namas te
jiveta yo mukti-pade sa daya-bhak  (SB 10.14.8)


That is also described in the prayers in Srimad Bhagavatam. “One who seeks Your compassion and tolerates all kinds of adverse suffering due to one’s own past misdeeds, who goes on serving You with his body, mind and words, certainly he becomes a bona fide candidate for Krsna’s mercy.” He does not blame Krsna, “Oh, why did You always let me suffer?! It is Your fault. I cannot surrender until I know why Krsna did this.”
Now I am going to go back to Bhaktivinoda Thakura. This is all an introduction to Bhaktivinoda Thakura. I did not forget. I am going to read it. I am probably going to end with it. This is Sri Bhaktyaloka.

“The Amnaya says that the living entities are minute particles of the spiritual sun, Krsna, and they are innumerable. As the spiritual world is manifested by Krsna’s cit, or spiritual potency, and as the material world is manifested by the inferior illusory energy, similarly the living entities are manifested by a portion of the spiritual energy.”

visṇu-saktiḥ para prokta
ksetra-jnakhya tatha para
avidya-karma-samjnanya
tṛtiya saktir isyate (Visṇu Puraṇa 6.7.61)

This is actually the three potencies of the Lord (we quoted it right in the very beginning) –  the superior, the inferior and living entities.

“Krsna’s spiritual form has all qualities in full. And those qualities are naturally present in the living entities in minute quantity.”

Krsna’s qualities are unlimited and are manifested in minute particles but in a limited way.

“The independent nature of Krsna is found insignificantly in the living entities.”

Krsna is supremely independent. We are minutely independent.

“Why? Why am I minutely independent? Why did He let me be independent?”
“Because we are part and parcel of Krsna. Krsna is unlimitedly independent. We are minutely independent.”
“I do not want to be minutely independent.”
“Oh, you do not want to be minutely independent? So, that means you want to be dependent, huh?”
“No, I am not ready to be dependent. But I do not want to be minutely independent either.”
“Oh, that means you don’t want to exist, right?”
“Maybe that’s what I am saying.”
“Sorry, you exist. And nothing is going to change.”
“I don’t want to be dependent, I don’t want to be minutely independent either.”

Anyway, let’s continue.

“The independent nature of Krsna insignificantly found in living beings. For this reason the living entities claim to be independent. As a result all living entities have developed different propensities. By one propensity the living entity searches for his own happiness.”

Fruitive activities... karma... avidya karma samjnana... from to topmost planets lowest planets.

“By one propensity the living entity searches for his own happiness. By another propensity he searches for Krsna’s happiness. Thus living entities are divided into two groups – those searching for their own happiness and those searching for Krsna’s happiness. Those who search for Krsna’s happiness are called nitya-mukta and those who search for their own happiness are called nitya-baddha. In this regard all inconceivable natures are under the subordination of spiritual time.”
“In this regard all these inconceivable nature are subordinate to spiritual time.”

Those who are still trapped in the material world cannot understand it.  Think of something that has no beginning …

Go ahead! Start! Let me know when you are finished. At some point you have to accept Krsna has no beginning. But if you try to get there by using  the limited mind, you cannot get there, because everything in our experience has a beginning.

Somebody may say, “Krsna has created the material world. It has a beginning.”

Well, that’s what you think, but the material world has always existed. And its creation and annihilation has been going on eternally, because Krsna’s energies are eternal. Not only Krsna is eternal but His energies are eternal. His energies have no beginning because Krsna has no beginning also. Just as you cannot conceive of somebody who has no beginning, His energies also have no beginning.”

“You mean to tell me that there was never the time when Krsna created His energies!?”

Here we go.

They have no beginning. They are always eternally manifest or unmanifest. And the complete understanding of the Supreme Being cannot be understood unless one accepts that Krsna and His energies exist simultaneously. One has to accept it.

Never was there a time when they are not created. Krsna says to Arjuna that “Never was there a time when I did not exist. Never was there a time you did not exist. You see all the kings assembled here on the battlefield. Never was there a time they did not exist. Nor in the future will any of us ever cease to be.”

Go ahead, start, and think about it! Let me know when you finish. We are still trapped by time.
I am explaining this to help you understand what Bhaktivinoda Thakura is about to say. Because when I finish reading this, this class is over. I want to make sure when I finish reading this, you have the greatest opportunity to accept it. Not that you are going to jump up and say, “Wait a minute! I have to ask this question. You cannot go now.”

Accept it. Just accept it. That’s my humble appeal. It will carry you a long way if you just accept it. Let us continue.

“In this regard all inconceivable natures are under the subordination of spiritual time. The time factor of the spiritual nature is a state of eternal present. But in the inferior illusory energy there are three states of existence – past, present and future.”

“Spiritual time – eternal present, material time – past, present and future; creation, maintenance, destruction. But what was created first? Time because without time there can be no creation, maintenance and destruction. First time is created.”

“When was time created?”

“Accept my dear prabhu.”

“Whatever considerations arise in this regard if related with the spiritual time factor,  then no doubts will remain; but if seen otherwise, then doubts will remain. Why did a pure spirit soul search for his own happiness? If one puts forward such a question, then doubt arising from material time factor will manifest. If one can give up such doubts, then he can perform devotional service, otherwise there will only be a series of arguments. If arguments are related to inconceivable nature, then anarthas arise.”

End of quote, end of class. Hare Krsna. All glories to Srila Prabhupada and our previous Acaryas.

data.title: Moscow and Beyond (Update)
data.blurb: Just before leaving Govardhana for my meeting in Delhi with Gopal Krsna Goswami, Madana-mohana dasa received news that my Russian visa could be picked up before 1:00 PM. He was told that if it was not picked up before 1:00 PM, we would have to wait until May 10th.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Just before leaving Govardhana for my meeting in Delhi with Gopal Krsna Goswami, Madana-mohana dasa received news that my Russian visa could be picked up before 1:00 PM. He was told that if it was not picked up before 1:00 PM, we would have to wait until May 10th.

Of course, the phone call came at 11:30 AM and we were still in Govardhana, almost three hours from Delhi. By Krsna's grace, we were able to authorize someone in Delhi to pick up my passports for me. Up until the time of that call, I was skeptical about getting my visa so quickly. But now that my doubts had been cleared, Madana-mohana and I immediately followed through with a tentative plan to leave Delhi the following morning for Moscow.

My plan now is to also follow through with my back treatment while I continue to recover from bronchitis. In fact, I had my first back treatment the same day I arrived in Moscow. A second, much more intense treatment, was done the next day.

I have no immediate plan to leave Moscow until it's clear that… either there is improvement and I should continue the treatment as long as required, or until it's clear that I've taken the treatment as far as it can take me. In other words, it's possible I could remain in Moscow as long as until early June. None of this will be clear for at least another two weeks.

Meanwhile, I will not take part in any local programs and/or private meetings until the last week of May. Once a schedule has been put together, it will be posted here on the site.

There is no need for anyone to contact Madana-mohana dasa with any invitation between now and the last week of May. I surely appreciate invitiations. But at this time, any invitation would be much less appreciated than usual.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Challenging Week
data.blurb: It all started on April 25th. I left Trai Prabhu's home in the outskirts of Bologna, expecting to catch a 12:20 PM flight to Vienna and then a connecting flight to Moscow.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
It all started on April 25th. I left Trai Prabhu's home in the outskirts of Bologna, expecting to catch a 12:20 PM flight to Vienna and then a connecting flight to Moscow.

I had come down with a very bad cold that day, an event which, unknown to me then, would contribute to the title of this blog. Being concerned how I would tolerate the flight with such a bad cold, I filled myself up with antihistamine, hoping that it would carry me through the long day of travel and that it would also minimize the risk of an ear canal inflammation, something which is always a risk when flying with a bad cold.

In Moscow my plan was to take an intensive treatment for my back until the third week of May. My back has been progressively getting worse for the past several months.

Without going into too much detail, I will simply say that this planned treatment was an attempt to do my part to avoid a reoccurrence of back problems similar to those which sidelined me for many months about seven or eight years ago.

About 1-2 kilometers from Trai Prabhu's home, the tire on the car taking me to Bologna Airport went completely flat. There was no spare tire and it was a holiday in Italy. There was no way to get a quick repair. To avoid missing the flight, we called Trai Prabhu, who promptly came in his car to drive me to the airport.

Fortunately I arrived at the airport within more than enough time to check in and catch my flight. Unfortunately, however, while checking in I discovered that my Russian visa, though still valid in my old passport was unacceptable unless it was transferred into my new passport. I did not expect this.

Just two months earlier, my valid Indian visa in my old passport, when provided along with my new passport, was accepted without issue for entering India. Moreover, I had been told from reliable sources, that this is a standard procedure… to show the still-valid visa in the old passport along with the new passport. Apparently this is not so for entering Russia.

In and of itself, this did not seem like that much of a problem. I therefore attempted to cancel my flight before it departed, to rebook my flight for either the next day or the day after, and to then find the closest Russian Embassy where I could transfer my visa from my old passport to my new passport.

I discovered, however, that not only was my ticket non-refundable, which meant that within the next hour I would lose my ticket to Moscow, but that the nearest Russian Embassy was in Milan, they were closed the next day, and they would answer queries only in the embassy and only after booking an appointment with them online. In other words, there was no way I could even find out if I could get my visa transferred in Milan until I drove there for a pre-scheduled appointment. It sounded too risky for me.

I contacted Madana-mohana dasa and asked him to inquire whether or not I could get my visa transferred into my new passport in India. He then contacted a Russian consulate in India. He was told that for a small fee it could be done.

It was then and there, while still sitting in the Bologna Airport, that I decided to fly to Delhi through Moscow. The first flight would be a direct flight from Bologna to Moscow, leaving shortly after midnight on the 27th morning. Both Trai Prabhu and Bhaktin Felicia, a local devotee who had accompanied both of us to the airport, were of the opinion that the cancelled flight was Krsna's arrangement for me to recuperate in Bologna from my bad cold before spending time in an airplane. I now had an extra day and a half to recover, and honestly speaking, with the way I was feeling, I couldn't help but fully agree with them.

After an additional day and a half with Trai Prabhu, although rested, my condition was worsening into something I've encountered before from the effects of a bad cold. It was slowly moving into my lungs. Still, not wanting to change plans once again, I decided to fly to Moscow anyway.

Since I could not leave the airport, I tried my best to rest in Sheremetyevo Airport for the eleven-hour transit before boarding my afternoon flight to Delhi where I had a 10:20 AM appointment at the Russian Embassy the following morning. To be safe, I booked a return flight to Moscow on May 4th morning, thinking that a week would give me enough time to get my work done in Delhi and to visit Bhakti Vijnana Goswami in Govardhana.

By the time I arrived in Delhi in the early hours of April 28th, I had all of the symptoms of bronchial asthma… a condition which, despite medication and long periods of resting, is still current as I am writing this blog. Needless to say, this illness has been a challenge in and of itself. But more challenges were yet come.

Having decided that, once again, I needed to stay in one place and recover before moving on, I proceeded to my 10:20 appointment in the embassy. data.title: More News from My Travels in the United States
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I apologize, but this trip I did not record any lectures from North America. If any lectures were posted, it's only because somebody in attendance recorded them and made them available for upload through one online resource or another. Hence, this is the main reason why no new lectures have been posted since I left Kiev.

Additionally, for those of you who live overseas, you might not be aware of the way I've been traveling for the last month.

New York – Hartford  - 250 kilometers
Hartford to Boston - 175 kilometers
Boston to Hartford -175 kilometers
Hartford to Alachua -1,800 kilometers
Alachua to Miami - 600 kilometers
Miami to Alachua - 600 kilometers
Alachua to Sandy Ridge, North Carolina - 900 kilometers
Sandy Ridge to Hartford - 1,100 kilometers
Hartford to Ottawa -700 kilometers
Ottawa to Toronto - 450 kilometers
Toronto to Fairfield - 850 kilometers

That was 7,600 kilometers traveled by car.

I usually do not travel this way, but this also had some impact on the number of lectures I've given this trip. A significant part of the time was spent in the car. Fortunately, my godbrother, Pyari Mohan Prabhu did most of the driving for the major part of my journey.

After leaving Guru Gauranga Prabhu's home in South Florida, I returned to Alachua for a day, mainly to pick up Pyari Mohan Prabhu and his wife. Still, I was able to spend the evening with Kirtiraja Prabhu and another old friend from Boston I have not seen in more than a decade. The following morning the three of us left for Prabhupada Village in Sandy Ridge, North Carolina.

First, a little history about my connection with Prabhupada Village…

I was requested to be GBC for The Festival of India (http://festivalofindia.org/) some time in the late 1980's. My godbrother and friend, Madhuha Prabhu, is in charge of this Festival of India.

My connection with Prabhupada Village, therefore, goes back to 1992 when Madhuha Prabhu acquired several hundred acres of land in the hills of North Carolina. Gradually, he subdivided the land, invited devotees, and over the course of many years devotees built their own homes on streets named Prabhupada Road, Seeta Drive, Radha's Way, Rama Road, Krishna Road, etc. As the community continued to grow, the devotees decided to build their own temple in the center of their community and called it "The Temple of the Holy Name" (see Google map below).

Naturally, since I've been visiting Prabhupada Village for twenty-five years, I developed relationships with many of the devotees who live there. Therefore in addition to the two lectures I gave at the Temple of the Holy Name, the rest of my two-day visit was filled with informal gatherings and meetings with many of the local devotees.

To be continued…

data.title: An Update While on the Road in the U.S.
data.blurb:
The following is an update while on the road in the United States:

After receiving all of my documents a few days earlier than expected, I was able to leave Kiev on the evening of March 14th.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is an update while on the road in the United States:

After receiving all of my documents a few days earlier than expected, I was able to leave Kiev on the evening of March 14th.

From Kiev I had a 14-hour layover in Istanbul. Upon arriving, just around midnight, I was greeted by Nrsimha Krsna dasa at the airport who then brought me to his home to rest for a few hours, to chant my rounds, to take breakfast, and to have some discussion with a few local devotees who came to see me. I decided to return to the airport three hours before departure, since security on direct flights from Istanbul to the United States can be more rigorous than on most other flights. Our discussion therefore continued into the car on the way to the airport.

I had one day to rest in the New York area and then proceeded to Hartford for a full day of consultation and meetings about a building the local devotees are considering to purchase for a new temple. There are more details I could give, but since the building acquisition is still a work in progress, I will wait until it's clear one way or the other if we will be able to get that building.

The next day, I proceeded to Boston, met up with Madhavananda dasa and Krishnakund dd, and then spent Sunday at the Boston temple. Since my schedule was already fixed prior to being delayed in Ukraine, unfortunately my visit to Boston was reduced from six days to one day. I'm still trying to think of a way I can make this up to the Boston devotees, hopefully with another visit before the end of this year.

On Sunday in Boston, I took part in a gathering of congregational members to discuss ways to create a better preaching vision for the Boston congregational community. Devotees had a lot of good ideas to offer and then I was asked to cap the meeting with some words of wisdom. I'm not sure if my words had wisdom, but I was very happy to at least spend some time with the community members who did come for the gathering.

I was then able to listen to a very interesting talk on the "Yoga of Lamentation", given by Madhavananda Prabhu. After the talk, the devotees who remained after the Sunday Feast program very enthusiastically took part in a kirtan for the final aratik, an event which has become one of my favorite parts of my visits to Boston. During this time I was able to take my last darshan of the day, and unfortunately, also of my visit, of Their beautiful and most merciful Lordships Sri Sri Radha Gopivallabha.

Everyone seemed so enlivened with the kirtan that I decided to have another kirtan after the aratik, which seemed as if it could have gone on well into the night. But I reluctantly decided to end it at a reasonable time because I had to leave early the following morning for another visit to the potential new temple building in Hartford, which included further discussion about some of the major obstacles which would need to be overcome to acquire it.

On Tuesday late morning, I left Hartford with my godbrother Pyari Mohan Prabhu and his wife, Jivanausadhi dd, for an 18-hour journey to Alachua, Florida. We made a short stop in New Jersey to leave Madhavananda and Krishnakund for their week-long seminar tour in the New York area, to see the site of the new Towaco temple, and we then continued on our way to the home of our hosts, my godbrother, Purusartha Prabhu and his wife Tulasi dasi's home, stopping only once along the way for a restful night's rest.

All in all, we had three wonderful programs in Alachua… an evening kirtan program at Purusartha Prabhu's home, an evening home program at the home of Jagadish dasa and Savitri devi dasi, and a morning informal gathering and kirtan in the association of old friends from the Boston temple who now live in Alachua.

I was also able to meet up with a lot old friends from other communities and temples, including my godbrother, Kirtiraja Prabhu, with whom I served closely during the late 80's and early 90's while preaching in the former Soviet Union. I am looking forward to receiving him and his wife, Haripuja dasi, at the Bhakti Sangama Festival in September. He assured me that he will be coming this year.

Unfortunately, other than one photo (posted below), I do not have any material from those programs to provide for the site. But sometimes these things show up in other places and devotees send photos, files, and/or links to the webmaster for posting at some later date.

Yesterday morning, after our last gathering, I quickly packed and proceeded to South Florida where I will spend the next several days with Guru Gauranga Prabhu and his wife, who happen to live right around the corner from an uncle I continue to visit and who will be turning 90 this year. He's very favorable, friendly, and always very happy to see me.

to be continued…(hopefully)

Hare Krsna

Your servant,

Body_raw.value:
March 10, 2016
Kiev

Dear Yadubara Prabhu,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

I've been wanting to write to you for a couple of reasons.

1) To find out how the fundraising is going as well as to find out how the work with the distributor is going.

2) To let you know that when I arrived in Kiev from India there was a small stack of Gryvnas on my desk with a list of Kiev donors. As you know the Ukraine devotees, in general, are not so materially wealthy. But after reading my blog some of them came forward to make their offerings to the cause, just like the famous spiders who were assisting Lord Rama with the construction of the bridge to Lanka. Thus their real wealth can be appreciated in their love for Srila Prabhupada and in your efforts to glorify him all over the world.

Here is the list of donors which was sitting on my desk:

Anya Kharchenko    10
Sergey Kariov    50
Vaishnava d, Tilakini dd    200
Vamsi Gopala d.    50
Ramini dd    20
Mandakini dd    100
Khudyakov Nina    10
Julia Kovalenko    20
Elizabeth    20
Buriak Eugene    100
Plokhotnichenko Timur, Ira    25
Bh. Alexey Petrov   70
Bh. Leoshko Alexander 200
Bh. Svyatoslav 19
Bhaktin Irina  70
Gaji dd 75
Bhaktin Olga 21

It adds up to approximately 1060 Gryvnas which at the current rate is approximately 40 USD. I know it's not a lot, but I also know how much you appreciate the efforts of the Ukraine devotees. So I didn't want to miss the opportunity to inform you about what they did after reading that you wanted everyone, everywhere to help as much as they could.

I'm returning to the United States some time next week. I can therefore send their donations directly to you in the form of a check along with anything else I may pick up along the way.

Can I send it to the same place as last time?

Hoping this meets you in good health.

Your servant,
Niranjana Swami

P.S. Another devotee, Akriti devi dasi, handed me 4,500 rupees, also apparently after reading my blog, and asked if I could arrange to get that to you. That donation was already sent to the fundraising site in the form of an anonymous donation.

data.title: To Make a Long Story Short
data.blurb:
My documents were not ready in time for my Ukrainian residency permit application.

I cannot return to the United States on March 7th (according to plan) but must now return to Kiev in order to re-apply for residency once the documents are ready.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
My documents were not ready in time for my Ukrainian residency permit application.

I cannot return to the United States on March 7th (according to plan) but must now return to Kiev in order to re-apply for residency once the documents are ready.

I will return to Kiev late next week and will remain until March 17th, at which time I will fly to the United States. If I can finish my business earlier, I will leave before March 17th, but that will not be known until the end of next week.

I will post more details about my newly scheduled visit to Kiev some time next week.

Meanwhile, I'm still recovering from the difficult journey from Kolkata to Delhi to Istanbul to Kiev, with eight-hour transits in both Delhi and Istanbul. As per tradition, I lost my ability to digest during the transition from Mayapura to Kiev and it is now very slowly recovering.

I will give Srimad Bhagavatam class here in Kiev on Saturday and Sunday mornings. Sunday class will have to be short, however, because I must leave for the airport very shortly after class.

Hare Krishna

data.title: Vyasa Puja Book and Other Offerings
data.blurb: I would like to report that last night, January 26, 2017, I finished reading  all of the Vyasa Puja offerings received this year as well as everything else which was given to me on the day Vyasa Puja was observed in Hartford, Connecticut.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I would like to report that last night, January 26, 2017, I finished reading  all of the Vyasa Puja offerings received this year as well as everything else which was given to me on the day Vyasa Puja was observed in Hartford, Connecticut.

Along with my usual reading, I've been reading a little each day from this year's Vyasa Puja book and that's why it has taken four weeks to post this blog.

I wish to thank all disciples and aspiring disciples who submitted offerings this year. I read each and every offering with great interest and appreciation for their manner of expressing their insightful and encouraging realizations.

Additionally, as I mentioned in my Vyasa Puja talk posted here on this site, hearing (and reading) offerings which recognize Srila Prabhupada's role in connection with my service as an initiating spirital master helps me to digest the glorification involved in this annual event.  It was very satisfying for me to observe that this theme in the offerings seems to be increasing from previous years.

And finally, I would also like to recognize and thank all the devotees (whose names are known to me) who took part in all aspects of producing this year's Vyasa Puja book as well as those who helped organize this year's Vyasa Puja event in Connecticut.

I am equally aware that devotees gathered in many places throughout the world to observe Vyasa Puja and I wish to thank all of you too for enriching my service to Srila Prabhupada by observing this event locally.

Hare Krsna

data.title: The "Acarya" documentary on Srila Prabhupada
data.blurb:
Dear devotees,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

I fall at the feet of all exalted Vaisnavas all over the world and beg you to help all of us realize a dream that any true follower of Srila Prabhupada surely wants to come true.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear devotees,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

I fall at the feet of all exalted Vaisnavas all over the world and beg you to help all of us realize a dream that any true follower of Srila Prabhupada surely wants to come true.

This "Acarya" documentary has the potential to increase Srila Prabhupada's glories exponentially. The more people know who is Srila Prabhupada, the more they will want to take his books, to visit his temples, and to deepen their understanding of the message he came to the West to deliver.

This movie is practically ready for distribution into the same cinemas visited daily by millions of movie enthusiasts throughout the whole world. It's inconceivable! The next step, therefore, will be to entrust the film into the hands of those who have the knowledge, resources, and connections to see that this becomes a reality.

I am so confident in Yadubara Prabhu's and his wife, Visakha devi dasi's, skills and devotion to Srila Prabhupada's lotus feet, that I am attempting to motivate everyone possible to join me in this effort to finance the distribution of this "Acarya" documentary.

Just last week at an event here in America, I tried to raise awareness of this effort and so many devotees kindly came forward and sent individual donations as well as a larger donation which was sent on my behalf from friends and well-wishers here too.

I pray that more and more devotees both here in America as well as throughout the rest of the world will help in whatever way that they can.

Please click on the link below for more information:

https://www.generosity.com/fundraising/acharya-theatrical-distribution

Thank you very much.

Yours in Srila Prabhupada's service,
Niranjana Swami

data.title: Mayapura, 2017
data.blurb:
Several devotees have been inquiring about my schedule for Mayapura next February, 2017.

In order to clear up any misunderstanding or speculation, I'm posting this blog now so that devotees visiting Mayapura next year can make their plans accordingly.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Several devotees have been inquiring about my schedule for Mayapura next February, 2017.

In order to clear up any misunderstanding or speculation, I'm posting this blog now so that devotees visiting Mayapura next year can make their plans accordingly.

Unfortunately, I must leave India no later than February 22nd in order to return to East Europe within sufficient time to renew my residency permits before the old ones expire. This means that next year, this will leave me with no time after the GBC meetings are over to meet with devotees, and/or to give any classes as I usually do after the GBC meetings. Neither will I be in Mayapura for next year's Kirtan Mela.

Due to the intensity of the GBC meetings and the time required for personal meetings with sannyasis, GBC's and godbrothers who will be in Mayapura next year for the SGGS (Sannyasa, Guru, GBC Sanga), I will not be able to meet with anyone other than with the few individuals I already  scheduled meetings with before I left Mayapura in November. Neither will I be able to conduct any programs from the time I will arrive on February 10 until February 22, the day of my departure.

Hopefully this will not become an annual necessity, but for next year, there is no alternative to this arrangement.

Thanking you in anticipation of everyone's understanding.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Trnad Api Sunicena
data.blurb:
Today I was reading from H.H. Bhakti Caru Maharaja's new book, "Ocean of Mercy." It's his personal memories about Srila Prabhupada.

Although I've heard the following anecdote before, I thought I would share it exactly as it has been written in Bhakti Caru Maharaja's book.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Today I was reading from H.H. Bhakti Caru Maharaja's new book, "Ocean of Mercy." It's his personal memories about Srila Prabhupada.

Although I've heard the following anecdote before, I thought I would share it exactly as it has been written in Bhakti Caru Maharaja's book.

One of Srila Prabhupada's godbrothers, O.B.L. Kapoor, was a well-known scholar and prominent personality in the Vrndavana community.

"He and Srila Prabhupada would reminisce, and after they spoke Dr. Kapoor would often sit with the devotees and tell us about their early days together.

He had met Srila Prabhupada in 1931 in Allahabad, where he was attending the university, during one of his visits to the Gaudiya Math. Srila Prabhupada was running his pharmaceutical business there and had once given Dr. Kapoor a tonic that he had manufactured. Upon receiving it, Dr. Kapoor had joked, "Abhay Babu, I wish you would give me the tonic which you yourself take, the tonic of 'krsna-prema' [pure love of Krsna]."

"I don't have the tonic as yet," Srila Prabhupada had replied, "but I have the formula."

"If the formula is not a secret, then will you please give it to me?"

"No, it is not a secret at all:

trnad api sunicena
taror api sahisnuna
amanina manadena
kirtaniyah sada harih

['One should chant the holy name of the Lord in a humble state of mind, thinking himself lower than the straw in the street. One should be more tolerant than the tree, devoid of all sense of prestige, and ready to offer all respects to others.  In such a state of mind one can chant the holy name of the Lord constantly.' (Sri Siksastaka 3)]

"This is the formula," he had said, "and I am going to preach it all over the world."

"At that time," Dr. Kapoor told us, "I couldn't recognize the significance of his words, that he really was going to preach it all over the world. I thought it was just a casual statement. But now I look back and can see that even he was thinking and planning to preach all over the world, which he did.
