Our fifth day on parikrama was another rainy day. We decided to travel a short distance outside Navadvipa Mandala to Ambika Kalna where the temple of Gauridas Pandita is situated. It was a bit of a drive, especially since the road is not always so smooth, but based on my experience of the previous four days, I knew it would be well worth the time and inconvenience.

Unfortunately, Dhanurdhara Maharaja had to return to Vrndavana the evening before. His presence was so much appreciated by all of us for many reasons, but especially because he was so easy to be satisfied. He was visibly enlivened by everything we did on parikrama—to hear, to read, and especially to chant bhajans. He must have told me at least four times that it was the best parikrama he had ever been on—and he's been on a lot of parikramas! Of course, it's possible he might have been saying that just to encourage me. But judging from his facial expression, I sensed that he was serious.

There is a wonderful story from Bhakti Ratnakara connected to the temple in Ambika Kalna. I was very eager to take darshan of the Gaura Nitai Deities Who had once left the altar to take part in the kirtan organized by Gauridas Pandita's disciple, Hrdaya Caitanya.

The following is the story exactly as it was told by Narahari Cakravarty in Bhakti Ratnakara, Chapter Seven, and translated by Kusakratha Prabhu:

One day he [Gauridas Pandita] told Hrdaya Nanda that the Lord's birthday was approaching.

"I shall visit the houses of my followers to collect provisions for the festvial and I shall return soon," said Gauridasa.

"Be very careful in your service to the Lord."  Then Gauridasa left his house.

Gauridasa passed some time in solitary places with other devotees singing about the glories of the Lord.

Meanwhile Hrdaya Nanda began to think, "Why is the master so late in returning?"

"Only two more days remain before the ceremony and enough provisions have already been collected here."

Considering these points and remembering the feet of his spiritual master he decided to send invitations everywhere for the great ocassion.

Pandita Gauridasa returned just one day before the festival and when he heard that Hrdaya had sent invitations everywhere, even without his permission, Gauridasa felt happy right to the core of his heart.

Outwardly, however he showed his displeasure and scolded Hrdaya angrily.  "While I am still living you have acted in an independent manner."

"You have sent invitation letters at your own will but I shall not join you."

Hrdaya bowed at his master's feet and went to the bank of the Ganges where he lived under a tree.

Gauridasa started the festival and mahantas from far and near assembled there.

One wealthy man sent a large quantity of provisions in a boat.

The rich man met Sri Hrdaya Nanda on the bank of the Ganges and handed the provisions to him.  Hrdaya Pandita sent a message to Pandita Gauridasa.

In mock anger the Pandita told the messenger to tell Hrdaya Nanda that he could use the provisions for his own celebration.

On the order of his guru Sri Hrdaya happily began to celebrate the occasion using those provisions.

A large number of Vaisnavas assembled there and in their association Hrdaya Nanda performed wonderful sankirtana.

As the sound of the khola and kartala reached the sky it seemed that the ocean of happiness would overflow its banks.

Vaisnavas danced in a circle, with tears flowing continously down their faces.

Suddenly Hrdaya observed that both Lord Nitai and Lord Caitanya - the incarnations of love - were dancing within the circle.

The style of their dancing was indescribable and their physical beauty brightened the whole world.

The faces of those two Lords defeated the pride of the moon and Hrdaya Nanda cried in joy as he observed them.

Hearing the joyous sound of that sankirtana Gauridasa became very pleased although he remained in his own place.

He gently told Gangadasa, "It is now time to worship.  Go to the temple."

But when Hara Gangadasa entered the temple he found no deities on the throne.

When he reported this to the Pandita, Gauridasa was overwhelmed in ecstasy as he realised that the two Lords had been bound in love of Hrdaya Nanda.

With a smile he took his stick in his hand and although he was happy to the core of his heart, he displayed outward anger and headed for that sankirtana gathering by the side of the Ganga.  There he saw his two Lords dancing.

Observing the mock anger of the Pandita the two Prabhus clandestinely entered the temple again.

Gauridasa witnessed that Sri Caitanya had entered into the heart of Hrdaya Nanda.

Seeing Caitanya present in the heart of Hrdaya Nanda Gauridasa could not control his tears.  He looked continually with unblinking eyes.  He forgot his mock anger and unconsciously the stick fell from his hand.

Stretching out his arms in ecstatic love he went forward to embrace Hrdaya.

"How fortunate you are," said Gauridasa. "From this day I name you Hrdaya Caitanya - the man in whose heart Sri Caitanya always resides."

He drenched Hrdaya with his tears and the disciple fell at the feet of his master.

Together they returned to the temple.

Acknowledging the special effulgence of the Lord, Gauridasa appointed Hrdaya Caitanya to the total service of the deities.

The Vaisnavas were all happy about this and the great festival they held defies description.

The grace of the Lord on Hrdaya became known to all. This is the story about Hrdaya Nanda's obtaining the name Hrdaya Caitanya." [end of reference]

When we arrived, we first took darshan of the tamarind tree where it is said that Lord Caitanya and Gauridasa Pandita once met. From there we entered the temple. Some local devotees were having kirtan. Not wanting to interfere with their mood, we set aside our kirtan paraphernalia and instead immediately went to take darshan of the Deities.

As soon as the pujari saw us enter the temple room, he motioned for us to come up the stairs on to the front of the altar so that we could have close darshan of all the Deities. At his request, we first washed our feet and then he invited us up right in front of the altar.

By the time we arrived at the altar of Sri Sri Gaura Nitai, unexpectedly, the pujari had closed the Deity doors. Not knowing how long the doors would be closed, Devamrita Maharaja and I went back to the doors of the first altar in order to attempt seeing Them from an angle. It was not a full darshan but we did manage to at least see Lord Nityananda and part of Lord Caitanya from a sharp angle.

Very shortly thereafter, the pujari opened the main Deity doors. This time we were able to see both of Them fully. I started by going first to Their lotus feet and gradually moved my gaze toward Their smiling faces. I wanted to closely study their features. I took note of Their hand gestures and was thinking to ask if there was a meaning to the way They were holding Their hands. Within in minute, however, if it was even that long, the pujari closed the doors again while we were still standing there, motionless, with our hands folded.

By this time, I remembered that the darshan of Sri Sri Gaura Nitai at this temple is similar to that of Banke Bihari in Vrndavana. The pujari opens and closes the doors at regular intervals to prevent Lord Caitanya and Lord Nityananda from jumping off the altar as They had previously done in loving reciprocation with Their dear servant, Hrdaya Caitanya.

The pujari then invited us to the last altar and pulled the glass case to the doorway in order in order to show us the Bhagavad-gita which is said (by some) to have been handwritten by Lord Caitanya. He apologized for not being able to open the red satin cloth within which the Bhagavad Gita is bound, explaining that over the years, being exposed to the air, the pages had decayed some of it beyond recognition. We took his word that the actual Bhagavad-gita was there and got down to offer our obeisances upon seeing the red cloth. Detecting some disappointment in us, however, he then focused our flashlight on a small piece of a page which was left open inside the glass case on which a verse from Bhagavad-gita was very delicately handwritten. I have to admit, it was beautiful. I felt a little bit better, although I was definitely hoping for the full darshan.

The pujari then brought out the small oar which, as it is told, was handed by Lord Caitanya to Gauridasa Pandita. While handing it to His devotee, the Lord said, "With this oar, you may help the fallen souls cross over the ocean of material existence." The oar has been kept there for all of these years.

By this time, the kirtan devotees were requesting us to come to the kirtan mandap to lead kirtan. They turned over the microphone to us and we eagerly proceeded to chant several bhajans, while some of them sat and took part in the chanting with us. We then read several pastimes about Gauridasa Pandita, including the above story, chanted once more and were then given small plates of prasadam to honor before leaving.

While taking our last darshan(s) of Sri Sri Gaura Nitai, I decided to ask my question to the pujari about the Deities' hands. He told me that it was to emphasize the importance of counting while chanting. I immediately remembered the verse from Saci-Sutastakam, kara-japya-karam hari-nama-param, and quoted the English to Devamrita Maharaja, "While chanting He counts the holy names on the fingers of His hands." Satisfied with his answer, we gradually gathered our belongings, left daksina with the pujari, as we did everywhere, and returned to the car.

While driving back to Mayapura, we took advantage of the remaining time to stop once again at Nrsimhapalli. This time, although there were pilgrims, it was not at all as crowded as it was last time. We were able to take darshan of Lord Nrsimhadeva for as long as we wanted.

I then asked Devamrita Maharaja if he would like to chant the Nrsimha prayers. He quickly agreed, so we brought out the mats and sat down for what I thought would be a short kirtan. However, I so much appreciated the mood after Maharaja's simple, but very heart-felt, kirtan that when he stopped, I couldn't take my fingers off the harmonium keys and started playing another melody, hoping he would continue chanting. Seeing my inclincation to chant more, Maharaja begged me to take over. So I did. For whatever reason, our kirtan really took off. At least thirty pilgrims drew closer to us and started to encircle us. Many of them sat down, and blissfully started clapping their hands, chanting enthusiastically along with us. We were a bit late for lunch that day, but it was definitely worth it.

Hare Krsna

To be continued…

Please click here to see the playlist of day number five.

It was not a full darshan but we did manage to at least see Lord Nityananda and part of Lord Caitanya from a sharp angle.

Very shortly thereafter, the pujari opened the main Deity doors. This time we were able to see both of Them fully. I started by going first to Their lotus feet and gradually moved my gaze toward Their smiling faces. I wanted to closely study their features. I took note of Their hand gestures and was thinking to ask if there was a meaning to the way They were holding Their hands. Within in minute, however, if it was even that long, the pujari closed the doors again while we were still standing there, motionless, with our hands folded.

By this time, I remembered that the darshan of Sri Sri Gaura Nitai at this temple is similar to that of Banke Bihari in Vrndavana. The pujari opens and closes the doors at regular intervals to prevent Lord Caitanya and Lord Nityananda from jumping off the altar as They had previously done in loving reciprocation with Their dear servant, Hrdaya Caitanya.

The pujari then invited us to the last altar and pulled the glass case to the doorway in order in order to show us the Bhagavad-gita which is said (by some) to have been handwritten by Lord Caitanya. He apologized for not being able to open the red satin cloth within which the Bhagavad Gita is bound, explaining that over the years, being exposed to the air, the pages had decayed some of it beyond recognition. We took his word that the actual Bhagavad-gita was there and got down to offer our obeisances upon seeing the red cloth. Detecting some disappointment in us, however, he then focused our flashlight on a small piece of a page which was left open inside the glass case on which a verse from Bhagavad-gita was very delicately handwritten. I have to admit, it was beautiful. I felt a little bit better, although I was definitely hoping for the full darshan.

The pujari then brought out the small oar which, as it is told, was handed by Lord Caitanya to Gauridasa Pandita. While handing it to His devotee, the Lord said, "With this oar, you may help the fallen souls cross over the ocean of material existence." The oar has been kept there for all of these years.

By this time, the kirtan devotees were requesting us to come to the kirtan mandap to lead kirtan. They turned over the microphone to us and we eagerly proceeded to chant several bhajans, while some of them sat and took part in the chanting with us. We then read several pastimes about Gauridasa Pandita, including the above story, chanted once more and were then given small plates of prasadam to honor before leaving.

While taking our last darshan(s) of Sri Sri Gaura Nitai, I decided to ask my question to the pujari about the Deities' hands. He told me that it was to emphasize the importance of counting while chanting. I immediately remembered the verse from Saci-Sutastakam, kara-japya-karam hari-nama-param, and quoted the English to Devamrita Maharaja, "While chanting He counts the holy names on the fingers of His hands." Satisfied with his answer, we gradually gathered our belongings, left daksina with the pujari, as we did everywhere, and returned to the car.

While driving back to Mayapura, we took advantage of the remaining time to stop once again at Nrsimhapalli. This time, although there were pilgrims, it was not at all as crowded as it was last time. We were able to take darshan of Lord Nrsimhadeva for as long as we wanted.

I then asked Devamrita Maharaja if he would like to chant the Nrsimha prayers. He quickly agreed, so we brought out the mats and sat down for what I thought would be a short kirtan. However, I so much appreciated the mood after Maharaja's simple, but very heart-felt, kirtan that when he stopped, I couldn't take my fingers off the harmonium keys and started playing another melody, hoping he would continue chanting. Seeing my inclincation to chant more, Maharaja begged me to take over. So I did. For whatever reason, our kirtan really took off. At least thirty pilgrims drew closer to us and started to encircle us. Many of them sat down, and blissfully started clapping their hands, chanting enthusiastically along with us. We were a bit late for lunch that day, but it was definitely worth it.

Hare Krsna

To be continued…

The fourth day of our parikrama was a bit of a rainy day. We decided to go to Mamagachi because the temples were partially enclosed. We could therefore sit to hear and chant out of the rain. Mamagachi is where the birthplace of Srila Vrndavana dasa Thakur is located. A very short walking distance from there is located the temple where the Deities of Saranga Thakur, Sri Radha Radha-Gopinath are worshiped.

We went first to Vrndavana dasa Thakur's birthplace and immediately took darshan of the presiding Deities Sri Sri Nitai Gauranga, Jagannatha, Baladeva, and Subhadra, (all worshiped by Srila Vrndavana dasa Thakur), and Sri Sri Radha Krsna. Radha Krsna were installed by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur. The temple was very quiet when we entered with only the pujari present. He allowed us to take darshan and to photograph the Deities. He also told us a few stories connected with the tirtha. We then spread our mat and I asked the Maharajas what they would like to do first. The Maharajas seemed to like beginning every session with a bhajan, so I suggested that we chant Saci-sutastakam.

Since the beginning of our parikrama, I was trying to assure both Maharajas that I had no fixed plan for the parikrama except that I would find material for us to read each day. I also wanted to assure them that I was open to spontaneity and to hear from them how we should organize each day's hearing and chanting. However, by today it was starting to become more obvious to me that they were fully satisfied simply to chant the bhajans I picked and to read the material I selected for each day. Fortunately, Devamrita Maharaja would also prepare selections from Caitanya Caritamrita for us to read. It did seem, however, that the bhajans were completely up to me to select.

Therefore, after chanting Saci-sutastakam and reading the translation, I suggested we chant Gaura Pahu once again and asked if, this time, everyone would like to hear Srila Prabhupada's commentary because I liked it so much. Judging from everyone's smile, I knew there would be no resistance to the proposal and proceeded to read it with great relish.

We then read and talked about Srila Vrndavana dasa Thakur, which led to an interesting discussion about defending the sampradaya. This came up when we talked about how strongly Vrndavana dasa Thakur defended Lord Nityananda as illustrated in the following verse from Sri Caitanya Bhagavat, Adi Khanda, Chapter 17, Verses 154-158:

"Someone says, 'Nityananda Prabhu is Balarama,' and another says, 'He is the most beloved devotee of Lord Caitanya.' Someone else says, 'He is a powerful personality,' and another says, 'We don't understand who He is.' Someone may consider Nityananda a sannyasi, someone may consider Him a devotee, and someone may consider Him a jnani. They may say whatever they like. Even if Nityananda is a most insignificant servant of Lord Caitanya, I would still keep His lotus feet in my heart. I therefore kick the head of any sinful person who disregards the glories of Lord Nityananda and dares to criticize Him."

Having discussed how foolish people have tried to find fault in Srila Prabhupada's words, it felt refreshing to be reminded about the importance of standing firm on the words of our previous acaryas.

We then relocated to the Saranga Deva Gaudiya Math where the Deities worshiped by Vasudeva Datta were still being worshiped. There we also took darshan of the Deities worshiped by Saranga Thakur, as well as the Deities of Gaura-Gadadhara. When we arrived, the pujari greeted us with a warm smile and extended us a welcome, both from him and also on behalf of Jagatbandhu, the pujari who had been serving the Deities in this temple for well over sixty years.

I had heard many enlivening stories about Jagatbandhu, especially about his enthusiasm to receive any guest who would arrive at the temple. He had a practice, based upon an order given to him by his spiritual master, to provide prasadam to anyone who visited this temple. Devotees told me stories how he would immediately run into the kitchen to cook sumptuous prasadam for any guest, no matter who they were and no matter what time of day it was. Sometimes, pilgrims would come, wanting only to take darshan. Upon returning with plates of prasadam he had prepared and offered specifically for them, he would sometimes find that his guests had already left. He would then stand there with tears in his eyes for having missed the opportunity to render service to them, anxiously hoping for their return.

Unfortunately, Jagatbandhu broke his hip some time ago, and is still unable to walk. Although he could stay anywhere, he chose to remain lying all day on the floor by the side of the Deity doors with his bead bag in his hand, chanting the Lord's holy names. When we arrived, he seemed to become more animated by our presence and although he could not hear so well, he launched into reciting pastimes from Caitanya Bhagavat, although he spoke only in Bengali.

We listened for a short time and also briefly spoke with the pujari who had greeted us along with Jagatbandhu. We then proceeded to chant the bhajan Kabe Habe Bolo Se Din Amar. A few children and other sevaites gathered around while we chanted. We then read the pastime of Saranga Thakur and how, despite his reluctance to do so, upon receiving the order from Lord Caitanya to accept disciples, he decided that he would accept the first person he saw the next morning as his disciple.

While taking his bath the next morning, he saw the dead body of a boy floating by. He touched the body with his foot, it came back to life,  and Saranga Thakur accepted him on the spot as his disciple. This disciple became famous as Thakur Murari, and faithfully served his spiritual master for the rest of his life.

Earlier we had asked Jagatbandhu what bhajan he would like us to chant. He mentioned that he would like us to chant "Gopinath." I suspected that he was attached to that bhajan because the Deities he worshiped were Sri Sri Radha Gopinath.

Although I had not chanted this bhajan for a very long time, I was eager to render some service to this Vaisnava and therefore attempted to chant it, despite the probability that Jagatbandhu couldn't even hear what was being chanted. Still, he sat and attentively watched while we slowly chanted all three parts of the bhajan. We then read the translation and decided that it was already time for us to leave. The pujari brought mahaprasadam for us. We enthusiastically honored the maha, washed our hands, and then circumambulated the bakula tree where Lord Caitanya would sometimes rest when going home from school in Vidyanagara.

We then proceeded back to Mayapura. It was another very satisfying day of sravanam kirtanam in the most auspicious Navadvipa Dhama.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Parikrama - Day Three
data.blurb: On the third day of parikrama we decided to drive to Godrumadvipa instead of taking the boat across the Jalangi. After forty minutes of driving we arrived first at Svananda Sukhada Kunja (Bhaktivinode Thakur's house).
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On the third day of parikrama we decided to drive to Godrumadvipa instead of taking the boat across the Jalangi. After forty minutes of driving we arrived first at Svananda Sukhada Kunja (Bhaktivinode Thakur's house).

Upon entering the compound we saw a woman sitting and loudly chanting bhajans in the kirtan mandap before the Deity of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur. I was hesitant as to whether or not we should usurp her space and expressed my concerns to the other two Maharajas. Within a minute or two, however, we were greeted by a young brahmacari who was apparently in charge at the time. He saw that we were carrying mats and a harmoniun and quickly understood our intentions.

He told us that they were going to have a gathering at 9:00 AM in the main temple to welcome the month of Kartika. He assured us that the woman chanting would not be disturbed if were to use that space for our hearing and chanting. He, however, did say that we would need to finish there no later than 9:00 AM. As an alternative, he suggested that we use the veranda outside Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's room for as long as we wanted. Not wanting to restrict the spontaneity of our little parikrama party, we immediately opted to go to the veranda.

It was from that veranda that Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur saw the horizon of Mayapura light up across the Jalangi, and foretold that there would be a "wonderful temple there which would broadcast the eternal service of Lord Gauranga throughout the world".

Since it was also the disappearance day of Srila Narottama das Thakur, we agreed that we would first chant "Saparsada-bhagavad-viraha-janita-vilapa", the song for departed Vaisnavas by Srila Narottama dasa Thakur. Dhanurdhara Maharaja then suggested that we utilize our time there on the veranda to chant different bhajans composed by Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur and read the translations. We all agreed and decided that we would read about Srila Narottama dasa Thakur during our evening readings back in Mayapura.

I chose to first chant "Suddha-bhakata-carana-renu" since it was right there in Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's house that the Thakur had experienced what he had described in that same bhajan, "je-dina grhe, bhajana dekhi/ grhete goloka bhaya." "One day while performing devotional practices, I saw my house transformed into Goloka Vrndavana." While chanting, I was deeply meditating on the words of the song and while reading the translation, we all smiled with the hope of seeing his house transformed into Goloka Vrndavana.

I then asked Devamrita Maharaja if he would like to chant one of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's bhajans, and he enthusiastically responded with, "Let's chant Jaya Radha Madhava", which he then proceeded to lead for all of us to follow.

Before we knew it, the time had passed so quickly that we decided we should move on to Surabhi Kunja. We gathered our paraphernalia, took darshan of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's room as well as the room where Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur used to stay, and proceeded to circumambulate the altar where Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's murti is situated and just around the corner, the altar of his personal Deities, Sri Sri Gauranga Mahaprabhu and Sri Sri Gadadhara Pandita. We then prostrated ourselves before Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji's bhajan-kutira, left the compound, and walked the short distance to Surabhi Kunja.

Upon arriving in Surabhi Kunja we immediately noticed that the place where we used to sit had been transformed into a major temple construction site and it even seemed as though it was quite advanced in it's construction. We were very warmly welcomed by the local sevaites, who immediately could understand that we needed a place to sit down to hear and chant. They vacated the veranda of their house and begged us to use it for our satsang. We immediately obliged as they stood nearby in anticipation of what would come next.

Everyone eagerly wanted to continue chanting Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's bhajans. So we then chanted "Boro sukher kabor gai," which mentions Surabhi Kunja, as the place where Lord Nityananda Himself opened a market place of the Holy Name. By that time some local pilgrims had gathered around and seeing our enthusiasm for chanting, some of them immediately started to eagerly chant and dance along with the kirtan.

By this time I was feeling overwhelmed by the mood of our small parikrama party, inspired by everyone's absorption in hearing and chanting. I then began to more deeply meditate upon the words of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur in that bhajan and the great mercy of Nityananda Prabhu, Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur, and of all our previous acaryas. Seeing everyone chanting, knowing that we were all chanting by the mercy of these transcendental personalities, increased my desire to take shelter of their mercy and the holy name more and more.

We chanted another bhajan, and then while reading from Navadvipa Dhama Mahatmya about the island of Godrumadvipa, one young Gaudiya Math sannyasi came to sit with us. He listened for awhile and then welcomed us to Surabhi Kunja. He pointed to a picture of his Guru Maharaja which was hanging there on the veranda, someone who I had neither heard of nor seen before, and told us that he had been requested by him to build a temple (pointing to the temple construction). He then apologized for his having appeared before us in a gamcha, but since he had dedicated himself to fulfilling that order and even to the construction of the building itself, he was often not in his sannyasa dress.

He did not speak that much English, so through Thakur Saranga Prabhu's translation he told us that he had one of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's works in handwriting and asked if we would like to see it. Naturally, we expressed our enthusiasm to take darshan of the book. He then retrieved it for us and eagerly showed us page after page.

Thakur Saranga began reading the Bengali script and we immediately recognized it as one of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's bhajans. Needless to say, we were enlivened by the opportunity to hold, to see, and and to hear directly from this most sacred book and the sannyasi was undoubtedly enlivened to share it with us. He then asked us if we would chant the bhajan, "Sri Godruma-Candra-Bhajana-Upadesa. For some reason, I did not immediately recognize the name of the bhajan and therefore asked if he would chant it for us. But Madana-mohana reminded me that it was the bhajan which began with the words "yadi te hari-pada-saroja-sudha". Immediately recognizing the words, I said, "I think I can chant if you like.", and he asked me to please do so. With the permission of my godbrothers, we then chanted that bhajan and then Dhanurdhara Maharaja read the translation so deeply absorbed in his reading that I felt as if I was present in Godruma's forest bowers eagerly waiting for Lord Gaura to bestow His mercy upon us.

We then decided that, considering our schedule, it was probably best to move on to Nrsimhapalli, which was to be our last stop before returning to Mayapura. However, our hosts would not allow us to leave without honoring prasadam first. They had prepared a little something for us while we were chanting the last bhajan. Fortunately, it was not a large quantity. We honored as much as we could, thanked them for their hospitality, and then parted with a warm embrace from the sannyasi. He seemed genuinely grateful that we had come. He thanked us several times for our association and begged us to please come again as soon as possible.

When we arrived at Nrsimhapalli, there were busloads of pilgrims mulling around and a large group of them were sitting in front of the Deity getting mahaprasadam from the pujari. The mood there was quite different from that which we had experienced on parikrama thus far. Everywhere else we had visited was relatively quiet and thus conducive for hearing and chanting. Nonethless, we still decided to at least take darshan of the self-manifested deity of Lord Nrsimha.

Fortunately, the crowd allowed us to gain access to the altar for darshan. After darshan, we then decided to sit on the mandap for a short kirtan for Lord Nrsimhadeva, which was led by Acyuta Priya Prabhu. Devamrita Maharaja then very feelingly read Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's prayers to Lord Nrsimhadeva from Navadvipa Dhama Mahatmya. We then left, but discussed the possibility of visiting there once again since we had to drive past it at least once more when we would go to Ambika Kalna.

For video clips of day three, please click here

To be continued…

So we then chanted "Boro sukher kabor gai," which mentions Surabhi Kunja, as the place where Lord Nityananda Himself opened a market place of the Holy Name. By that time some local pilgrims had gathered around and seeing our enthusiasm for chanting, some of them immediately started to eagerly chant and dance along with the kirtan.

By this time I was feeling overwhelmed by the mood of our small parikrama party, inspired by everyone's absorption in hearing and chanting. I then began to more deeply meditate upon the words of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur in that bhajan and the great mercy of Nityananda Prabhu, Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur, and of all our previous acaryas. Seeing everyone chanting, knowing that we were all chanting by the mercy of these transcendental personalities, increased my desire to take shelter of their mercy and the holy name more and more.

We chanted another bhajan, and then while reading from Navadvipa Dhama Mahatmya about the island of Godrumadvipa, one young Gaudiya Math sannyasi came to sit with us. He listened for awhile and then welcomed us to Surabhi Kunja. He pointed to a picture of his Guru Maharaja which was hanging there on the veranda, someone who I had neither heard of nor seen before, and told us that he had been requested by him to build a temple (pointing to the temple construction). He then apologized for his having appeared before us in a gamcha, but since he had dedicated himself to fulfilling that order and even to the construction of the building itself, he was often not in his sannyasa dress.

He did not speak that much English, so through Thakur Saranga Prabhu's translation he told us that he had one of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's works in handwriting and asked if we would like to see it. Naturally, we expressed our enthusiasm to take darshan of the book. He then retrieved it for us and eagerly showed us page after page.

Thakur Saranga began reading the Bengali script and we immediately recognized it as one of Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's bhajans. Needless to say, we were enlivened by the opportunity to hold, to see, and and to hear directly from this most sacred book and the sannyasi was undoubtedly enlivened to share it with us. He then asked us if we would chant the bhajan, "Sri Godruma-Candra-Bhajana-Upadesa. For some reason, I did not immediately recognize the name of the bhajan and therefore asked if he would chant it for us. But Madana-mohana reminded me that it was the bhajan which began with the words "yadi te hari-pada-saroja-sudha". Immediately recognizing the words, I said, "I think I can chant if you like.", and he asked me to please do so. With the permission of my godbrothers, we then chanted that bhajan and then Dhanurdhara Maharaja read the translation so deeply absorbed in his reading that I felt as if I was present in Godruma's forest bowers eagerly waiting for Lord Gaura to bestow His mercy upon us.

We then decided that, considering our schedule, it was probably best to move on to Nrsimhapalli, which was to be our last stop before returning to Mayapura. However, our hosts would not allow us to leave without honoring prasadam first. They had prepared a little something for us while we were chanting the last bhajan. Fortunately, it was not a large quantity. We honored as much as we could, thanked them for their hospitality, and then parted with a warm embrace from the sannyasi. He seemed genuinely grateful that we had come. He thanked us several times for our association and begged us to please come again as soon as possible.

When we arrived at Nrsimhapalli, there were busloads of pilgrims mulling around and a large group of them were sitting in front of the Deity getting mahaprasadam from the pujari. The mood there was quite different from that which we had experienced on parikrama thus far. Everywhere else we had visited was relatively quiet and thus conducive for hearing and chanting. Nonethless, we still decided to at least take darshan of the self-manifested deity of Lord Nrsimha.

Fortunately, the crowd allowed us to gain access to the altar for darshan. After darshan, we then decided to sit on the mandap for a short kirtan for Lord Nrsimhadeva, which was led by Acyuta Priya Prabhu. Devamrita Maharaja then very feelingly read Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's prayers to Lord Nrsimhadeva from Navadvipa Dhama Mahatmya. We then left, but discussed the possibility of visiting there once again since we had to drive past it at least once more when we would go to Ambika Kalna.

data.title: A Kirtan for Lila Smarana devi dasi
data.blurb: Madana-mohana dasa posted last night's kirtan on Youtube and wrote that it was dedicated to Lila Smarana devi dasi. I thought I should elaborate to avoid confusion.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Madana-mohana dasa posted last night's kirtan on Youtube and wrote that it was dedicated to Lila Smarana devi dasi. I thought I should elaborate to avoid confusion.

Yesterday we were told that Lila Smarana devi dasi was rushed to the hospital on November 1st. She collapsed from inability to breathe. She was placed into the Intensive Care Unit and to date she remains there requiring oxygen to breathe. All that is known right now is that they are running a series of tests on her heart.

For those of you who know Lila Smarana devi dasi, please say a prayer for her well-being. For those of you who don't know her, she joined Krsna consciousness in Ukraine back in the late 1980's and served for more than ten years as the senior leader of the women's asrama for so many devotees, first in Odessa and later in Kiev. A little over ten years ago, she married my godbrother, Ganesa Prabhu, and since that time took responsibility for publication of my books in English. Please remember her in your prayers.

Hare Krsna

On the second day of parikrama we proceeded directly to Sri Caitanya Math. This temple was Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's headquarters for his preaching througout India. He called it Vrndavana Pattan, which means the place where the Vrndavana forest is manifest. There, just behind the temple, you can find Radha Kunda, Syama Kunda, and off to the side, just next to Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji's samadhi, you will also find Govardhana Hill.

We wanted to start first at Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's samadhi, since that is the first place you come upon when entering the main gate. We therefore carried our paraphernalia, (mats, cushions, instruments, etc.) to the samadhi. As we were about to place everything on the floor, we noticed that one of the brahmacaris was meticulously washing the floor. He very respectfully asked if we could wait fifteen minutes before setting everything down until he finished and suggested we first take darshan of the presiding Deities, Sri Sri Radha Gandharvika-Giridhari in the temple nearby. He then thoughtfully cleaned a spot where we could keep everything until we returned.

When we arrived in the temple, the Deity doors were still closed but we were told that the darshan would be in ten minutes. We therefore sat down, waited, and discussed philosophy until the Deity doors opened. At 7:45 the doors opened and we were all overwhelmed by the beautiful presence of Their Lordships. I turned to the devotees and said, "Let's have a kirtan for Them!", and asked Dhanurdhara Maharaja if he would chant Yasomati-Nandana. He resisted, but with a little prodding he finally agreed. Everyone enthusiastically chanted with arms outstretched. I accompanied him with the mrdanga. After kirtan, we took carinamrita and then returned to Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's samadhi.

There we started first with a kirtan and then we read for at least an hour about Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's childhood and early years, leading up to the time he spent in Mayapura. We also read Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's instructions to Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur about the importance of Sri Mayapura Dhama. Before Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur departed he instructed Srila Bhaktisiddhanta in this letter to start circumambulation of Sridhama Mayapura as soon as possible and to make sure that service to Mayapura will become permanent. So many other instructions were given to him in this one letter and we could immediately appreciate how Srila Bhaktisiddhanta took these instructions upon his head as a major part of his life's work in service to the divine instructions of his father and preceptor, Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur.

After a couple of hours at Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Thakur's samadhi we proceeded to Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji Maharaja's samadhi, but since Govardhana Hill was so nearby we decided to first circumambulate Govardhana Hill three times before entering the samadhi. There we read for about an hour about Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji's life from the book entitled, "Babaji Maharaja". One pastime which stands out in my mind took place in Sridhama Mayapura, while Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur was living at the Yoga Pitha.

Once Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji Maharaja arrived alone at the Yoga Pitha in the early morning hours. Later that day, knowing that Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji Maharaja was externally completely blind, Srila Bhaktisiddhanta asked Babaji Maharaja what time he had arrived. Babaji Maharaja told him that he had arrived about two in the morning. Srila Bhaktisiddhanta was naturally surprised and further inquired how it was possible for him to come alone, especially since there were no footpaths from Kuliya to Mayapura and there were no landing places for boats along the Ganga. He was wondering who would bring him such a long distance by the hand and then upon arriving, suddenly leave in the middle of the night. Babaji Maharaja nonchalantly responded, "Someone showed me the proper way." Again Srila Bhaktisiddhanta submitted his question and Srila Gaura Kisora dasa Babaji in an amused manner replied, "Someone took me across the river." Srila Bhaktisiddhanta could then understand that the mysterious person could have been no one other than Krsna Himself.

We chanted another bhajan, and then proceeded to the home of Murari Gupta which was down the path through the field behind Sri Caitanya Math. Upon arriving in the temple, there was an elderly pujari dressed in saffron sitting in front of the altar stringing garlands for the Deity. He seemed so content in his service, but as soon as I approached the altar, he immediately got down on the floor in front of me and offered his obeisances at my feet. I stood in front of him with my hands folded as I oftentimes do, especially since it is not easy for me to repeatedly get down because of my bad back. My back was also especially hurting from having sat so long on the floor that morning. I therefore respectfully offered my pranamas to him, he returned to his Deity seva and I continued to circumambulate the Deity room.

While circumambulating, I realized how foolish I was that I had not gotten down to offer my obeisances to this Vaisnava who must have been at least fifteen to twenty years senior in age to me and reminded myself that I should not be illusioned into thinking that I am a sannyasi and therefore do not need to offer my obeisances to such a senior Vaisnava. The next time I came before him, I immediately got down on the floor and offered my obeisances to him while he was sitting in front of the altar making the garland. To my dismay, he stopped his seva, got down, and immediately returned his obeisances to me, thus teaching me an very important lesson in humility. In my heart I felt very grateful to this Vaisnava for, knowingly or unknowingly, teaching me such an important lesson about humility.

I couldn't explain it but there was something very special about the atmosphere there. I expressed this to the others and Devamrita Maharaja reminded me that I was saying that about every place we had been so far. I thought about it and within I had to agree that I probably was saying that about every place because that's just how I was feeling. In my heart I was starting to feel how all of Sri Mayapura Dhama is such a special place filled with so much mercy. I was then reminded about Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur's words in "Sri Navadvipa Dhama Mahatmya" while describing the glories of Sri Navadvipa Dhama.

"As long as bodily consciousness is not given up and humility does not awaken within, one cannot obtain the treasure of Sri Caitanya and Sri Nityananda's mercy, no matter what efforts one make, even if he be Siva or Brahma."

In my heart, I once again thanked the pujari who was teaching me by his example the importance of humility and realized just how much more I had to learn about this most essential quality if I really wanted to experience the mercy of Sri Mayapura Dhama.

We then proceeded to chant, and began reading so many wonderful pastimes from Caitanya Bhagavata and Caitanya Caritamrita about Murari Gupta's love for Lord Caitanya. We read for at least another hour, in a very animated way, the wonderful pastimes which took place in the home of Murari Gupta.

At the end of our reading there was an arati, so we had a very enthusiastic kirtan while the pujari offered arati to the Sita, Rama, Laksmana and Hanuman. After he blew the conchshell, he turned to me and said something to me in Bengali. I sensed that he wanted me to say the prema-dhvani, but being unsure I just looked at him, and then to Thakur Saranga dasa who spoke Bengali. Unfortunately, I wasn't fast enough and seeing my predicament, he starting reciting the prema-dhvani prayers which probably lasted for at least five to seven minutes. We all looked at each other, marveling the intensity and enthusiasm this pujari displayed for glorifying the the Lord, the Vaisnavas and all the sacred places of pilgrimage. We then took carinamrita, and some mahaprasadam which the pujari distributed to all of us and realized that it was already time to return for the day. What a wonderful day!

Hare Krsna

For video clips of Day Two, click here

To be continued…

data.title: Parikrama - Day One
data.blurb: Madana-mohana dasa took many video clips of our daily parikramas. They are clips and are not full-length recordings of the each day's parikrama. Still, they consist of bhajans, kirtans, parts of our readings, and some deity darshans.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Madana-mohana dasa took many video clips of our daily parikramas. They are clips and are not full-length recordings of the each day's parikrama. Still, they consist of bhajans, kirtans, parts of our readings, and some deity darshans.

These clips have been put together into playlists, which include all of the clips he had taken each day. We will try to post these playlists here on the site on a daily basis and I will also try to write a few words about our parikrama for that day.

The day before our parikrama began, we all decided that we would leave at 7:00 AM every morning and that we would return by 1:00 PM. By leaving at 7:00, it also enabled me to take care of all my newly prescribed morning rituals which consist of mixing and taking medicines and heating and applying different medicinal oils. I was also able to complete sixteen rounds before departing.

This schedule gave us six solid hours for parikrama each day. Of course, some days were spent driving significant distances on roads which had been destroyed by the heavy rains during the rainy season. Still, our unanimous conclusion was that even the six-hour drive to Katwa and back (we returned at 4:00 PM on that day), traveling on a fifteen to twenty kilometer patch of the worst road I have ever ridden on in my life, was worth it. Every tirtha we visited provided us the most wonderful venue for hearing, chanting, praying to, and remembering the Lord and His eternal associates.

On the first day of our parikrama we left promptly at 7:00 and walked together to the Yoga Pitha. Upon entering we discovered that there was another group of devotees in the kirtan hall, so we decided to have our kirtan and reading at the small temple where Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur is worshiped, just to the right upon entering the compound.

Each day I selected relevant pastimes for the tirthas we visited, mostly from Caitanya Bhagavata and Caitanya Caritamrita. At Yoga Pitha we read about the appearance of the Lord's associates, the reason why they appeared in places other than in Navadvipa, and how they all gathered in Navadvipa to assist the Lord in His divine pastimes. We also read some of the Lord's childhood pastimes. All three of us, Dhanurdhara Maharaja, Devamrita Maharaja, and I, took turns reading from the selected references. Between readings we chanted bhajans, and read the translations.

After reading and chanting for at least two hours, we moved on to Srivas Angan, where we chanted and had wonderfully animated and exceptionally absorbing readings from Caitanya Bhagavata, describing the kirtans which the Lord conducted in Srivasa Pandita's home and especially the maha-prakasa lila, or the sata-prahariya bhava—the Lord's ecstasy of twenty-one hours. After spending at least another two hours hearing and chanting in Srivasa Angan, and especially after the last kirtan we had in that most auspicious place which is considered the rasa-sthali of Navadvipa, I was already convinced that this was going to be a very memorable nine days for me.

From Srivasa Angana we walked down the path to Advaita Acarya's house. We chanted a bhajan and then read from Caitanya Bhagavata about the pastimes performed there. We returned to our residence by 1:00, showered, and then Dhanurdhara Maharaja, Devamrita Maharaja, and I took our lunches together until approximately 3:00 PM. We left 3:00 – 7:30 PM open as free time for reading, preparing our readings for the next day, and resting. We then gathered again in the evening for Damodarastakam and more readings.

Before we began parikrama, we had decided that only English would be spoken throughout the whole nine days. This means that translations were not allowed at any time in order to keep the readings and the mood flowing. This created the most conducive environment for becoming absorbed—especially for those of us whose first language is English. In the evenings, anyone who wanted to listen to the Lord's pastimes in English was welcome.

Here is the link to the videos of the Day One.

To be continued…

We left 3:00 – 7:30 PM open as free time for reading, preparing our readings for the next day, and resting. We then gathered again in the evening for Damodarastakam and more readings.

Before we began parikrama, we had decided that only English would be spoken throughout the whole nine days. This means that translations were not allowed at any time in order to keep the readings and the mood flowing. This created the most conducive environment for becoming absorbed—especially for those of us whose first language is English. In the evenings, anyone who wanted to listen to the Lord's pastimes in English was welcome.

Here is the link to the videos of the Day One.

To be continued…

data.title: Navadvipa Mandala Parikrama
data.blurb: I've been in Mayapura since October 20th. Today Devamrita Swami and I just completed our nine-day Navadvipa Mandala Parikrama. Dhanurdhara Maharaja was also with us for the first four days.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I've been in Mayapura since October 20th. Today Devamrita Swami and I just completed our nine-day Navadvipa Mandala Parikrama. Dhanurdhara Maharaja was also with us for the first four days.

Devamrita Maharaja and I were supposed to travel together for two weeks in Ukraine just after the Bhakti Sangama Festival. But since my health did not allow it and since I had to spend those same weeks in the South Indian clinic, we decided that we would compensate for the time we were unable to travel together by hearing and chanting in Mayapura instead.

Acyuta Priya and Madana-mohana also took part in our parikrama and an additional four devotees came to assist with photographing, driving, playing mrdanga, and setting up each day for the many hours we would spend at each place we visited. Needless to say, for me it was one of the most wonderful experiences I've had in decades.

There is more I could write about the past nine days. But, for now, I just wanted to explain why I've not had any time to post blogs since October 18th. Soon Madana-mohana will be posting videos and the many photographs taken on our parikrama. In fact, one slideshow done by our expert photographter, Thakur Saranga dasa, should be posted within the next day or so. As time permits, I also hope to be able to resume posting some blogs.

My plan is to continue to focus on my health for the next ten days I'll be here in Mayapura. When I left the clinic, I was given approximately fifteen kilograms of medications which I'm supposed continue taking at regular intervals, nine different times during the day. I also have to resume my back exercises because I was not allowed to exercise during my entire stay in the clinic.

I have not given any classes in Mayapura and neither will I be giving any classes between now and my departure. After Mayapura, I will follow through with my previously planned itinerary for the rest of the year.

Hare Krsna

data.title: The Meaning of "Tireless Endeavors"
data.blurb: The intensive part of the treatment finished on October 14th. I was given permission to go outside for a short walk on the 14th evening. October 15th was the first day I was allowed to leave the room without restriction.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The intensive part of the treatment finished on October 14th. I was given permission to go outside for a short walk on the 14th evening. October 15th was the first day I was allowed to leave the room without restriction.

However, now that the intensive treatments are over, practically all day long there are new treatments and medicines I've needed to take. All together these have taken up a significant amount of my time. I'm reading. But I've not had the same opportunity for reading which was available to me during the previous eleven days. I've also been spending every evening with Sivarama Maharaja for kirtan and katha. Hence, I've had less time to write blogs.

Today, instead of writing about my readings, I decided to answer one of the questions given to me during one of our sessions at Bhakti Sangama Festival. Here is the question:

"Do I understand it correctly, that unless and until we work in devotional service until we almost drop dead, we cannot develop love for Krsna?"

Although I'm sure that not everyone drew this conclusion from the example I gave on the second day of my seminar, when I read this question I became concerned that possibly other devotees were thinking this way. For this reason, I've chosen this question to answer.

I suspect that this question was asked because of the story I told about Mother Yasoda's "exhausting" efforts to tie up her mischievous son, Krsna. During the course of my talk, I had paraphrased Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur's commentary, part of which is as follows:

"Krsna’s mercy, which reigns as the king of all His potencies and illuminates all others, melts the heart of the Lord and turns it into butter. The appearance of Krsna’s mercy made His satya sankalpa and vibhuti saktis immediately disappear. The distance of two fingers was filled by the devotee’s effort and hard work (parisramam) and the Lord’s causeless mercy (krsna krpa). The bhakta-nistha (firm faith of the devotee) seen in his tireless endeavors to serve and worship the Lord, and the sva-nistha (the steady quality in the Lord), which brings forth His mercy upon seeing the devotee’s effort and fatigue caused Krsna to be bound."

Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur is helping us understand the importance of making our own efforts to please Krsna. A devotee always endeavors for Krsna's mercy and knows that without His mercy, which manifests both from Krsna and through His devotees, he cannot achieve pure love for Krsna. We can (and in fact, should) expect Krsna's mercy, but whenever He wishes to give it. However, without making efforts to please Krsna, it would be an illusion to think that love of God will manifest in our hearts automatically without them.

The "tireless endeavors" to serve the Lord, however, does not refer to the physical efforts made in service to Krsna. It may, but it really depends on what the Lord, or His devotee, wants from us for the Lord's pleasure.

We should therefore not be misled into thinking that Mother Yasoda's "tireless endeavors" were something that were physically exhausting for her. She is not "physically exhausted" by anything. She is ecstatically engaged, one hundred percent, on the spiritual platform of unalloyed love for Krsna and Krsna is eternally pleased by this unalloyed love of His mother. In one sense, therefore, Krsna already has everything He wants from Yasoda. He has a mother whose only desire is to serve Krsna exclusively as her son.

In our case, however, we have to endeavor to achieve Krsna's pleasure because it's only unalloyed love which fully pleases Him. And even those who have unalloyed love, never think that they have it. Krsna's pleasure is the ultimate goal of our sadhana and not the goal of our physical work. Our tireless endeavors and the fatigue which manifests from such endeavors, come from our efforts to please Krsna by constantly remembering Him, by worshiping Him, and by offering our prayers unto Him. While executing our service, Krsna knows when we are thinking only of His pleasure and He is also very inclined to help us in our endeavors when He sees how determined we are to please Him.

Hare Krsna

Sivarama Maharaja arrived here at the clinic on the 10th evening, along with Syama Bihari dasa and Tarakanath dasa. It was he who learned about this clinic from a disciple in England. One of the local leaders also highly recommended this clinic to him. Maharaja then requested his disciple to reserve a place for him and these two other devotees.

When I was with Sivarama Maharaja in New Vraja Dhama last month he suggested that I try this clinic too. Considering all the medication I had been put on in Almaty, I thought it was a good idea but I had doubts about being able to come here so soon. He then asked his disciple if she could secure a reservation for me immediately after the Bhakti Sangama Festival. Within two to three days the reservation was secured.

As I mentioned before, this clinic usually has a waiting list of six months to one year. I therefore accepted the prompt response to her request as Krsna's arrangement. So now, also by Krsna's grace, Sivarama Maharaja and I will be here together for some time.

When I first mentioned to Maharaja that I would be confined to my room for eleven days, he subsequently referred to this part of the treatment as "house arrest." So considering that I'm still under house arrest and knowing that it's not easy to be confined in a room under these conditions, Maharaja has kindly been coming to see me every evening since his arrival. It just so happens that he brought a small harmonium with him from Delhi. So after we spend a little time talking together, Syama Bihari and Tarakanath come over and we all have kirtan before our evening medicine and meal.

As usual, Madana-mohana complies with requests from devotees for videos. He therefore took out his iphone and shot some during our kirtan here in my room. He then posted a couple on Youtube, so I imagine they will be available soon here on the site.

I didn't mention it before but another restriction imposed upon me during the intensive part of the treatment is that I was not allowed to shave. So if my face appears a little scruffy, it's only because I've been following doctor's orders.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Vaisnava is also a poet ("kavi")
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I was informed that there were some questions posted in the comments section of my previous blog. I'll say something in response to them here. But before I do that, I just wanted to remind everyone that this is not an interactive website. Although it would be nice, I am not able to open new forums for dialogue beyond those which already exist—and even those I cannot keep up with.

What was it that I found so wonderful in Srila Prabhupada's rendition of the five verses Lord Caitanya spoke to Srila Rupa Goswami? The answer is as follows…

One of the twenty-six qualities of a Vaisnava is that he is poetic. Srila Prabhupada told us that when he submitted his first speech in English to the "Harmonist", along with the English poem he had written as a Vyasa Puja offering to Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur, Prabhupada was immediately recognized by his godbrothers as a competent writer in English and many of them even began calling him "kavi", or "learned poet."

Also, in "Caitanya-caritamrta", Antya 1, 195-196, in his conversation with Lord Caitanya, Ramananda Raya praises the wonderful poetic description written by Srila Rupa Gosvami as follows:

"What is the use of a bowman's arrow or a poet's poetry if they penetrate the heart but do not cause the head to spin? Without Your mercy such poetic expressions would be impossible for an ordinary living being to write."

Simply put, I was overwhelmed by Srila Prabhupada's poetry-like rendition of the following five verses he had translated differently in "Sri Caitanya Caritamrta."

TEXT 151
TRANSLATION
"According to their karma, all living entities are wandering throughout the entire universe. Some of them are being elevated to the upper planetary systems, and some are going down into the lower planetary systems. Out of many millions of wandering living entities, one who is very fortunate gets an opportunity to associate with a bona fide spiritual master by the grace of Krsna. By the mercy of both Krsna and the spiritual master, such a person receives the seed of the creeper of devotional service.

TEXT 152
TRANSLATION
"When a person receives the seed of devotional service, he should take care of it by becoming a gardener and sowing the seed in his heart. If he waters the seed gradually by the process of sravana and kirtana [hearing and chanting], the seed will begin to sprout.

TEXT 153
TRANSLATION
"As one waters the bhakti-lata-bija, the seed sprouts, and the creeper gradually grows to the point where it penetrates the walls of this universe and goes beyond the Viraja River, lying between the spiritual world and the material world. It attains brahma-loka, the Brahman effulgence, and penetrating through that stratum, it reaches the spiritual sky and the spiritual planet Goloka Vrndavana.

TEXT 154
TRANSLATION
"Being situated in one's heart and being watered by sravana-kirtana, the bhakti creeper grows more and more. In this way it attains the shelter of the desire tree of the lotus feet of Krsna, who is eternally situated in the planet known as Goloka Vrndavana, in the topmost region of the spiritual sky.

TEXT 155
TRANSLATION
"The creeper greatly expands in the Goloka Vrndavana planet, and there it produces the fruit of love for Krsna. Although remaining in the material world, the gardener regularly sprinkles the creeper with the water of hearing and chanting.

A poet, or “kavi”, is allowed to take license with words so they “penetrate the heart” and “make the head spin”. As a kavi par excellence, Srila Prabhupada would often skillfully render his verse translations with words not directly found in the Sanskrit or Bengali, revealing their deeper meaning, beauty, and relevance. But I found that, in rendering the above Caitanya-caritamrta passage in his purport to SB 3.2.6, which I posted in my previous blog, Srila Prabhupada's fulfillment of the quality of "kavi" is simply breathtaking!

Hare Krsna

Body_raw.value:
Today I was reading this wonderful purport in Srimad Bhagavatam 3.2.6. Within the context of the purport, Srila Prabhupada rendered Verses 151 – 155, Caitanya Caritamrita, Madhya Lila, Chapter 19, in the most beautiful way. These were Lord Caitanya's instructions to Srila Rupa Goswami which include the often quoted verse:

brahmanda bhramite kona bhagyavan jiva
guru-krsna-prasade paya bhakti-lata-bija

These verses were cited in reference to Uddhava. When Vidura met Uddhava, he inquired about Lord Krsna. Upon hearing his inquiries, Uddhava immediately remembered the Lord, and became so absorbed in transcendental ecstasy that he forgot all about the external world.

In his purport, Srila Prabhupada writes, " Even though a pure devotee is present on this mortal planet, he is here in relation to the Lord for engagement in transcendental loving service, and not for any material cause. A living entity can live either on the material plane or in the transcendental abode of the Lord, in accordance with his existential condition. The conditional changes of the living entity are explained in the Caitanya-caritamrta in the instructions given to Srila Rupa Gosvami by Lord Sri Caitanya:"

And then here is Srila Prabhupada's rendering of Verses 151 – 155:

"The living entities all over the universes are enjoying the effects of the respective fruitive results of their own work, life after life. Out of all of them, some may be influenced by the association of pure devotees and thus get the chance to execute devotional service by attainment of taste. This taste is the seed of devotional service, and one who is fortunate enough to have received such a seed is advised to sow it in the core of his heart. As one cultivates a seed by pouring water to fructify it, the seed of devotional service sown in the heart of the devotee may be cultured by pouring water in the form of hearing and chanting of the holy name and pastimes of the Lord. The creeper of devotional service, so nourished, gradually grows, and the devotee, acting as a gardener, goes on pouring the water of constant hearing and chanting. The creeper of devotional service gradually grows so high that it passes through the entire material universe and enters into the spiritual sky, growing still higher and higher until it reaches the planet Goloka Vrndavana. The devotee-gardener is in touch with the abode of the Lord even from the material plane by dint of performing devotional service to the Lord simply by hearing and chanting. As a creeper takes shelter of another, stronger tree, similarly the creeper of devotional service, nourished by the devotee, takes shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord and thus becomes fixed. When the creeper is fixed, then the fruit of the creeper comes into existence, and the gardener who nourished it is able to enjoy this fruit of love, and his life becomes successful."

Wonderful! Simply wonderful!

Hare Krsna

A living entity can live either on the material plane or in the transcendental abode of the Lord, in accordance with his existential condition. The conditional changes of the living entity are explained in the Caitanya-caritamrta in the instructions given to Srila Rupa Gosvami by Lord Sri Caitanya:"

And then here is Srila Prabhupada's rendering of Verses 151 – 155:

"The living entities all over the universes are enjoying the effects of the respective fruitive results of their own work, life after life. Out of all of them, some may be influenced by the association of pure devotees and thus get the chance to execute devotional service by attainment of taste. This taste is the seed of devotional service, and one who is fortunate enough to have received such a seed is advised to sow it in the core of his heart. As one cultivates a seed by pouring water to fructify it, the seed of devotional service sown in the heart of the devotee may be cultured by pouring water in the form of hearing and chanting of the holy name and pastimes of the Lord. The creeper of devotional service, so nourished, gradually grows, and the devotee, acting as a gardener, goes on pouring the water of constant hearing and chanting. The creeper of devotional service gradually grows so high that it passes through the entire material universe and enters into the spiritual sky, growing still higher and higher until it reaches the planet Goloka Vrndavana. The devotee-gardener is in touch with the abode of the Lord even from the material plane by dint of performing devotional service to the Lord simply by hearing and chanting. As a creeper takes shelter of another, stronger tree, similarly the creeper of devotional service, nourished by the devotee, takes shelter of the lotus feet of the Lord and thus becomes fixed. When the creeper is fixed, then the fruit of the creeper comes into existence, and the gardener who nourished it is able to enjoy this fruit of love, and his life becomes successful."

Wonderful! Simply wonderful!

Hare Krsna

Along with my readings every day, I also listen to Srila Prabhupada's lectures three times a day while I honor some simple prasadam. Although I oftentimes refer to Srila Prabhupada's lectures from the prayers of Queen Kunti as some of my most favorite lectures, I'm also very attracted to the lectures Srila Prabhupada gave in New York in 1966 on the Caitanya Caritamrita. So, one by one, I've been once again listening to them every day.

When I listen to these lectures I marvel upon Srila Prabhupada's quality of compassion. None of Srila Prabhupada's books were published in November/December 1966 other than the few Srimad Bhagavatams he brought with him from India. Srila Prabhupada had to give everything to his audience in his talks.

It's simply wonderful to hear how Srila Prabhupada introduces bhakti to his fledgling devotees. Not only am I enamored by the content of Srila Prabhupada's talks, but also by the intonation of his voice. His voice is like that of a loving and caring father, carefully holding his children's hands as he encourages them to learn how to walk.

Here is something which caught my attention in yesterday's lecture:

"Always remember that this Krsna consciousness is a sort of declaration of war with this illusory material nature. So there is war. She will always try to get you fall down. Daivi hy esa guna-mayi mama maya duratyaya [Bg. 7.14]. It is very strong, powerful. How you can save yourself? Mam eva ye prapadyante mayam etam taranti te. If you persistently simply adhere to the devotional service of Krsna, there will be no more strength of this illusory nature to drag you. No more. There will be no more power to get you into this province of sense gratification. Material nature means the jurisdiction of sense gratification. That's all. Simply people are engaged by sense gratification like cats and dogs. That's all. This is material atmosphere. And in the spiritual atmosphere there is no sense gratification; there is only activity for satisfying the Supreme, Krsna. That is the difference.

"So if you adherently be always engaged in some sort of service, twenty-four hours in the service of the Supreme Lord Krsna in Krsna consciousness, there is no power in the world who can drag you into this sense gratification province. You at once become nirguna. This is the process. So we have to stick to this principle: "How I can serve Krsna always, always?" Iha yasya harer dasye. If you cannot do, if you simply think, "How can I do? How can I do? How can I do?" simply this, if you practically cannot do, but if you simply think that "How can I do?" oh, then also you become liberated. Then also you become liberated. And what to speak of when we actually serve. This is such a nice thing, Krsna consciousness. So if you want to save yourself from this material turmoil, then always stick to this Krsna consciousness persistently. Yes." [Sri Caitanya-caritamrta, Madhya-lila 20.313-317 -- New York, December 21, 1966]

Hare Krsna

data.title: A few words from my room in the clinic
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The intense part of my treatment began yesterday, October 4th. All patients undergoing this part of the treatment are recommended to avoid working on the computer and watching television as much as possible. Of course, it's probably been about forty-two years since I spent much time watching television, but unfortunately, I can't say the same for the computer. I'm therefore going to restrict my time on the computer as much as possible and utilize this time for reading and chanting, especially since I'm not allowed to leave my room for the next eleven days. I'm also not allowed to sleep at all during the day.

I'm currently reading Srimad Bhagavatam, Third Canto with commentaries by Srila Prabhupada and Srila Visvanath Cakravarti Thakur alongside one another. I have been doing this from time and time and find it so wonderful to see how chaste Srila Prabhupada is to the commentaries of our previous acaryas and, at the same time, how relevant he makes them for his Western disciples.

This morning I was reminded of a wonderful commentary Srila Prabhupada wrote to the verse 3.1.16. I used to refer to this commentary often in which Srila Prabhupada explains how Maya sometimes acts both internally for Krsna's devotees and externally for His nondevotees. Srila Prabhupada writes:

"In spite of being very strongly insulted by Duryodhana's words, Vidura could see that Duryodhana, under the influence of maya, the external energy, was making progress on the path toward his own ruination. He therefore considered the acts of the external energy to be supreme, yet he also saw how the internal energy of the Lord helped him in that particular situation. A devotee is always in a renounced temperament because the worldly attractions can never satisfy him. Vidura was never attracted by the royal palace of his brother. He was always ready to leave the place and devote himself completely to the transcendental loving service of the Lord. Now he got the opportunity by the grace of Duryodhana, and instead of being sorry at the strong words of insult, he thanked him from within because it gave him the chance to live alone in a holy place and fully engage in the devotional service of the Lord."

I'm also reading "Mathura Meets Vrndavana" once again and naturally I'm relishing Srila Gour Govinda Maharaja's deep revelations of kevala bhakti. And I've also resumed reading "Nava Vraja Mahima" by Sivarama Maharaja. This book has been published in nine volumes and contains more than four thousand pages, so I don't expect to complete it while I'm here. Still, having read some of the manuscripts which Sivarama Maharaja gave me before Nava Vraja Mahima's publication, I am eager to read the final offering to the lotus feet of Sri Sri Radha Syamasundara.

Hare Krsna

Body_raw.value:
As I mentioned in my earlier blog, Sacinananda Maharaja created several ficticious personalities in his book to represent different sides of the individual that surface during his or her spiritual journey. Sanatana Baba is our deeply spiritual self who genuinely seeks the truth and Visvambhara represents our doubting side.

The last time we heard from Sanatana Baba (who was speaking to Visvambhara) he explained the need to become silent to the outside and inside world in order to hear the mantra properly. He continues:

"I feel that to chant the holy name is to pass from a state where mercy is only secretly present in our heart to the state of an inner awareness of the presence and the voice of the Lord – not as a passive theory, but as an active divine revelation.

But how are we to start? When the door to the world closes behind us, how do we move forward to enter his living world? How do we move from merely repeating words to truly entering a flow of divine communication? My answer starts here: first establish a connection! Chanting requires building up, as in any relationship. Of course relationships of love are not built from step-by-step rules, but there are always a few principles.

The first principle is to take on a cooperative mood, and express that mood by making serious efforts to chant with faith. This will attract the beautiful name to hear your chanting! The next principle is the effort to at least be attentive. At the very least, try to chant without external  interruptions. Attach your mind to the Divine names, one by one as they move over your tongue. To be attentive, you must be present – 'in the here and now' – relentlessly. Practice it! Bind your mind to the "naked now" – weld it to the name, which is right now! Seize the present name. To be attentive and present you must be patient. Endure your inner dryness that always pushes your thoughts into seeking relief in the "oasis" of past or future possibilities. There is no past or future; they are only figments of the mind.

Krsna will be watching all this from a hidden place. He is especially interested to see where you will run for relief in those dull moments of dryness. Convince him that you know that only he can truly relieve you, and then he will come out of hiding. He will respond to you in the heart when the time is right. Meanwhile, be happy to stay in his presence." [End of quote]

Hare Krsna

data.title: More about Chanting the Holy Name
data.blurb: As I mentioned in yesterday's blog, I had written to Sacinandana Maharaja earlier that morning about my impressions from reading his book. Today, he had wrote back and had the following to say in response to my letter:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As I mentioned in yesterday's blog, I had written to Sacinandana Maharaja earlier that morning about my impressions from reading his book. Today, he had wrote back and had the following to say in response to my letter:

"Your well thought through class at the German Kirtan Mela about mercy has really inspired me in a very deep way. I have just done rereading of Ajamil's story, together with the purports of Srila Visvanatha Cakravarti Thakura. I really think that the prema-dharma of Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu is one which is pervaded and breathing with mercy. When Ajamil wakes up from his trance-like state where he saw the Visnudutas arguing to the Yamadutas that they could not take him on the strength of his chanting one Name, I thought very much that we have been given the Holy Names by the mercy of Srila Prabhupada and Sri Caitanya Mahaprabhu and are therefore also in the supremely fortunate position where we can expect mercy. Srila Visvanatha Cakravarti Thakura has this to say:

"Ajamila chanted without faith - because he was dying.
What will happen to someone who chants with faith?
Ajamila chanted while dying.
What will happen to someone who chants while living?
Ajamila chanted to indicate his son.
What will happen to someone who chants to indicate the Lord?
Ajamila was most sinful.
What will happen if a sinless person chants?"
(Sarartha Darsini, 6.2.49, commentary)" [End of quote]

Such wonderful, encouraging words to strengthen our hope!

More to come soon from my readings in "Broken Names"…

Hare Krsna
