data.title: "Broken Names"
data.blurb: When I was at the German Kirtan Mela this year, I had the opportunity to spend some quality time with my godbrother, Sacinandana Swami. We met at least twice and spoke at length about pure devotional service.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
When I was at the German Kirtan Mela this year, I had the opportunity to spend some quality time with my godbrother, Sacinandana Swami. We met at least twice and spoke at length about pure devotional service.

Before I left Germany, he offered to send me his new book, entitled "Broken Names", once it was published and asked where he could send it to me. I gave him the temple address in Hungary because I knew they would hold it for me there until I arrived.

By Krsna's grace, the book did arrive before I did, but it wasn't until yesterday that I got my first opportunity to sit down and read it without any distraction. It is not a very big book—only about eighty pages.

This morning I wrote the following to Sacinandana Maharaja:

"I'm now in a South Indian clinic. I arrived just a few days ago. Yesterday, I got the first opportunity to sit down without distraction and to read "Broken Names" from cover to cover. What can I say? Simply wonderful! Extremely relevant-- not only to me but I"m sure it will be to all struggling sadhakas worldwide. You've hit on a point that every sincere sadhaka must confront and deal with and Visvambhara personifies it perfectly. Although the whole book is relevant, the chapter "The Living Name" captures the essence and truly brings the reader into the realm of hope for a meeting with the "living name". This point of "hope" is something I find myself speaking about again and again to devotees. I tell them that without it, we'll never succeed. But as I mentioned in class at the German Kirtan Mela, we have every reason in creation, and more, to have it. Thank you very much for confirming this to the Visvambhara within me. You've added so much more hope to that which was already there." [End of quote]

I encourage everyone who can read and understand English to read this book. As I mentioned to Sacinandana Maharaja, it so very relevant to every sincere sadhaka.

Here is a very short excerpt from the chapter entitled "The Living Name". It is spoken by Sanatana Baba, a fictitious personality Sacinandana Maharaja used in his book to represent "our deeply spiritual self who genuinely seeks the truth."

[…] "Only the holy name can completely repair your broken faith. Broken faith means broken names. Today I will share something with you about how to chant the living names. I will speak from my own experience – not theory.

To hear the mantra properly you must first become silent to the outside and inside world. Only when the outer and inner chatter stops does the mantra speak to you. Of all things, to become silent is the hardest. By "silence" I don't just mean a temporary cessation of speech, nor even a pause between thoughts. No. Inner silence in its true sense is an attitude of attentive alertness, a type of quiet eagerness for the Lord, and above all, inner silence means listening.

Yes, inner silence is required if we wish to hear God! Let him increase his voice within the heart, and let the other voices decrease." [End of quote]

More to come…

Hare Krsna

data.title: Where I am and what I am doing
data.blurb: Now that I'm settled at my next destination, I decided to reveal where I am and why I decided to come here.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Now that I'm settled at my next destination, I decided to reveal where I am and why I decided to come here.

About two weeks ago I decided to take a treatment for several weeks in a South Indian clinic. Ordinarily an applicant has to wait at least six months before getting admission into this clinic. But through the arrangement of a few devotees who know the head doctor here, I was able to get a confirmation within just a few days. I accepted it as Krsna's arrangement and therefore immediately made plans to come just after the Bhakti Sangama Festival.

Based upon my previous health update, I believe the reason why I'm here should be obvious. I've been neglecting my health. To give a small example of this… it's been two months since I did any exercises for my back. My back is not the reason why I'm here. I know what needs to be done to take care of my back. I simply need to resume doing my exercises again every day. But other problems, such as digestion and blood pressure, are not a quick fix. Either I take heavy medications for the remaining time in this body (as I was told by the previous specialist in Almaty) or I try something more proactive like Ayurveda. So that's why I'm here.

The chief doctor of the clinic will be overseeing my case. It just so happens he was not here when I arrived, but he will be here tomorrow and will discuss all the details of my treatment with me then. Meanwhile, yesterday his assistant looked over my medical records and then met with me. He said that they will be preparing me for the treatment over the course of the next several days. But some time later this week, I should expect to be confined to my room. I believe that should give some indication of the kind of condition I should soon expect to be in. That may also give some indication of how much I will be able to share with all of you in the upcoming weeks.

Naturally there will be no audio lectures uploaded for the next several weeks. However, as time and health permits, I will write blogs, will send some realizations, and will share some excerpts from what I plan to be reading while I'm here. Also, now that I'll have some time to review some lecture transcriptions, you can also expect more of those to appear on the site too.

Hare Krsna

It just so happens he was not here when I arrived, but he will be here tomorrow and will discuss all the details of my treatment with me then. That may also give some indication of how much I will be able to share with all of you in the upcoming weeks.

Naturally there will be no audio lectures uploaded for the next several weeks. However, as time and health permits, I will write blogs, will send some realizations, and will share some excerpts from what I plan to be reading while I'm here. Also, now that I'll have some time to review some lecture transcriptions, you can also expect more of those to appear on the site too.

Hare Krsna

data.title: My Thoughts about the Bhakti Sangama Festival
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last night I left Evpatoriya very tired, but very blissful from having participated in a very wonderful and inspiring event. Each year, not only is the attendance of the Bhakti Sangama Festival increasing, but my satisfaction from the event seems to be increasing as well. As I was leaving I was thinking that Srila Prabhupada must also be satisfied, otherwise how could I experience such spiritual satisfaction?

On the last day of my presentation on the "Teachings of Queen Kunti", towards the end of the presentation, I had just enough time to read Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's quote about the purpose of festivals. For the benefit of my readers who were not present, I would like to quote the relevant part of what I read here.

"We conduct festivals in the temple to give everyone the opportunity to associate with devotees, to destroy their attachment for material life, to display compassion for all living entities, to develop a taste for chanting the holy name, and to engage in the service of Hari, guru, and the Vaisnavas. The Matha’s main purpose in holding festivals, reciting Srimad-Bhagavatam, and discussing hari-katha is to awaken the soul’s constitutional propensity to serve Krsna. If we hear hari-katha in the association of devotees, we revive awareness of our constitutional position and attain the ultimate goal of life."[Amrita Vani]

Several years ago I gave a lecture on this quote and subsequently witnessed how Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakur's words inspired so many devotees to more fully take part in the event-- not only by hearing so many discourses given by the guest speakers, but also by volunteering their services in order to facilitate the event. I am very pleased to see that this mood is not only still very much alive, but it seems to be increasing as well.

It is my hope that the devotees who were serving in this capacity also experienced great spiritual satisfaction from the services they rendered for the pleasure of the "Hari, guru and the Vaisnavas." Such satisfaction is, in itself, an indication that Srila Prabhupada is both pleased with and grateful for your service.

However, I would like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude too. I wish to thank every one of the 1,500 devotees who served in the background to make this event successful. I would also like to thank all the devotees who came for no other reason than to hear hari-katha and to congregationally chant. Without all of you, the event could never be so successful.

All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Brief Reminder about Bhakti Sangama Festival
data.blurb: This a brief reminder to everyone attending the Bhakti Sangama Festival about personal meetings.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This a brief reminder to everyone attending the Bhakti Sangama Festival about personal meetings.

As in previous years, I will only consider requests for personal meetings if the devotees requesting the meetings will make themselves available to meet on September 22nd, and according to the schedule arranged by Madana-mohana dasa. I make this same request every year, so it should not come as a surprise to anyone.

I will not accept any requests for personal meetings at any time during the entire Bhakti Sangama Festival. Please, therefore, do not even bother to approach Madana-mohana with such a request.

For those who are prepared to meet on September 22nd, please contact Madana-mohana dasa in Evpatoriya and not before. Please give your name, the time of your departure from Evpatoriya, and the reason why the meeting is being requested.

Additionally, please book your departure from Evpatoriya for no earlier than the evening of September 22nd. If everyone books their departure for late morning on September 22nd, then obviously there will not be sufficient time to meet with everyone.

If you know somebody who requires this information, please pass it on.

Thank you very much.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Update September 22 - October 10
data.blurb: If anyone checked my calendar during the past week, you saw that my Ukraine tour from September 22 – October 10 has been cancelled. I just want to also confirm the same here. Unfortunately, I will not be able to follow through with these plans.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
If anyone checked my calendar during the past week, you saw that my Ukraine tour from September 22 – October 10 has been cancelled. I just want to also confirm the same here. Unfortunately, I will not be able to follow through with these plans.

I have a tentative plan where I will go during this time, but since every plan is tentative right now, I will not put anything on my calendar. Wherever I will go, for the most part, I will not be available for programs or for meetings.

This decision was made in consultation with several senior devotees and were based upon the results of the medical tests which were done in Almaty two weeks ago. Everything is the same now as that which was written in the last health update. The only difference is that I'm putting some of the changes in travel plans into effect sooner than early next year.

Hare Krsna

Body_raw.value:
News Briefs

Bhakta George and Dina Gauranga have teamed up and are brainstorming to create many new search features on the site. Dina Gauranga dasa sent out his first "News Brief" a few days ago, outlining a few new developments. As you will read, work is also in progress to have all audio and video files dating back to 1985 immediately available through a variety of search critera. Other enhancements are also already in place and will continue to come in the future.

Dina Gauranga will continue to send news briefs as more site developments come into place. However, for those of you who are Gmail users, Dina Gauranga has already discovered that the news briefs are going into Gmail's new "Promotions" tab. If you have not seen the news brief and you are a Gmail user, then you should check inside your "Promotions" tab in your Gmail account.

If you would like to insure that all future emails from Dina Gauranga will automatically appear under your "Primary" tab, Dina Gauranga is suggesting that you do the following very simple procedure online:

Left-click and hold on the email to drag it from the Promotions tab over to the Primary tab.
￼
Releasing the mouse drops the email into the newly selected tab. Once dropped, Gmail displays a yellow box asking if you want to make this change permanent. Click Yes to ensure that all messages with the same "from" address will appear in the Primary tab going forward.

That's all you have to do. Henceforward, all newsletters will automatically be placed in your Primary folder.

If you are not receiving the newsletter, and would like to be added to the mailing list, you can signup for the newsletter below. However, first please make sure that you are not already on the list of receivers. Check your inbox again, and if necessary, also check your spam folder in case the newsletter was somehow filtered by your email provider and placed there. In other words, please do not sign up here if you are already receiving the newsletter.

Hare Krsna

Although my Vyasa Puja offering has been posted a day early, I would like to encourage those of you who now have access to it to please remember that I have not formally offered it to Srila Prabhupada yet. Of course, in one sense it was offered the moment that it was written. Still, the usual tradition is to formally offer it to him on his appearance day, standing before him where he sits in his temples and in devotees' homes throughout the world.

I remember in earlier years when Srila Prabhupada's Vyasa Puja book would arrive in the temple, we would never even open the book until it was offered to Srila Prabhupada in the temple room on the day of his Vyasa Puja. We always considered that every offering was for his eyes and ears first. On Vyasa Puja day, before beginning to read our homages before Srila Prabhupada, one devotee would open one copy of the book for the first time while standing directly in front of Srila Prabhupada. He would then turn from one page to the next, giving Srila Prabhupada the opportunity to accept the devotees' offerings from all over the world first. We would then leave the book with Srila Prabhupada, while devotees would read their personal offering or the offerings of others to Srila Prabhupada from another copy of his Vyasa Puja book. Only after the feast would we then open our copies of Srila Prabhupada's Vyasa Puja book and individually begin to read all the offerings to him from around the world. This was always the tradition.

In the same spirit, I humbly request my readers to try their best to follow the tradition. My offering has been posted a day early in case any of you would like to read it or to have it read to Srila Prabhupada during your Vyasa Puja ceremony wherever and whenever you will be observing it. That is the main reason why I have posted it early. Please, however, try your best to refrain from personally reading it until at least the time that I have offered it to him which would be during the late morning, Almaty time, on August 29, 2013.

Thank you very much.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Vyasa Puja Offering (written on August 26, 2013)
data.blurb:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your beautiful, soft, and exceptionally cool, two lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your beautiful, soft, and exceptionally cool, two lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.

Today is your Vyasa Puja. It's the time for me to take a closer look into the heart I offered you forty years ago and to honestly assess whether or not I've lived up to your expectations. As I stand before you today, unfortunately I feel prone to lament more than anything else. I am so much in need of your mercy, but what have I done to qualify myself for all the mercy the most magnanimous Lord Nityananda has empowered you to give? Whatever I've done, there is one thing I'm sure of—it was not enough. There is so much more I know that you expect from me.

These days, the topic of mercy is something I speak about a lot. I must speak about it because I know that I'm desperately in need of it. The simple truth, known only to those who are worthy to be considered as a devotee by the Lord and His pure devotees, is that a devotee is one who is always dependent upon the mercy of the Lord and His pure devotees. But I have no right to get the Lord's mercy. I have no right to even ask the Lord for His mercy. Why should He even listen to me? Who am I? I have not bound Him within the core of my heart. I have not served Him in any way that would be pleasing to Him. I do not desperately call out to Him like a child calling for his mother. I don't remember Him in both happiness and distress. In fact, I don't remember Him in any condition of life. I haven't surrendered my life to Him—what to speak of the fact that I haven't surrendered anything at all unto Him. And worst of all is that I have absolutely no love for Him. Why should He give me even a drop of His mercy?

Yet I have the audacity to quote Lord Brahma in lectures again and again that, "if one is favored by even a slight trace of the mercy of Your [Krsna's] lotus feet, he can understand the greatness of Your [Krsna's] personality", as if I have understood something significant about Krsna's personality. The sad truth is that I know nothing about the greatness of Krsna's personality and the reason for that is so obvious. I've done absolutely nothing to qualify myself for even the slightest trace of a trace of His mercy.

Yet, somehow, by some unimaginable good fortune, created only by you, despite all my disqualifications, Krsna, the Supersoul in everyone's heart, revealed something to me forty years ago about the greatness of YOUR personality. I don't know what I did to deserve that mercy, but since it has been confirmed in sastra that it comes only by the combined mercy of Krsna and you, I can only conclude that you must have somehow included this insignicant jiva in your prayers when you asked Krsna to give out that mercy. Certainly I did not ask for it. I didn't even know it existed.

naivopayanty apacitim kavayas tavesa
brahmayusapi krtam rddha-mudah smarantah
yo 'ntar bahis tanu-bhrtam asubham vidhunvann
acarya-caittya-vapusa sva-gatim vyanakti

O my Lord! Transcendental poets and experts in spiritual science could not fully express their indebtedness to You, even if they were endowed with the prolonged lifetime of Brahma, for You appear in two features -- externally as the acarya and internally as the Supersoul -- to deliver the embodied living being by directing him how to come to You. [SB 11.29.6]

Krsna listens to you. You have everything from Krsna that I don't have. You are the true possessor of Krsna's mercy and it is you who has the power to pour upon me more and more of that same mercy which was revealed to me then. But it seems that even though forty years have passed since the time I received His mercy through you and from Him, still I have not lived up to your expectations. I need to become ever-increasingly greedy for your mercy. I know that there must be no limits to the mercy you carry, because every day of my life I see so many examples of those who have received it from you.

When I travel to so many places throughout the world, I see people come to life when they hear about you. I see devotees becoming ever-increasingly eager to glorify you and to dedicate every fiber of their existence in service to you. I see people dance in ecstasy upon receiving the holy names which you continue to deliver throughout the world and even in the most remote corners of the world. I see people, who never before knew anything about you, beg for the opportunity to read the books written by you. I see devotees shunning invitations to find mercy elsewhere due to the deepest convictions that everything needed for Krsna's mercy is coming from you. I see people's lives changing, and gradually transforming into bright-faced, enthusiastic beggars for your mercy by having associated with those who love you. I see children, who have grown up in your movement and who are making plans to spend the rest of their lives in service to you. I see devotees crying unlimited tears in gratitude for all that you've done for them. All this, and so much more is all due to your mercy. The evidence is clear. There is no limit to your mercy.

Still, somehow this unfortunate beggar, has not progressed enough in his desire to receive another installment of this inexhaustible mercy. I can only lament and maintain hope against hope that one day you may consider me a fit candidate for your unlimited mercy.

On this most auspicious day of your divine appearance in this material world, I therefore beg you to please know that I have nothing left to do before you today than to beg, plead, and if it's at all possible, even cry out for your mercy. Despite my continued lack of qualification, I know I have no other hope and yet I remain confident that there is every good reason to hope.

In the dust of your lotus feet,
Your unworthy servant,
Niranjana Swami

data.title: Health Update
data.blurb: It's been awhile since I've posted a report on my health—mainly because there have been no changes to report. For the most part, aside from an aging body which always has parts that wear down over time, I've been able to maintain a reasonable level of activity without jeopardizing my health.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
It's been awhile since I've posted a report on my health—mainly because there have been no changes to report. For the most part, aside from an aging body which always has parts that wear down over time, I've been able to maintain a reasonable level of activity without jeopardizing my health.

The reason I'm writing a report now, however, is because over the course of the last week I've received some indications that I should adjust my activities once again. I'm not sure yet how I will adjust. But I've decided that I have to adjust and I should do it soon.

I did not come to Almaty expecting to have any tests done. However, while I was in Germany some unusual pain appeared on the right side of my abdomen. Since it was not going away, I decided to have it looked into soon after I arrived here in Almaty.

Under the direction of one of the top gastroentorologists in Almaty, many tests were taken, including blood tests, a sonogram, an endoscopy and a liver scan. There are no reasons to be alarmed. No more tests are required and most of the test results were quite good—especially the blood tests. Still, the indications were that my digestive disorders need to be dealt with more attentively in order to avoid more serious consequences in the future. No surgeries are required. But I do need to follow the doctor's prescription. He also strongly recommended that qualified physicians should monitor my gastrointestinal tract organs more closely over the course of the next year.

That pretty much sums up the diagnosis without having to go into any further detail than that. I assure my readers that I've not withheld anything which would be any cause for alarm unless of course, you will be alarmed to see what adjustments I will make in the near future.

Having observed how devotees speculated in the past when it came to my health, I humbly request that if you should decide to discuss this matter with other devotees, please simply quote the facts as they have been given here. There is no need add or subtract anything else. Neither is there any need to contact Madana-mohana dasa or anyone else for more details. Other than every minute detail in the medical reports, this is pretty much the full picture.

Regarding the adjustments I will make, I have no immediate answer for that. Likely it will include a reduction of travel once again and it will also include being in a place where I can focus a little more on my health than I have in the past few years. However, for now, I will likely follow through with whatever travel plans I have made for the rest of this year.

Next year, things will be different. I will therefore make a more final decision about these adjustments by early next year. I'm aware that there are likely many devotees who would like to suggest specific places where I could stay. I've experienced this before. However, there is no need to make any suggestions. I am not planning to go anywhere other than those places where I am already visiting on a regular basis.

Hare Krsna

data.title: User List
data.blurb: I'm reposting this page as a blog. This page was posted on the previous site and the service is now available on this site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm reposting this page as a blog. This page was posted on the previous site and the service is now available on this site.

A new menu item has been added which serves the same function it did on the old site. If you click on the "User List" tab at the top of the home page, you will be taken to the list all registered users.

The benefit of this feature is that you can contact another user on the site through their contact form. If you wish to allow other users to contact you, click on "User account". Then click on the "Edit" tab under your user name. Scroll down to "Contact settings", and then click on the box next to "Personal contact form" Make sure that the box is checked.

Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on "Save". Your settings will be saved.

Once you have saved these settings, any registered user can find you on the "User list", can then click on your user name, and can then click on the "Contact" tab under your user name.

A screen will open which will allow the registered user to post a message to you. The message will be sent as an email to the email address you used to register on this site. No messages will be posted anywhere on the site. Neither will your email address become visible. You will simply receive an email from the other registered user, and you will also receive the other registered users email address to which you may then send a reply.

Hare Krsna

data.title: In Defense of the Site Administrators
data.blurb: I feel it's important for all site users to know that the decision to put the new site up now, even though there are still many details which still need to be fine tuned and/or changed, was my decision.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I feel it's important for all site users to know that the decision to put the new site up now, even though there are still many details which still need to be fine tuned and/or changed, was my decision. The administrators could have put the new site through a beta testing period and that was their original plan. But it was my decision to put the new site up now.

Please, therefore, do not post any comments assuming that the details which are not available on the site now were intentional ommissions by the admininstrators. This would only result in an unnecessary and premature judgement towards all the unbelievably hard work the administrators have been doing to upgrade this site.

You can definitely leave comments about details that are not there, which you would like to see on the new site. But, again, please don't assume that it was the plan of the administrators to not have these details there.

Many of the details which are missing will gradually be added to the new site. But it will take time to put these details in place. Please be tolerant and patient, two very important qualities which you will find spoken about in so many lectures on this site.

Meanwhile, as I have already written, the old site is completely available online (http://old.niranjanaswami.net) and it will continue to be updated with new material in tandem with the new site. If you prefer to access the old site, please feel free to go there. Everything is still there and will continue to be there until the work on the new site is complete.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Slight Itinerary Change
data.blurb: Two days ago I was informed that the dental surgery I was trying to arrange while I was in Kiev was confirmed for the morning of July 12th.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Two days ago I was informed that the dental surgery I was trying to arrange while I was in Kiev was confirmed for the morning of July 12th.

This means that, due to circumstances beyond my control, my schedule had to be adjusted in order to be able to arrive in Kiev the day before surgery.

For those of you who have been keeping track of my schedule on the calendar, please note the changes which were made in order for this to happen.

Some cities were shifted by one day, but my visit to Alchevsk was all together removed during this tour. My plan is to now include Alchevsk during a tour with Devamrita Swami in October. Please take note, therefore, that my visit to Alchevsk was not cancelled, but was only postponed until October at which time we will be visiting Donetsk and Lugansk as well.

Devotees in Kiev should also be aware that the surgeon has cautioned me that due to the nature of the surgery which he will have to perform, I should prepared to take one full week to recover. Therefore, July 12 - 19 in Kiev will be scheduled for recovery only and nothing else is being scheduled during that week.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Fileshare and the Revision of http://niranjanaswami.net
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Through the efforts of Bhakta George in Latvia and Dina Gauranga dasa in the United States, the newly revised http://niranjanaswami.net will soon be making it's appearance. I have had the opportunity to see how it will look and work, and I believe that all the registered users will be pleased with the upcoming changes both in appearance as well as it's functionality.

There is still not a fixed date of arrival. There are some final details that need to be worked on which could take a few more weeks. Then a few testers will be given the opportunity to work with it online to make sure there are no bugs. However, based upon the rate of progress, I believe I can safely say that the site will appear online very soon.

Meanwhile, Dina Gauranga dasa would like to get a sense of how popular the "Fileshare" section of the site is. Do many devotees use it? It is definitely going to be there in the next version whether the response to this question is low or high. Still, it would be helpful if devotees could comment on how much it is currently being used.

In other words, who looks for files there? How often do you look for files there? Most of the audio files dated more than twenty years back include files from the "Tape Ministry Archive" maintained by Kanjalocana dasa. There are also other many other files available for download in the Fileshare. Old video files can also be made available in Fileshare. In other words, a lot of work could be done to upgrade the Fileshare section of the site, but if it is not accessed so often or if there is little interest for using the Fileshare section in the future, it will impact on the amount of work that will go into setting it up.

Please share your comments below.

Hare Krsna

Thank you.

Body_raw.value:
We had a very nice program at the "Vaikuntha Center" in Bologna on the evening of May 11th. The event was advertised as a lecture by Niranjana Swami on the topic of "developing loving relationships in the age of conflict and hypocrisy." More than a hundred people attended, many of them were relatively new people.

I began my talk by explaining the symptoms of the current age. I then explained how conflict, one of the primary symptoms of this age, was due to selfishness, both individual and collective. In order to overcome the prevailing influence of selfishness, one needed to learn how to love and I then gave the foundational principles of loving relationships. I explained how real love could be expressed only from the spiritual platform and then briefly explained how this love was experienced by the soul and not by the body.

In the course of describing the symptoms of love, I gave the example which Srila Prabhupada often used that the closest example of love in this world was the love the mother had towards her child. For some reason, unknown to me at the time, I felt compelled to then tell about the relationship I had with my own mother and how she still accepted me even though my goals in life did not meet her expectations. I described my own disappointment with my efforts to offer my love to her from the spiritual platform and how she was uninterested in knowing anything about the existence of the soul or about our eternal relationship with Krsna, even up until her physical demise. From that point, I gave a detailed account of the events which led up to the time I was chanting for my mother while she took her last breath.

Little did I know at the time that Italians are well-known for the affection they have towards their mothers. Not only that, but I was also totally unaware that the next day, May 12th, was "Mother's Day", the day when everyone shows appreciation to their mothers. I was therefore surprised to see how the story of a son's effort to return a debt to his mother from the spiritual platform, and how the culmination of that effort took place where he chanted Krsna's name for her at the time of her death, moved many of those in attendance to tears.

Upon completing my account of my mother, I explained how the distribution of Krsna's names in this age was a true manifestation of love, since it was being offered to anyone who is simply willing to take them and they are offered without expecting anything in return.

After the lecture we had an amazing kirtan. Everyone took part so enthusiastically that I was also moved to tears to see how Lord Caitanya's mercy and kindness was so much available to everyone by Srila Prabhupada's loving grace. There was not the least bit of doubt in my mind that Srila Prabhupada appeared in this world as the personification of Lord Caitanya's love. It is only due to his mercy that I could speak on how to love in this age of conflict and hypocrisy.

The event was advertised as a lecture by Niranjana Swami on the topic of "developing loving relationships in the age of conflict and hypocrisy." More than a hundred people attended, many of them were relatively new people.

I began my talk by explaining the symptoms of the current age. I then explained how conflict, one of the primary symptoms of this age, was due to selfishness, both individual and collective. In order to overcome the prevailing influence of selfishness, one needed to learn how to love and I then gave the foundational principles of loving relationships. I explained how real love could be expressed only from the spiritual platform and then briefly explained how this love was experienced by the soul and not by the body.

In the course of describing the symptoms of love, I gave the example which Srila Prabhupada often used that the closest example of love in this world was the love the mother had towards her child. For some reason, unknown to me at the time, I felt compelled to then tell about the relationship I had with my own mother and how she still accepted me even though my goals in life did not meet her expectations. I described my own disappointment with my efforts to offer my love to her from the spiritual platform and how she was uninterested in knowing anything about the existence of the soul or about our eternal relationship with Krsna, even up until her physical demise. From that point, I gave a detailed account of the events which led up to the time I was chanting for my mother while she took her last breath.

data.title: An attempt to clear up a possible misunderstanding
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Recently I heard that the sale of the "Just Chant" CD on digital distribution sites and its promotion on this site appeared to be a contradiction to the spirit which is being promoted at the Bhakti Sangama Festival. In order to avoid any possible misunderstanding in this regard, I would like to make it more clear that it is not a contradiction at all.

Many years ago, one devotee in the United States asked if he could promote the sale of my recorded bhajans and kirtans on digital distribution sites. His reasoning was that by selling them on digital distribution sites the same bhajans and kirtans which are available for free on my fileshare site would get greater exposure to nondevotees who frequent these sites looking for music to purchase. I fully supported the idea and encouraged him to immediately do it.

Over the course of the past several years, I discovered that these CD's were, in fact, being purchased through these distribution sites. I would not say that they are very popular, but they are being purchased regularly by nondevotees and some profit from sales has been accummulated.

I could have requested that all of the profits from the sale of those CD's be donated to a temple, or even to the Bhakti Sangama Festival. However, instead I decided to use all the profits from the online sale of those CD's to produce a studio-recorded CD in a professional music studio. My reasoning for this was two-fold.

1) I was assuming that if nondevotees were going to Itunes, amazon.com, and so many other digital distribution sites to purchase recordings of my kirtans, then they would probably come back to those same sites to look for something new. And 2), the devotee who originally put the audio files on the sites had just completed his studies in audio engineering and he wanted to donate his newly acquired skills as a service for producing a professionally recorded CD.

So last year several well-known kirtaniyas were invited to take part in the studio recording. Three of the kirtaniyas grew up among ISKCON's youth. Purusartha Prabhu has also traveled extensively with the ISKCON Youth Tour in North America as a supervisor. Since they were all also donating their services to produce the CD, and since the CD was going to be sold on digital distribution sites, I proposed that we use all of the profits from the CD for the North American Youth Tour. Everyone was very happy with the proposal.

Of course, I could have proposed donating all of the profits from the CD to a temple or to the Bhakti Sangama Festival, but I saw no difference between donating to the North American Youth Tour and to the Bhakti Sangama Festival. The North American Youth Tour is also nonprofit. In other words, nobody earns any personal income from it.

Therefore the foundational principles between the Bhakti Sangama Festival and the North American Youth tour are the same. Their goals are to enhance the spiritual lives of all those who participate. No individual derives any monetary profit from any of the donations received and with them, either the facilities for the event are upgraded or those who cannot afford to participate in the event are sponsored.

I therefore encouraged devotees to purchase the "Just Chant" digital recordings in my previous blog in the same way as devotees are encouraged to donate when they register to take part in the Bhakti Sangama Festival. The only difference is that digital distribution sites don't accept donations. There has to be a fixed price.

Also, in this case, I did not make the digital recordings simultaneously available for free on my site because to do that would have been contrary to the agreement I made with all of the kirtaniyas.

In conclusion, anyone who purchases the digital recordings of the "Just Chant" EP, as well as the full CD which will hopefully come out later this year, is donating directly to the North American Youth Tour. They will be fulfilling the wishes of all the devotees who donated their services to produce the studio recording including Devananda, who also did some mixing for the CD and who also traveled with the North American Youth Tour for many years.

Hare Krsna

I'll arrive in Kiev on April 8th evening.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I wish to give notice on what my plans will be during my visit next week to Kiev.

I'll arrive in Kiev on April 8th evening.

On April 9th, the morning after my arrival I will have to spend a good part of the morning and early afternoon dealing with some visa issues and other related matters.

I plan to give Srimad Bhagavatam class on April 10th morning and on April 13th morning and the Sunday Feast lecture on April 14th. There may be a program on April 12th evening, though it won't be confirmed until later in the week. It may be a kirtan program. A kirtan program on the evening of April 13th is already confirmed.

Madana-mohana must leave Kiev on April 11th evening. This means that the only days I will have available for personal meetings will be on April 10th and April 11th. Therefore, anyone wishing to have a private meeting with me should try to meet with Madana-mohana on April 8th or April 9th to submit their requests so there will be sufficient time to schedule meetings for the 10th and the 11th. Madana-mohana will not be accompanying me on the 9th morning, so he will be available at the temple to take requests on that day.

There will be a National Council Meeting in Kiev from April 12th to 14th. I will be taking part in those meetings for some of the time.

I will be departing Kiev on April 15th afternoon. It's possible that I will give Srimad Bhagavatam class on April 15th morning, although there are some factors which make it unknown at this time whether or not it will be possible.

If there are any changes to the above schedule, announcements will be sent out to the community through the usual means.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Mother Isa Has Departed...
data.blurb: It is with deep regret that I wish to inform devotees that my dear godsister, Isa devi dasi, has left this world. I was just notified today that she departed some time last week. I am greatly lamenting her loss. She was such an amazing soul and a great source of inspiration for me.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
It is with deep regret that I wish to inform devotees that my dear godsister, Isa devi dasi, has left this world. I was just notified today that she departed some time last week. I am greatly lamenting her loss. She was such an amazing soul and a great source of inspiration for me.

We did not find out until today because, as I've mentioned before, the nursing home where Mother Isa was being taken care of was not obliged to contact us with any updates about her. By law, only her legal guardian was entitled to get information about her. Therefore devotees had to regularly call the nursing home to get information about her. Syamarupa dasa was told today by an employee at the nursing home that Mother Isa mostlikely departed on March 28th, although that is still unconfirmed. Devotees will need to wait until Monday before they can get the final confirmation.

Meanwhile, we should all remember this great soul. I have requested the devotees in Boston to hold a festival in her honor and will be encouraging as many devotees as possible to go there to share their memories of her.

I am reposting the transcription of the lecture I gave in Moscow last year about Mother Isa here. And below you will find the video which Syamarupa dasa took last year of Mother Isa chanting.

All glories to Mother Isa, Srila Prabhupada's very dear disciple who perfected her life in his service!!!

September 9, 2012 - Moscow Sunday Feast - About Mother Isa

Thank you all for coming today for our Sunday feast program. Do we have any guest that we are welcoming today for the first time? I see, there are few of you. Welcome. I am very happy that you were able to come today. I am very happy to be here. I am happy that I was able to come today too. Today I am going to speak on a different topic. Actually, it’s not a different topic, but a different type of presentation. As you can see, there is a screen here. We are going to show something towards the end of our presentation. It will be about ten minutes long, and will be related to the topic about which I am going to speak.

Generally, when Vaishnavas depart from this world, it is quite commonplace for devotees to assemble to hear about the activities the departed Vaishnava performed in this world. But, as I said, today it’s a little bit different, because today we are going to speak about a Vaishnava who has not yet departed. And we don’t know when this Vaishnavi will depart. But one thing is for sure: her life is in Krsna’s hands. This devotee lived in the Boston area for many years. The devotees in Boston want to be prepared, for when this Vaishnavi departs from the world, they want to have as many Vaishnavas throughout the world to share their memories about her. She is truly a very unique soul, as you will hear about her tonight. And I have to be honest and admit that actually this woman is one of my siksa-gurus. I have spoken about her many times, because I often times think about her. I find that the more I think about her, the more I meditate on her life and her example, the more my heart becomes free from lust, envy, and greed. And that’s the type of impact that this Vaishnavi has upon me and has upon many. So obviously, if that experience is there, then there must be something very pure about this person.

And purity is a state of being that we all, at least those who are practitioners of Krsna consciousness, are aspiring for. We have been speaking a lot on this topic, about the necessity to become more pure in heart, to become free from all the bad qualities that are manifested in those conditioned by the laws of nature. Especially we have been speaking a lot about envy and the need to overcome the influence of envy in our lives and in our dealings with others.

In fact, just this morning we were reading from a commentary by Srila Prabhupada in which he was describing two types of envious beings. He said that one envious being is a snake. And he said that a snake could be pacified by mantras or herbs. But he added that when a person is envious, there is nothing that can pacify him. That is the nature of a person whose heart is filled with envy. Of course, we went on to explain that although there is nothing material that can pacify an envious person, it is certain that purity and the association of a devotee of the Lord – especially the association of a devotee whose heart is pure – can eradicate envy even in the heart of the most envious person.

We were reading from a verse by Prahlada Maharaja in which he was praying to Lord Nrsimhadeva, “Let all envious persons in this world become pacified by engaging in the process of bhakti-yoga.” And he said, “Because only then one will be able to genuinely think of the welfare of others.” So this was the prayer of Prahlada Maharaja, praying for all living beings in this world, for their hearts to become pure and to become pacified, free from envy, so that they can think of the welfare of others.

As long as there is any trace of envy within the heart, then there are unfulfilled desires. And it is very difficult to think of what is completely beneficial for someone else while one is still thinking about what is beneficial for himself. The whole life of a practitioner of bhakti-yoga is therefore aimed at purification of the heart. The more the heart becomes clean, the more the heart becomes pure, then one becomes satisfied. And a self-satisfied person can actually think of the welfare of others. We oftentimes offer this prayer to Vaishnavas:

vancha-kalpatarubhyas ca krpa-sindhubhya eva ca patitanam pavanebhyo vaisnavebhyo namo namah

“We offer our respectful obeisances unto all the Vaishnava devotees of the Lord. They can fulfill the desires of everyone, just like desire trees, and they are full of compassion for the fallen souls.”

When I think of this Vaishnavi and just meditate on her activities, her life, and her example, I feel that my heart becomes free from unwanted things. There are many other people who have a similar experience of her, not only today but as they knew her many, many years ago. Therefore, for my own purification, I would like to speak about her glories. I hope that by so doing it will attract you also to this devotee and make you aspire for what she has achieved in this life by her own purity. An ordinary materialistic person may look at what she has achieved, which I am going to tell you about tonight, and they may not see anything. They may not be able to understand. Although, I am sure even they would appreciate her simplicity.

I should probably tell you a little bit more about this person, so that you can have a better understanding of why I am speaking about her. She is my God-sister, an initiated disciple of His Divine Grace Srila Prabhupada. Her name is Isa Devi Dasi. Isa is presently ninety-five years old. She joined the Krsna consciousness movement when she was fifty-five. At that time in the early 1970s most people who joined the Krsna consciousness movement were less than half her age. It was very rare for a person her age to join the movement, move into the temple, and engage in full-time devotional service. What to speak of how extraordinary it was for her to live with young people – to associate with and serve with them. She was like a mother to everybody. It was not easy for her to live under those circumstances. She didn’t have to live in a temple. But she wanted to live in the temple, because she wanted to dedicate her whole life to the service of Srila Prabhupada.

In the early 1970s she was living in our New York temple. At that time the BBT, the Bhaktivedanta book Trust, was not yet actually established. It used to be called ISKCON Press. Everything was right there in New York – all the pre-press work, even the printing, the storage for Prabhupada’s books – everything was right there in New York.

Isa’s service was transcription. She would get Prabhupada’s translations and commentaries on tape, and she would be the first person to listen to them and transcribe them. In fact there was a picture of her in our “Back to Godhead” magazine in 1974. She is sitting with her usual bright effulgent smile, and she has huge headphones on, and she is typing as she is listening to Prabhupada’s words. That was her service for some time. But then a little bit later ISKCON Press moved out to Los Angeles. Everything moved and became the “Bhaktivedanta Book Trust,” but Isa didn’t go.

For some time she was sent to India, where she was serving in our Bombay temple, taking care of Tulasi-devi. I didn’t know Mother Isa at this time. She had been in New York, when I was in Boston. And then, when she went to India…Our paths just didn’t cross. But I finally got to know her when I was the temple president in Boston. I became temple president in 1979. At that time she no longer actually lived in the temple. She lived about a 100 kilometers south of Boston.

It was difficult for her to live in the temple. Her body was getting older. The temple couldn’t provide for her personal needs. Because she had a place to live south of Boston, she decided to move there, where she lived alone. She had been previously married to a man who was actually a well-known professor of mathematics in one of the universities in Massachusetts. But he had already died and they had no children. And she was living alone for the latter part of her life. But she would very frequently come to the temple – as much as she possibly could. She would come and do service in the temple. As I said, I was temple president at that time. She would oftentimes come to the temple and she would report to me. She would tell me about what she was doing at home, and she would tell me about her preaching.

One thing Mother Isa always did, and this is the most wonderful quality about her, she wouldn’t speak about anything except Krsna and Prabhupada. I never heard her speak a word of nonsense. I never heard her speak about others in a critical way. Actually, one time she did say something to me about someone else. She said, “I am concerned; he seems to be in maya.” But that was the only thing I ever heard her say about somebody else. She used to come to my office quite frequently. Whenever she would come to Boston, she reported to me. As soon as she entered the temple, if any guests were there, she would immediately start preaching to them. Her preaching was very simple – very simple, but very pure.

She would always carry Hare Krsna mantra cards in her pockets. Whenever she met anybody, she would immediately say, “Can you sing this with me?” She was an elderly woman, so she commanded some respect. So, she did that in the temple, but as I later found out, she did it wherever she was living, wherever she went. She was always carrying some books, some pamphlets, some mantra cards, and she was always approaching people, saying, “Please, sing this with me.” And then: Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna Krsna, Hare Hare/ Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare. Then she would look at them and say, “Can you sing it yourself?” People were just so disarmed. They could not say anything…just “Hare Krsna…” They would just chant.

She especially used to come on Sunday, when all the guests come. If she were here right now, she would probably come to each of you who are here for the first time. She would hand you a card and say, “Chant with me.” Whoever she approached, everybody chanted. That is the way she was.

She didn’t have any time to talk about anything else. Her preaching was always very, very simple – but profound. She would say, “Krsna is the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He can do anything, because He is the Supreme Lord. If you take shelter of Him, He can do anything. Whatever you need, He can take care of.” She was speaking from her own realization. It was not pretentious. This was her realization because it was very difficult for her to live alone. She did not have much money; she lived very, very simply. She went through many difficulties in her life. She lost many family members.

She had one brother, who was older than her. She used to have to take care of him, and he was very antagonistic. She used to come to the temple and tell me, “That brother of mine, he won’t chant Hare Krsna.” That was her problem: her brother wouldn’t chant Hare Krsna. She also had a niece that was very antagonistic. But she never wanted to accept any help from her family members. She wanted to depend on Krsna.

She was living in a city called Hyannis on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. She was effectively the main preacher there. She would always go introducing people to Prabhupada’s books. Everywhere she went she had Prabhupada’s books. She would ride around town on a bicycle. That is how she got everywhere. Whenever she would go into a store to buy something, she would always have some of Prabhupada’s books and some mantra cards. And everyone she met she would always give them books and preach to them. Gradually some people became attracted to her and they wanted to learn more about Prabhupada and Krsna. Whenever there was a group of people that she had been introducing to Krsna consciousness, she would invite me, “Please come down and give a lecture to these people.”

So I used to go down; not that regularly, but once every few months we would go down and have a program. Isa would introduce to me all the people she had met in the course of her travels. Her preaching was just always the same. “Krsna is God. Krsna can do anything. Just take shelter of Him and chant these names.” It was not very complicated. She did not give lectures or anything like that. She just spoke, and then exemplified what she said. That was her life. That is all I know of her life. It was her life just to take shelter of the holy name, to preach the glories of the holy name, and to preach the glories of Prabhupada. She definitely was very much attracted to always speaking about Prabhupada.

Her life went on like this for quite a few years. And she continued to come to the temple very regularly – every Sunday. She oftentimes would sew. She liked to sew, so she would sew things for devotees and for the Deities. She liked to make Prabhupada’s hats, because she always saw these hats on Prabhupada in his pictures. When she saw Prabhupada in person, he was wearing his famous “Prabhupada hat” that he would tie under his chin. Every week she came, she would always bring these hats for the brahmacaris and the other devotees in the temple. And bead bags – she liked to make bead bags. Nobody could refuse. Everybody was wearing Prabhupada hats in the temple. She was the kind of woman you just can’t refuse. If she asked you to take a hat, you had to take it and immediately put it on. She would just immediately smile; it made her so happy. She was so happy, because she was so grateful she could do some service for the devotees. That was her life – just doing some service according to her means. She wanted to serve the devotees and to serve Radha-Gopivallabha, the Radha-Krsna Deities in Boston.

As soon as she came into the temple, She would report to me, telling me about her preaching. Then she would immediately go to shower, put on clean clothes, and go down to the pujari room to iron all the Deities’ clothes. She would iron handkerchiefs, and she would iron the Deity’s cadars and clothes. She would stay in the pujari room until the Sunday feast program was about to start, and then she would go out and preach to the guests. She would preach to the guests all the time during the Sunday program. She would only take a little prasada; she never ate the feast, because she was so busy preaching. She would just honor a little maha-prasada, because she wanted to serve to her full capacity while she was in the temple. Then she would go home. She would take a bus 100 km home late at night every Sunday.

From time to time, she would come during the week, but mostly she came on Sundays. She just continued doing this for so many years. She never complained. I never heard a complaint from this woman’s mouth. She was so happy just to have Prabhupada and Krsna, to be able to associate with the devotees. It was her life. Sometimes people think that when you live away from the devotees, it is very difficult to stay in Krsna consciousness: so many distractions, so many allurements. Sometimes people lament that, “I need to live closer to the devotees.” But she was self-satisfied, and she went on like that for many years. I started travelling on this side of the world many years ago, and so I didn‘t see her so often. But I always used to inquire about her. Because I knew her, I knew she was living far away.

As the years went by, not many devotees in the temple knew her, especially when it became too difficult for her to come to the temple. But I didn’t want anybody to forget that she exists. So I would always either send an email or call, or whenever I came I would say, “Where is Mother Isa? How is she doing?” And I would hear, “Oh, Mother Isa? We haven’t seen her for a long time.” She was already in her eighties at that time. I would say, “What do you mean you haven’t seen her for a long time? What kind of an answer is that? That’s not an answer. I haven’t seen her for a long time. Do you know why you haven’t seen her for a long time?” I always had the biggest fear in my heart that this woman might leave the planet and nobody would know about it. It was always a fear in my heart. It would be a travesty: such an exalted Vaishnavi leaves and nobody knows. So I used to make the devotees find out where was Mother Isa. And they did.

She was getting too old to make the bus trip to Boston. But she was still doing whatever she could. She was no longer on a bicycle, but she was still going places, meeting people and introducing them to Krsna consciousness. Actually, it got to the point where it was very difficult for her even to do her basic shopping. She had met one woman in a health food store. Isa was preaching to this woman because she worked in a health food store that Isa would go to quite regularly. Isa would always give her books and preach to her. So, the woman wanted to find out more about Isa, because she was very attracted to Isa. She gradually found out that Isa was living alone, that she was a devotee, a disciple of Srila Prabhupada, and that all she would talk about was Krsna and Prabhupada. This woman began to feel like she wanted to do some service for Mother Isa. She started buying Mother Isa’s food, so that she would not have to go out. This woman was taking care of all Isa’s personal needs. She was so drawn to Isa that she couldn’t help but serve her. I didn’t know about this. But I found out about it in 2006. In 2006 this woman – she is probably now in her late thirties, maybe forty years old – she called the Boston temple and left a message on the answering machine. She said, “I don’t know if this is the right number to call or not, but I wanted to tell you that there is a woman here in Hyannis, her name is Isa Devi Dasi. She just had a stroke, and she is in a hospital. I thought you may be interested to hear this.” That was the message. She also left her name and phone number.

Unfortunately, at that time nobody in the temple knew who Isa was. But, fortunately, I was in America at the same time, so I called the temple, and somebody in the temple said, “Somebody left a message about some Isa Devi Dasi who just had a stroke.” I said, “Isa had a stroke? What’s wrong? Where is she? What happened?” – “We don’t know anything about it.” Immediately, I said, “Did they leave a number?” – “Yes, they left the number.” So, I immediately called, and Sandy - she introduced herself – told me about everything that had happened. She said that Isa had had a stroke and was in the hospital. Sandy had found Isa at the bottom of the stairs, where she was lying unconscious. She said that Isa was currently in the hospital, that she was not conscious, but that the doctors were hopeful she would regain consciousness soon.

As it turned out, she did regain consciousness very soon. But the result of having had the stroke was that the doctors found out that was one of many strokes she had had. The doctors said that Isa must have had at least five or six strokes before that one. That particular stroke completely took away her memory. She didn‘t know who she was; she didn‘t know her name; she didn‘t know where she lived; she didn‘t remember anybody; though, Sandy said, she claimed she remembered me. She also remembered one other devotee – his name was Damodara – who also used to serve together with her in the Boston temple. I asked Sandy, “Where is she? Can I come and see her?” She said, “It will be better to come see her when she is brought to the rehabilitation hospital. She will be transferred there in two days.”

So, in two days I called to see if Sandy was there and if I could meet her and see Isa. Sandy was right there in the room with Isa at that time. She answered the phone. I introduced myself, and she said to Isa, “Isa, it’s Niranjana Swami. Do you remember Niranjana Swami?” Isa didn’t really respond. She gave the phone to Isa and said, “Isa, say something to Niranjana Swami.”

“Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna, Krsna, Hare Hare/ Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!” That’s what she said. And then she handed the phone back to Sandy. She was singing just like that, in that melody, and with great enthusiasm. I said to Sandy, “It sounds like she hasn’t lost all her memory.” But Sandy said, “It seems to be that’s all she remembers.” So I said, “It can’t be all that bad.”

I went that day to visit her with another devotee. She was there at a rehabilitation hospital, and the doctors were teaching her how to eat – because she forgot how to eat – teaching her how to dress, how to walk – she forgot how to walk. She couldn’t remember any of these things. She had no memory of anything. We waited for some time while she was in therapy. And then finally she was wheeled into the room where we were waiting for her. She had this very intense stare; she was looking at me. I started talking to Mother Isa, “Hare Krsna. How are you?” She couldn’t say much.

At one point we were sitting and talking to her, we were trying to bring back her memory. One of the nurses came over to Isa, because when you forget, one of the things to do is to try to stimulate a person‘s memory. So she sat down in front of Isa – her name is Edith – and she said, “Edith, where do you live? Where is your home, Edith?” And Isa says, “My home? In a very slow, deliberate, but innocent way, she said the word, "Vrindavan.” The nurse couldn‘t understand. She said something like, “I think she said Chicago.” Isa said, “No. Vrindavan is my home.” That was one thing that really caught my attention.

Then we were sitting and talking to Isa. She wasn‘t really responding so much. Sandy was sitting at the table and we were mostly talking to Sandy, because Isa wasn‘t responding so much. Sandy was telling us the story about how she got to know Isa. She told us how Isa came and preached to her in the health food store, how she started serving Isa, and how she was in a conflict with her husband because she was serving Isa more than she was serving the family. I said, “You’re doing a lot of service. You must be a devotee.” She said, “A devotee? I don‘t know what a devotee is. All I know is she talks about Krsna.” And she said, “All I know is, I love Isa. And if loving Isa means I am a devotee, then I am a devotee.”

I could see that this woman’s heart was really being transformed by associating with Isa. She was just so dedicated to serving her. She was already making plans, how they could add on to her home so that when Isa got out from the rehabilitation hospital Isa could move in with them so that she could take care of her. They weren‘t a very wealthy family, but she was ready to do anything for Isa. Still, the husband he was a little reluctant. And it turned out that the husband started putting up some resistance…

The best part is yet to come. This is leading up to the best part. Do you want me to end? <Devotees say no> Ok, I‘ll continue. And I‘ll try to not keep you too long from your feast. But don‘t forget, Mother Isa would fast. She wouldn‘t be so much concerned about the feast. She only wanted to hear and chant about Krsna.

So, it was a problem. The husband didn‘t want Isa to move into their home. Sandy was explaining all this to us. All of a sudden another nurse walked over to the table, and Isa looked up and she sternly asked, “Are you a vegetarian?” And Sandy started clapping, “That‘s the Isa I know.” She was so happy. Immediately she said, “Isa is coming back. That‘s the Isa I know. She is always preaching.” Meanwhile, the nurse was just startled. She didn‘t know what to say. She said, “Well, I try not to eat red meat.” Isa wasn‘t satisfied. She just gave a dirty look, but she didn‘t say anything more. Damodara had to explain to her about the benefits of being vegetarian. The woman left, saying, “Well, I am going to think seriously about becoming vegetarian now.”

So, we went back into Isa‘s room, and there was another devotee…Actually, this was another visit, not the same visit. Isa was already in the room when I came with another devotee. Isa was staring at this devotee as he was chanting japa; she was staring at his bead bag. I asked Sandy, “Where are her beads? Does she have beads?” Sandy said, “Actually, no. Her beads broke when she fell down the stairs during her stroke. She has no beads.” She said, “But my husband is restringing them for her.” But Mother Isa was still looking at the bead bag. Although we were trying to get her to communicate, she just wouldn‘t take her eyes away from the bead bag. So the devotee, Yamuna Jivana, gave his bead bag to Isa. Isa looked like a little child who had just received a Christmas present she had been waiting for all year. She put her hand into the bead bag immediately and just started chanting, “Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna…” She didn‘t notice anything else that was going on in the room. She just stayed that way for the whole rest of the visit, just chanting japa, as if she had been waiting such a long time for those beads.

Unfortunately, that was the last time I saw Isa until just two weeks ago. But I arranged for a whole group of devotees to rotate and go visit her from time to time. After a while I found out they were becoming a little negligent, and nobody was visiting her. So, just on my last trip to the United States I took two other devotees with me, and we went down to the nursing home where she is now. We tried very hard to find a way that Mother Isa could live with devotees, so that devotees could take care of her. But it was very, very difficult. I knew that Mother Isa had some funds, because one time she called me and asked for my name – she wanted to put my name into her will so that all her money would be given to me when she died.

So, I asked Sandy, because Sandy took responsibility for her accounts also, how much money was available? Maybe we could build a house in one of the farm communities, and the devotees could take care of her. Unfortunately, it wasn‘t very much. But, even worse, her niece refused to let her be taken away. Her niece had full custody of Isa, because she was the only living relative. They wouldn‘t let us take her to any place far from where she had been living.

We went to the nursing home. I hadn‘t seen Mother Isa for five or six years. She was wheeled into the room. I could see that she was a lot older. When I talked to her she was a lot less responsive. Her memory was practically completely gone. When I would talk to her, I would say, “Isa, tell me something about Prabhupada. Tell me something about Krsna.” She would just look at me very intensely – in the eyes – but she couldn‘t say anything. So, I decided to go to the nurses’ station to ask them if they could tell me about her current state. I told them who I was and how I had known her for almost forty years. I was told at the nurses’ station that actually the morning is a very bad time of day to get her to respond because she is very, very tired. The nurse said, “But if you come during the day, she‘ll sing the Krsna song for you.” I said, “Oh, really?” Immediately I became enlivened, because I knew she was still chanting. I couldn‘t imagine Mother Isa not chanting Hare Krsna. So, I went back into the room again and I reached out for her hand, and she immediately grabbed my hand very tightly.

I said, “Mother Isa, Hare Krsna.” And she looked at me and said, “Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna Krsna…” She chanted the whole mantra all the way through. She did this for several minutes. But we couldn‘t get her to say anything else but the maha-mantra. That‘s all she could say. We could see that she was very tired, so we decided after forty-five minutes that we would leave and try to come back some time in the afternoon.

As we were leaving the nursing home, one of the nurses saw me out of the corner of her eye – I was dressed in my robes – she was helping a group of elderly people to get into a van. She came over to me and said, “Who are you here to see?” So I said, “I am here to see Edith Graves.” She said, “I knew it. I love that woman. Everybody in this whole building loves that woman. She‘s the most peaceful person, so self contented. She never complains. Every Friday we get together and we sing patriotic songs together. And she leads everybody in a Krsna song.” The whole group of people, she just starts leading them in kirtana. She just chants Hare Krsna, and everybody just follows along and chants with her.

There was another elderly woman in a wheelchair. She was being wheeled onto the van. She immediately put her hand out and she said, “Very nice to meet you. My name is Kay. I love that woman too. That woman is a real live wire. When she starts chanting that Krsna song with such enthusiasm, everybody just has to chant. Everybody has to sing with her. Tell me, how old is she? Nobody knows how old she is.” I said, “She is ninety-five years old.” She said, “Oh.” Maybe she became very reverential when she heard that Isa was ninety-five years old. She begged us, “Please come back again.” And the other nurse said, “Please come back. You have to come and see her. Nobody has been visiting her.” So I thanked them profusely, and I told them, “Thank you for sharing these stories about Isa with me. It means so much to me. We‘ll definitely come back.”

So the devotee that came with me, it just so happened that he had to be near there on that Friday afternoon. So I told him, “You have to take a camera. I want you to take a video of Mother Isa chanting. Then you should interview everybody and ask them what they think about her.” As it turned out, there was a strict policy in the nursing home not to allow events to be videotaped. They obviously don’t allow anybody to go around and interview people on video. But this devotee took some video clips of Mother Isa chanting. She can‘t say anything from memory, except the Hare Krsna mantra. Sometimes she may repeat a word or two, but it‘s just repetition. But as soon she starts with the Hare Krsna mantra, it just comes out with such enthusiasm, with such devotion – it‘s profound.

I’m thinking that Krsna has taken away everything, but she has everything she needs for a perfect life. She doesn‘t have to think about her body, she doesn‘t complain about anything, she doesn‘t have to think about anything, because the only thing she can think about is the holy name. It‘s the only thing that comes out of her mouth. I tried to get something else, but nothing else would come, just the Holy name. So, I’m thinking that Krsna, who is in the heart, has actually rewarded her for a life of only speaking about Krsna.

I wrote the story and I put it on the internet, and devotees are writing back and leaving little comments. Sivarama Maharaja says, “If having a stroke means that all I’ll be able to say is Hare Krsna, then maybe I should have a stroke.” Other devotees are writing things like this, “Wonderful! It‘s amazing! All glories to Prabhupada! This is shocking!”

Now we are going to show this video. It‘s ten minutes. But I want you to take note what she does when the woman who is with her tries to get her to chant. When she chants, the woman and Syamarupa both say, “That‘s wonderful, Mother Isa.” Watch the expression on her face when they say, “That‘s wonderful, Mother Isa.” It‘s the same expression she would always show when everybody would try to glorify her. Because she never wanted glorification. She would always think nothing of it. She didn’t want to hear it. So when you hear, “That’s wonderful,” watch her expression. The other thing…towards the end you‘ll see such an effulgent smile. It will melt your heart. For me, it brings tears to my eyes, because she is my siksa-guru. She has always been an object of my meditation.

So, I’d like to introduce you to Mother Isa. Hare Krsna.
