It is with deep regret that I wish to inform devotees that my dear godsister, Isa devi dasi, has left this world. I was just notified today that she departed some time last week. I am greatly lamenting her loss. She was such an amazing soul and a great source of inspiration for me.

We did not find out until today because, as I've mentioned before, the nursing home where Mother Isa was being taken care of was not obliged to contact us with any updates about her. By law, only her legal guardian was entitled to get information about her. Therefore devotees had to regularly call the nursing home to get information about her. Syamarupa dasa was told today by an employee at the nursing home that Mother Isa mostlikely departed on March 28th, although that is still unconfirmed. Devotees will need to wait until Monday before they can get the final confirmation.

Meanwhile, we should all remember this great soul. I have requested the devotees in Boston to hold a festival in her honor and will be encouraging as many devotees as possible to go there to share their memories of her.

I am reposting the transcription of the lecture I gave in Moscow last year about Mother Isa here. And below you will find the video which Syamarupa dasa took last year of Mother Isa chanting.

All glories to Mother Isa, Srila Prabhupada's very dear disciple who perfected her life in his service!!!

September 9, 2012 - Moscow Sunday Feast - About Mother Isa

Thank you all for coming today for our Sunday feast program. Do we have any guest that we are welcoming today for the first time? I see, there are few of you. Welcome. I am very happy that you were able to come today. I am very happy to be here. I am happy that I was able to come today too. Today I am going to speak on a different topic. Actually, it’s not a different topic, but a different type of presentation. As you can see, there is a screen here. We are going to show something towards the end of our presentation. It will be about ten minutes long, and will be related to the topic about which I am going to speak.

Generally, when Vaishnavas depart from this world, it is quite commonplace for devotees to assemble to hear about the activities the departed Vaishnava performed in this world. But, as I said, today it’s a little bit different, because today we are going to speak about a Vaishnava who has not yet departed. And we don’t know when this Vaishnavi will depart. But one thing is for sure: her life is in Krsna’s hands. This devotee lived in the Boston area for many years. The devotees in Boston want to be prepared, for when this Vaishnavi departs from the world, they want to have as many Vaishnavas throughout the world to share their memories about her. She is truly a very unique soul, as you will hear about her tonight. And I have to be honest and admit that actually this woman is one of my siksa-gurus. I have spoken about her many times, because I often times think about her. I find that the more I think about her, the more I meditate on her life and her example, the more my heart becomes free from lust, envy, and greed. And that’s the type of impact that this Vaishnavi has upon me and has upon many. So obviously, if that experience is there, then there must be something very pure about this person.

And purity is a state of being that we all, at least those who are practitioners of Krsna consciousness, are aspiring for. We have been speaking a lot on this topic, about the necessity to become more pure in heart, to become free from all the bad qualities that are manifested in those conditioned by the laws of nature. Especially we have been speaking a lot about envy and the need to overcome the influence of envy in our lives and in our dealings with others.

In fact, just this morning we were reading from a commentary by Srila Prabhupada in which he was describing two types of envious beings. He said that one envious being is a snake. And he said that a snake could be pacified by mantras or herbs. But he added that when a person is envious, there is nothing that can pacify him. That is the nature of a person whose heart is filled with envy. Of course, we went on to explain that although there is nothing material that can pacify an envious person, it is certain that purity and the association of a devotee of the Lord – especially the association of a devotee whose heart is pure – can eradicate envy even in the heart of the most envious person.

We were reading from a verse by Prahlada Maharaja in which he was praying to Lord Nrsimhadeva, “Let all envious persons in this world become pacified by engaging in the process of bhakti-yoga.” And he said, “Because only then one will be able to genuinely think of the welfare of others.” So this was the prayer of Prahlada Maharaja, praying for all living beings in this world, for their hearts to become pure and to become pacified, free from envy, so that they can think of the welfare of others.

As long as there is any trace of envy within the heart, then there are unfulfilled desires. And it is very difficult to think of what is completely beneficial for someone else while one is still thinking about what is beneficial for himself. The whole life of a practitioner of bhakti-yoga is therefore aimed at purification of the heart. The more the heart becomes clean, the more the heart becomes pure, then one becomes satisfied. And a self-satisfied person can actually think of the welfare of others. We oftentimes offer this prayer to Vaishnavas:

vancha-kalpatarubhyas ca krpa-sindhubhya eva ca patitanam pavanebhyo vaisnavebhyo namo namah

“We offer our respectful obeisances unto all the Vaishnava devotees of the Lord. They can fulfill the desires of everyone, just like desire trees, and they are full of compassion for the fallen souls.”

When I think of this Vaishnavi and just meditate on her activities, her life, and her example, I feel that my heart becomes free from unwanted things. There are many other people who have a similar experience of her, not only today but as they knew her many, many years ago. Therefore, for my own purification, I would like to speak about her glories. I hope that by so doing it will attract you also to this devotee and make you aspire for what she has achieved in this life by her own purity. An ordinary materialistic person may look at what she has achieved, which I am going to tell you about tonight, and they may not see anything. They may not be able to understand. Although, I am sure even they would appreciate her simplicity.

I should probably tell you a little bit more about this person, so that you can have a better understanding of why I am speaking about her. She is my God-sister, an initiated disciple of His Divine Grace Srila Prabhupada. Her name is Isa Devi Dasi. Isa is presently ninety-five years old. She joined the Krsna consciousness movement when she was fifty-five. At that time in the early 1970s most people who joined the Krsna consciousness movement were less than half her age. It was very rare for a person her age to join the movement, move into the temple, and engage in full-time devotional service. What to speak of how extraordinary it was for her to live with young people – to associate with and serve with them. She was like a mother to everybody. It was not easy for her to live under those circumstances. She didn’t have to live in a temple. But she wanted to live in the temple, because she wanted to dedicate her whole life to the service of Srila Prabhupada.

In the early 1970s she was living in our New York temple. At that time the BBT, the Bhaktivedanta book Trust, was not yet actually established. It used to be called ISKCON Press. Everything was right there in New York – all the pre-press work, even the printing, the storage for Prabhupada’s books – everything was right there in New York.

Isa’s service was transcription. She would get Prabhupada’s translations and commentaries on tape, and she would be the first person to listen to them and transcribe them. In fact there was a picture of her in our “Back to Godhead” magazine in 1974. She is sitting with her usual bright effulgent smile, and she has huge headphones on, and she is typing as she is listening to Prabhupada’s words. That was her service for some time. But then a little bit later ISKCON Press moved out to Los Angeles. Everything moved and became the “Bhaktivedanta Book Trust,” but Isa didn’t go.

For some time she was sent to India, where she was serving in our Bombay temple, taking care of Tulasi-devi. I didn’t know Mother Isa at this time. She had been in New York, when I was in Boston. And then, when she went to India…Our paths just didn’t cross. But I finally got to know her when I was the temple president in Boston. I became temple president in 1979. At that time she no longer actually lived in the temple. She lived about a 100 kilometers south of Boston.

It was difficult for her to live in the temple. Her body was getting older. The temple couldn’t provide for her personal needs. Because she had a place to live south of Boston, she decided to move there, where she lived alone. She had been previously married to a man who was actually a well-known professor of mathematics in one of the universities in Massachusetts. But he had already died and they had no children. And she was living alone for the latter part of her life. But she would very frequently come to the temple – as much as she possibly could. She would come and do service in the temple. As I said, I was temple president at that time. She would oftentimes come to the temple and she would report to me. She would tell me about what she was doing at home, and she would tell me about her preaching.

One thing Mother Isa always did, and this is the most wonderful quality about her, she wouldn’t speak about anything except Krsna and Prabhupada. I never heard her speak a word of nonsense. I never heard her speak about others in a critical way. Actually, one time she did say something to me about someone else. She said, “I am concerned; he seems to be in maya.” But that was the only thing I ever heard her say about somebody else. She used to come to my office quite frequently. Whenever she would come to Boston, she reported to me. As soon as she entered the temple, if any guests were there, she would immediately start preaching to them. Her preaching was very simple – very simple, but very pure.

She would always carry Hare Krsna mantra cards in her pockets. Whenever she met anybody, she would immediately say, “Can you sing this with me?” She was an elderly woman, so she commanded some respect. So, she did that in the temple, but as I later found out, she did it wherever she was living, wherever she went. She was always carrying some books, some pamphlets, some mantra cards, and she was always approaching people, saying, “Please, sing this with me.” And then: Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna Krsna, Hare Hare/ Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare. Then she would look at them and say, “Can you sing it yourself?” People were just so disarmed. They could not say anything…just “Hare Krsna…” They would just chant.

She especially used to come on Sunday, when all the guests come. If she were here right now, she would probably come to each of you who are here for the first time. She would hand you a card and say, “Chant with me.” Whoever she approached, everybody chanted. That is the way she was.

She didn’t have any time to talk about anything else. Her preaching was always very, very simple – but profound. She would say, “Krsna is the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He can do anything, because He is the Supreme Lord. If you take shelter of Him, He can do anything. Whatever you need, He can take care of.” She was speaking from her own realization. It was not pretentious. This was her realization because it was very difficult for her to live alone. She did not have much money; she lived very, very simply. She went through many difficulties in her life. She lost many family members.

She had one brother, who was older than her. She used to have to take care of him, and he was very antagonistic. She used to come to the temple and tell me, “That brother of mine, he won’t chant Hare Krsna.” That was her problem: her brother wouldn’t chant Hare Krsna. She also had a niece that was very antagonistic. But she never wanted to accept any help from her family members. She wanted to depend on Krsna.

She was living in a city called Hyannis on Cape Cod in Massachusetts. She was effectively the main preacher there. She would always go introducing people to Prabhupada’s books. Everywhere she went she had Prabhupada’s books. She would ride around town on a bicycle. That is how she got everywhere. Whenever she would go into a store to buy something, she would always have some of Prabhupada’s books and some mantra cards. And everyone she met she would always give them books and preach to them. Gradually some people became attracted to her and they wanted to learn more about Prabhupada and Krsna. Whenever there was a group of people that she had been introducing to Krsna consciousness, she would invite me, “Please come down and give a lecture to these people.”

So I used to go down; not that regularly, but once every few months we would go down and have a program. Isa would introduce to me all the people she had met in the course of her travels. Her preaching was just always the same. “Krsna is God. Krsna can do anything. Just take shelter of Him and chant these names.” It was not very complicated. She did not give lectures or anything like that. She just spoke, and then exemplified what she said. That was her life. That is all I know of her life. It was her life just to take shelter of the holy name, to preach the glories of the holy name, and to preach the glories of Prabhupada. She definitely was very much attracted to always speaking about Prabhupada.

Her life went on like this for quite a few years. And she continued to come to the temple very regularly – every Sunday. She oftentimes would sew. She liked to sew, so she would sew things for devotees and for the Deities. She liked to make Prabhupada’s hats, because she always saw these hats on Prabhupada in his pictures. When she saw Prabhupada in person, he was wearing his famous “Prabhupada hat” that he would tie under his chin. Every week she came, she would always bring these hats for the brahmacaris and the other devotees in the temple. And bead bags – she liked to make bead bags. Nobody could refuse. Everybody was wearing Prabhupada hats in the temple. She was the kind of woman you just can’t refuse. If she asked you to take a hat, you had to take it and immediately put it on. She would just immediately smile; it made her so happy. She was so happy, because she was so grateful she could do some service for the devotees. That was her life – just doing some service according to her means. She wanted to serve the devotees and to serve Radha-Gopivallabha, the Radha-Krsna Deities in Boston.

As soon as she came into the temple, She would report to me, telling me about her preaching. Then she would immediately go to shower, put on clean clothes, and go down to the pujari room to iron all the Deities’ clothes. She would iron handkerchiefs, and she would iron the Deity’s cadars and clothes. She would stay in the pujari room until the Sunday feast program was about to start, and then she would go out and preach to the guests. She would preach to the guests all the time during the Sunday program. She would only take a little prasada; she never ate the feast, because she was so busy preaching. She would just honor a little maha-prasada, because she wanted to serve to her full capacity while she was in the temple. Then she would go home. She would take a bus 100 km home late at night every Sunday.

From time to time, she would come during the week, but mostly she came on Sundays. She just continued doing this for so many years. She never complained. I never heard a complaint from this woman’s mouth. She was so happy just to have Prabhupada and Krsna, to be able to associate with the devotees. It was her life. Sometimes people think that when you live away from the devotees, it is very difficult to stay in Krsna consciousness: so many distractions, so many allurements. Sometimes people lament that, “I need to live closer to the devotees.” But she was self-satisfied, and she went on like that for many years. I started travelling on this side of the world many years ago, and so I didn‘t see her so often. But I always used to inquire about her. Because I knew her, I knew she was living far away.

As the years went by, not many devotees in the temple knew her, especially when it became too difficult for her to come to the temple. But I didn’t want anybody to forget that she exists. So I would always either send an email or call, or whenever I came I would say, “Where is Mother Isa? How is she doing?” And I would hear, “Oh, Mother Isa? We haven’t seen her for a long time.” She was already in her eighties at that time. I would say, “What do you mean you haven’t seen her for a long time? What kind of an answer is that? That’s not an answer. I haven’t seen her for a long time. Do you know why you haven’t seen her for a long time?” I always had the biggest fear in my heart that this woman might leave the planet and nobody would know about it. It was always a fear in my heart. It would be a travesty: such an exalted Vaishnavi leaves and nobody knows. So I used to make the devotees find out where was Mother Isa. And they did.

She was getting too old to make the bus trip to Boston. But she was still doing whatever she could. She was no longer on a bicycle, but she was still going places, meeting people and introducing them to Krsna consciousness. Actually, it got to the point where it was very difficult for her even to do her basic shopping. She had met one woman in a health food store. Isa was preaching to this woman because she worked in a health food store that Isa would go to quite regularly. Isa would always give her books and preach to her. So, the woman wanted to find out more about Isa, because she was very attracted to Isa. She gradually found out that Isa was living alone, that she was a devotee, a disciple of Srila Prabhupada, and that all she would talk about was Krsna and Prabhupada. This woman began to feel like she wanted to do some service for Mother Isa. She started buying Mother Isa’s food, so that she would not have to go out. This woman was taking care of all Isa’s personal needs. She was so drawn to Isa that she couldn’t help but serve her. I didn’t know about this. But I found out about it in 2006. In 2006 this woman – she is probably now in her late thirties, maybe forty years old – she called the Boston temple and left a message on the answering machine. She said, “I don’t know if this is the right number to call or not, but I wanted to tell you that there is a woman here in Hyannis, her name is Isa Devi Dasi. She just had a stroke, and she is in a hospital. I thought you may be interested to hear this.” That was the message. She also left her name and phone number.

Unfortunately, at that time nobody in the temple knew who Isa was. But, fortunately, I was in America at the same time, so I called the temple, and somebody in the temple said, “Somebody left a message about some Isa Devi Dasi who just had a stroke.” I said, “Isa had a stroke? What’s wrong? Where is she? What happened?” – “We don’t know anything about it.” Immediately, I said, “Did they leave a number?” – “Yes, they left the number.” So, I immediately called, and Sandy - she introduced herself – told me about everything that had happened. She said that Isa had had a stroke and was in the hospital. Sandy had found Isa at the bottom of the stairs, where she was lying unconscious. She said that Isa was currently in the hospital, that she was not conscious, but that the doctors were hopeful she would regain consciousness soon.

As it turned out, she did regain consciousness very soon. But the result of having had the stroke was that the doctors found out that was one of many strokes she had had. The doctors said that Isa must have had at least five or six strokes before that one. That particular stroke completely took away her memory. She didn‘t know who she was; she didn‘t know her name; she didn‘t know where she lived; she didn‘t remember anybody; though, Sandy said, she claimed she remembered me. She also remembered one other devotee – his name was Damodara – who also used to serve together with her in the Boston temple. I asked Sandy, “Where is she? Can I come and see her?” She said, “It will be better to come see her when she is brought to the rehabilitation hospital. She will be transferred there in two days.”

So, in two days I called to see if Sandy was there and if I could meet her and see Isa. Sandy was right there in the room with Isa at that time. She answered the phone. I introduced myself, and she said to Isa, “Isa, it’s Niranjana Swami. Do you remember Niranjana Swami?” Isa didn’t really respond. She gave the phone to Isa and said, “Isa, say something to Niranjana Swami.”

“Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna, Krsna, Hare Hare/ Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!” That’s what she said. And then she handed the phone back to Sandy. She was singing just like that, in that melody, and with great enthusiasm. I said to Sandy, “It sounds like she hasn’t lost all her memory.” But Sandy said, “It seems to be that’s all she remembers.” So I said, “It can’t be all that bad.”

I went that day to visit her with another devotee. She was there at a rehabilitation hospital, and the doctors were teaching her how to eat – because she forgot how to eat – teaching her how to dress, how to walk – she forgot how to walk. She couldn’t remember any of these things. She had no memory of anything. We waited for some time while she was in therapy. And then finally she was wheeled into the room where we were waiting for her. She had this very intense stare; she was looking at me. I started talking to Mother Isa, “Hare Krsna. How are you?” She couldn’t say much.

At one point we were sitting and talking to her, we were trying to bring back her memory. One of the nurses came over to Isa, because when you forget, one of the things to do is to try to stimulate a person‘s memory. So she sat down in front of Isa – her name is Edith – and she said, “Edith, where do you live? Where is your home, Edith?” And Isa says, “My home? In a very slow, deliberate, but innocent way, she said the word, "Vrindavan.” The nurse couldn‘t understand. She said something like, “I think she said Chicago.” Isa said, “No. Vrindavan is my home.” That was one thing that really caught my attention.

Then we were sitting and talking to Isa. She wasn‘t really responding so much. Sandy was sitting at the table and we were mostly talking to Sandy, because Isa wasn‘t responding so much. Sandy was telling us the story about how she got to know Isa. She told us how Isa came and preached to her in the health food store, how she started serving Isa, and how she was in a conflict with her husband because she was serving Isa more than she was serving the family. I said, “You’re doing a lot of service. You must be a devotee.” She said, “A devotee? I don‘t know what a devotee is. All I know is she talks about Krsna.” And she said, “All I know is, I love Isa. And if loving Isa means I am a devotee, then I am a devotee.”

I could see that this woman’s heart was really being transformed by associating with Isa. She was just so dedicated to serving her. She was already making plans, how they could add on to her home so that when Isa got out from the rehabilitation hospital Isa could move in with them so that she could take care of her. They weren‘t a very wealthy family, but she was ready to do anything for Isa. Still, the husband he was a little reluctant. And it turned out that the husband started putting up some resistance…

The best part is yet to come. This is leading up to the best part. Do you want me to end? <Devotees say no> Ok, I‘ll continue. And I‘ll try to not keep you too long from your feast. But don‘t forget, Mother Isa would fast. She wouldn‘t be so much concerned about the feast. She only wanted to hear and chant about Krsna.

So, it was a problem. The husband didn‘t want Isa to move into their home. Sandy was explaining all this to us. All of a sudden another nurse walked over to the table, and Isa looked up and she sternly asked, “Are you a vegetarian?” And Sandy started clapping, “That‘s the Isa I know.” She was so happy. Immediately she said, “Isa is coming back. That‘s the Isa I know. She is always preaching.” Meanwhile, the nurse was just startled. She didn‘t know what to say. She said, “Well, I try not to eat red meat.” Isa wasn‘t satisfied. She just gave a dirty look, but she didn‘t say anything more. Damodara had to explain to her about the benefits of being vegetarian. The woman left, saying, “Well, I am going to think seriously about becoming vegetarian now.”

So, we went back into Isa‘s room, and there was another devotee…Actually, this was another visit, not the same visit. Isa was already in the room when I came with another devotee. Isa was staring at this devotee as he was chanting japa; she was staring at his bead bag. I asked Sandy, “Where are her beads? Does she have beads?” Sandy said, “Actually, no. Her beads broke when she fell down the stairs during her stroke. She has no beads.” She said, “But my husband is restringing them for her.” But Mother Isa was still looking at the bead bag. Although we were trying to get her to communicate, she just wouldn‘t take her eyes away from the bead bag. So the devotee, Yamuna Jivana, gave his bead bag to Isa. Isa looked like a little child who had just received a Christmas present she had been waiting for all year. She put her hand into the bead bag immediately and just started chanting, “Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna…” She didn‘t notice anything else that was going on in the room. She just stayed that way for the whole rest of the visit, just chanting japa, as if she had been waiting such a long time for those beads.

Unfortunately, that was the last time I saw Isa until just two weeks ago. But I arranged for a whole group of devotees to rotate and go visit her from time to time. After a while I found out they were becoming a little negligent, and nobody was visiting her. So, just on my last trip to the United States I took two other devotees with me, and we went down to the nursing home where she is now. We tried very hard to find a way that Mother Isa could live with devotees, so that devotees could take care of her. But it was very, very difficult. I knew that Mother Isa had some funds, because one time she called me and asked for my name – she wanted to put my name into her will so that all her money would be given to me when she died.

So, I asked Sandy, because Sandy took responsibility for her accounts also, how much money was available? Maybe we could build a house in one of the farm communities, and the devotees could take care of her. Unfortunately, it wasn‘t very much. But, even worse, her niece refused to let her be taken away. Her niece had full custody of Isa, because she was the only living relative. They wouldn‘t let us take her to any place far from where she had been living.

We went to the nursing home. I hadn‘t seen Mother Isa for five or six years. She was wheeled into the room. I could see that she was a lot older. When I talked to her she was a lot less responsive. Her memory was practically completely gone. When I would talk to her, I would say, “Isa, tell me something about Prabhupada. Tell me something about Krsna.” She would just look at me very intensely – in the eyes – but she couldn‘t say anything. So, I decided to go to the nurses’ station to ask them if they could tell me about her current state. I told them who I was and how I had known her for almost forty years. I was told at the nurses’ station that actually the morning is a very bad time of day to get her to respond because she is very, very tired. The nurse said, “But if you come during the day, she‘ll sing the Krsna song for you.” I said, “Oh, really?” Immediately I became enlivened, because I knew she was still chanting. I couldn‘t imagine Mother Isa not chanting Hare Krsna. So, I went back into the room again and I reached out for her hand, and she immediately grabbed my hand very tightly.

I said, “Mother Isa, Hare Krsna.” And she looked at me and said, “Hare Krsna, Hare Krsna, Krsna Krsna…” She chanted the whole mantra all the way through. She did this for several minutes. But we couldn‘t get her to say anything else but the maha-mantra. That‘s all she could say. We could see that she was very tired, so we decided after forty-five minutes that we would leave and try to come back some time in the afternoon.

As we were leaving the nursing home, one of the nurses saw me out of the corner of her eye – I was dressed in my robes – she was helping a group of elderly people to get into a van. She came over to me and said, “Who are you here to see?” So I said, “I am here to see Edith Graves.” She said, “I knew it. I love that woman. Everybody in this whole building loves that woman. She‘s the most peaceful person, so self contented. She never complains. Every Friday we get together and we sing patriotic songs together. And she leads everybody in a Krsna song.” The whole group of people, she just starts leading them in kirtana. She just chants Hare Krsna, and everybody just follows along and chants with her.

There was another elderly woman in a wheelchair. She was being wheeled onto the van. She immediately put her hand out and she said, “Very nice to meet you. My name is Kay. I love that woman too. That woman is a real live wire. When she starts chanting that Krsna song with such enthusiasm, everybody just has to chant. Everybody has to sing with her. Tell me, how old is she? Nobody knows how old she is.” I said, “She is ninety-five years old.” She said, “Oh.” Maybe she became very reverential when she heard that Isa was ninety-five years old. She begged us, “Please come back again.” And the other nurse said, “Please come back. You have to come and see her. Nobody has been visiting her.” So I thanked them profusely, and I told them, “Thank you for sharing these stories about Isa with me. It means so much to me. We‘ll definitely come back.”

So the devotee that came with me, it just so happened that he had to be near there on that Friday afternoon. So I told him, “You have to take a camera. I want you to take a video of Mother Isa chanting. Then you should interview everybody and ask them what they think about her.” As it turned out, there was a strict policy in the nursing home not to allow events to be videotaped. They obviously don’t allow anybody to go around and interview people on video. But this devotee took some video clips of Mother Isa chanting. She can‘t say anything from memory, except the Hare Krsna mantra. Sometimes she may repeat a word or two, but it‘s just repetition. But as soon she starts with the Hare Krsna mantra, it just comes out with such enthusiasm, with such devotion – it‘s profound.

I’m thinking that Krsna has taken away everything, but she has everything she needs for a perfect life. She doesn‘t have to think about her body, she doesn‘t complain about anything, she doesn‘t have to think about anything, because the only thing she can think about is the holy name. It‘s the only thing that comes out of her mouth. I tried to get something else, but nothing else would come, just the Holy name. So, I’m thinking that Krsna, who is in the heart, has actually rewarded her for a life of only speaking about Krsna.

I wrote the story and I put it on the internet, and devotees are writing back and leaving little comments. Sivarama Maharaja says, “If having a stroke means that all I’ll be able to say is Hare Krsna, then maybe I should have a stroke.” Other devotees are writing things like this, “Wonderful! It‘s amazing! All glories to Prabhupada! This is shocking!”

Now we are going to show this video. It‘s ten minutes. But I want you to take note what she does when the woman who is with her tries to get her to chant. When she chants, the woman and Syamarupa both say, “That‘s wonderful, Mother Isa.” Watch the expression on her face when they say, “That‘s wonderful, Mother Isa.” It‘s the same expression she would always show when everybody would try to glorify her. Because she never wanted glorification. She would always think nothing of it. She didn’t want to hear it. So when you hear, “That’s wonderful,” watch her expression. The other thing…towards the end you‘ll see such an effulgent smile. It will melt your heart. For me, it brings tears to my eyes, because she is my siksa-guru. She has always been an object of my meditation.

So, I’d like to introduce you to Mother Isa. Hare Krsna.

data.title: "Just Chant"
data.blurb: Last year I posted a blog about a studio recording I took part in, accompanied by Purusartha Prabhu, Ananta Govinda dasa, Krsna Kishore, Acyuta Gopi devi dasi, Rati Manjari devi dasi, and Akincana Krsna dasa. Hrsikesa dasa was overseeing the production.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last year I posted a blog about a studio recording I took part in, accompanied by Purusartha Prabhu, Ananta Govinda dasa, Krsna Kishore, Acyuta Gopi devi dasi, Rati Manjari devi dasi, and Akincana Krsna dasa. Hrsikesa dasa was overseeing the production.

Unfortunately there were many delays with the CD production last year due, in part, to the lack of experience the sound engineer had with recording kirtans. It was no fault on his part. He was a great person to work with and I would defintely do it again. Still, it was his first time recording the instruments of kirtan, especially mrdanga and kartals, and the way the kirtans were recorded made it difficult to properly mix some of the tracks.

With the help of Purusartha Prabhu, Bada Haridas Prabhu, and Devananda, gradually, an EP (extended play) version was produced to introduce our CD, which will be entitled "Just Chant." An extended play (EP) is a musical recording that contains more music than a single, but is too short to qualify as a full studio album. We decided to promote the CD with an EP, hoping that when the full CD is released people will already know that it's coming.

The idea to produce the CD in the first place came to mind last year because my CD's were becoming somewhat popular on digital distribution sites like iTunes, CDBaby.com, and others. data.title: My Visit to Bhaktivedanta Hospital
data.blurb: I left Mayapura on March 22nd, and then spent two days in Mumbai at Radha Gopinath Mandir. I gave an evening lecture there on the 23rd, and then early on the 24th morning I went to Bhaktivedanta Hospital, along with Madana-mohana and Devananda.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I left Mayapura on March 22nd, and then spent two days in Mumbai at Radha Gopinath Mandir. I gave an evening lecture there on the 23rd, and then early on the 24th morning I went to Bhaktivedanta Hospital, along with Madana-mohana and Devananda.

The primary purpose for my visit to the hospital was to see all the developments which the hospital has undergone since my last visit one year ago and to spend time associating with the senior devotees who have been responsible for the hospital's development ever since it was opened. I am always encouraged by the dedication these devotees have towards keeping the hospital focused not only as a hospital which provides excellent physical care for its patients, but even more significantly as a hospital which provides excellent spiritual care for anyone who enters its doors-- which makes Bhaktivedanta Hospital a major preaching force for expanding the glories of the Krsna's holy names.

I was greeted by Vishvarupa Prabhu when I arrived and then while Madana-mohana was having X-rays taken of his knee, Devananda and I were taken on a tour to see all the new developments which have come up since my last visit. After a one-hour tour and having been introduced to many of the new important staff members who have taken up the daily chanting of sixteen rounds and following the four regulative principles, we relocated to Visvarupa Prabhu's home nearby for lunch with Dwakadish Prabhu, the head physician of the hospital, with Visvarupa Prabhu, the head of the spiritual care department, with Madhavananda Prabhu, the head administrator of the hospital, with Giriraja Prabhu, the head of orthopedic surgery, with Vaisnava Seva Prabhu, also a surgeon (and in addition who is the primary force behind http://iskcondesiretree.net), and with Adi Kesava Prabhu who is the head of the dermatology department.

We talked extensively about the hospital, it's goals, and about the way they planned to expand it's various programs for spreading Krsna consciousness. As I was listening to the many stories about how people were becoming devotees by having come in contact with the doctors, nurses and staff members of the Bhaktivedanta Hospital, the thought occured to me that someone should write a book of these stories. I mentioned this to them, and they admitted that although there were so many stories which could be compiled, to date they were so busy that they were unable to compile them. I then volunteered to help them find somebody who could take up the task of interviewing doctors, staff members, patients, and family members for the purpose of putting their interviews into a book. I already have someone in mind, but since he may not be available, I would be interested to hear if any of you, my readers, might have a proposal of someone who is good at interviewing and writing. Obviously they should be fluent in Engliah and should have some training in journalism.

Another interesting point about the Bhaktivedanta Hospital is that this year, during the GBC meetings, Madhavananda Prabhu came and gave a presentation to the GBC about the goals and vision of the hospital and about the developments which have evolved over the years since its inception. At the bottom of this blog you will soon find the Power Point presentation which Madhavananda Prabhu spoke from during his presentation to the GBC. Although there is no narration, just by following each slide of the presentation you will get a good sense of what his presentation was all about. Please come back to this blog within the next 1-2 days. It should be posted there by then. Please also take note of the statistics you will find towards the end of the presentation. They are quite impressive.

After hearing Madhavananda Prabhu's presentation the GBC composed and voted upon the following GBC resolution:


A Letter of Appreciation and Commendation to the Bhaktivedanta Hospital, Mumbai

From the Governing Body Commission of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness

March 10, 2013

The Governing Body Commission (GBC) of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness (ISKCON) offers its deepest appreciation to the members and leaders of the Bhaktivedanta Hospital in Mumbai for their excellent service and dedication to His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada and his ISKCON society.

We are grateful for the high level of professional and devotional care the Hospital provides for hundreds of Vaishnavas and tens of thousands of others each year, especially for the care provided to the many senior devotees who seek your services.

We especially note the contributions of the Hospital through its spiritual care department, and its success in bringing many people to the shelter of Lord Krishna and to active engagement in His devotional service. As such, thousands of people have taken up the chanting of the Hare Krishna mantra and several hundred have taken spiritual initiation.

We also applaud the high standard of sadhana that is maintained by many of the doctors, nurses and other staff members. And, we are pleased to note the Hospital has expanded its services to Vrindavana and Mayapura.

We strongly encourage you to continue your good work. We pray for your continued success in pleasing Srila Prabhupada by serving his devotees, his ISKCON society, and all the various constituencies you so excellently serve.


Hare Krsna

data.title: A Few Words from Mayapura
data.blurb: The day after I arrived in Mayapura, the "Sanga for GBC's, Gurus, and Sannyasis" began and continued until March 2nd. Approximately 80 – 100 devotees took part in this event.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The day after I arrived in Mayapura, the "Sanga for GBC's, Gurus, and Sannyasis" began and continued until March 2nd. Approximately 80 – 100 devotees took part in this event.

During the morning and afternoon sessions all the assembled devotees heard presentations, discussed important topics concerning ISKCON's future, and developed strategies for future implementation.

B.B. Govinda Maharaja and I were requested to conduct evening kirtans every evening for all the attendees. One evening Bhurijana Prabhu was also requested to present a "lila kirtan." He did a dramatic reading of the pastime of Devananda Pandita and I accompanied him on the harmonium.

Today and tomorrow the GBC members are taking part in discussions with the "Strategic Planning Network", an assembly of more than 100 devotees. The GBC meetings will then begin on March 5th and will continue through March 10th.

This evening is the first chance I've gotten to post this short blog. Soon recordings of our evening programs will be posted in the audio section.

These recordings were made and edited by Devananda, the son of my godbrother, Purusartha dasa. Devananda has been traveling with me since the end of February and will stay with me until March 22nd at which time he will return to the United States. He recorded the programs with the same recorder I always travel with but since he has experience with audio recording and audio engineering, he tried his best to produce better quality recordings for all of you.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Classes in Radha Gopinath Mandir
data.blurb: Sunday, after the lecture, I spoke with Gauranga dasa from Radha Gopinath Mandir. Since my plan was to stay there for a few days, he asked if I would give evening classes on a particular theme to draw in congregational devotees.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Sunday, after the lecture, I spoke with Gauranga dasa from Radha Gopinath Mandir. Since my plan was to stay there for a few days, he asked if I would give evening classes on a particular theme to draw in congregational devotees. When I told him that I had been giving seminars from Bhaktyaloka about tolerating the urge to speak, he was very eager for me to deliver a series of talks on this particular topic and said that probably many devotees from the congregation would want to attend.

To my surprise, Monday evening approximately 300 devotees attended my talk. I was told that an additional 300 devotees were also watching the lecture broadcasted online. On Tuesday and Wednesday there were even more devotees attending. The response from devotees was overwhelming. At the end of the talks, so many devotees came up to thank me for giving them something so very relevant to their spiritual life. There were also so many questions it was impossible to keep up with all of them due to limited time.

I was told that after the first night's talk that some of the counselor group leaders were requesting their counselees to make sure they attended the talks on Tuesday and Wednesday. The enthusiasm for the topic was so overwhelming that I felt that it inspired me to give more in some of these talks than I had given in previous talks. Therefore, despite the fact that many of my previous lectures on this topic have already been posted, I decided to post these talks online as well for two reasons:

1) There were many questions and answers, especially on the last day.

2) These talks were given without any simultaneous translation, which means that they may be easier to digest for an English-speaking audience.

These talks will probably be available very soon in the same audio section as usual.

Hare Krsna

data.title: My Upcoming Visit to Moscow
data.blurb: This blog will be another announcement. I will not promise, but it seems to me that once I leave Moscow, I will be able to resume posting more than announcements.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This blog will be another announcement. I will not promise, but it seems to me that once I leave Moscow, I will be able to resume posting more than announcements. There are many wonderful experiences and realizations I obtain in the course of my travels as well as from reading both Srila Prabhupada's books and the books of our previous acaryas. I try my best to share them in lectures. But, from time to time, I also like to share more in blogs. I look forward to sharing these with my readers again soon. Meanwhile, here's one more announcement.

To the best of my understanding, the only days I will be attending public programs in Moscow will be on January 26th and January 27th. I believe that I will give one or possibly two lectures and that there will also be some kirtan on at least one of those evenings. And although I am now scheduled to arrive in Moscow on January 22nd, it's quite likely that the earliest I will be able to attend a morning program in Dinamo (in the way I usually do when I'm in Moscow) will be January 24th.

Although I am not a member of the Russian National Council, I have been requested to attend their meetings on January 25, 26, and 27. It is therefore also quite likely that other than the public events I will be requested to attend on the 26th and 27th and my participation of the National Council meetings, I will not be available for anything else from January 22 until January 27th

I will have two days left in Moscow after the Sunday program (January 28th and 29th). My flight leaves Moscow on January 30th. Devotees in Moscow will have to consult with Sarvajna dasa, whom I have requested to assist me during this visit in Moscow as my secretary, to find out what my schedule will be on those two days. If anyone requires a personal meeting, please fully explain the reason behind your request to Sarvajna dasa. Requests for meetings will be prioritized and therefore no confirmations can be given until January 27th.

Hare Krsna

Some devotees are having difficulties downloading audio files. The administrators are being told that the files download partially and then the download stops and will not continue. Some devotees are reporting that when listening to the audio files online, the file stops and will not continue.

It appears to the administrators that these incidences are isolated and not widespread. Most users are not confronting this problem. data.title: Where I've been and what I've been doing
data.blurb: After observing Holy Name Day in Budapest on November 18th, 2012, I spent twelve hours flying all day to New Jersey on November 19th. Today is December 4th, 2012.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
After observing Holy Name Day in Budapest on November 18th, 2012, I spent twelve hours flying all day to New Jersey on November 19th. Today is December 4th, 2012. Since devotees may be wondering where I've been and what I've been doing, I thought I should fill everyone in on the events I've been involved with over the past two weeks. Although I was quite active, I decided to take a break from recording lectures and kirtans, something which I oftentimes take responsibility to do myself.

November 22, 2012 was Thanksgiving Day in the United States. According to tradition, most Americans spend time with family that day, have a big feast on unmentionable items they call food, sit around and drink after the meal, and watch football games on television well into the evening. Also, since it's a four-day weekend, it's the biggest travel weekend of the year. On the Wednesday before Thanksgiving and on the Sunday that follows, the roads, airports, train stations, bus stations and every possible venue for travel are all heavily packed with travellers.

Anticipating the heavy traffic on November 21st, I decided to immediately relocate to Hartford the day after I arrived in Newark, New Jersey, in order to avoid the heavy congestion expected on the roads on the 21st. Unfortunately, as it turned out, it was heavy even on the 20th. What should have taken two and a half hours took almost four hours. I arrived in Hartford by early evening on the 20th, rested from all of my travels (including the jet-lag from my transatlantic flight) on the 21st and then celebrated Thanksgiving Day, November 22nd, with the Hartford devotees at the Hartford temple with a big kirtan and an amazing feast, prepared by one of ISKCON's best cooks, Jivanausadhi devi dasi. I have to confess, I broke my kichri (no-salt) diet that day and felt no regrets whatsoever.

At 4:00 AM the following morning, Pyari Mohan Prabhu and I were on our way to the airport to catch our 6:00 AM flight to Atlanta, and then our connection to Jacksonville, Florida, where we picked up our rental vehicle in order to continue to Alachua, Florida for two full days of 12-hour kirtan.

Several of the youth from the Alachua, Florida community started organizing these kirtan festivals a few years ago and this year they had contacted me several times, asking if I would be willing to take part. I had heard that these devotees had adopted a mood similar to that which we've incorporated into the Bhakti Sangama Festival in Ukraine. Although the scale of the event is not quite the same, still, wanting to encourage them in their efforts, I committed myself to take part in their kirtan event as much as I possibly could during the two full days it was held. So although they gave me a slot from 7:00 – 8:00 PM on the 23rd, and from 10:15 to 11:15 AM on the 24th, I spent most of both days just sitting and chanting with all of the assembled devotees.

I have to admit, the event was fantastic, the mood was great, the kirtans were great, and when I finally got the opportunity to talk with all the organizers on the evening of the 24th, we were really all enlivened when we all started sharing our visions and moods for hosting festivals on a donation basis only with no fixed fees. Personally I was very encouraged to see that these youth were really wonderfully motivated to facilitate kirtan at its best. They begged me to come back next year, and I'm already thinking how I can be there.

It was especially wonderful for me in Alachua because Pyari Mohan Prabhu and I spent both evenings at the home of my godbrother, Purusartha Prabhu and his wife, Tulasi dd. When we weren't in kirtans, we were in great association, discussing many philosophical issues which seemed to be enriching discussions for us all.

Early Sunday morning, Pyari Mohan and I set out for our next destination. We had an eight-hour drive ahead of us to Charlotte, North Carolina, where devotees were gathering for a Sunday program I was scheduled to give at 6:30 PM. Jagadish dasa and Savitri dd, formerly from Ukraine, now living in Alachua, prepared enough prasadam for a week-long trip. One thing Pyari Mohan Prabhu and I did not have to worry about was going hungry on the way to North Carolina. We arrived in Charlotte by 6:00 PM, and by 6:30 PM, I was leading kirtan and then gave an hour long lecture from "The Teachings of Queen Kunti." After the lecture, we chanted Damodarastakam, had another short kirtan, and then we continued another two hours to Prabhupada Village, in Sandy Ridge, North Carolina.

Prabhupada Village is not your typical rural community project. It is unique in many respects. One of the community's greatest assets is the wealth of devotional experience it has in it's members. Prabhupada Village is home to many senior disciples of Srila Prabhupada. I felt both fortunate and privileged to be given the opportunity to spend the next three days in their association, chanting with them, honoring prasadam with them, and speaking daily whatever meager realizations I could muster up to share with the already-experienced devotees living there. Although by the way each evening program was arranged, it may have appeared that I was sharing with them, but it was I who learned a lot from all of them. I pray that they will consider me their servant whenever I get the next opportunity to be with them in their community once again.

Early on the morning of November 29th, Pyari Mohan Prabhu and I set out for the 8-10 hour drive back to Jacksonville, Florida. Unfortunately, I also took along some kind of virus with me, which prevented me from holding down food for almost five days. By the time I finished my two flights back to Hartford on November 30th, I was ready to see a doctor.

On December 1st, I was told that I had an upper respiratory infection, bronchitis, a fever, and I had to immediately be put on antibiotics and other medications. Rest also became mandatory, and rest is exactly what I've been doing already for three continuous days. And although I'm supposed to leave for Boston soon, I'm already questioning whether I'm going to be able to do anything at all once I get there. That will have to remain to be seen.

Meanwhile, I have no choice. I am going to continue to rest because other than write this brief report, that's really all I can do.

Hare Krishna

data.title: Kiev Writing Retreat
data.blurb: About two months ago Sri Radha devi dasi (who is currently working on "Lectures from a Disciple – Volume 3) and I coordinated our schedules in an effort to produce this new English publication for early next year.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
About two months ago Sri Radha devi dasi (who is currently working on "Lectures from a Disciple – Volume 3) and I coordinated our schedules in an effort to produce this new English publication for early next year. Many obstacles have appeared and it is unsure at this time whether or not everything can be completed in time.

Still, in order to do what I could to meet our deadlines, I scheduled a writing retreat in New Vraja Dhama from November 13 – 18. During that time I was planning to observe Govardhana Puja and Srila Prabhupada's Disappearance Day there with the Hungarian yatra devotees and would then depart to the United States on November 19th.

To my surprise, I recently discovered that Govardhana Puja is being observed on November 11th in New Vraja Dhama. Since I am already scheduled to be in Kiev for the Counselor Retreat from November 9 – 11, I will not be able to observe Govardhana Puja in New Vraja Dhama. And if I follow my previous schedule to fly to Hungary on November 12th, I will then miss Govardhana Puja completely.

Remembering what Srila Prabhupada had written in Krsna Book at the end of Chapter 24,

"Krsna also declared at that meeting, 'One who neglects the worship of Govardhana-puja, as I am personally conducting it, will not be happy. There are many snakes on Govardhana Hill, and persons neglecting the prescribed duty of Govardhana-puja will be bitten by these snakes and killed. In order to assure the good fortune of the cows and themselves, all people of Vrndavana near Govardhana must worship the hill, as prescribed by Me.'",

I decided that if I can't worship Govardhana Hill in New Vraja Dhama, then I should stay in Kiev and engage in the worship of Giriraja there. However, in order to do this I must also keep the same schedule to work on my new book.

Therefore my schedule for Kiev will be as follows:

November 9 – 11 (Participation in the Counselor Retreat)
November 12 – 13 (Writing Retreat – no classes, no meetings)
November 14 (Writing Retreat/ participation in Govardhana Puja celebrations only)
November 15 Departure from Ukraine

Hare Krsna

data.title: The Passing of my Mother
data.blurb: Last night, October 30th, at approximately 9:20 PM, my mother breathed her last breath. By Krsna's grace, I was standing by her side, chanting a simple Hare Krsna melody, and watching her leave very peacefully. No one else was present.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last night, October 30th, at approximately 9:20 PM, my mother breathed her last breath. By Krsna's grace, I was standing by her side, chanting a simple Hare Krsna melody, and watching her leave very peacefully. No one else was present.

Reflecting on the events during the days leading up to her departure, I decided to share some of them here with my readers.

Some time on Friday, October 26th, it became obvious that my mother's pain was increasing. Since the doctors could no longer do anything to treat her, the nurses began to administer only that which would give her comfort from pain. From this point on, at least during my visits, other than saying something about "a beautiful blue sky", I did not hear anything else from her. My sister said that my mother had been talking about weather just before I entered the room. Still, the way my mother spoke those few words, I could not rule out the thought that she might have been talking about something else.

On Saturday the hospice nurses were called in to assess her condition. We were told that her "vitals" (blood pressure, heartbeat, and oxygenation) were all strong, a symptom which indicated that she could continue as she was for as long as a week or even much longer.

My flight to Europe was scheduled to depart on Monday, October 29th. By Saturday, I was of two minds. "Should I leave, or should I just stay?" I tried to call the airline to ask if my ticket could be changed, but discovered that the office I needed to speak to for that particular ticket was closed until Monday. After a short visit to the nursing home on Sunday, I decided to drive to Hartford, half-way between Boston and New York, so that I could be closer to the airport in case I was not able to rebook my ticket on Monday.

As it turned out, Sunday was also the same day that one of the largest hurricanes ever to hit the United States began barrelling through the New York area, closing all of the airports in the Northeast USA by Sunday night for an indefinite period of time. My flight was "rebooked" for me. When I finally connected with the airline, it was easy to change the date of my departure, since all the airlines were eager to rebook their passengers due to the storm.

By Tuesday morning, October 30th, the brunt of the hurricane had passed. I returned to Boston, settled a few matters and arrived at the nursing home by 7:15 PM to relieve my sister and Saranagati devi dasi so that they could go home for the night instead of staying all night with my mother. My sister had already stayed the whole night before.

Rohininandana insisted on staying with my mother on that particular night. We arranged that I would pick him up at the train station nearby. His train was scheduled to arrive at 9:26 PM. Somehow, though it could have not been anything other than Krsna's arrangement, his train was cancelled. Rohininandana texted me at 8:30, stating that he would come whenever he could get the next train. Of course I did not realize it then, but had his train not been cancelled, I would have probably left my mother by 9:10 to pick him up.

Since I no longer knew how long I would be waiting, I decided to start reading "Jaiva Dharma." Although I became very absorbed in the reading, still I would look up from time to time to see how my mother was doing. At approximately 9:15, I noticed that her breaths appeared longer than they had been. Since my sister had warned me that my mother had apnea and from time to time she would lapse in her breathing, I was unsure if this was a sign of her departure or not.

Still, not wanting to miss the opportunity, I decided to stand next to her and I just started chanting, all the time watching her breathing. Gradually, the duration of each breath seemed to be getting longer and longer. I just continued to chant. Within the next five minutes she took one very long breath and that was her last.

Although many thoughts started to surface, somehow, the most prominent was a feeling of great satisfaction. I realized that Krsna arranged everything so that I would be able to fulfill the original purpose behind my journey to be with her. Had He not intervened, as much as I had wanted to, I probably would have not been there to chant for her during the time of her passing.

Hare Krsna

After a short visit to the nursing home on Sunday, I decided to drive to Hartford, half-way between Boston and New York, so that I could be closer to the airport in case I was not able to rebook my ticket on Monday.

As it turned out, Sunday was also the same day that one of the largest hurricanes ever to hit the United States began barrelling through the New York area, closing all of the airports in the Northeast USA by Sunday night for an indefinite period of time. My flight was "rebooked" for me. When I finally connected with the airline, it was easy to change the date of my departure, since all the airlines were eager to rebook their passengers due to the storm.

By Tuesday morning, October 30th, the brunt of the hurricane had passed. I returned to Boston, settled a few matters and arrived at the nursing home by 7:15 PM to relieve my sister and Saranagati devi dasi so that they could go home for the night instead of staying all night with my mother. My sister had already stayed the whole night before.

Rohininandana insisted on staying with my mother on that particular night. We arranged that I would pick him up at the train station nearby. His train was scheduled to arrive at 9:26 PM. Somehow, though it could have not been anything other than Krsna's arrangement, his train was cancelled. Rohininandana texted me at 8:30, stating that he would come whenever he could get the next train. Of course I did not realize it then, but had his train not been cancelled, I would have probably left my mother by 9:10 to pick him up.

Since I no longer knew how long I would be waiting, I decided to start reading "Jaiva Dharma." Although I became very absorbed in the reading, still I would look up from time to time to see how my mother was doing. At approximately 9:15, I noticed that her breaths appeared longer than they had been. Since my sister had warned me that my mother had apnea and from time to time she would lapse in her breathing, I was unsure if this was a sign of her departure or not.

Still, not wanting to miss the opportunity, I decided to stand next to her and I just started chanting, all the time watching her breathing. Gradually, the duration of each breath seemed to be getting longer and longer. I just continued to chant. Within the next five minutes she took one very long breath and that was her last.

Although many thoughts started to surface, somehow, the most prominent was a feeling of great satisfaction. I realized that Krsna arranged everything so that I would be able to fulfill the original purpose behind my journey to be with her. Had He not intervened, as much as I had wanted to, I probably would have not been there to chant for her during the time of her passing.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Slight Change in Plans
data.blurb: Many of you may be aware that my mother's health started to seriously deteriorate this year. She is 90 years old, so it has not been easy for her to recover from the many issues she's had to face with her poor health.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Many of you may be aware that my mother's health started to seriously deteriorate this year. She is 90 years old, so it has not been easy for her to recover from the many issues she's had to face with her poor health.

In a phone conversation with my sister yesterday, I learned that my mother has been taken out of the hospital and will be put under hospice care. There is nothing the hospital can do for her now. When I asked my sister if she felt that my mother might be around in December during my planned visit to the United States my sister said that she felt my mother's condition has become so serious that her departure is more likely to be counted with days rather than weeks.

I gave it some thought and decided to cancel my trip to India and to go to the United States instead. Yesterday I contacted the GBC members who would be concerned about my absence from the meetings in Tirupati. Among them, I also sent a message to Sivarama Swami since I was also expecting to meet him in Tirupati.

His reply was short but reassuring. Athough I did not ask for his opinion about my decision, he took the liberty to write the following to me:

"It's the right thing to do. I hope that you are there when your mother leaves for that will be the greatest gift you can give her and will relinquish you from any debt you have to her."

I'm grateful that he reminded me of this. After reading his short message, it prompted me to look for the reference in Srimad Bhagavatam spoken by Krsna Himself to Vasudeva and Devaki. Among the other statements He made on this topic, there Krsna also says:

"Even in a lifetime of one hundred years, no son can ever repay the debt he owes his parents, from whom he receives his very body." (Srimad Bhagavatam 10.45.4)

Of course, Srimad Bhagavatam also states, and Srila Prabhupada would also often quote, that anyone who gives up material duties and takes full shelter of the lotus feet of Lord Mukunda, is not indebted to the demigods, great sages, ordinary living beings, relatives, friends, mankind or even one's forefathers who have passed away (SB 11.5.41). Still, I should not assume that this verse is speaking about me. Why should I therefore not at least try to offer my mother the gift of my presence along with my prayer? If there's a chance that it will help her to think of Krsna, then it will be well worth the effort and time I will be making and taking to go there.

If the Vaisnavas are so inclined, may they also assist me in this endeavor with their prayers for her safe onward journey.

Hare Krsna

data.blurb:

Hare Krsna

September 22, 2012

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I would like to share the following letter I received from the daughter of Nadesi devi dasi, my disciple who recently departed from this world on September 16, 2012. The letter speaks for itself.

Hare Krsna

September 22, 2012
Vladikavkaz

Hare Krishna, dear Guru Maharaja Srila Niranjana Swami!

All glories to Lord Krishna! All glories to Guru Parampara! All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

Please accept humble obeisances at the dust of your lotus feet from Nilakantha Priya dd from Vladikavkaz, an imperfect disciple of HH Gopal Krishna Goswami and the daughter of Nadeshi devi dasi.

I am praying to Lord Krishna that your health may always remain good for the pleasure of your disciples and well-wishers.

Dear Guru Maharaja, please let me share my realizations that Lord Krishna allowed me to experience in connection with disappearance of the servant of devotees, your disciple Nadeshi dd.

Nadeshidd left this material world at the age of 77 at 1.30 a.m. by Moscow time on the 16th of September, listening to maha mantra Hare Krishna. Two days before she left, September 13, she had to undergo an abdominal region surgery - the state of her physical body was critical because of duodenum ulcer perforation accompanies by weakness of her heart and lungs. Condition of Nadeshi was very critical but she always remained conscious. To satisfy devotees and relatives Nadeshi agreed to undergo a surgery, even though she didn't want to stay in her body and was sure she will leave.

Dear Guru Maharaja, after you have mercifully given Nadeshidd last instructions by phone. Lord Krishna gave her strength to bless every Vaishnava of Vladikavkaz yatra for devotional service, and she gave spiritual advice to everyone who was with her at that time.

One by one devotees entered the intensive care ward to Nadeshidd and came out with a smile and tears in their eyes. I was the last one to enter and asked Nadeshidd to bless me. She was smiling even though her heart was hardly beating. Nadeshi said: «Chant the holy name and serve devotees.

As long as Nadeshi dd remained in her body which by all medical symptoms must have suffered very much, she found some strength for spiritual association with devotees.

She didn't feel any anxiety about her leaving her body, and her last words were: "I never forget Krishna and I know that 1 am His servant." When she was told that she might not be able to bear the anesthesia she laughed as if saying: Is it the reason to worry?

When Nadeshi dd was being wheeled to surgery block, Vaishnavas were standing on both sides from her. Seeing all devotees together, Nadeshi's face beamed with a smile, and her eyes irradiated happiness. She looked completely satisfied. By the mercy of Lord Krishna as well as by your mercy, dear Guru Maharaja, at the surgery and later, at the intensive care ward next to Nadeshi there were her Deities Gaura-Nitay, Tulsi-devi, water from Radha-kund and the dust of Vrindavan.

After the surgery Nadeshi regained consciousness but she couldn't breathe independently. She was breathing with the help of artificial respiration unit and was in medication sleep. But when someone put earphones on her and Hare Krishna mantra sounds penetrated her consciousness, her face beamed with a happy smile and for a moment she opened her eyes.

Being in the intensive care wards after the surgery both devotees and medical workers were surprised by unusual things that were happening to Nadeshi. When someone told her: "You will recover", she would frown and her face would become very strict, and when she was told: "Radha and Krishna are waiting for you", she was smiling joyfully.

15th of September is birthday of Radha, thedearest grand-daughter of Nadeshi dd. Probably Nadeshi didn't want this day to be associated with her disappearance, she didn't want Radha to suffer on that day. For some minutes in the intensive care ward there was no electricity, and then Nadeshi opened her eyes and started breathing independently. Once her heart stopped, but some seconds later it started beating again. It seemed like Nadeshi was waiting for this day to be over. Nadeshi dd left her body early in the morning September 16. Krishna gently stopped her breathing and then her heart.

Devotees saw Nadeshi off just like they see Vaishnavas off, at the transcendental sounds of kirtan. Cremation of Nadeshi's body was done with merciful participation of devotees of Vladikavkaz and Rostov yatras on the 18th of September.

Ashes of Nadeshi dd will be taken to Vrindavan on the month of Kartika to finish the ceremony. Throughout her life Nadeshidd was lovingly serving not only devotees of Krishna, but all living beings who needed her care and help.

In an amazing way. old people, young children, young people and even animals were attracted to her. She gave everyone her warmth, a piece of advice and some prasadam. Serving everyone was her nature, and Nadeshidd left in the mood of a servant.

Disappearance of Nadeshi dd became for all devotees and especially for me the example of spiritual maturity and endurance. As she was leaving, Nadeshi made our yatra even more united, she encouraged devotees to be more unanimous, more sensitive and merciful. She showed how important it is to serve Vaishnavas if we want spiritual advancement in Krishna consciousness.

We can often be blind and not always can we appreciate unique character of every devotee next to us, and only his disappearance opens our spiritual vision and lets us understand simple and sacred truth.

Lord Krishna manifested special mercy towards the Vaishnava family and to the family of Nadeshi dd. He didn't allow grief and feeling of loss to dwell in our hearts. We feel only love, gratitude and sadness of separation till our next meeting wherever Lord Krishna allows to continue our service to Him.

Dear Guru Maharaja Niranjana Swami, I am grateful to you for your instructions and your spiritual participation that you gave to Nadeshidd and through her to all her family. Nadeshidd loves you very much. I am sure that you are the source of her spiritual strength and inspiration before and after she left. On her paper with Gayatri mantra she put your picture where you are a small boy. Before starting her prayer she would laugh and talk to your picture. She said that even many years later inside you there will still be this wonderful boy, cheerful and mischievous. She would always lament like a mother and would feel pain when you had problems with health. Sometimes I heard her talking to you looking at your photos. At the head of her bed there is your picture and the picture of your feet. She used to say: "These are unusual feet, they serve Lord Krishna."

Dear Guru Maharaja Niranjana Swami, disappearance of Nadeshi dd showed me that spiritual science just like any other science has theory and practice. All this time I've been only studying theory, but Lord Krishna showed that it's time to pass on to practice and check my realization. Inthe situation that I am experiencing now, you, my Guru Maharaja Gopal Krishna Goswami and Nadeshidd give me firm faith that either in this or the other world there is no other way except for serving the servants of Lord Krishna.

With sincere gratitude.

Daughter of your disciple Nadeshi dd who is trying to become a servant of a servant,

Nilakantha Priya dd

data.title: A Feast at the Airport
data.blurb: On September 22nd, Devamrita Maharaja, Radhikesa dasa, Candramauli Swami, Nagapatni devi dasi, Suresvara Prabhu, Tota Gopinath dasa and myself all flew from Simferopol to Kiev on the same morning flight.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On September 22nd, Devamrita Maharaja, Radhikesa dasa, Candramauli Swami, Nagapatni devi dasi, Suresvara Prabhu, Tota Gopinath dasa and myself all flew from Simferopol to Kiev on the same morning flight.

To our surprise, we were greeted at the airport by several devotees who had prepared a feast for our transit in Kiev. After scanning the terminal in an effort to find a suitable place to sit down and honor prasadam, we all concluded that it would probably be best to continue our search somewhere outside the terminal.

Shortly thereafter, we were all escorted about thirty meters away from the main terminal entrance where a few benches were located. After taking a quick glance at the spot, I had my doubts if it would be a suitable place for all of us to honor prasadam together. But within a couple of minutes, a gentleman sitting on one of the benches kindly offered his place to us so that the benches could be arranged facing each other, a table manifested itself a few moments thereafter (thoughtfully brought by our hosts), and we all sat down practically right in front of Terminal B for a multi-course feast.

Before everything had been served, I decided to take a quick video clip of our lunch venue. I have to admit, despite the chilly weather, it was the best arrangement for lunch prasadam I have ever experienced during an airport transit. I was very satisfied to see my godbrothers and godsister receiving the same hospitality they received in Evpatoriya at the festival. My thanks to the devotees working behind the scenes and to those who came to the airport to greet us.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Some Seminar Questions Answered
data.blurb: During the seminars I gave in Evpatoriya, questions based on my classes had been collected and submitted to me. However, due to the limited time available for each class, I did not start answering these questions until the last day.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the seminars I gave in Evpatoriya, questions based on my classes had been collected and submitted to me. However, due to the limited time available for each class, I did not start answering these questions until the last day. When it became obvious that there was still not enough time to answer questions, I announced that I would try to answer some of them here in my blog. Here are a few of them along with my answers:

Question #1) What to do if one is forcefully involved in discussing others?

Answer: Every devotee needs to discriminate between topics about others that are necessary to hear and topics that are not necessary to hear.

An example of topics necessary to hear could be if one is in a position capable of helping the devotee being discussed--- for instance, if one is accepted as a spiritual authority and is trusted by the devotee being discussed. In this case, the devotee who is speaking should speak only to those who are in that position. In other words, it should be a confidential discussion and the decision on whether the devotee under discussion can be helped or not should be left up to the person who is the spiritual authority for the devotee being discussed. In this case, it may seem that one is forced by circumstances to hear about another devotee. Still one should try to accept it as an opportunity to serve that devotee.

If one is not in a position of being able to help the devotee being discussed, then there is no need to listen to such discussions. If the speaker tries to force the topic upon the listener, then the listener should simply ask the speaker what is his/her intention for telling this to him/her and should then try his/her best to avoid hearing the unnecessary talk about others. If the devotee continues to speak anyway, one solution would be to just leave.

Of course, this answer does not cover the full spectrum of possible scenarios related to this question, but, in principle, it is a good guideline to follow for most devotees.

Question #2) What to do if one unintentionally hears discussion about others?

Answer: One should apologize to the person discussed and beg forgiveness for listening to something about him/her which wasn't necessary to hear. One should also learn from his/her mistakes in order to be better equipped to avoid such discussions in the future.

Question #3) How should we behave towards devotees who involve us in talks about others?

Answer: The answer to this question has already been given in the answer to question #1.

Question #4) What to do when devotees open their hearts to us how other devotees treated them improperly?

Answer: We should first ask him/her if it is a confidential discussion based upon a genuine desire from the devotee speaking to ease the pain in his/her heart, or, if it is a complaint about someone which is being propagated without restriction. If it's an unrestricted complaint, then this is really not "opening one's heart." One does not need to listen to it. Opening the heart means that it is spoken in confidence. By definition, "in confidence" means "the telling of a private matter in mutual trust."

But if the account is being spoken in confidence and to only one or two trusted individuals, then we should compassionately listen and try to help the devotee understand what can be learned from that experience.
