data.title: Love is in the Details (by Vrndavana Vinodini devi dasi)
data.blurb: We often hear that time is conspicuous by its absence in the spiritual world. Here at the Bhakti sangama festival, we’re all getting some realization of how this can be true. The days fly by with Krsna katha resounding everywhere and the the sweet atmosphere of loving exchanges.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
We often hear that time is conspicuous by its absence in the spiritual world. Here at the Bhakti sangama festival, we’re all getting some realization of how this can be true. The days fly by with Krsna katha resounding everywhere and the the sweet atmosphere of loving exchanges. As darkness begins to edge away the light of day, it simply serves as a reminder to everyone that it’s time for everyone to congregate in the massive pandal for the heart-melting kirtans that are yet to come.

Everything is massive and all engulfing here- the tents, the prasadam, the hospitality, the hearts of the devotees, their smiles and definitely the sound system that allows one to hear the chanting of Krsna’s names far and wide!

For a festival done on such a massive scale it would be expected, what to speak of understandable, to forget the small details. And true enough, it can be easy for any festival attendee to be caught up in the huge sounds and sights. But if one looks closely, that’s when you begin to see the hidden secret of the festival- even the details are looked after with such care and attention.

This morning I had the wonderful opportunity to witness the devotees serve out prasadam to the thousands upon thousands of devotees attending this year. Before starting anything, the leaders of the prasadam serve-out team had a quick meeting. After ensuring everyone was on track, another group of devotees ushered the thousands waiting to honour prasadam, quickly and efficiently. While this was going on, the devotee in charge of the group I was in, sweetly explained that we should serve prasadam in a courteous and friendly spirit. Intelligently utilizing a spray water bottle in place of an acaman cup, everyone’s hands, feet and heads were sprayed and we were set to go!

As devotees sat down, the serve-out teams were ready. Within seconds, thousands of devotees found sitting in front of them a bowl, spoon and cup. Every row had at least 6-7 servers who walked up and down dishing out hot oatmeal, herbal tea, bread and an apple. It was amazing to see how quickly bowls were replenished and cups were filled up. Many devotees didn’t even have to wait or ask for something more as the servers were there to anticipate their needs.

As happy devotees left the pandal, well-fed and energized for the nectar-filled day ahead of them and a new wave of devotees entered in for breakfast, I was overcome by how such a sweet mood of service had been created. Although extremely impressed by the efficiency and planning, it was this small detail of how the prasadam serve-out leader took just 2 minutes of time to explain the mood of serving out prasadam that left a deep impression in my heart.

This detail could easily be considered unimportant or skipped over in the stress or panic of feeding so many hungry vaisnavas, but it wasn’t. Just like purifying all the devotees with the makeshift acaman spray bottle, it served as an important reminder that love really is demonstrated in the details.

data.title: Thoughts about the Bhakti Sangama Festival [Written on September 16, 2011]
data.blurb: Although I am still very busy with post-festival meetings, I wish to take just a few moments to publicly express my gratitude to all the hard-working devotees who voluntarily took part in rendering background service during the Bhakti Sangama Festival 2011.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Although I am still very busy with post-festival meetings, I wish to take just a few moments to publicly express my gratitude to all the hard-working devotees who voluntarily took part in rendering background service during the Bhakti Sangama Festival 2011.

While touring the festival site, as well as the VIP guest facilities, I was overwhelmed to see how many devotees were volunteering to selflessly serve in all the different departments of the Bhakti Sangama Festival. As I was told, the attendance at this year's festival was approximately 6,000 devotees, and literally hundreds and hundreds of those who attended were also volunteer festival servants!

Without exception, every senior Vaisnava I spoke with (and I spoke to a lot), told me that the atmosphere of this festival was beyond their imagination. Many were saying that it was the best festival they ever attended. As I was overwhelmed, they were also overwhelmed to see so many Vaisnavas happily serving other Vaisnavas, so many eager devotees enlivened to hear hari-katha, and so many enthusiastic devotees, all in one place, to enthusiastically chant Krsna's names for several hours every evening.

As in all big endeavors, there will always be some flaws. But each year brings another opportunity to improve. I would just like to say "thank you" to all the devotees who, year after year, continue to make this Bhakti Sangama Festival the wonderful festival that it has become today, and I also wish to thank those devotees who served in the festival organization for the first time this year. I pray that whatever drops of inspiration you hopefully received from Vaisnava seva will inspire you to go on serving in future festivals so that more and more devotees can come to relish the wonderful taste of unmotivated devotional service.

Hare Krsna

data.blurb: I need to inform devotees who are planning to attend the Bhakti Sangama Festival this year that unlike most other years, when I usually plan to stay at the festival site one to two extra days after the festival for personal meetings, this year I am leaving Ukraine on the last day of the festival,
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I need to inform devotees who are planning to attend the Bhakti Sangama Festival this year that unlike most other years, when I usually plan to stay at the festival site one to two extra days after the festival for personal meetings, this year I am leaving Ukraine on the last day of the festival, September 22nd, very early in the morning. This means that I cannot accept requests for personal meetings as I usually do.

I realize that there will be some devotees who will still want to meet with me. My humble request, therefore, is that you please bear in the mind the following conditions which I must enforce during the Bhakti Sangama Festival:

  • I cannot attend the full morning program, give a seminar, host my godbrothers and other guests, attend evening kirtan, perform my daily exercises for my back, occasionally look in on the background organization for the festival, and accept requests for personal meetings all in the same day.
  • As the host of the festival, every day I should attend the full morning program, host my godbrothers and other guests, attend the evening kirtans, and occasionally look in on the background organization for the festival. I must also perform exercises for my back daily.
  • I should also give a seminar on most days, meet with candidates for initiation, give initiations if there are recommendations, and accept requests for personal meetings which are essential.
  • Therefore, the more requests for essential meetings that are submitted to Madana-mohana dasa, the more likely it will become necessary for me to cut back on the number of seminars I'll be able to give. Please bear this in mind when/if you submit a request for a meeting.


If you wish to request Madana-mohana dasa for a meeting with me, best that you submit your request right at the beginning of the festival— on September 16th, or the latest on September 17th. This way Madana-mohana dasa can determine which meetings are essential and we can then try to schedule them all on the same day so that I will not have to cut back on more than one seminar.

In other words please do not approach Madana-mohana dasa during the middle or at the end of the festival and tell him that you must meet with me. Anyone who does this will definitely minimize their chances for a meeting.

If you know someone who is hoping to meet with me, please draw their attention to this notice.

I need to add one additional, but unrelated, point of information. If anyone is thinking of going to Hungary after the Bhakti Sangama festival, I will not be giving any classes in Hungary at all. This has already been arranged and confirmed with the organizers of the New Vraja Dhama festival.

Hare Krsna

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This picture of Mother Isa, taken in 1974, was published in a 1974 Back to Godhead magazine article describing the dedication and devotion of those who assist Srila Prabhupada in publishing transcendental literature for the enlightenment of the whole world. It was during this time that Mother Isa was serving in the BBT in Brooklyn, New York, transcribing Srila Prabhupada's translations and purports to Srimad Bhagavatam.

My visit to Mother Isa

About two weeks ago Syamarupa dasa, Caitya Guru dasa and I drove eighty miles south of Boston to visit my godsister, Mother Isa, in southern Massachusetts. I have spoken about Mother Isa many times in my lectures. She is an amazing devotee who would only speak about Krsna and Srila Prabhupada throughout all the time I had known her (at least thirty-five years). I was very eager to see Isa again, especially since I had not seen her since 2006, shortly after the time she had a severe stroke at age 89. The stroke took away almost all of her memory.

Before continuing with this blog, please CLICK HERE to read the Vyasa Puja homage I offered to Srila Prabhupada in 2008. After reading my homage, you will have a very good background to better help you understand all that will follow.

Shortly after Mother Isa's stroke, I, along with several other devotees who knew Mother Isa, made several attempts to situate her in a place where she could be cared for by devotees. Unfortunately, we ran into many obstacles. Among them was a strong resistance from Isa's only living family member, her niece, who would not permit Isa to leave the area. After many weeks of research and inquiries on Isa's behalf, we all had to accept that Isa would have to remain where she was.

Soon thereafter we learned that Mother Isa was released from the rehabilitation hospital and was sent to a nearby assisted-living facility. I arranged for devotees to visit her from time to time and would always inquire about her whenever I visited Boston. Some time later she was put under the care of a state nursing home where she now lives.

When we arrived at the nursing home, we signed in and were then directed to a place where we could find Mother Isa. I was taken aback by her appearance, but soon remembered that she is now ninety-five years old. Time has a way changing the body's appearance, but as I was soon to observe, it can not take away the essence of the soul's yearning for Krsna.

I spent the first part of our meeting trying to establish some connection with Mother Isa, but was disappointed to find that she was extremely tired and for the most part was unresponsive to my attempts for a dialogue with her. After fifteen minutes or so, I went back to the nurses' station to tell them who I was in relation to Mother Isa and to ask them if they could tell me all they knew about her current medical state. I did not expect them to be able to tell me about her state of consciousness, knowing that they would probably not understand Mother Isa's symtoms of devotion to Krsna. Still, I explained that she seemed a lot less responsive since the last time I saw her in 2006.

I was told that mornings were not a good time for Isa and that if we wanted her to be more responsive, afternoons were always a better time to get her to speak and to hear her sing the "Krsna chant." I immediately smiled when I heard "the Krsna chant" and was relieved to learn that she still seemed to be the same Mother Isa I always knew. I couldn't imagine Mother Isa not chanting Hare Krsna. I returned to the visitor's room and tried once again to establish communication with her.

This time I held out my hand, started talking to Isa about Srila Prabhupada and Krsna and then tried to induce her to respond to the mahamantra. She gripped my hand tightly, looked very intently, right into my eyes, and started to enthusiastically chant the Hare Krsna mantra together with me two words at a time. This went on for several minutes but it appeared she was too tired for a long session with us. Though I tried to get her to say something else related to Krsna, it seemed that the only words she could speak without difficulty were the Hare Krsna mahamantra. I had hoped for a lot more, but I figured that if that's all she can remember, then what else does she really need?

After spending approximately forty-five minutes with her, we decided that it was probably best to let her rest and to just hope for a better session during another time when we could visit in the latter part of the day.

As we were leaving the nursing home, there was a vehicle for disabled persons just outside the front door. One by one, residents from the home were being carried into the vehicle in their wheelchairs. One of the nurses who worked there and who was assisting all of them saw me out of the corner of her eye. She noticed that I was dressed in robes and approached me to ask who I had come to see. I told her that I was there to see Edith Graves, which is the name Mother Isa is known by in the nursing home.


The woman immediately burst into a huge smile and exclaimed, "I knew it! When I saw your robes I knew that you must have come to see Edith! I love that woman! Everyone loves that woman! I'm so happy that someone has come to see her. You should come and see her on Friday afternoons at 2:00 PM when we are all gathered to sing patriotic songs. She leads everyone in singing the Krsna song with such enthusiasm."

But that wasn't all. Another elderly woman in a wheelchair was listening nearby. She extended her hand to me and introduced herself as Kay. With the most pleasant smile and a look filled with charm and respect she also started glorifying Mother Isa. "I love that woman too", she said. "She's a real live wire, especially when she sings that beautiful Krsna song for all of us." She went on to express her appreciation for Isa and once again confirmed that everyone who knew Isa had nothing but feelings of affection towards her. They described her as the most self-contented person in the whole building. Then she asked, "Can you tell me how old Edith is?" I told her that she was ninety-five years old. The woman smiled again and said that she was always wondering how old she was. She then asked all of us to please come back to visit again.

I thanked both of them profusely and told them that meeting them was the icing on the cake of my visit to see Mother Isa. I was leaving Isa, feeling somewhat disappointed by her lack of responsiveness. But it was now becoming crystal clear that Mother Isa was none other than the Mother Isa I always knew— taking advantage of every opportunity which came her way to induce other's to chant Krsna's name. Even at the advanced age of ninety-five, and even though she had lost all memory of her past as a result of severe stroke, she was a shining light of enthusiasm for singing the "Krsna song" to everyone without reservation.

On our way back to Boston I requested Syamarupa dasa to visit Mother Isa on a Friday afternoon in order to film her chanting during the session when everyone sings songs all together. I also asked him if he could interview other workers and residents in order to hear their words of appreciation for Mother Isa. And last but not least, I asked him to establish a clear line of communication with the nursing home so that we could be kept updated if there were any major changes in Mother Isa's state of health.

As it turned out, Syamarupa dasa was scheduled for an evening kirtan event not far from where Mother Isa resides, just three days after the day when we visited her. I gave him the video camera which Madana-mohana dasa uses for making videos of my lectures when we travel together, and asked him if he could get as much on video as he possibly could.

Unfortunately the nursing home has a strict policy which does not allow visitors to take videos of events. Syamarupa dasa was also unable to interview the residents as we had hoped. Still, he was able to take several video clips of his exchanges with Mother Isa.

Please watch the following edited version of the clips Syamarupa dasa took during his visit with Mother Isa and closely observe her. I'm amazed by her enthusiasm and especially by her spontaneity for chanting Krsna's names. She seems to be right there, in Krsna consciousness, when she is chanting, remembering nothing else but Krsna in the form of His holy names.

I find these video clips to be precious and my admiration for Mother Isa and my gratitude for what Srila Prabhupada has given to all of us has increased without limit due to my association with her.

All glories to Srila Prabhupada! All glories to Mother Isa!

Hare Krsna

I immediately smiled when I heard "the Krsna chant" and was relieved to learn that she still seemed to be the same Mother Isa I always knew. I couldn't imagine Mother Isa not chanting Hare Krsna. I returned to the visitor's room and tried once again to establish communication with her.

This time I held out my hand, started talking to Isa about Srila Prabhupada and Krsna and then tried to induce her to respond to the mahamantra. She gripped my hand tightly, looked very intently, right into my eyes, and started to enthusiastically chant the Hare Krsna mantra together with me two words at a time. This went on for several minutes but it appeared she was too tired for a long session with us. Though I tried to get her to say something else related to Krsna, it seemed that the only words she could speak without difficulty were the Hare Krsna mahamantra. I had hoped for a lot more, but I figured that if that's all she can remember, then what else does she really need?

After spending approximately forty-five minutes with her, we decided that it was probably best to let her rest and to just hope for a better session during another time when we could visit in the latter part of the day.

As we were leaving the nursing home, there was a vehicle for disabled persons just outside the front door. One by one, residents from the home were being carried into the vehicle in their wheelchairs. One of the nurses who worked there and who was assisting all of them saw me out of the corner of her eye. She noticed that I was dressed in robes and approached me to ask who I had come to see. I told her that I was there to see Edith Graves, which is the name Mother Isa is known by in the nursing home.

The woman immediately burst into a huge smile and exclaimed, "I knew it! When I saw your robes I knew that you must have come to see Edith! I love that woman! Everyone loves that woman! I'm so happy that someone has come to see her. You should come and see her on Friday afternoons at 2:00 PM when we are all gathered to sing patriotic songs. She leads everyone in singing the Krsna song with such enthusiasm."

But that wasn't all. Another elderly woman in a wheelchair was listening nearby. She extended her hand to me and introduced herself as Kay. With the most pleasant smile and a look filled with charm and respect she also started glorifying Mother Isa. "I love that woman too", she said. "She's a real live wire, especially when she sings that beautiful Krsna song for all of us." She went on to express her appreciation for Isa and once again confirmed that everyone who knew Isa had nothing but feelings of affection towards her. They described her as the most self-contented person in the whole building. Then she asked, "Can you tell me how old Edith is?" I told her that she was ninety-five years old. The woman smiled again and said that she was always wondering how old she was. She then asked all of us to please come back to visit again.

I thanked both of them profusely and told them that meeting them was the icing on the cake of my visit to see Mother Isa. I was leaving Isa, feeling somewhat disappointed by her lack of responsiveness. But it was now becoming crystal clear that Mother Isa was none other than the Mother Isa I always knew— taking advantage of every opportunity which came her way to induce other's to chant Krsna's name. Even at the advanced age of ninety-five, and even though she had lost all memory of her past as a result of severe stroke, she was a shining light of enthusiasm for singing the "Krsna song" to everyone without reservation.

On our way back to Boston I requested Syamarupa dasa to visit Mother Isa on a Friday afternoon in order to film her chanting during the session when everyone sings songs all together. I also asked him if he could interview other workers and residents in order to hear their words of appreciation for Mother Isa. And last but not least, I asked him to establish a clear line of communication with the nursing home so that we could be kept updated if there were any major changes in Mother Isa's state of health.

As it turned out, Syamarupa dasa was scheduled for an evening kirtan event not far from where Mother Isa resides, just three days after the day when we visited her. I gave him the video camera which Madana-mohana dasa uses for making videos of my lectures when we travel together, and asked him if he could get as much on video as he possibly could.

Unfortunately the nursing home has a strict policy which does not allow visitors to take videos of events. Syamarupa dasa was also unable to interview the residents as we had hoped. Still, he was able to take several video clips of his exchanges with Mother Isa.

Please watch the following edited version of the clips Syamarupa dasa took during his visit with Mother Isa and closely observe her. I'm amazed by her enthusiasm and especially by her spontaneity for chanting Krsna's names. She seems to be right there, in Krsna consciousness, when she is chanting, remembering nothing else but Krsna in the form of His holy names.

I find these video clips to be precious and my admiration for Mother Isa and my gratitude for what Srila Prabhupada has given to all of us has increased without limit due to my association with her.

All glories to Srila Prabhupada! All glories to Mother Isa!

Hare Krsna

data.title: Maya's Business
data.blurb: Just prior to my moving into the Boston temple, I had acquired a recording of one of Srila Prabhupada's lectures given in early 1973 on the "The Prayers of Queen Kunti".
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Just prior to my moving into the Boston temple, I had acquired a recording of one of Srila Prabhupada's lectures given in early 1973 on the "The Prayers of Queen Kunti". It was the only audio recording I had of Srila Prabhupada at the time, which means that I used to listen to it again and again. I often tell the story of how one quote from that lecture had a very deep impact on me and how it saved me shortly after I moved into the Boston temple. Since I've been asked about that quote many times, the following (which can be found in the "Teachings of Queen Kunti", chapter 3) is the exact quote from that lecture:


"Now here also, in this verse, Kunti continues to express herself with humility. This humility is very good in devotional service. Therefore Sri Krsna Caitanya Mahaprabhu teaches us, trnad api sunicena taror api sahisnuna: "One should be more tolerant than the tree and humbler than the grass to make progress in spiritual life." This is necessary because for one who is living in this material world there will be so many disturbances, just as if one were traveling on the ocean. One cannot expect a very peaceful situation on the ocean; even a big ship may also be unsteady, and at any moment there may be tumultuous waves. Similarly, in this material world we should always expect danger; one cannot expect a very peaceful life within this material world. The sastra, the Vedic literature, says, padam padam yad vipadam (SB 10.14.58): at every step there is danger. But if one becomes a devotee, then one can escape (mayam etam taranti te [Bg. 7.14]).

If one takes to Krsna consciousness, in the beginning there will be many disturbances caused by Maya, the material energy of illusion. Maya will test us to see how firmly we are fixed in Krsna consciousness. Because she is also an agent of Krsna, she does not allow anyone the freedom to disturb Krsna. Therefore she tests very rigidly to see whether we have taken to Krsna consciousness to disturb Krsna or are actually serious. That is Maya's business. So in the beginning there will be tests by Maya, and we shall feel so many disturbances while making progress in Krsna consciousness. But if we follow the rules and regulations and chant regularly as prescribed, then we shall remain steady. If we neglect these principles, Maya will capture us immediately. Maya is always ready. We are in the ocean, and at any moment we may be disturbed."

data.title: An Appeal from this Site's Service Coordinator
data.blurb:
The following appeal was written by Vrndavanesvari devi dasi. Since I know of no other place where she could submit it, I have copied it here in my blog.

Hare Krsna

Dear devotees,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following appeal was written by Vrndavanesvari devi dasi. Since I know of no other place where she could submit it, I have copied it here in my blog.

Hare Krsna


Dear devotees,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

My name is Vrndavanesvari devi dasi.

A few months ago all registered users were sent a survey for the "Fileshare Site of His Holiness Niranjana Swami." According to the feedback received, about 30 devotees kindly volunteered to render one or more of the services used for the fileshare site. I have been asked to coordinate those service offerings.

We are very grateful to all the devotees who volunteered their services. Unfortunately, however, we don't have a sufficient number of volunteers who can check the fidelity of English transcriptions to the original recording of Niranjana Swami's lecture and to edit the English transcriptions. Native English speakers are preferred.

If your native language is English we appeal to you. If you can check for for the fidelity of the transcriptions to the original recording, if you can edit transcriptions of Niranjana Swami's lectures or if you know somebody who can do either of these, please let me know. We need your help. My e-mail address is vrnda.nrs@gmail.com.

Editing will be done on a trial basis so that Niranjana Swami can check the edit to see if it meets his satisfaction. There are different levels of editing and although devotees may not be enlisted to do the final polish editing, still their work may be satisfactory enough to do a first edit.

Even if your native language is not English, but if you have a good command of the English language, we are also suggesting that you try to edit.

If anyone would like to offer some other service for this site, please write to me. A list of possible services can be found here:

http://niranjanaswami.net/node/5173.

Thank you very much.

Your servant, Vrndavanesvari devi dasi
- Service Coordinator

data.title: My Upcoming Visit to Moscow
data.blurb: As those of you who follow my itinerary know, I am scheduled to arrive in Moscow on September 6th on a flight from New York. However for those of you who don't know, this trip to Moscow was planned for one reason only— so that I could take part in a weekend retreat with the Moscow Sevakas.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As those of you who follow my itinerary know, I am scheduled to arrive in Moscow on September 6th on a flight from New York. However for those of you who don't know, this trip to Moscow was planned for one reason only— so that I could take part in a weekend retreat with the Moscow Sevakas. Otherwise I would have stayed a little bit longer in North America and would have gone directly to Ukraine for the Bhakti Sangama Festival.

Therefore this announcement is meant to inform the devotees in Moscow about my schedule while I am there.

I will be fully resting from my long flight from New York for the remainder of the day on September 6th until the afternoon of September 7th.

The weekend retreat will begin on September 7th and will continue until the late morning of September 9th. I will make the same request as I did for the last retreat to the organizers that if anyone comes to this retreat without an invitation they should be respectfully but firmly asked to leave the neighborhood.

I will give one public lecture only and that will be the Sunday Feast lecture on September 9th.

I have a previous commitment on September 10th which will involve my participation for the whole day. I probably will not even have time to take part in the morning program at Dinamo on that day.

September 11th is being planned by the local leaders, and I am not sure yet what is being planned for me on that day. However, I have a GBC conference call on September 11th from 2:30 PM until 4:00 PM which I must take part in. So whatever is scheduled for me on that day will have to be scheduled around that commitment.

My flight leaves Moscow on September 12th morning.

Having just now written the above, one obvious conclusion I have come to and I hope others will come to as well, is that I will not have time for any personal meetings while I'm in Moscow. I apologize for this but hopefully I will have more time on my next visit to Moscow.

Hare Krsna

data.title: New Fileshare Site Location: http://niranjanaswami.net
data.blurb: Some of you may have already noticed that this fileshare site is now in a different location (http://niranjanaswami.net). Please make a note of it.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Some of you may have already noticed that this fileshare site is now in a different location (http://niranjanaswami.net). Please make a note of it.

We would like to thank Dina Gauranga dasa, who has now teamed up with Gangambupada Prabhu, for his contribution to this endeavor. This new location is no small change. The site is now located on a server which is many times faster than the previous two servers. You should immediately experience the "feel" of this new location by observing the speed at which pages load as you browse through the site. Other operations should appear to be enhanced as well.

Previously this fileshare site was hosted on a server which provides free hosting to non-profit organizations. However, in recent times, it was becoming increasingly obvious that there were too many limitations with the old service. Many of you may have also experienced problems with page errors, slow loading, and other similar events.

After observing these problems, Dina Gauranga dasa volunteered to sponsor the rather high cost of this new server. Moreover, over the course of the next couple of months both he and Gangambupada Prabhu will be re-designing the site, giving it a new look and feel along with new enhancements for all users. If any of you feel inclined to help defray the cost of this new server, you may contribute by donating here on the home page in the "Donate" section.

Additionally, if you happen to type into your browser either of the old addresses (http://nrs.iskconboston.org or http://fileshare.niranjanaswami.org), you will automatically be redirected to the new server. However, it is recommended that you begin using http://niranjanaswami.net as soon as you can make the change.

In this connection, Gangambupada Prabhu has requested that if any of you are managing any websites, facebook pages, or other pages on other social media sites containing links to this fileshare site, then it would be helpful if you could update those links with this new link (http://niranjanaswami.net). Or if you know anyone who has links to this site on their website or social media page, then if you could kindly contact them with this request it would be very helpful.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Vyasa Puja Offering
data.blurb:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.

During the months of May/June, 1972, you wrote individualized letters to several disciples containing the same theme.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.

During the months of May/June, 1972, you wrote individualized letters to several disciples containing the same theme.

"Now I want that we shall concentrate on making our devotees Krishna conscious and ourselves becoming Krishna conscious, and not be so much concerned with expanding ourselves widely but without any spiritual content. Just like boiling the milk, it becomes thicker and sweeter. Now do like that, boil the milk." (Letter to: Rupanuga -- Honolulu 9 May, 1972)

Not long after these letters were written, a guest began visiting your temple in Boston. Little did he know at the time that this was your mood. Neither was this ever discussed. As far as he knew, Krishna consciousness was still expanding widely, and the clarion call to recruit many more soldiers into Lord Caitanya's Sankirtan army was gradually drawing another recruit into its ranks. His name—or as he was called then—was "Bhakta Neal".

Now, exactly forty years later, this same recruit (known now as Niranjana Swami) is just beginning to realize that the condensed milk preparation you wanted to make at that time still needs more boiling, especially because he, somehow or other, was added into the preparation even though you wanted only to turn up the flame.

"You can thin milk by adding water and you can make it thick by boiling. Now is the time for us to begin the boiling process." (Letter to: Damodara -- Honolulu 9 May, 1972)

Srila Prabhupada, you are the best cook ISKCON has ever known and with your own hands you personally taught disciples how to cook for Krishna's pleasure.

"On the Tuesday afternoon, at the request of Tusta Krishna, Prabhupada entered the kitchen to show a couple of the ladies how to cook milk sweets.[…]

[…]Prabhupada poured a couple of litres of milk into a wide pan, added sugar and brought it to a rapid, rolling boil. Stirring methodically, he condensed the sweetened milk until it reached a creamy, sauce-like consistency. Lowering the heat, and stirring more firmly, he further reduced the mixture to a very thick, dark cream-coloured sticky paste that started to pull away from the sides.

Prabhupada then scraped the milk fudge onto the side of the pan. It was done. Now the burfi, when cooled, could be rolled into balls, or pressed into a tray and cut into squares, ready to offer to Radha and Krishna." (The Great Transcendental Adventure by Kurma dasa)

Srila Prabhupada, ISKCON is one of your preparations still requiring your attention. I know because I am that Niranjana Swami who slipped into your movement even though you warned that no more recruits should come until everyone was more perfectly trained.

[…]We may thin the milk till it becomes useless, or we may boil it until it becomes thick and sweet, so now we have got enough followers, let us train them up perfectly in the philosophy and activities of Krishna Consciousness way of life. " (Letter to: StokaKrishna -- Los Angeles 20 June, 1972)

I'm not sure why you allowed me to join despite my lack of qualifications. Neither can I understand why you accepted me as your disciple very shortly thereafter. Both of these events can only be explained as your unlimited and causeless mercy and my gratitude for this knows no bounds. I did not deserve to be trained in the way that you called for it forty years back.

I am sorry to confess this to you, but after forty years in your service, I am still not fully trained. Due to my own causeless unwillingness to surrender, I have been unable to fully embrace all that you came to give us.

On this most auspicious day of your divine appearance in this world, I beg you. Please continue this boiling process with me and never stop training me up "in the philosophy and activities of Krishna Consciousness way of life". Help me to become "thick and sweet" and don't allow me to water down your mission any longer.

Some day, whenever you deem fit, please allow me to truly follow in your footsteps and cook very condensed sweets, making each of them ready to be offered to the lotus feet of Radha and Krishna.

Your faithful servant, always in need of the dust from your two lotus feet,

Niranjana Swami

Yesterday, my first day in Ottawa, I was told that the devotees here were not expecting any programs so that I could rest from my long day of traveling the day before. Dina Gauranga dasa and I drove more than nine hours from Hartford to Ottawa, including a small unexpected delay prior to our border crossing from USA to Canada. Since I did not write a Vyasa Puja offering to Srila Prabhupada for publication in this year's Vyasa Puja book, I gratefully accepted the kind offer to rest and instead spent a good part of the day writing my offering.

Vyasa Puja is on August 10th in North America. However, Vyasa Puja is on August 11th in East Europe. I would like to share my offering with devotees on Srila Prabhupada's Vyasa Puja day, but I also would like to humbly request that you that it be read only on the same day as Srila Prabhupada's Vyasa Puja.

I will therefore post my Vyasa Puja offering in English early tomorrow morning, August 10th, according to USA Eastern Standard Time. If anyone in North America would like to read it tomorrow or if you would like to have it read during the time of your Vyasa Puja offerings in your local temple, it will be available to you here tomorrow in English.

Meanwhile, Madana-mohana dasa is translating my offering into Russian today. Tomorrow evening, August 10th, (again USA Eastern Standard Time), the offering will be posted here in Russian.

Madana-mohana dasa will also post the Russian version of my offering on the NRS Disciples Conference some time tomorrow.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Regarding Lecture Transcriptions
data.blurb: I am aware that in the past devotees have transcribed lectures of mine and have disseminated either soft or hard copies of these transcriptions to others.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I am aware that in the past devotees have transcribed lectures of mine and have disseminated either soft or hard copies of these transcriptions to others.

As far as I know, this is not being done anymore. But just so that everyone understands my reasoning for this policy, I would like to briefly explain everything here. By doing so, it is my hope that devotees will have a better understanding of why there is a policy. It is also my hope that those who do have this inclination or who have had this inclination in the past will not feel that their desires to make these transcriptions available or not appreciated by me. I appreciate it very much. Still, based upon my observations of this in the past, I must set some clear policy down in writing for now and in the future.

First of all, the Russian division of Gauranga Press, the publisher who publishes all of my books in Russian, is managed by Yugala Piriti devi dasi. She oversees all lecture transcriptions which are published in my books. She is fully conversant with my policy and knows my wishes in this regard. If anyone ever has any questions about my policies, even after reading this blog, they can contact her at the address found in the front of my books and I am confident that she will be able to help.

Besides Gauranga Press, however, currently there are also transcribed lectures posted on fileshare.niranjanaswami.org. These Russian translations are not reviewed by Gauranga Press, but still every transcription, whether published in books or on fileshare.niranjanaswami.org follows a similar procedure.

Every lecture transcription is first done in English based upon the words I have spoken (not the translator's words). After they have been transcribed (and in some cases also edited) they come to me to be checked for accuracy before they can be published in books or on the site.

Generally, for all transcriptions made for posting on fileshare.niranjanaswami.org, I find numerous mistakes. Some of them are very serious mistakes, including words that I did not say and which give a whole different meaning to the point being made.

Moreover, it is also possible that my translator may have said something inaccurate, which means that a direct transcription of the Russian translator can also be inaccurate. Of course, Madana-mohana is usually very meticulous in his translation because he has been translating my lectures for so many years. Still, because it is a spontaneous translation, it may not be the exact way I stressed a particular point.

I realize that if there is an inaccuracy in the Russian translation on an audio file which has been posted on my site, it can be perpetuated in the audio file. But at least my English is also right there if anyone wishes to cross-reference something which may not be clear. But when something is put into writing, in black and white, and when it's only in Russian, the mistake carries far more weight. Once it's in writing, it's there in perpetuity.

Therefore I humbly request that if anyone has transcriptions of my lectures which were not first transcribed into English and then checked by me, please do not disseminate them. You may certainly keep them for your own reference. But they should not be used for anything else.

Thank you very much.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Initiations at Bhakti Sangama Festival
data.blurb: I'm posting this message more than two months ahead of the Bhakti Sangama Festival so that devotees being recommended for initiation at the festival can have adequate time to humbly and respectfully request their counselors to submit a current report about them to the counselor report database.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm posting this message more than two months ahead of the Bhakti Sangama Festival so that devotees being recommended for initiation at the festival can have adequate time to humbly and respectfully request their counselors to submit a current report about them to the counselor report database.

My general experience each year at the time of these initiations is that very few devotees being recommended have reports already submitted into the database about them. This slows down the process of reviewing the recommendations and speaking to the candidates being recommended.

I understand that in most places, and for most gurus, the written recommendations are all that is expected for receiving initiation. But considering that most candidates being initiated by me have been waiting a minimum of five years since they began chanting sixteen rounds a day and following the four regulative principles, I would like to know more about the candidates before speaking to them than what can be found in a signed recommendation form.

Some counselors encourage their counselees to hand me a hard copy of their own report about themselves and that is certainly better than no report at all. I am grateful to have those reports and to be able to read them upon receiving them. I would like to encourage more devotees to do that.

But it is also important to me to have a reports submitted by these devotees' counselors. I am therefore asking here for both personal reports and for reports about initiation candidates from their counselors.

I am also aware that in yatras other than Ukraine and Moldova devotees are being recommended for initiation who do not have any counselor. It is unfortunate if it happens that way, but I have no control of the management in most of these yatras. I have to comply with the standards they follow for recommending new candidates for initiation.

I must also expect that most temple authorities have neither the time nor the inclination to write reports about the devotees they are recommending. I have good reason to expect this because only rarely will a temple authority give me a written report about a devotee aspiring to be initiated by me. Again, I cannot control these things and I just accept this and respect that these temple authorities have more important priorities to attend to than to write reports about initiation candidates in their yatra.

But for devotees serving as counselors, it seems more reasonable for me to expect reports from them, since for many counselors, counseling is their main service.

Please, therefore, make it known to all those concerned that I am hoping to see more reports come in between now and the Bhakti Sangama Festival.

Those counselors who have already submitted reports to the database already know the procedure for this. The procedure has not changed. You already have direct access to post this information and all that follows does not apply to you. You don't even need to read any further.

But for those counselors who have never posted reports into the database, then the procedure for gaining access to the database is to first go to the following URL by either clicking on it or by cutting and pasting the link into your browser:

http://niranjanaswami.com/contact-2

The database managers have a list of authorized counselors. If your name is on that list, you will then be sent further information explaining where you can submit your list of counselees. Once your list of counselees has been processed, you will then get access to the database and a small manual will be sent to you explaining how to enter your reports.

If your name is not on the list, then you will directed to the link where you will be asked to provide more information which will help the database managers continue with the verification process.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Srila Prabhupada story recently shared with me by my godbrother, Tejiyas Prabhu
data.blurb: Srila Prabhupada visited the Hyderabad farm for two weeks during December 1976. He had a lot of hope for the project and had assigned three managing trustees--Mahamsa Swami, Hamsaduta Swami, and myself--to get it going.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Srila Prabhupada visited the Hyderabad farm for two weeks during December 1976. He had a lot of hope for the project and had assigned three managing trustees--Mahamsa Swami, Hamsaduta Swami, and myself--to get it going. Unfortunately, due to miscommunication, paranoia, and a desire for control, there were big misunderstandings building up between Mahamsa Swami and the two of us.

Srila Prabhupada tried to mediate, sometimes jolting me with statements such as "Do not be bureaucratic" and even instructing me to "go out in back, fight it out with Mahamsa like cats and dogs, finish this up, and get the project going." We all felt frustrated and wanted a solution, but we were not talking with each other.

One day, looking for solace, direction, and inspiration, we all--separately but at the same exact moment--reached the door to Srila Prabhupada's room. When we entered, we were astounded by what we saw: The sun was shining through the window, bathing Srila Prabhupada with golden-white rays. His eyes were firmly closed but without strain or tightness. He sat upright behind his desk, on his cushion, his right hand in his bead bag. You could see how attentively he was fingering the beads, and you could hear their clacking as he rubbed them between his fingers. You could even see the bag's cloth rustling around them. His face was serene, but there was every indication that he was fixed in hearing the holy name. As he chanted--Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna, Krishna Krishna, Hare Hare/ Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rama Rama, Hare Hare--his tongue rolled in his mouth and his lips moved in a circle. He seemed to be tasting something delicious, chewing it with care to savor every bit. His chanting was quite distinct; the words were clear and articulate, and he pressed down on each syllable. His head swung slightly side to side with a bit of an up-and-down movement.

Simultaneously, all three of us thrust our hands into our bead bags and joined His Divine Grace in japa. At least for the moment, we were united and transcendent to our differences. Together, as brothers, we watched him with wide-open eyes, delighting in this rare vision. After some time, Srila Prabhupada opened his eyes for a moment and without moving his head looked gently but seriously at us, one after the other, and pronounced, "Just go on chanting and all your problems will be solved."

data.title: Regarding lectures given on June 29 and 30
data.blurb: Two talks given on June 29 and June 30 will be posted soon onto the site. Both talks were given to all the leaders who assembled for the Ukrainian National Council meeting from June 28 – July 1 in Magdalinivka.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Two talks given on June 29 and June 30 will be posted soon onto the site. Both talks were given to all the leaders who assembled for the Ukrainian National Council meeting from June 28 – July 1 in Magdalinivka.

It's important for anyone who listens to the June 29th presentation to also listen to the Srimad Bhagavatam class I gave on June 30th (S.B. 5.18.9). Although the talk I gave on June 30th was more of a presentation (with questions and answers) than a class, the Srimad Bhagavatam talk was an actual lecture on a verse selected to complement the presentation which was given the day before.

I have observed that information can oftentimes be redistributed in a way which defeats the whole purpose for giving the information in the first place. As aspiring devotees we all need to improve the art of effective preaching. This lecture touches upon this point in a (hopefully) relevant way for anyone desiring to help bring others closer to guru and Krishna.

Hare Krishna

data.title: Itinerary Update
data.blurb: Unfortunately, due to circumstances beyond my control, my itinerary for late June and July must be adjusted in order to comply with the procedures I need to follow for securing my religious visa in Ukraine.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Unfortunately, due to circumstances beyond my control, my itinerary for late June and July must be adjusted in order to comply with the procedures I need to follow for securing my religious visa in Ukraine. The Ukrainian laws were changed earlier this year and I was not made aware of these changes until the same day I applied for my visa.

Please therefore take note of the new itinerary:

June 29 – July 1 Magdalinivka

[Please note that the National Council Meeting in Magdalinivka is for invited Ukrainian leaders only!!! Anyone arriving in Magdalinivka who was not invited to participate in this event by the appropriate authorities will be respectfully, but firmly, asked to leave. I humbly request everyone's cooperation in this regard.]

July 2 – 3 Dnepropetrovsk
July 5 – 6 Donetsk
July 7 Mariupul
July 8 Donetsk
July 10 Lugansk

Obviously, I did not originally plan my schedule this way. I was planning to stay a little longer in each city I visited. But, for whatever reason, Krishna has now arranged things differently for me. Hopefully all of us will be able to adjust our plans accordingly.

If you are from any of the above-mentioned cities and you were hoping to request for a personal meeting with me, please forgive Madana-mohana dasa if he has to explain to you that it will not be possible for him to fulfill your request. He will have to be strict so that I can meet all priorities the leaders will be requesting of me. There will therefore be very little time for personal meetings in these cities.

My schedule from July 11th until the time I'll leave Ukraine for the Lithuania Festival (the opening day of the festival is July 16th) is not clear. However, wherever I will be, there will be no programs and no personal meeting requests will be accepted.

Hare Krishna

data.title: Sharing Some Thoughts and Memories about My Trip to Bologna
data.blurb: I have a two-hour transit in Munich Airport on my way back to Budapest from Bologna today. I thought I would take advantage of the available time here to say a few words about my visit to Bologna.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I have a two-hour transit in Munich Airport on my way back to Budapest from Bologna today. I thought I would take advantage of the available time here to say a few words about my visit to Bologna.

As many of you probably know, I try to visit Bologna every year to spend time with my godbrother Trai Prabhu and his wife Krsnaloka dd. Although while I'm there, I take part in other events, the primary reason I go there is because Trai Prabhu is there. I'm always happy to be with him, to chant with him, and to discuss Krsna consciousness with him. One of the topics we talked about today was about the importance of inspiring the second generation of devotees to appreciate, hear from, and serve senior devotees other than their own initiating spiritual masters. Trai Prabhu asked me to speak on the topic, "What is Our Karma Teaching Us and How to Learn from Our Mistakes." More than fifty guests attended the program. Everyone was listening so attentively to the talk that I did not want to stop. Questions continued for at least another half-hour after the talk. We then had a very enthusiastic kirtan, followed by an opulent "Italian" feast of lasagna, bread, and many other tasty preparations (I heard they were very tasty but unfortunately I was not able to experience it for myself). During the feast many guests gathered with Trai and myself to ask more questions about Krsna consciousness.

In Bologna, Trai Prabhu organizes a Saturday lecture and feast for the local Italian people and on Sunday there is a Sunday Feast and lecture organized by Bangladeshi devotees for the Bangladeshi devotees and congregation. Hare Krsna

data.title: My visit to Kiev from May 13 - 21
data.blurb: Anticipating my upcoming visit to Kiev from May 13 – 21, I thought it would be best to outline my plans for it here in this blog so that devotees can make their plans accordingly.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Anticipating my upcoming visit to Kiev from May 13 – 21, I thought it would be best to outline my plans for it here in this blog so that devotees can make their plans accordingly.

Before I do that, however, I feel I should inform everyone that I originally planned my visit to Kiev between May 13 – 21 because Sridama and Kisori were scheduled to be in Kiev during that time. Moreover the counselor retreat was also scheduled from May 18 – 20. On that basis, my schedule before and after Kiev had been built around my May 13- 21 commitment in Kiev. However, the counselor retreat was cancelled when it became obvious that Sridama and Kisori would be unable to secure visas to Ukraine this year. By that time, it was too late to change my other plans, so I kept my scheduled visit to Kiev. Had I known about the retreat cancellation earlier, I probably would have come to Ukraine at the end of May and would have just stayed in Ukraine to visit other cities immediately after Kiev.

Now that the counselor retreat has been cancelled, I have decided to use some of my time in Kiev to work on GBC-related matters. This work will likely require at least 2-3 full days of my time.

Also, for those of you who aren't aware of the existence of my online itinerary, I thought I should also mention what my plans are for the other cities in the Ukraine region this summer:

May 31 – June 7 (Kishinev, Beltsi, Tiraspol)
June 10 – 13 (Simferopol)
June 25 – 28 (Dnepropetrovsk)
June 29 – July 1 (National Council Meeting in Magdalinivka)

[Please note that the National Council Meeting in Magdalinivka is for invited Ukrainian leaders only!!! Anyone arriving in Magdalinivka who was not invited to participate in this event by the appropriate authorities will be respectfully, but firmly, asked to leave. I humbly request everyone's cooperation in this regard.]

July 3 – 11 (Lugansk, Donetsk, Mariupul)
September 13 – 22 (Kiev, Bhakti Sangama Festival)
October 8 – 11 (Kharkov)

Here is an approximate schedule of my Kiev visit:

May 13 (Arrival) (I may or may NOT give the Sunday Lecture, depending on how rested I am when I arrive) (Evening Bhajans and Kirtans)
May 14 – 15 (GBC work)
May 16 (Meetings and Evening Bhajans)
May 17 (Meetings and the rest of the day reserved for finishing GBC work)
May 18 (Meetings/ Evening program)
May 19 (General Meeting (Details to be anounced later)/ Evening program)
May 20 (Sunday Feast lecture/ Evening Bhajans and Kirtans)
May 21 (Departure from Ukraine)

If you are from any of the above-mentioned cities and you are hoping to have a personal meeting in Kiev, unless you have been personally invited to meet me in Kiev by Madana-mohana dasa, there will be no guarantee that you will be given time for a personal meeting. Better to wait and ask for a meeting when I visit your city. All other devotees with meeting requests should contact Madana-mohana dasa with your request by May 14th, the latest. Please make it clear why you are requesting a meeting.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Weekend Sevaka Retreat
data.blurb: I'm sorry to have to post a message of local concern to such a broad-based audience, but I know of no other way to get the following message out to devotees presently in the Moscow region.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm sorry to have to post a message of local concern to such a broad-based audience, but I know of no other way to get the following message out to devotees presently in the Moscow region.

This weekend I will be attending a three-day retreat (outside Moscow) organized exclusively for Sevakas. In a discussion this morning with the retreat organizers, I was made aware that the facilities for this retreat are very limited. In fact, we even had to apologize to some of the Sevaka candidates who were invited, for not being able to facilitate their participation this time.

I am therefore making the following humble request. Unless you were invited (and those who were invited know who they are) please do not attempt to visit this retreat. I have instructed the organizers that if anyone tries to participate whose name was not on the invitation list, they should be respectfully, but firmly, asked to leave, not only the property, but also the neighborhood.

Thank you very much.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Service Opportunities
data.blurb: Recently a survey was sent out to all registered users of this site. The data will be compiled and an effort will be made to incorporate many of the survey's results and other suggestions devotees made for improving the site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Recently a survey was sent out to all registered users of this site. The data will be compiled and an effort will be made to incorporate many of the survey's results and other suggestions devotees made for improving the site. If you did not take part in this survey and wish to do so now, you can find it at the following URL:

http://kwiksurveys.com?s=LLIOGG_9e010e47

The survey will remain open for at least several more weeks.

According to the information gathered so far, there has been a large response to the last question of the survey which asked if devotees would like to participate in providing material for the site. I was very happy about this. There are now plans on how more devotees could realize their proposals for service.

The following is the list of services which have been offered so far:

Transcribing lectures into English
English editing
Fidelity checking the English to the original recording
Translating English subscriptions to Russian
Compiling Lecture summaries in English
Compiling lecture summaries in Russian
Russian editing
Audio enhancement
Photo enhancement
Providing photos
Filming lectures and providing them for upload
Compiling daily quotes
Archiving lectures into topics
Promoting the site among devotees

Before we can incorporate all of the above-mentioned services into the site, Madana-mohana dasa needs to find a coordinator, or someone who can take full responsibility to

  1. Communicate with these volunteers.
  2. Assign responsibilities based upon the skills of each volunteer.
  3. Coordinate those with similar services to insure that everyone has an equal opportunity to perform their service.
  4. Systematically organize their contributions.


This would be a voluntary service which would require the following qualifications:

  • Must be a good and punctual communicator
  • Must be conversant in both English and Russian
  • Must have organizational skills
  • Must have reliable internet access
  • Must have time available at least once a day to check and answer all correspondence connected to this service
  • Must be patient, tolerant, humble and respectful in their dealings with others
  • Must have the following computer skills:
    • Email
    • Sufficient knowledge to upload and download files
    • Sufficient knowledge to compress (zip) and uncompress (unzip) files
    • Website management skills are not required (the coordinator will not be required to deal with any adminstrative responsibilities connected to the site)


Anyone interested in applying for the above service can contact Madana-mohana dasa (mm@pamho.net) with a short summary of your experience, a short explanation on why the service interests you, and to set up a day and time when you could speak with him.

Hare Krsna

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This blog is intended to both acknowledge and to thank the many devotees from all over the former Soviet Union who have been donating to a fund managed by devotees in Moscow.
This fund primarily helps to cover the cost of my (and Madana-mohana dasa's) traveling expenses.

No one has asked me to write this blog. I'm writing it of my own choice. However, I will admit, I have mixed feelings about writing this for reasons which I will now explain.

On one hand, it is proper to make it known to everyone donating that their donations have been received. Naturally, it is also proper to thank them since I am undoubtedly grateful. On the other hand, I've had to ask myself, "Why acknowledge and thank only those devotees whose names have been compiled along with their donations? What about the many devotees who hand their donations to me in the course of my travels?" (Unfortunately it is impossible for me to keep track of every person who donates when I travel.) Furthermore, and definitely no less important, "What about the many devotees who are sacrificing the accumulation of personal income to serve in other capacities? Shouldn't they be recognized too? Why should I risk minimizing the sacrifices of those who maintain strong sadhana, who maintain home worship, and who reduce their time and energy spent earning their means of livelihood so that they can serve in these and in so many other capacities, by making it appear that I am placing greater importance on donations received than other services?" The answer to all of these questions is that I shouldn't. And that's why I've hesitated to publicly thank everyone who has donated to the above-mentioned fund in Moscow.

Still, because I do have an easily accessible list of their names, I want to acknowledge receipt of these donations and to thank these devotees. But I also humbly submit, please do not think that I do not recognize the other valuable services rendered by those devotees whose names will not appear in the following list. I do have that list. But since it's in my heart (and not in my computer) it's not as easy to post in a blog. I therefore also wish to thank all of you here.

data.title: Visit to Russia
data.blurb: I've been asked what my plans are for Moscow, Kursk and Tomsk. I would have liked to post something in response to that question before this, but I had not yet received word from the leaders in Moscow what they wanted from me.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I've been asked what my plans are for Moscow, Kursk and Tomsk. I would have liked to post something in response to that question before this, but I had not yet received word from the leaders in Moscow what they wanted from me. I just received this information a few days ago.

In principle (not only because it is my principle, but also because as I understand, it is a fundamental principle within ISKCON) it is the responsibility of any visiting preacher to serve the interests of the yatra he/she is visiting by first inquiring from the local leaders, "Do you have any wishes how I may serve while I'm here?" I always try to uphold this principle beyond any preferences of my own. In some temples I ask upon my arrival. But in temples such as Moscow, because it is such a big yatra and a place where I could potentially be pulled into many directions, I usually ask before I go.

I will therefore first give my schedule for Moscow and I will then explain what I believe could happen in Kursk and Tomsk. Please also take into consideration that the morning programs (as I usually follow them), personal meetings on many or most days (which are supposed to be scheduled in consultation with Madana-mohana), and my own health limitations (which cannot always be predicted) must be factored into each of these schedules as well.

Moscow:

April 19th – Arrival
April 20th – Some prearranged meetings
April 21st – General meeting with disciples (11:00 – 14:00 Botanicheskiy Sad)
April 22nd – Sunday Feast Lecture together with Bhakti Vijnana Goswami (16:00)
April 23rd – Meeting with new Sevaka candidates (depending upon the number, this could take many hours)
April 24th – Meeting with Governing Body of Dynamo Temple and New Temple Project
April 25th – Meeting with Sevaka Board (11:00 – 14:00 – Dynamo)
April 26th – Meeting with brahmacaris
April 27th – Relocating outside Moscow for a three-day retreat with Moscow Sevakas
April 28th – 30th – Retreat
May 1st – Congregation program for Moscow Sevakas, nama-hatta and bhakti-vrksa leaders
May 2nd – Departure for Kursk

Beyond this, depending upon the number of requests for personal meetings, it is quite possible that there will be at least one or two evening programs. But I can neither promise nor predict when (or if) these will take place.

Kursk:

I have not contacted Nitai Caitanya Goswami yet for his proposals for my visit. Since I expect that he will be in Moscow at some point during my visit there, I was planning to discuss it with him then. However, May 5th is Nrsimha Caturdasi and as I understand, it is also planned as the temple opening of our new temple in Kursk. Moreover it is my first visit to Kursk in probably more than ten years. And since I am a co-GBC in Kursk and the rest of Central Moscow Region where Nitai Caitanya Goswami is the Regional Secretary, and since Nitai Caitanya Goswami is generally inclined to approach me for assistance with the affairs of that yatra during my visits, it's possible I will be asked to take part in local and also regional concerns during some of the other three days that I will be there. Of course, I will still also give classes on most days of my visit, but I do not know to whom I will be speaking.

Tomsk:

Since tickets have not been booked to Tomsk yet, it's difficult to say right now what my schedule will be while I'm there. It's quite possible that it will be a late-night flight to Tomsk on the 8th and a morning return flight on the 12th, which will leave me approximately 2.5 days in Tomsk. But my schedule for Tomsk will not be known until Madana-mohana discusses it with Sadhu Swami some time later this month.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Health Update
data.blurb: When the doctor came to look at my ankle today, we decided that we will not seek the help of a surgeon to deal with the infection.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
When the doctor came to look at my ankle today, we decided that we will not seek the help of a surgeon to deal with the infection. By elevating my leg, taking medication to promote better circulation, applying compresses daily, resting, and ultimately, by the will of Lord Krsna,

[balasya neha saranam pitarau nrsimha
nartasya cagadam udanvati majjato nauh
taptasya tat-pratividhir ya ihanjasestas
tavad vibho tanu-bhrtam tvad-upeksitanam (SB 7.9.19)]

the swelling has gone down and the infection has significantly reduced. Today I was even able to get around a little more than I've been able to do for the past 4-5 days.

By Krsna's grace, I've had a lot of time to read some books which I've been waiting for the right time to read. I also began watching the "Following Srila Prabhupada" series again. I am so grateful to Yadubara Prabhu for these priceless treasures.

Today I watched Srila Prabhupada as he danced throughout the entire London Rathayatra ending in Trafalgar Square in 1973 and listened to the many commentaries devotees who were present at that time gave. I then listened to (and watched) one of my favorite stories when Srila Prabhupada was received in Paris by the mayor and other local dignitaries. I could summarize the story, but you have to watch the expression on the people's faces and listen to the commentary in order to fully relish the pastime.

Additionally, I had been reading the material which the "Devotee Care Committee" produced for the "ISKCON Leadership Sanga" in Mayapura this year. Revati Raman dasa, the Chairman of that Committee had gifted me with two beautiful publications which were produced by their committee. I read a lot from both of them, but since I also had a meeting yesterday with two senior counselors in Hungary, I decided to pass the material on to them.

At this point in time, it's difficult to say whether I will be able follow through with my upcoming travel plans to Bologna or not. It should be clearer within the next 2-3 days.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Update
data.blurb: When I arrived in Budapest on March 28th, I had been traveling for thirty consecutive hours from Taiwan to Beijing to Frankfurt and finally to Budapest.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
When I arrived in Budapest on March 28th, I had been traveling for thirty consecutive hours from Taiwan to Beijing to Frankfurt and finally to Budapest. I got a chance to rest the remainder of the 28th, but the next day I had to drive more than six hours to a pre-scheduled appointment in Kaposvar to reapply for my Hungarian residency permit. We stopped first in New Vraja Dhama where I received a beautiful darshan from Sri Sri Radha Syamasundara, greeted many of the New Vraja Dhama residents, took lunch and then continued on to Kaposvar for my appointment. After the appointment, I returned to New Vraja Dhama briefly to rest and then returned to Budapest by late evening.

Since March 26th, I had been tolerating a reoccurring problem with my ankle. From time to time it swells and becomes infected. This has happened about four times over the past nine months. Generally if I tolerate it, rest it, soak it, and if necessary, use compresses which help it to drain, the problem goes away within a week's time. But with all of the traveling and after Friday night's harinama this time it looked more serious than in the past.

Yesterday a doctor came to look at it and expressed concern. I was told to stay off my feet. We tried using a compress overnight, I took some medication, and today there seems to be some improvement. Today a new compress was applied. I was recommended to continue to stay off my feet as much as possible, to keep my leg elevated, and rest. If it continues to improve, I may be up and around within the next few days. If it doesn't continue to improve, other measures will need to be taken. So for now, I am spending most of my time lying down, chanting and reading. Therefore this will have to be short.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Bringing Back the Yamuna River to Vrndavana
data.blurb: During the GBC meetings this year in Mayapura, Brajraj Sharan Baba from Varsana gave a presentation to the GBC Body about the current state of the Yamuna River in Vraja.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the GBC meetings this year in Mayapura, Brajraj Sharan Baba from Varsana gave a presentation to the GBC Body about the current state of the Yamuna River in Vraja. (Please see video below.) He humbly requested the GBC to adopt the following proposal and it was immediately voted upon and accepted. He also came to speak with me personally and I assured him that I would do my best to promote this to others.

The following is the resolution which was passed by the GBC Body:

Title of Proposal: Bringing back the Yamuna River to Vrindavan

Explanation of the proposal:

Currently 100% of the water from the Yamuna is blocked above Delhi and this water is diverted for industries and irrigation. Below the dams above Delhi there is simply a dry river bed.

The water that we presently find in the Yamuna River bed is runoff from the Delhi sewerage system, and from the streets of Delhi and the towns above Vrindavan.

The Governmental Authorities in Delhi have suggested some feasible methods for again allowing the Yamuna water to flow in Vrindavan, and to divert the sewerage elsewhere.

Proposal

Whereas there is not even one drop of water from the Yamuna river to be found in the Yamuna River bed in Vrindavan.

Whereas all the original waters are diverted before River Yamuna enters Vraj Vrindavan.

Whereas only sewage and runoff which comes from upstream Delhi flows in the Yamuna River bed at present. The sewage is partially treated and is extremely dangerous for humans to come in contact with. There are many credible and official studies verifying the contamination

Whereas any contact with the water in the River Yamuna bed is hazardous for health of devotees and general public. The water carries several antibiotic resistant bacteria which can be the cause of death. In addition many viruses, toxic chemicals, and toxic metals are carried by the water.

Whereas there are methods by which the original Yamuna River water can again flow to Vrindavan.

Whereas a campaign to influence the Governmental authorities to act can achieve success in bringing the Yamuna waters back to Vrindavan.

Whereas bringing the Yamuna waters back to Vrindavan is direct service to the holy Dham of Vrindavan which is direct service to the Divine Couple Sri Sri Radha Krishna.

Whereas the aforementioned campaign can increase the public’s appreciation of ISKCON.

Whereas the aforementioned campaign can help ISKCON’s worldwide insofar as ISKCON will be seen at forefront of the environmental movement.

Therefore ISKCON temples, congregations, yatras, and devotees are encouraged to:

1. To include Yamuna Maharani in their daily prayers.

2. To explain the spiritual importance of Shri Yamuna Maharani to others.

3. To organize special kirtans or dedicate existing kirtans to the Yamuna cause.

4. To organize special programs or dedicate existing programs to the Yamuna cause.

5. Explain the environmental issues to other, especially working through the relevant ISKCON ministries that deal with the environment.

6. Create world-wide campaigns

7. Encourage and assist in petitions to accomplish the aforementioned purposes.

8. Using internal media( Back to Godhead etc.) and external media(newspapers, Television etc.) effectively.

9. To encourage spread of campaign through internet websites (dandavats.com, desiretree.com etc) social groups (facebook etc) etc.

Please watch this small 5 min presentation video http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=69tm_yCAzY8 and

sign the petition at http://www.saveyamuna.org/sign-yamuna-petition

Visit http://www.saveyamuna.org/ to more about this issue.

data.title: Harinama in Bali and Reflections
data.blurb: By now, many of you probably know that I'm currently in Bali, Indonesia with Devamrita Swami.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
By now, many of you probably know that I'm currently in Bali, Indonesia with Devamrita Swami. Both of us arrived here March 6th to take part in the Gaura Purnima celebrations on March 8th and then to rest from March 9th to March 18th. My health has not been good for quite some time and Devamrita Swami is presently recovering from extensive oral surgery. So when Madana-mohana suggested a good, quiet place for me to rest, knowing that Devamrita Swami was also recovering at this time and also knowing that he was not so far away, I invited him to stay along with us. Although this time has been posted on my itinerary as a "health retreat", for the most part, I've been simply resting and reading.

We celebrated Gaura Purnima at one of our temples in Denpasar (there are five temples in Bali) and now we are staying about 1.5 – 2 hours from Denpasar in the small village of Candidasa.

We both had a wonderful Gaura Purnima celebration with the devotees from Bali. Approximately 300 devotees attended the festival which included abhiseka, bhajans, talks from myself and Devamrita Swami, and then arati. There was a short drama after arati, but unfortunately, it was already late and since we had to drive back to Candidasa after the program, Devamrita Swami and I decided to break our fast after arati and return to our residence.

On the way back to Candidasa, the local Temple President, Padmalocana dasa, told us that if we would go out on harinama with them on Sunday, we could expect at least 200 devotees to participate. I asked how often they go out on harinama. He said that at least 30 devotees go out every day. Each day of the week they have a special spot they go to in order to give maximum exposure of the Lord's Holy Names to all the residents of the Bali. Padmalocana said that on Sunday, they would be going to the beach and lots of people would be there.

Although it would be another long drive, I didn't want to pass up the opportunity to go out on harinama, so I agreed to go. I definitely didn't regret it. It was a wonderful experience to see the enthusiasm the devotees had for harinama.

When Madana-mohana and I arrived, it was already 5:00 PM. All the devotees were sitting on the beach, chanting with harmonium, mrdangas and kartalas. But shortly thereafter, everyone lined up for harinama down the beach. I asked for someone else to lead for awhile and chanted along with them. But after 20 minutes or so, they asked if I would lead. I then led for about an hour and then another devotee led while we returned to our orginal spot.

Madana-mohana took at least 20 video clips of the harinama. A few of them have been posted here, but I'm not sure how much they show the enthusiastic participation of the local people as well as the foreigners who are in Bali for their vacation. It was especially enlivening to see the local Muslims sincerely chanting and dancing along with the kirtan.

These days, more and more, I am marveling upon Srila Prabhupada's compassion, desire, and potency to attract conditioned souls onto the path of devotional service and back home back to Godhead. One morning, in Mayapura, I experienced this overwhelming sensation during Guru Puja.
