It is hard to fully comprehend how fortunate we are to be associated with service to his divine lotus feet. But seeing Krsna consciousness manifesting all over the world, is no doubt, an impetus to remember and to reflect on our good fortune.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: A Few Words From Radha Gopinath Mandir
data.blurb:
March 3, 2012
Radha Gopinath Mandir, Mumbai
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
March 3, 2012
Radha Gopinath Mandir, Mumbai

It's been a long time since anything has been posted on the site. Unfortunately, while in Mayapura, I was much too busy to write any blogs. And although several lectures have been recently given and many kirtans were recorded in Mayapura, there was no internet connection available to transfer the files.

The GBC meetings kept me very busy from February 10 -21, and then the Kirtan-mela went from February 22 – 25. I averaged five hours/day in the the Kirtan-mela kirtans. The rest of my time from February 10th onwards, was spent meeting devotees during lunch every day, visiting devotees, and dealing with GBC-related matters assigned to me by a GBC committee.

Once the Kirtan-mela was over, I met personally with many devotees, I gave two evening classes, and continued with my GBC committee work which continues even up until today. Although I was scheduled to leave Mayapura on February 27th, due to the many commitments which remained after the Kirtan-mela was over, I was unable to make it for the first two days of the Govardhan Asram Japa Retreat, where I was scheduled to speak daily on the topic of "Appreciating the Association of the Holy Name."

Moreover, on March 1st, my evening flight from Kolkata to Mumbai was delayed three hours. When I arrived in Mumbai it was almost 1:00 in the morning. I was therefore unable to make it to Govardhan Asram in time for the first of two classes devotees were hoping to hear from me on that day. By the time I arrived in Govardhan Asram, there was only enough time for a two-hour class, which begain at 2:00 PM, with an additional hour of questions and kirtans. Still, it was a very wonderful retreat (see photo at http://govardhanashram.com/). More than sixty devotees from Pune and Mumbai registered for the three-day retreat. They all seemed very grateful that I was able to make it at all.

Govardhan Asrama has developed very nicely since my last visit one year ago. There are very nice and comfortable guest quarters for up to one hundred guests. Just before I left Govardhan Asram today, two busloads of devotees from Pune had just arrived for a weekend retreat. So when Gauranga Prabhu asked if I would delay my departure for a couple of more hours to speak and have kirtan with the arriving devotees, I immediately agreed. I left Govardhan Asrama at 3:30 and arrived here in Radha Gopinath Mandir at approximately 6:00 PM.

Tomorrow, Bhakti Caitanya Swami and I will give the Sunday Feast lecture together here at Radha Gopinath Mandir. Maharaja is scheduled to arrive this evening and will be here all day tomorrow. Monday, I hope to visit all the sincere Vaisnavas at Bhaktivedanta Hospital, and then Monday night I will move on to my next destination.

This afternoon Madana-mohana called me and informed me that somewhere between 150 – 200 devotees are planning to take part in a large harinama in the city on Gaura Purnima day. I very much look forward to that.

Hopefully, my schedule will soon normalize and I will begin to post blogs from time to time once again. There are at least five lectures which need to be uploaded, and all the kirtans from Kirtan-mela are also ready to be uploaded. I'm not sure when everything will be posted, but hopefully many files will be coming very soon.

Hare Krsna

data.title: These Past Several Weeks
data.blurb: I apologize to my readers for the long lapse with posting blogs. It probably deserves some explanation.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I apologize to my readers for the long lapse with posting blogs. It probably deserves some explanation.

This trip to the United States became exceptionally busy when, during some testing in New York, the doctors discovered a major increase of my blood pressure. I then had to balance all of my already-existing commitments throughout the Northeast with no less than four, two-hour and sometimes four-hour trips to Upstate New York, usually spending at least one night in New York and then returning back to Boston and/or Hartford. All these tests and consultations had to be scheduled in New York with doctors who have been overseeing some of my medical issues for the past several years. Therefore all my lectures, programs, meetings, and other commitments had to be scheduled around these doctor appointments. It got so hectic towards the end of my visit to the U.S. that I had to cancel my visit to Ottawa, Ontario in order to finish everything in time for my departure on January 13th.

I wish to thank Mayapura Chandra dasa, one of the doctors in New York, who arranged all of these details for me and who never failed to call me every single day over a period of at least 3-4 weeks to check and to see if my blood pressure was coming down to acceptable levels. Mayapura Chandra and his entire family including his parents, his wife and two children, his four brothers, along with their wives and children, are all very dedicated and sincere devotees. They all live together in one home in Upstate New York. It is a pleasure to stay with them in their home and to see how they have put Krsna in the center of their lives.

After finishing with my travels and finalizing how to best deal with these medical issues, I then was able to follow through with a Brooklyn studio recording I had scheduled for January 10-12 some time back in early December. Since this endeavor included the participation of many other devotees, some traveling from as far as Florida, I did not want to cancel.

By Krsna's grace, I was able to keep that commitment with the help of Syamakunda dasa, Anandarupa devi dasi, Hrsikesa dasa, Sukhesvari devi dasi, and Dina Gauranga dasa. They all helped in many ways by taking care of all the backup arrangements.

Another reason why I was so intent on keeping my commitment to do this recording is because I pledged to use all the proceeds from the sale of the CD for helping Manorama dasa, the devotee who has been overseeing the Youth Bus Tour in North America for so many years. Please see their website at http://www.krishna.com/bustour. It is definitely a project worth supporting and everyone who participated felt good about our goal to support it.

Many excellent and wonderful kirtaniyas took part in this recording and I wish to thank them all for their enthusiastic participation. My godbrother Purusartha dasa came from Alachua and also coordinated everyone else who took part in the recordings. Ananta Govinda dasa came from Brooklyn, Acyuta Gopi devi dasi came from Brooklyn, Krsna Kishora dasa came from Alachua, and Akincana Krsna dasa and Rati Manjari dd who, though both currently live in India, were, by Krsna's grace, visiting Brooklyn at the time. Some pictures taken in the recording studio will probably be posted here in the Photo Gallery soon.

There was probably at least 120 minutes of recording time. We are hoping for at least 9-10 tracks on the CD. Not only did I lead some of the kirtans and bhajans, but kirtans were also led by Ananta Govinda, Acyuta Gopi, Krsna Kishora and and Akincana Krsna. Hrsikesa dasa will be doing all the mixing and mastering in his spare time. So although we would all like to see this CD available as soon as possible, realistically we will likely not see it until some time around the middle of this year.

The day after our recording I flew from Newark, New Jersey to Budapest. I arrived on the 14th late afternoon, exhausted and with jet lag, and yesterday I had to finish the latest deadline on the revised paper I had written for the GBC. I worked almost all day yesterday from 4:30 AM until 2:00 AM this morning, the time when I finally submitted my work to the GBC committee overseeing the paper. So today is the first day in weeks that I've actually had a little time to write.

I have an unlimited amount of correspondence to work on. Still, in the days to follow, I will try my best to contribute more to this blog.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Book Distribution Results for Prabhupada Marathon 2011
data.blurb: One important event I will miss this year is receiving the Prabhupada Marathon book distribution results from disciples all over the CIS. Traditionally, the results were always read to me in January during Vyasa Puja in Ukraine.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
One important event I will miss this year is receiving the Prabhupada Marathon book distribution results from disciples all over the CIS. Traditionally, the results were always read to me in January during Vyasa Puja in Ukraine. Still I am very eager to receive everyone's results in January after the Prabhupada Marathon is over.

I would therefore like to encourage everyone who has distributed books during the month of December to post their book distribution results in the following Prabhupada Marathon book distribution result sheet. If you like you can post whatever results you have now, and then simply update them when the marathon is over.

Additionally, after the marathon is over, I would be very grateful if devotees could gather distribution results from other disciples. If one devotee from every temple (or region) could request this information from either the local sankirtan leader or any other devotee responsible for gathering the book distribution results locally, you could then take responsibility to enter the results for all disciples in your temple or region.

The process for entering results is very easy. You can enter names either in English or in Russian.

Click on the following link (or copy the link and paste it into your web browser):

https://docs.google.com/document/d/16F7-mBCzmN60G4ssw_7VUZ9Dwt9cfYBNEofRwGtV9Ag/edit

Then simply enter the data according to the sample given. One line for each person. Changes will be saved automatically. All I ask is that you please enter actual book distribution results and don't enter anything other than the actual book distribution results of each devotee.

Hare Krsna

data.title: BG Court Case Dismissed! + Letter from Bhakti Vijnana Goswami
data.blurb:
Dear Maharajas and Prabhus,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Maharajas and Prabhus,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

This is the victory of the whole ISKCON. Of course, ultimately everything was arranged by Sri Krishna Himself, and the whole credit goes to Him. It was very clear to me being in the epicenter of the battle, but still some devotees deserve special mention.

The EC members, Niranjana Maharaja and Acyuta-priya Prabhu extended their support, and created the awareness within ISKCON about the importance of the case.

Gopal Krishna Maharaja met will dozens of press reporters, many important people, used all his contacts and brilliant intelligence and diplomatic skills to help protecting Bhagavad-gita. he also facilitated the service of Madana-mohan Prabhu and ourselves.

His team, and first of all Vrajendranandana Prabhu worked tirelessly, day and night.

Madana-mohana Prabhu prepared the ground, all the materials, spent many hours putting together materials for Wikipedia, etc.

Parijata mataji, Sankirtan Prabhu (Mumbai), Radharaman Prabhu (Kolkatta), Jasomatinandana Prabhu, Braja Hari Prabhu, Basu Ghosh Prabhu and others Indian leaders helped with the campaign in different cities and states of India.

Basu Ghosh Prabhu, Sridama Prabhu (Mumbai), Anuttama Prabhu, Gadadhar Prabhu, bhn. Inna, Gopal Hari Prabhu worked hard to get the reviews and endorcement letters.

Garuda Prabhu (!!!), Saranagati dd, Ishvara Krishna Prabhu, Radhika Raman Prabhu and others wrote nice letters of support.

Our strategic team spent many month preparing and executing the strategy, they are Gaura Krishna Prabhu, Radha Damodar Pr, Yadunandana Pr, Maha-Balarama Pr, bh. Alexander.

NE BBT, Gopal Krishna Maharaja, Prabhavishnu Maharaja, Bhaktivaibhava Maharaja and many other devotees helped financially. We spent around 100,000$ on this battle.

Thousands of devotees and other people signed the petition, prayed, performed kirtans and yagnas.

So the credit goes to all of them, they made this victory the historical fact.

Thank you again very much for your help and support. I am sure that Srila Prabhupada is immensely pleased with this victory.

Your servant Bhakti Vijnana Goswami

data.title: "Bhagavad-gita On Trial in Tomsk!! (Update)
data.blurb:
The following is Bhakti Vijnana Goswami's appeal posted today, December 16th. Please forward this information and be prepared for more after next week's trial.

Dear Maharajas, Prabhus, members of this conference,
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is Bhakti Vijnana Goswami's appeal posted today, December 16th. Please forward this information and be prepared for more after next week's trial.

Dear Maharajas, Prabhus, members of this conference,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

Today we received the testimony of the experts from Kemerovo State University. As it should have been expected, it is highly negative.

We uploaded the petition. It is self-explanatory, and formulated in such a way that not only ISKCON devotees can vote. Please feel free to share this link.

http://www.petitions24.com/gita

Please find below the text of the petition. On the site it is both in Russian and English.

Bhagavad-gita As It Is, one of the most respected holy scriptures of the world today, is under the threat of being banned in Russia.

The court proceedings will resume in Siberian city Tomsk, Russia, on Monday 19th. The persecutors in Tomsk suggest that the widely distributed book translated and commented upon by A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada should be included in the Justice Ministry's list of banned extremist literature.

Bhagavad-gita As It Is is translated in more than 80 languages. Over 100 million copies of this book was distributed to date all over the world! Millions of people in the world today consider it as the main book in their life.

The persecutors with great determination and vigor are pushing through this absurd case. During the first three court hearings, the testimony of the Tomsk experts upon which the persecutors built their case for the court was recognized as «inadequate». However, the Persecutor's office ordered the new testimony. Noteworthy, that the testimony was requested not from the well-known experts of Hinduism from Moscow, but from some unknown experts from Kemerovo State University. This move clearly suggests that the court decision is already predestined. This practice brings to memory the Middle Age Inquisition, Witch hunting, burning of books and the persecution of the dissidents during Soviet period of Russian history.

Tomsk Ombudsperson, eminent scholars of Hinduism, the members of the Public Chamber of Russian Federation, representatives of Indian community in Russia, and people belonging to different religious denominations in Russia have already expressed their perplexity and outrage caused by the activities of Tomsk persecutors.

We demand to stop the court over the Holy Scripture! These initiatives of the Tomsk Persecutor's Office offend the religious sentiments of all the followers of Hinduism and bring disgrace to the country of Russia.

Once you sign the petition - you will receive e-mail asking you to confirm your vote. This is very important - otherwise it will be canceled.

And please share this link to your friends.


Your servant Bhakti Vijnana Goswami

data.title: Srila Prabhupada's Bhagavad-gita is Going on Trial
data.blurb:
The following message was posted today by Bhakti Vijnana Goswami. The message speaks for itself. Please read it and inform others about it's content.

December 15, 2011

Dear Maharajas and Prabhus,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following message was posted today by Bhakti Vijnana Goswami. The message speaks for itself. Please read it and inform others about it's content.


December 15, 2011

Dear Maharajas and Prabhus,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

On Dec. 19th and 20th the court case trying to declare "Bhagavad-gita as it is" as an extremist literature will resume.

A lot is at stake. If we lose the case, the consequences will be very dramatic, long-lasting and very gloomy. It may put under question the very existence of our movement in Russia.

The fact that two days are alotted for the hearing from the beginning makes us suspicious that they plan to finish the whole process within these two days. It is a bad sign.

Also they practically did not give us time to prepare, just today we got the news, and it is already practically weekend, and the court will start on Monday. We still do not have the copy of the so-called expert opinion submitted to the court.

We humbly ask all of you to offer your prayers, to hold special kirtans and yajnas. Please ask your congregation to pray.

We are also formulating our petition following Sivarama Maharaja's example. As soon as we are ready, I will ask you to mobilize your congregation to sign the petition on line.

Your servant Bhakti Vijnana Goswami [end of quote]


I spoke with Bhakti Vijnana Goswami this morning. The petition mentioned above will have little impact on the outcome of the December 20th court ruling. Nonetheless, should there be an unfavorable ruling on December 20th, devotees worldwide will immediately need to be mobilized to start a massive international campaign against the court's decision. The impact that a negative ruling could have on the existence of ISKCON in Russia is incalculable. In this connection, I would like to quote something Acyuta Priya dasa wrote this morning to GBC members throughout the world:

"If Bhagavad-gita would be declared an extremist literature, that practically means that basically ALL of Srila Prabhupada's books could be forbidden in Russia, because all of them have quotes from Bhagavad-gita. It would be forbidden to distribute, read, and even keep at home these books! It would be strictly forbidden to discuss and give lectures on Bhagavad-gita or other books of Srila Prabhupada.

It could practically finish up or set back for decades our movement in Russia.

Now, Russia is a very important country in the Eastern World. This will affect heavily all countries there and their religious policy—Belorussia, Ukraine, Moldova, Kazakhstan etc. will be affected first of all." [end of quote]

I therefore request all of my readers, especially those of you living outside the CIS, to prepare yourselves to launch a massive letter-writing campaign against this potential injustice. You should also begin preparing your mailing lists.

Should there be a negative decision, I'm quite hopeful that a whole packet of material for emailing and posting on websites (and blogs) will become available very shortly thereafter.

Hare Krsna

For those of you who did not read "The Moscow Times" article entitled "Krishna Holy Book Faces Ban in Tomsk", please click on the following link. It is quite informative.

Krishna Holy Book Faces Ban in Tomsk

The book may be accused of expressing religious hatred, suppressing human dignity and declaring one religion superior to all others. But "Bhagavad Gita As It Is" can hardly be called Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf."

data.title: Tulasi-kirtana
data.blurb: There are some devotees who may wonder why I never lead Tulasi-kirtana in Ukraine, especially in Kiev. The answer lies in the Tulasi-kirtana recording which has been posted in the audio section today.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
There are some devotees who may wonder why I never lead Tulasi-kirtana in Ukraine, especially in Kiev. The answer lies in the Tulasi-kirtana recording which has been posted in the audio section today.

Over the years I have made several unsuccessful attempts to teach the devotees in Kiev the proper melody for Tulasi-kirtana. The irregularity of the melody chanted in Kiev (though not only in Kiev) is not extreme, or at least it's not as extreme as the irregularity of the Sri Guru Vandana prayers used to be. Nonetheless the way that Tulasi-kirtana is chanted there is still an irregularity which could be corrected if more effort was made to correct it.

The irregularity comes on the last two or three words of the last line of each verse as indicated below. Please listen to the recording while reading along with the prayers, and take note of the way the words "ei abhilasi", "vrndavana-vasi", "yugala-rupa-rasi", "koro-nija-dasi", and "sada yena bhasi" are chanted. If you listen to my version and then listen to what is chanted generally everywhere throughout Ukraine, you will see what I am talking about.

My intention of this posting is not to give this as ammunition to my readers to become faultfinders of those who do chant the Tulasi-kirtana improperly. I humbly ask that you do not use it in that way. My hope is that devotees will listen to the recording, share the recording and this posting with others, and then gradually devotees will begin to see the discrepancy that I am talking about. By so doing, hopefully in time I can begin leading Tulasi-kirtana in Ukraine once again.

Hare Krsna

Sri Tulasi-kirtana

(1) namo namah tulasi krsna-preyasi namo namah
radha-krsna-seva pabo ei abhilasi

O Tulasi, beloved of Krsna, I bow before you again and again. My desire is to obtain the service of Sri Sri Radha and Krsna.
(2) ye tomara sarana loy, tara vancha purna hoy
krpa kori' koro tare vrndavana-vasi

Whoever takes shelter of you has his wishes fulfilled. Bestowing your mercy on him, you make him a resident of Vrndavana.
(3) mora ei abhilasa, vilasa kunje dio vasa
nayana heribo sada yugala-rupa-rasi

My desire is that you will also give me a residence in the pleasure groves of Sri Vrndavana-dhama. Thus within my vision I will always behold the beautiful pastimes of Radha and Krsna.
(4) ei nivedana dhara, sakhira anugata koro
seva-adhikara diye koro nija dasi

I beg you to make me a follower of the cowherd damsels of Vraja. Please give me the privilege of devotional service and make me your own maidservant.
(5) dina krsna-dase koy, ei yena mora hoy
sri-radha-govinda-preme sada yena bhasi

This very fallen and lowly servant of Krsna prays, "May I always swim in the love of Sri Sri Radha and Govinda."

data.title: More Signatures Please!
data.blurb: As of today, 9:00 PM, Hungary time, there are approximately 8,200 signatures on the petition to be submitted to the Hungarian government on December 13th. This means we have one week to collect another 90,000 signatures!
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As of today, 9:00 PM, Hungary time, there are approximately 8,200 signatures on the petition to be submitted to the Hungarian government on December 13th. This means we have one week to collect another 90,000 signatures!

I am therefore humbly requesting everyone to please send the following to as many people as possible and appeal to them to get online to sign the petition.

"Dear Devotees. The new 'Church Law' in Hungary will take away ISKCON Hungary’s church status as of January 1st requiring us to reapply for the same next year. However the government has not provided any legal stipulation for the society’s continued ownership of Krsna Valley’s lands in the interim period until we are again reregistered. In short we risk losing Krsna Valley with no pasture for our cows or land to grow our food. I therefore request that you sign the online petition—link below—and forward this message to as many people as possible, who would also petition against this injustice. Thank you. Sivarama Swami."

http://www.petitions24.com/krisna

If you know devotees with websites, please write to them too, and ask them to post something on their site. If you know non-devotees who might be sympathetic to the cause, then write to them too.

Sivarama Swami had this to say yesterday to all the members of the GBC:

"I cannot over-emphasize the importance of the positive effect that the petition is having. Thank you."

Also, the following is a political cartoon published yesterday, December 5th, in a national Hungarian newspaper. The translation is:

"Rudolph, you have nothing to complain about. You are much luckier than the Hare Krishna`s cows."

Hare Krsna

data.title: The Devotees in Hungary Need Your Help
data.blurb: The following is a transcription of Sivarama Swami's short podcast, posted yesterday, December 3rd on www.sivaramaswami.com.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is a transcription of Sivarama Swami's short podcast, posted yesterday, December 3rd on www.sivaramaswami.com. It has been transcribed and posted here to make all of my readers aware of the serious situation in Hungary, especially the ominous threat against New Vraja Dhama. Please read it and then sign the online petition, which can be found by clicking on the designated link. We hope that this short transcription will be translated promptly into Russian. Soon we will also be posting a translation of the actual petition.

Today I'd like to talk about a subject that I had mentioned before: the change of church laws in Hungary. It's a topic I brought up in July, something that we keep on the agenda in the form of a campaign, something that we request listeners to also participate and to help in.

But let me first give you a little summary in brief.

In July the Hungarian government submitted a draft law to the Parliament on religious organizations, or as we call them here, churches. According to the draft law, the “churches” in Hungary, over 300 of them, were going to be classified into three different categories. Those that had been in Hungary for hundreds of years were in category one, those who are recognized world religions, like us, in category two. And then other “new” religions in category three. Those who did not fit in either would lose their church status. It wasn’t ideal, but it was acceptable. The declared purpose of this was to weed out businesses that work under the name of religion.

Anyway, what ended up happening in July was that arbitrarily 14 churches that had been in existence in Hungary and recognized in a law dated 1895 were recognized as existing religious organizations and they would continue to function in the same way in the future while everyone else would lose their church status at the end of this year and would have to transform into religious associations and then reapply for their church status which needed a two-thirds majority vote of parliament.

Obviously this wasn't favorable. First of all, there was no particular reason for taking away the church status of churches in good standing, including us, who are the fourth most popular church in Hungary. It also very much affects rights-- like for instance, if you are not a church you don't have tax exemption. It also means your automatic rights to book distribution aren't guaranteed. It means that, for instance, the government subsidy that we get for our gurukula and for our theological college are lost. If you're not a church, you cannot have a theological college. All of these things would cease, including the one percent of personal income tax allocated by our supporters on an annual basis.

Over the period of the last four or five months, we were working on a premise that the existing law would be amended. It needed to be amended because it was messy and on the basis of that amendment, government people said, we were going to be included together with the other original world religions.

Recently it has come to our notice that there's going to be no amendment of that law this year, rather, it will go into effect on January 1st as it is now and everyone, including us, will have to apply for re-registration.

We haven't been sitting around. We've been moving energies, devotees, contacts, on a global level-- Europe, India, America, and locally in Hungary. In fact it's been a full time job for quite a few devotees, taking them away from other services. And one very important thing is, which is going to be the centerpiece of what I am talking about now, is a certain way in which that law actually affects specifically us.

Unlike any of the other churches in Hungary, we have got agricultural land. And existing land laws state that associations cannot hold land, which means that at the present time, between now and the end of the year, we need some kind of clarification as to what happens to our land come January the 1st. By land we mean 200 hectares or about 500 acres of New Vraja Dhama's pasturing grounds and agricultural land. We don't expect that the government is going to come and take it away, still, there's been no particular law or arrangement made that actually deals with what happens to Krsna Valley's agricultural lands from January 1st to the time when we are again accepted as a church. That makes the situation of the land is precarious.

A religious association, not being a church, which is what we would be on January 1st, cannot legally hold agricultural land. It can hold other types of land, like town property and so on. But not agricultural land. So some type of amendment has to be made.

Of course we've seen many politicians and when they wake up to the reality of the situation then they say, "Well of course, obviously something has to be done." The issue is that time is running out and nothing has been done.

So now we are focusing on our campaign and this is where everyone else comes in. We are bringing this to the public view that our cows don't have a future starting January 1. Are they able to continue grazing on the land? What is the status of their land? What is the status of our self-sufficient community which is based on the fact that we grow our own food? This needs to be settled.

So we are bringing this into the forefront. For that reason we are doing a leaflet campaign and a petition. On December 13th we are going to be outside of the parliament with cows and devotees and kirtan in order to bring this to the attention of the general public as well as of the members of parliament. We will be handing over a petition also to the Parliament to communicate that there is an unresolved problem. They’ve got their church law, but they still have got this loophole that needs to be addressed and we need our lands protected in that regard.

So how can the devotees here on this podcast help? We are having an online petition at http://www.petitions24.com/krisna, and we request everyone to sign on to that petition. Moreover if every listener also gets ten other people, to sign on, and they, in turn, to get ten more people—all the better. We're really trying to get lots and lots of signatories, as many as we can to hand over to the government, to show them that this is not just a national concern, but it is an international concern. We need signatories from Russia, from India, from South America, from South Africa, from Asia, from Canada, from Alaska, from the South Pole. Anywhere, anyone listening. Or wherever you know someone, please ask them to just get on the site and do that.

And we are quite sure that some type of arrangement will be forthcoming. Of course, the easiest arrangement is if the government recognizes our right, "We better give them their church rights back and make some kind of amendment for that." That automatically takes care of the land problem. If they don't do that but want us to continue by putting in our application on January 1st, then they have to make some kind of amendment to the land law or to pass some kind of other special law, that deals with this particular issue.

So this is what the petition says: "Please, you have to deal with this. This is the biggest self-sufficient community in Europe-- Hindu community, Krishna conscious community-- and it really needs the attention of the Hungarian government.”

I am not going to deal with the other problems like 1% tax allocation, college status etc. just now. This is the most important thing that we need to deal with because this isn't addressed. The following is a transcription of Sivarama Swami's short podcast, posted yesterday, December 3rd on www.sivaramaswami.com. It has been transcribed and posted here to make all of my readers aware of the serious situation in Hungary, especially the ominous threat against New Vraja Dhama. Please read it and then sign the online petition, which can be found by clicking on the designated link. We hope that this short transcription will be translated promptly into Russian. Soon we will also be posting a translation of the actual petition.

Today I'd like to talk about a subject that I had mentioned before: the change of church laws in Hungary. It's a topic I brought up in July, something that we keep on the agenda in the form of a campaign, something that we request listeners to also participate and to help in.

But let me first give you a little summary in brief.

In July the Hungarian government submitted a draft law to the Parliament on religious organizations, or as we call them here, churches. According to the draft law, the “churches” in Hungary, over 300 of them, were going to be classified into three different categories. Those that had been in Hungary for hundreds of years were in category one, those who are recognized world religions, like us, in category two. And then other “new” religions in category three. Those who did not fit in either would lose their church status. It wasn’t ideal, but it was acceptable. The declared purpose of this was to weed out businesses that work under the name of religion.

Anyway, what ended up happening in July was that arbitrarily 14 churches that had been in existence in Hungary and recognized in a law dated 1895 were recognized as existing religious organizations and they would continue to function in the same way in the future while everyone else would lose their church status at the end of this year and would have to transform into religious associations and then reapply for their church status which needed a two-thirds majority vote of parliament.

Obviously this wasn't favorable. First of all, there was no particular reason for taking away the church status of churches in good standing, including us, who are the fourth most popular church in Hungary. It also very much affects rights-- like for instance, if you are not a church you don't have tax exemption. It also means your automatic rights to book distribution aren't guaranteed. It means that, for instance, the government subsidy that we get for our gurukula and for our theological college are lost. If you're not a church, you cannot have a theological college. It needed to be amended because it was messy and on the basis of that amendment, government people said, we were going to be included together with the other original world religions.

In fact it's been a full time job for quite a few devotees, taking them away from other services. And one very important thing is, which is going to be the centerpiece of what I am talking about now, is a certain way in which that law actually affects specifically us.

By land we mean 200 hectares or about 500 acres of New Vraja Dhama's pasturing grounds and agricultural land. A religious association, not being a church, which is what we would be on January 1st, cannot legally hold agricultural land. It can hold other types of land, like town property and so on. But not agricultural land. So some type of amendment has to be made.

That automatically takes care of the land problem. All right. Thank you very much and look for the link. Hare Krishna.

data.title: A Story I Recently Told to One Devotee
data.blurb: Three days ago I met with a devotee in Budapest. In the course of our discussion I recalled an unforgettable experience I had about thirty-six years ago when I was a brahmacari and was regularly distributing books for the Boston temple.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Three days ago I met with a devotee in Budapest. In the course of our discussion I recalled an unforgettable experience I had about thirty-six years ago when I was a brahmacari and was regularly distributing books for the Boston temple. I remember telling this story before, but I can't remember when and where I might have told it. I thought I would repeat it here since it seemed to make a positive impression on the devotee I told, especially in light of the experiences this devotee had prior to coming to speak with me.

Some time in early 1975, my godbrother and Temple President, Trai Prabhu, left Boston to join the Radha Damodara Traveling Sankiran Party. Soon thereafter another devotee was sent by our GBC to replace him. I will not mention his name because there is no need.

Right from the time of his arrival, this new president seemed very strict with everyone living in the temple. I did not know why, but I remembered thinking that maybe it was because he thought that Trai Prabhu was too lenient with all of us. Although he was a householder, he seemed especially strict with the brahmacaris.

It wasn't long after he became president, I started to notice that he would oftentimes insult me in public even though he had previously authorized me to be the Sankirtan Leader for all of the brahmacaris. For some time I just accepted it as training for my new position. I even began thinking that it was also his way of showing his affection for me.

Gradually, however, I couldn't accept it as easily as I was able to when he first came. I remember trying hard to not defend myself. Neither would I try or even think of avenging myself. I also never talked about it with anyone. I just kept on letting it bottle up within me until it started getting to the point when I thought I would not be able to tolerate it any more.

It was right around that time that I distinctly remember being asked to give Srimad Bhagavatam class in the temple a lot more than I had been giving before. I believe it was because I had returned to the temple from traveling sankirtan and I was asked to stay back at the temple indefinitely in order to oversee all of the Sankirtan parties. On traveling sankirtan, I would give Srimad Bhagavatam class every day to the devotees on my book distribution party, but I would usually give only one Srimad Bhagavatam class in the temple whenever our party returned. On that particular week, I had given at least three consecutive Srimad Bhagavatam classes, all from the chapter, "The Discussion Between Jada Bharata and Maharaja Rahugana", in the Fifth Canto.

The verses Krsna arranged for me to speak from were all verses about the criticisms and insults Maharaja Rahugana hurled at Jada Bharata for inconveniencing him by the way Jada Bharata was carrying his palanquin. And Srila Prabhupada's purports were all about how to become free from the influence of insult. The verses couldn't have been any more directly related to all that I was going through.

I do not remember the reason, but the temple president was not present for any of the classes I gave that week. I therefore felt more free to speak according to the realizations which came to me from my own experiences, although I never once mentioned the particulars about what I was going through at the time. The most vivid memories I have from giving those classes was the sheltered feeling I got by accepting everything that was happening to me— specifically the insults and especially the opportunity to be speaking on those particular verses— as Krsna's direct arrangement. It was almost as if He was personally massaging my tormented heart with His hand as I was speaking whatever realizations that would come to me.

However, another realization came to me as I was speaking that I did not share with my audience in those classes. That realization was that my Temple President was none other than Krsna's representative, sent directly to deal with my false ego. So many mixed emotions welled up within me while I was speaking. I felt purified, elated, relieved, and especially grateful for everything that was happening to me. I even felt grateful that Krsna sent this devotee to be temple president and not somebody else, thinking that this arrangement may not have happened if the new president had been somebody different.

Time passed, although I don't think it was very long. Those feelings continued and in due course of time I noticed that my temple president started insulting me less and less, until it was practically nil. It's not that my false ego was gone. But I did feel as though Krsna was preparing me for more that was still yet to come.

About twenty-five years later I unexpectedly met this former Temple President in the course of my travels. By that time, I had related some of the details of this story to a few devotees. While standing in the hallway of the temple we were both visiting at the time, he told me that he had heard that I had told this story from someone we both knew. Right there on the spot he prostrated himself, attempting to touch my feet and he apologized to me for whatever offenses he might have committed while he was president. Remembering all those wonderful realizations, I simply embraced him and thanked him for all that he did for me.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Message for Counselors
data.blurb: During the counselor retreat in Kiev I made a presentation about the new system which counselors can use to send reports to me about their counselees.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the counselor retreat in Kiev I made a presentation about the new system which counselors can use to send reports to me about their counselees. I'd like to summarize here the points which should be noted by those who are counselors of my disciples (both diksa and siksa) and aspiring disciples.

From now on, all counselor reports can be submitted directly into an online database. The preferred language for the resports is English, but if that is not possible, then the data and the reports can also be entered in Russian which will then be translated later online. The interface for the database is in both English and Russian.

Before anyone can access the database and enter reports, he/she must first get authorization. Only authorized counselors will be allowed to submit reports.

The initial stage of the authorization process can be found at the following URL:

http://niranjanaswami.com/contact-2

Please click on the above link or cut and paste the link into your browser

The database managers have a list of authorized counselors. If your name is on that list, you will then be sent further information explaining where you can submit your list of counselees. Once your list of counselees has been processed, you will then get access to the database and a manual will be sent to you explaining how to enter your reports.

If your name is not on the list, then you will directed to the link where you will be asked to provide more information which will help the database managers continue with the verification process.

To learn more on the subject, listen to the November 12th audio recording entitled "About Counselor Reports".

Hare Krsna

data.title: A few of the notes taken from my reading this morning
data.blurb: A few notes from my reading this morning:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
A few notes from my reading this morning:

"You, who have the audacity to challenge even Lord Indra, who lives for milleniums, should happily circumambulate Govardhana Hill along with your cows, bulls and calves. Do not think, 'How can we have faith that Giriraja will gratify our desires?' Soon Giriraja will fulfill all your desires and become famous as a second Mahendra. He will reward you handsomely and make all your endeavors fruitful. What more can I say? O father! If you want to, you can follow My advice and achieve an auspicious result." (Ananda Vrndavana Campu)

"Govardhana is reciprocating with your overflowing love and devotion. He is acting like a hungry person extending his arms bedecked with jeweled bangles. Look! Just see how this hill has appeared in person to full your desires! Now offer respects to him." (Ananda Vrndavana Campu)

By joyfully worshiping Govardhana Hill, the Vrajavasis realized that Govardhana is a person. (Ananda Vrndavana Campu)

Anyone who simply hears and chants about the glories of Giri-Govardhana, which are inconceivable to ordinary people, will be delivered from all calamities. (Ananda Vrndavana Campu)

When Vraja's king offered a great quantity of foodstuff to Govardhana Hill, Krsna, the enemy of Aghasura, assumed a gigantic form, proclaimed that He was actually Govardhana Hill, invited everyone to ask boons from Him, and, fooling even Srimati Radharani, ate all the offered food. Let me take shelter of the anna-kuta festival, when Lord Krsna enjoyed these pastimes.
(Raghunath das Goswami – Vraja Vilasa Stava, Verse 75)

When, aimlessly wandering around Govardhana Hill, madly calling out “O Radha! O Krsna!” again and again, and stumbling as I walk, will I sprinkle the places of the Lord’s pastimes with tears from my eyes? (Raghunath das Goswami – Vraja Vilasa Stava, Verse 103)

data.title: Arrived in Govardhana
data.blurb: My apologies to all for my prolonged absence. Sometimes it gets like that for me. As much as I want to write something regularly, I get caught up with my surroundings and writing what's going on around me, within me, (or both) gets relegated to a lesser priority.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
My apologies to all for my prolonged absence. Sometimes it gets like that for me. As much as I want to write something regularly, I get caught up with my surroundings and writing what's going on around me, within me, (or both) gets relegated to a lesser priority.

It wasn't until just a few days before I departed Budapest to Mumbai that I actually decided I would go. From one day to the next there was an internal struggle within me whether or not I should risk the progress I made with my back by traveling again. Sivarama Swami was advising me to not go, especially when he learned that a cervical disc had ruptured again. However feeling dutybound to other GBC members, who really wanted me to be in Mumbai, I decided that after almost three weeks of time dedicated for improving my back, I would go.

I suspect that some of you may have already known that I arrived in Mumbai on October 15th. Madana-mohana dasa, who later that day met us at Madhumangala dasa's home, has a regular posting he does through something called Twitter. I'm not sure what that is and I've not seen any of his postings. However, a couple of months ago he did send me a link (http://twitter.com/#!/Following_NRS) and said that he was making regular postings there in Russian for devotees who use Twitter.

So, early on the morning of October 15th, Agastya Muni dasa and I were met by Madhumangala dasa and Syama Gopal dasa and we were brought immediately to the home of Madhumangala dasa. Madhumangala and his family live approximately 15-minute's drive from the Juhu temple where the GBC meetings were scheduled from October 16 - 21.

I rested for awhile and soon thereafter Sridama and Kisori came to spend some time with me. Shortly before they left, Sridama expressed a strong desire for me to attend the Sarad-Purnima program that evening at Radha Gopinath Mandir. He said that Radhanath Swami, Giriraja Swami and other devotees were also hoping I would come. I agreed and when I arrived I found at least 2,000 people both inside the temple and outside the temple listening attentively to Giriraja Swami's talk about the gopis' conversation with Krsna. For those who could not fit in the temple (the majority) video screens were set up for them to watch and listen to the lecture.

After the lecture we all got a magnificent darshan of Sri Sri Radha Gopinath, surrounded by Lalita, Visakha, and other gopis under the full moon. The atmosphere appeared as if it must have been non-different to the place where Krsna's rasa-lila took place along the banks of the Yamuna. Radhanath Swami then requested me to sit and lead kirtan, which I did, and then I stayed a little bit longer mainly because I had "homework" to do before the meetings started the following morning.

There's more I could say about the week of the GBC meetings, but maybe some other time. Two days ago, Madana-mohana dasa, Syama Gopal dasa, Agastya Muni dasa and I flew to Delhi. I took lunch with Gopal Krsna Goswami in Delhi and shortly thereafter we drove to Govardhana, where I plan to stay for a little more than two weeks.

Early this morning, Dhanurdhara Swami, Syama Gopal dasa, and Agastya Muni went on parikrama half-way around Govardhana Hill. While entering Aniyora, we were pleasantly surprised to see BB Govinda Swami, Sacinandana Swami, Srutakirti Prabhu, Madhava Prabhu, and several other devotees doing dandavat parikrama around Govardhana Hill. I had heard they were doing dandavat parikrama every other day for four hours in the morning, but I had no idea where and when they were doing it. We all exchanged obeisances and embraces, but since I could see that they were very absorbed in their vrata, we quickly continued on our parikrama through Govinda Kunda, punchari, and then along the inner path towards Govardhana village.

Before continuing our "walking" parikrama, I asked Syama Gopal to take a few pictures with his smartphone of the devotees doing their dandavat parikrama. They should be posted below for your pleasure.

More from Govardhana soon…

Hare Krsna

For those who could not fit in the temple (the majority) video screens were set up for them to watch and listen to the lecture.

After the lecture we all got a magnificent darshan of Sri Sri Radha Gopinath, surrounded by Lalita, Visakha, and other gopis under the full moon. The atmosphere appeared as if it must have been non-different to the place where Krsna's rasa-lila took place along the banks of the Yamuna. Radhanath Swami then requested me to sit and lead kirtan, which I did, and then I stayed a little bit longer mainly because I had "homework" to do before the meetings started the following morning.

There's more I could say about the week of the GBC meetings, but maybe some other time. Two days ago, Madana-mohana dasa, Syama Gopal dasa, Agastya Muni dasa and I flew to Delhi. I took lunch with Gopal Krsna Goswami in Delhi and shortly thereafter we drove to Govardhana, where I plan to stay for a little more than two weeks.

Early this morning, Dhanurdhara Swami, Syama Gopal dasa, and Agastya Muni went on parikrama half-way around Govardhana Hill. While entering Aniyora, we were pleasantly surprised to see BB Govinda Swami, Sacinandana Swami, Srutakirti Prabhu, Madhava Prabhu, and several other devotees doing dandavat parikrama around Govardhana Hill. I had heard they were doing dandavat parikrama every other day for four hours in the morning, but I had no idea where and when they were doing it. We all exchanged obeisances and embraces, but since I could see that they were very absorbed in their vrata, we quickly continued on our parikrama through Govinda Kunda, punchari, and then along the inner path towards Govardhana village.

Before continuing our "walking" parikrama, I asked Syama Gopal to take a few pictures with his smartphone of the devotees doing their dandavat parikrama. They should be posted below for your pleasure.

More from Govardhana soon…

Hare Krsna

data.title: An Article Written by Devamrita Swami for "ISKCON News"
data.blurb: ISKCON's Biggest Festival: The Inside Story
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
ISKCON's Biggest Festival: The Inside Story

If indeed the USA is the best democracy money can buy, then certainly Ukraine, the largest country wholly within Europe, is a democratic price-grabber's flea market. Open-air, unvarnished, the affairs of any level of government—judicial, legislative, or executive—are on sale, 24/7.

Slip your money under the vendor's table. Then watch the police, courts, hospitals, and universities wobble and totter your way. First-world visitors—from what are now known as the mature, industrial democracies—can't stomach this apparent mayhem.

Ukrainians, however, long reconciled to their system, often shrug it off as how life is in this world and as a form of wealth distribution that keeps everyone happy. If you want to get something done, it's only fair, they often say, that everyone in the food chain, from the lowest clerk to the top bureaucrat, gets a bite. And why not point your finger at those piggy American bankers, who plunged the world into the Global Financial Crisis; yet how many have gone to prison?

During the Middle Ages, the territory of Ukraine was a mighty center of Slavic culture—before the Mongols poured in and eradicated the population. Seven centuries of constant strife followed, as neighboring European powers took turns pummeling and dissecting the phantom Ukrainian nation. Then in the 20th Century came Stalin, who made the Mongol hordes look like sugar babes.

Obsessed with collectivizing Ukraine’s famed agrarian prowess, his policies of forced collectivization and land confiscation obliterated the food supply. Starvation, augmented by firing squads and mass exiles, decimated a land often considered Europe’s greatest breadbasket. Historians, still arguing over the total death toll, estimate that at least 25% percent of Ukraine's population died in what is known as the Holodomor, or Ukrainian Holocaust.

In 2003 at the United Nations, 25 countries including Russia, Ukraine and United States, signed a joint statement on the 70th anniversary of the Holodomor with the following preamble:

"In the former Soviet Union millions of men, women and children fell victims to the cruel actions and policies of the totalitarian regime. The Great Famine of 1932-1933 in Ukraine (Holodomor), took from 7 million to 10 million innocent lives and became a national tragedy for the Ukrainian people."

Now, however, the same perennially mauled territory is a chakra of eternal bhakti culture. Graced with over 8,000 devotees participating in over 120 ISKCON centers and formal congregational gatherings, Ukraine, though economically one of Europe’s poorest countries, is exceedingly wealthy in devotional service.

The crown jewel of ISKCON’s endeavors there is the annual weeklong festival, in September, on the Black Sea. It’s theme: selfless devotional service, performed with no material motivation or gain. Amazingly, for its weeklong bhakti extravaganza, spanning from predawn to near midnight, the festival charges no fee.

In 1996, when the festival began, 400 devotees attended. By 2002, the attendance had climbed to 1,800, as a yearly bevy of visiting international senior Vaishnavas led seminars and kirtans. Each devotee paid a fee, in addition to accommodation, and received a plastic wristband allowing access to seminars, kirtans, and prasada meals.

After the 2008 festival, however, HH Niranjana Swami, an ISKCON Governing Body Commissioner, suddenly changed that approach. Walking at 5am to mangal-arti, the day's first congregational chanting, he noticed devotees, who couldn’t afford the festival fees, stealthily trying to elude the Vaishnava security-guards and clandestinely join the kirtan. Their sincere determination—to rise so early and participate in the predawn chanting—thoroughly moved his heart. Niranjana Swami began to rethink the festival’s concepts.

Out went the festival fees and enforcers checking for wristbands, national secretary Acyuta-priya das explains. The new policy: “Come one, come all—we’ll depend on Krishna and serve as many as show up.” Moreover, no longer would festival staff members receive any remuneration or expense compensation for their herculean, marathon efforts—all devotional service would be completely voluntary offerings of bhakti.

Upon registration, devotees are informed that the cost for festival prasada and programs averages approximately $40 per head, but everyone can pay what they can or want, whether nothing, less, or more.

The 2011 festival, just concluded Sept. 15, officially recorded 6,000 devotees attending—easily ISKCON"s biggest all-devotee event. Mystically, the festive accounts balanced, augmented by wealthy donors from both within Ukraine and abroad, inspired by the festival's bold spiritual vision and expert management.

How do you feed breakfast and lunch to more than 6,000 guests? Every day a different major temple in Ukraine takes responsibility for the massive cooking. To my delight, the veteran, senior international guests could opt for especially healthy cuisine—even amaranth, quinoa, and heaps of marinated ginger.

This year's international lineup of special guest speakers and kirtan leaders included HH Niranjana Swami, HH A.C. Bhaktivaibhava Swami, HH Prabhavishnu Swami, HH Indradyumna Swami, HH Prahladananda Swami, HH Bhakti Vijnana Goswami, HH Devamrita Swami, HG Bada Hari das, HG Yadubara das, HG Ganesh das, HG Dhanesvara das, HG Navina Nirada das, HG Caitanya Candra Charan das, HG Madhava das, HG Sarvatma das, and HG Devaki dasi.

Extending the festival's policy of donate what you can from the heart, the huge festival gift shop decided to go the same route. Devotees could walk into the shop, pick out any devotional paraphernalia or clothing, and pay what they could or wanted. Amazingly the store turned a profit.

Whether from the registration donations or the gift shop, any surplus funds are directly plowed back into next year's festival. With attendance growing by over 1,000 per year, a delightful problem presses: where to find a tent with floor that facilitates at least 7,000 eager Srimad Bhagavatam hearers and jubilant Hare Krishna kirtan jumpers.

data.title: All the Kirtans from Kirtan Mela
data.blurb: During the early part of this year, H.H. Sacinandana Swami contacted me and humbly requested my presence for the First Kirtan Mela Festival to be held in a rented campground near Leipzig, Germany.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the early part of this year, H.H. Sacinandana Swami contacted me and humbly requested my presence for the First Kirtan Mela Festival to be held in a rented campground near Leipzig, Germany. Initially, I was very hesitant to attend, knowing that the event would likely come very closely between two major events (Kazakhstan and Bhakti Sangama Festival). However, by June, after receiving several more requests from Sacinandana Maharaja and after looking closely at my calendar, I decided that it would be possible to go.

As most devotees who checked the Kirtan-Mela Website know, the festival consisted of four full days of 12-hour kirtan, plus opening kirtans on the first day and a Rathayatra in Leipzig on the last day of the event. Devotees came from all over the world to take part in the mela. For me, it was definitely an event worth attending, though I regret that my health (in particular, my back) was not doing so well. I was therefore very limited by the amount of time I could take part in the kirtans.

Fortunately, the organizers made recordings of most of the kirtans so I was able to hear a lot of the kirtans I missed. Some kirtans were missing from the recordings they made, but I was also able to find a few of the missing kirtans and added them to everything else which was given to me.

For those of you who would like to experience the intense devotional atmosphere created by 12 hours of continuous kirtan for over four days, all of these files are available here on this site. You can either download them or listen to them online. Moreover, each morning's Srimad Bhagavatam class is also available.

You can find everything on the home page in the box on the left entitled "Kirtan Mela 2011".

Also, if you are interested in downloading files from Bhakti Sangama Festival 2011, everything is available at the following link:

http://www.bhaktisangama.org.ua/audio.php

And if you are interested in downloading the audio files from the Toronto 12-hour kirtan, all of these kirtans can be found at the following link:

http://kirtan.krishna.com/recordings-2011-07-15-toronto-12hk

Hare Krsna

data.title: Thoughts About Gopiparanadhana Prabhu
data.blurb: I've been told that some devotees are wondering why I have not posted anything yet about the departure of our wonderful godbrother, Gopiparanadhana Prabhu. The explanation is this:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I've been told that some devotees are wondering why I have not posted anything yet about the departure of our wonderful godbrother, Gopiparanadhana Prabhu. The explanation is this:

I learned about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's departure on the 15th morning while honoring breakfast prasadam with a few godbrothers. The 15th was also the last day of the Evpatoriya Festival and the first full day of meetings which approximately 25 devotees scheduled with me for the 15th and 16th. Naturally I was torn between these events, but I had to follow through with the meetings since so many devotees remained in Evpatoriya exclusively for that purpose.

Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's departure was not only a shock to me but it was a shock to ISKCON's central nervous system. When I think of Gopiparanadhana Prabhu, I think of the one devotee in ISKCON upon whom all future Sanskrit translations would be resting upon. It's not that he was expected to translate all the works of the Goswamis himself (although he was certainly fully committed to his translation work). But Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was singlehandedly training future Sanskritists who would carry on the tradition of producing scholarly translations and commentary. He was a jewel among Vaisnava scholars and was deeply committed to carrying on the tradition of translating and commenting in the same mood as Srila Prabhupada.

If fact whenever I refer to the Brhad-Bhagavatamrita, I repeatedly state that, although so many books have been translated since Srila Prabhupada's departure, this translation and commentary of Brhad-Bhagavatamrita is the one book that I can read, quote, and meditate upon with the same confidence as if Srila Prabhupada had translated it and commented upon it himself. I was so much looking forward to reading Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's work on the Sandarbhas by Srila Jiva Goswami. I cannot imagine how this work will continue without him.

It is very rare in this world to find someone who is so scholarly and so humble at the same time. Gopiparanadhana Prabhu embodied both qualities like no other Vaisnava I've ever known. Both his scholarship and his humility were profound. He was not interested in position, recognition, and followers. Many years ago, I recall that even though many senior devotees worldwide were encouraging him to accept disciples, he was unwilling to take even the slightest initiative to be recognized as a spiritual master. For years, he simply continued to translate, preach, teach, and serve in a way which was most natural for him. His mood was that if ISKCON wanted him to accept disciples, then someone else would have to take the initiative. He was not at all interested in promoting himself as anything other than Srila Prabhupada's servant. And even though he was recognized several years ago as a disciple of Srila Prabhupada fit to serve as a spiritual master, his temperament never changed in the least.

I remember earlier this year I learned that Gopiparanadhana Prabhu had a conference called "Questions and Answers." The same day I learned that the conference existed, I immediately enrolled in his conference. My thoughts at the time were that if somebody was going to be asking questions related to sastra, Gopiparanadhana Prabhu would give answers I could count on for their authenticity. The mere thought that there was a repository of such questions and answers enlivened me so much that I immediately downloaded every question and answer in the whole conference. I'm now left to wonder, "Where will everyone who was asking now go for their answers?"

A little less than three months ago, when I was flying out of Moscow, I was informed in the airport that Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was transiting Sheremetyevo Airport at the same time. I immediately changed course and asked the devotees to take me to see him. I was surprised to see him dressed in Western clothes, since I had never seen him dressed that way before. But I quickly learned that he was on his way to China to preach. We embraced, and we sat down together to talk for about 20 minutes. I was eagerly inquiring from him about his translation work and was asking when we could expect his next book to be published. Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was his usual self— unassuming, jolly, and informative. It was a pleasure to be with him, but unfortunately, it has now turned into the last time I will get the opportunity to be with him here in this world.

Although I have not been able to write anything about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu until now, I have talked about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu with many over the course of the last three days. Without exception, every senior Vaisnava I have spoken with has reacted the same way about his departure. They were both sad at the loss of such a great soul, but happy to hear that he left his body in Govardhana, the very place where he wanted to always remain. Although I pray that he has entered into Radha Syamasundara's pastimes, deep down within me there is a strong, confident feeling that he is already there.

Gopiparanadhana Prabhu ki jaya!
Body_raw.safe_value:
I've been told that some devotees are wondering why I have not posted anything yet about the departure of our wonderful godbrother, Gopiparanadhana Prabhu. The explanation is this:

I learned about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's departure on the 15th morning while honoring breakfast prasadam with a few godbrothers. The 15th was also the last day of the Evpatoriya Festival and the first full day of meetings which approximately 25 devotees scheduled with me for the 15th and 16th. Naturally I was torn between these events, but I had to follow through with the meetings since so many devotees remained in Evpatoriya exclusively for that purpose.

Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's departure was not only a shock to me but it was a shock to ISKCON's central nervous system. When I think of Gopiparanadhana Prabhu, I think of the one devotee in ISKCON upon whom all future Sanskrit translations would be resting upon. It's not that he was expected to translate all the works of the Goswamis himself (although he was certainly fully committed to his translation work). But Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was singlehandedly training future Sanskritists who would carry on the tradition of producing scholarly translations and commentary. He was a jewel among Vaisnava scholars and was deeply committed to carrying on the tradition of translating and commenting in the same mood as Srila Prabhupada.

If fact whenever I refer to the Brhad-Bhagavatamrita, I repeatedly state that, although so many books have been translated since Srila Prabhupada's departure, this translation and commentary of Brhad-Bhagavatamrita is the one book that I can read, quote, and meditate upon with the same confidence as if Srila Prabhupada had translated it and commented upon it himself. I was so much looking forward to reading Gopiparanadhana Prabhu's work on the Sandarbhas by Srila Jiva Goswami. I cannot imagine how this work will continue without him.

It is very rare in this world to find someone who is so scholarly and so humble at the same time. Gopiparanadhana Prabhu embodied both qualities like no other Vaisnava I've ever known. Both his scholarship and his humility were profound. He was not interested in position, recognition, and followers. Many years ago, I recall that even though many senior devotees worldwide were encouraging him to accept disciples, he was unwilling to take even the slightest initiative to be recognized as a spiritual master. For years, he simply continued to translate, preach, teach, and serve in a way which was most natural for him. His mood was that if ISKCON wanted him to accept disciples, then someone else would have to take the initiative. He was not at all interested in promoting himself as anything other than Srila Prabhupada's servant. And even though he was recognized several years ago as a disciple of Srila Prabhupada fit to serve as a spiritual master, his temperament never changed in the least.

I remember earlier this year I learned that Gopiparanadhana Prabhu had a conference called "Questions and Answers." The same day I learned that the conference existed, I immediately enrolled in his conference. My thoughts at the time were that if somebody was going to be asking questions related to sastra, Gopiparanadhana Prabhu would give answers I could count on for their authenticity. The mere thought that there was a repository of such questions and answers enlivened me so much that I immediately downloaded every question and answer in the whole conference. I'm now left to wonder, "Where will everyone who was asking now go for their answers?"

A little less than three months ago, when I was flying out of Moscow, I was informed in the airport that Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was transiting Sheremetyevo Airport at the same time. I immediately changed course and asked the devotees to take me to see him. I was surprised to see him dressed in Western clothes, since I had never seen him dressed that way before. But I quickly learned that he was on his way to China to preach. We embraced, and we sat down together to talk for about 20 minutes. I was eagerly inquiring from him about his translation work and was asking when we could expect his next book to be published. Gopiparanadhana Prabhu was his usual self— unassuming, jolly, and informative. It was a pleasure to be with him, but unfortunately, it has now turned into the last time I will get the opportunity to be with him here in this world.

Although I have not been able to write anything about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu until now, I have talked about Gopiparanadhana Prabhu with many over the course of the last three days. Without exception, every senior Vaisnava I have spoken with has reacted the same way about his departure. They were both sad at the loss of such a great soul, but happy to hear that he left his body in Govardhana, the very place where he wanted to always remain. Although I pray that he has entered into Radha Syamasundara's pastimes, deep down within me there is a strong, confident feeling that he is already there.

Gopiparanadhana Prabhu ki jaya!

data.title: Thoughts About Bhakti Sangama Festival
data.blurb: Although I am still very busy with post-festival meetings, I wish to take just a few moments to publicly express my gratitude to all the hard-working devotees who voluntarily took part in rendering background service during the Bhakti Sangama Festival 2011.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Although I am still very busy with post-festival meetings, I wish to take just a few moments to publicly express my gratitude to all the hard-working devotees who voluntarily took part in rendering background service during the Bhakti Sangama Festival 2011.

While touring the festival site, as well as the VIP guest facilities, I was overwhelmed to see how many devotees were volunteering to selflessly serve in all the different departments of the Bhakti Sangama Festival. As I was told, the attendance at this year's festival was approximately 6,000 devotees, and literally hundreds and hundreds of those who attended were also volunteer festival servants!

Without exception, every senior Vaisnava I spoke with (and I spoke to a lot), told me that the atmosphere of this festival was beyond their imagination. Many were saying that it was the best festival they ever attended. As I was overwhelmed, they were also overwhelmed to see so many Vaisnavas happily serving other Vaisnavas, so many eager devotees enlivened to hear hari-katha, and so many enthusiastic devotees, all in one place, to enthusiastically chant Krsna's names for several hours every evening.

As in all big endeavors, there will always be some flaws. But each year brings another opportunity to improve. I would just like to say "thank you" to all the devotees who, year after year, continue to make this Bhakti Sangama Festival the wonderful festival that it has become today, and I also wish to thank those devotees who served in the festival organization for the first time this year. I pray that whatever drops of inspiration you hopefully received from Vaisnava seva will inspire you to go on serving in future festivals so that more and more devotees can come to relish the wonderful taste of unmotivated devotional service.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Today's Bhajan Class with Bada Haridas Prabhu
data.blurb: Several devotees who attended the Kirtan-mela in Germany, stopped in Kiev for a few days on their way to the Evpatoriya Festival.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Several devotees who attended the Kirtan-mela in Germany, stopped in Kiev for a few days on their way to the Evpatoriya Festival. This morning during prasadam with Bada Haridas dasa, Yadubara dasa, Navina Nirada dasa, Sarvatma dasa, Divyananda devi dasi, and Yajna Purusa dasa, I suggested that all of us attend a bhajan class with Bada Haridas Prabhu. Everyone happily accepted the proposal and at noon we gathered in one of the new temple conference rooms to chant bhajans.

As usual Bada Haridas Prabhu had some wonderful bhajans to share with us. Tota Gopinath dasa played the mrdanga, Sarvatma Prabhu played kartals, and we were all swimming in the ocean of Vaisnava sanga, happily chanting together and not wanting to stop.

I thought I would share a few of the bhajans we chanted here with all of you. They will give you a glimpse of what's in store for those of you who will be attending Bada Haridas Prabhu's bhajan class in Evpatoriya.

Unfortunately, the battery ran out of my recorder just at the beginning of "Krsna Prema-mayi Radha.", and I didn't notice it. But since the same bhajan was chanted during Bada Haridas Prabhu's class on Radhastami (which will be posted elsewhere on the site), I won't feel as bad that I wasn't able to share that bhajan from today's bhajan session. Although you should listen to both parts of his Radhastami presentation, I believe that "Krsna Prema-mayi Radha" will be in Part Two.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Evpatoriya Festival
data.blurb: The Evpatoriya Festival is quickly approaching. The opening day is only one week away.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The Evpatoriya Festival is quickly approaching. The opening day is only one week away. Anticipating the number of devotees who will be attending this year, especially the number of godbrothers and guests who I have personally invited, I wish to once again inform devotees about my personal preferences for meetings and initiation recommendations.

The Evpatoriya Festival, in particular, is a wonderful opportunity for me to see so many devotees who I otherwise do not get an opportunity to see now that I am traveling less. I would be very happy if I could meet with everyone. But by now, as hopefully most of you know, it is not possible for me to do so. Still, I know that many devotees come to the festival anticipating an opportunity to meet with me and it disappoints me when I have to tell them that I cannot meet them or when Madana-mohana dasa has to tell them the same.

Anyone with any degree of sensitivity should be able to understand where my attention is focused during this event. I am hosting so many godbrothers and invited guests at an event which is also attended by more than 5,000 devotees. I want to make sure that my godbrothers and personally invited guests are felt welcome, their concerns are addressed, and that they are being taken care of nicely. I am also concerned that everyone else attending the festival is being served with Vaisnava hospitality. I also wish to attend the morning program, to chant japa with devotees, to take part in the evening kirtans, and to speak at the times which have been designated for me to speak.

To be able to accomplish all of the above (with the additional need to exercise and rest my back at regular intervals each day) it is not possible for me to conduct private meetings DURING the festival. It is for this reason I always try to stay at least one extra day so that personal meetings can be scheduled AFTER the festival. This year I will be doing the same. I will stay for personal meetings on September 15th and most of September 16th. Meetings on September 15th will begin after 11:00 AM. Meetings on September 16th will begin earlier.

If you wish to schedule a meeting with me, please, therefore, do not book your return ticket on September 14th or September 15th. Please arrange your schedule and your accommodations in Evpatoriya so that you can be there all day on September 15th, and if possible, even on September 16th. I will still be in Evpatoriya for most of September 16th. It just doesn't work when 90% of the devotees wishing to meet with me tell Madana-mohana dasa, "I have to leave by 11:00 AM on September 15th morning." Under those circumstances, the logistics for accommodating everyone's request before their departure obviously cannot work.

Regarding recommendations for initiation, please make sure to bring written recommendations along with contact information for those who have written your recommendation in case they need to be contacted. Recommendations should be turned in directly to Madana-mohana dasa my secretary and they should be turned in by September 12th, the latest.

Thank you very much.

Hare Krsna
