data.title: My Visit with Rohini Suta Prabhu
data.blurb: When Rohini Suta Prabhu and I were together earlier this year in Mayapura, he showed me photographs of the beautiful deities he worships at his home. After seeing Them, I knew I had to get Their darshan.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
When Rohini Suta Prabhu and I were together earlier this year in Mayapura, he showed me photographs of the beautiful deities he worships at his home. After seeing Them, I knew I had to get Their darshan. Before we finished our meal, I proposed to Rohini Suta Prabhu that I visit him some time in Zurich. When he happily accepted my proposal, I fixed my determination to schedule a visit later this year.

Unfortunately, prior to our meeting in Mayapura, it had been almost ten years since the last time Rohini Suta Prabhu and I were together. We used to cross paths frequently in Russia and India. But since he reduced his travels over the last decade and since I also reduced my travels for almost five years, our paths did not cross. Still, as always, I was eager for his association.

While putting together my schedule in June, I decided that Friday, August 26th, would be the best date to stop in Zurich on my way to the Kirtan-mela in Germany. My flight to Dusseldorf left Kiev at 3:40 PM where I was to catch my next connection to Zurich. Unfortunately heavy thuderstorms in Germany delayed my departure to Zurich. When I arrived at 8:00 PM, Rohini Suta Prabhu was right there waiting for me. We happily embraced and from the airport we went to his home for a simple, but fully satisfying, dinner of soup, salad and capatis. Although our evening was cut short by my late arrival, I had almost nothing to do the next day other than to be in his and Gauranga Priya devi dasi's association.

By Krsna's grace, on Saturday, we got the opportunity to catch up on the last ten years. Although I did have a conference call in the evening, we spent the rest of the day talking, walking, chanting, honoring prasadam, and discussing philosophy. On Gauranga Priya's recommendation, Rohini Suta Prabhu and I also went to a nearby thermal bath so that I could take advantage of the mineral spring jet-sprays to reduce my back pain, which unfortunately, has increased significantly over the past couple of weeks.

From the thermal bath we visited nearby Wittengen, and the small village where Rohini Suta Prabhu grew up as a child. We walked the neighborhood and Rohini Suta Prabhu showed me the house where he grew up, the small schoolhouse he attended, and even the house where he used to go and play with his friend. It was an intimate day with a good friend. It was so nice to be in his association again that I begged him to consider coming to the Ukraine Festival this year. He apologized and said it would be difficult on such a short notice, but he did say that he would definitely try to come next year.

The night before I left I decided to take a video darshan of Sri Sri Krsna Balarama, Sudama, Sridama, Sri Sri Radha Gopinath, Gaura Nitai, Vrndadevi, Sadbhuja, and Srila Prabhupada. It wasn't much of a video, but still I decided to share it with you.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Vyasa Puja Offering, 2011
data.blurb:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to your divine grace!
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to your divine grace!

Recently I was with a dear godbrother who told me a story about you I never heard before. For my offering to you today, I would like to repeat the story he told, combined with an additional short story of how it was told. By so doing, I wish to show, once again, the power of your purity and the impact it has in the hearts of those who come in contact with you.

Last month I spent an evening with this devotee in the home of two of your spiritual grandchildren, both of whom love you very much and are always eager to hear everything they can about you. They cooked a wonderful meal, offered it to their home Deities and then the three of us— your disciple, his wife, and myself, sat down to honor the remnants.

At the end of the meal, your disciple was asked by one of his hosts, "Please, please, tell us something about Srila Prabhupada." Out of humility, he was reluctant to speak. But by the way he was asked, it quickly became obvious to him that it was not going to be an easy request to refuse. So he proceeded to narrate a few anecdotes he remembered from his association with you, one of which had a very deep impression on me.

He had been developing an uncharted region in Europe for your pleasure. By so doing, he was able to inspire you to come and to also preach there. He went on to describe to us the efforts he made to arrange meetings for you with as many dignitaries there as he could gather to meet with you. One particular dignitary was not as easy to convince as the others, but in due course of time, he agreed and said that he would be happy to meet you.

While describing these arrangements he made for your preaching, I was reminded of stories told, just one week earlier in Moscow, by your disciple and former secretary, Syamasundara Prabhu. He was relating his experiences with you to a large gathering of devotees on just how intense it was to be responsible for organizing your preaching engagements. He said that in 1971, after your meeting with Professor Kotovsky, he could not imagine how you would be able to tolerate the remaining three days in Moscow with no other preaching engagement. He knew well the intensity of your desire to give Krsna consciousness to others and that put a lot of pressure on him to find someone to whom you could preach—a task not so easy in Moscow in 1971, especially since preaching there was not only prohibited but also quite risky. He then went on to describe how he found someone on the street for you to preach to, and how you spent the following two days injecting as much Krsna consciousness into this person as he could absorb so that he could carry on your mission in the Soviet Empire.

The circumstances in Western Europe were not quite the same. But the pressure to find people who would be willing to hear from you seemed like it was. This devotee wanted you to meet the most important people he could convince to hear from you and he was ready to undergo whatever austerity required to bring them to your lotus feet.

Unfortunately I cannot remember the position held by this particular gentlemen who finally agreed to meet you. All I can remember is that he was quite influential. He came at the designated time for his meeting with you, he was then greeted and escorted into your simple quarters. He humbly sat down on the floor in front of you, and then you immediately asked him if he had any questions. "No," was his quick reply. Your disciple was both crestfallen and shocked. He knew that his spiritual master wanted to preach, it seemed, with the same conviction that Syamasundara Prabhu had. He was dejected, feeling he had let you down by bringing a disinterested guest unwilling to ask you even one question.

But it seemed you weren't bothered at all. You turned to your disciple and humbly requested, "Can you please bring me the harmonium?" Perfectly calm and totally unconcerned about social convention, you deftly began playing a devotional melody and then began chanting as if only you and Krsna were present. After some time, your disciple was staring at your guest. He was patiently sitting, listening attentively, and from his facial expression it seemed to your disciple as if he was being transported into another dimension, almost as if he was preparing himself to come join you and Krsna. Although he did not keep time, your disciple remembered that you continued chanting for quite a long time—at least twenty minutes—and he could see that you were completely absorbed as if in a trance. Finally you stopped, came back into their presence, looked up at your guest, and with an innocent look on your face, you said to your guest, "This is what we do." And that was it. That was your meeting. No questions were ever asked but all answers were given.

You then turned to your disciple and said, "Please give him some prasadam," and the story ended right there. But the memories of you did not and neither did the feelings of separation. Although your disciple was there, in front of me, it seemed he was also with you, almost as if he was hearing that same call you made to your guest while you were chanting. By that time profuse tears were gliding down the face of your disciple as he was recollecting those precious moments in your divine association.

It was contagious. Seeing his tears and his intense attachment to you, I also couldn't contain myself and my eyes welled up with tears too. Unlike my godbrother who continued to sit motionless in remembrance of you, I excused myself for a minute while I went into the other room to wipe the tears from my eyes.

When I returned, your disciple was still sitting there, still indifferent to the tears streaming down his cheeks. Recognizing his deep attachment to you, and probably also wanting to break what seemed like a long silence, our host then asked your disciple what was the most outstanding quality in you which attracted him to you. He immediately answered, "Srila Prabhupada was authentic."

In a world of hypocrisy, you, Srila Prabhupada, were the most authentic person he ever encountered in his entire life. And how that rings true, Srila Prabhupada, to all of us too.

On this most auspicious day of your divine appearance, I humbly prostrate myself before your divine lotus feet, and I beg you, Srila Prabhupada, please always let me stay in the association of those devotees who worship your lotus feet as the the most authentic medium for Krsna's mercy. I beg you to please also call me to join you, and to join all of them too (as it seems that so many are already answering your call) wherever you may be and whenever you consider me fit to remain,

Your eternal servant,

Niranjana Swami

He had been developing an uncharted region in Europe for your pleasure. By so doing, he was able to inspire you to come and to also preach there. He went on to describe to us the efforts he made to arrange meetings for you with as many dignitaries there as he could gather to meet with you. One particular dignitary was not as easy to convince as the others, but in due course of time, he agreed and said that he would be happy to meet you.

While describing these arrangements he made for your preaching, I was reminded of stories told, just one week earlier in Moscow, by your disciple and former secretary, Syamasundara Prabhu. He was relating his experiences with you to a large gathering of devotees on just how intense it was to be responsible for organizing your preaching engagements. He said that in 1971, after your meeting with Professor Kotovsky, he could not imagine how you would be able to tolerate the remaining three days in Moscow with no other preaching engagement. He knew well the intensity of your desire to give Krsna consciousness to others and that put a lot of pressure on him to find someone to whom you could preach—a task not so easy in Moscow in 1971, especially since preaching there was not only prohibited but also quite risky. He then went on to describe how he found someone on the street for you to preach to, and how you spent the following two days injecting as much Krsna consciousness into this person as he could absorb so that he could carry on your mission in the Soviet Empire.

The circumstances in Western Europe were not quite the same. But the pressure to find people who would be willing to hear from you seemed like it was. This devotee wanted you to meet the most important people he could convince to hear from you and he was ready to undergo whatever austerity required to bring them to your lotus feet.

Unfortunately I cannot remember the position held by this particular gentlemen who finally agreed to meet you. All I can remember is that he was quite influential. He came at the designated time for his meeting with you, he was then greeted and escorted into your simple quarters. He humbly sat down on the floor in front of you, and then you immediately asked him if he had any questions. "No," was his quick reply. Your disciple was both crestfallen and shocked. He knew that his spiritual master wanted to preach, it seemed, with the same conviction that Syamasundara Prabhu had. He was dejected, feeling he had let you down by bringing a disinterested guest unwilling to ask you even one question.

But it seemed you weren't bothered at all. You turned to your disciple and humbly requested, "Can you please bring me the harmonium?" Perfectly calm and totally unconcerned about social convention, you deftly began playing a devotional melody and then began chanting as if only you and Krsna were present. After some time, your disciple was staring at your guest. He was patiently sitting, listening attentively, and from his facial expression it seemed to your disciple as if he was being transported into another dimension, almost as if he was preparing himself to come join you and Krsna. Although he did not keep time, your disciple remembered that you continued chanting for quite a long time—at least twenty minutes—and he could see that you were completely absorbed as if in a trance. Finally you stopped, came back into their presence, looked up at your guest, and with an innocent look on your face, you said to your guest, "This is what we do." And that was it. That was your meeting. No questions were ever asked but all answers were given.

You then turned to your disciple and said, "Please give him some prasadam," and the story ended right there. But the memories of you did not and neither did the feelings of separation. Although your disciple was there, in front of me, it seemed he was also with you, almost as if he was hearing that same call you made to your guest while you were chanting. By that time profuse tears were gliding down the face of your disciple as he was recollecting those precious moments in your divine association.

It was contagious. Seeing his tears and his intense attachment to you, I also couldn't contain myself and my eyes welled up with tears too. Unlike my godbrother who continued to sit motionless in remembrance of you, I excused myself for a minute while I went into the other room to wipe the tears from my eyes.

When I returned, your disciple was still sitting there, still indifferent to the tears streaming down his cheeks. Recognizing his deep attachment to you, and probably also wanting to break what seemed like a long silence, our host then asked your disciple what was the most outstanding quality in you which attracted him to you. He immediately answered, "Srila Prabhupada was authentic."

In a world of hypocrisy, you, Srila Prabhupada, were the most authentic person he ever encountered in his entire life. And how that rings true, Srila Prabhupada, to all of us too.

On this most auspicious day of your divine appearance, I humbly prostrate myself before your divine lotus feet, and I beg you, Srila Prabhupada, please always let me stay in the association of those devotees who worship your lotus feet as the the most authentic medium for Krsna's mercy. I beg you to please also call me to join you, and to join all of them too (as it seems that so many are already answering your call) wherever you may be and whenever you consider me fit to remain,

Your eternal servant,

Niranjana Swami

Dear ______________ dasa,

Please accept my blessings. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

It is very important that the following information is disseminated so that devotees don't come to Kiev with false expectations about my visit.

From August 5 - 10, I worked practically all day, every day, on a paper which the GBC commissioned me to write. August 10th was the deadline. By Krsna's grace, I was able to submit the first draft of my paper on the night of August 9th. However, the first draft is only a part of the process. Now other GBC members on the committee are reviewing the paper and they are already sending their comments to the committee chairman. According to the schedule outlined by the committee chairman, all the comments will be summarized and submitted to me on August 23rd (the day of Vyasa Puja), at which time I have three days to look at them all and to begin work on the paper's revision in time for a conference call on August 27th.

What this means is that during August 21 - 26, the only public functions I will take part in are Janmastami and Vyasa Puja. Once Vyasa Puja is over, I will likely be too busy working on this paper to do anything other than that from August 24 - 26. In reality, I may not even have time to attend mangala arati on those days as I usually do.

Please see that this information gets posted to the community members and anyone else who may be thinking of coming to Kiev for my visit. I will also be posting this information on my website.

Hoping this meets you in good health.

Your well-wisher,

Niranjana Swami

data.title: Update
data.blurb: Other than the fact that I've not had a working internet connection for over a week, for more than a month it's also been too difficult for me to find time to either offer or upload material for posting on this site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Other than the fact that I've not had a working internet connection for over a week, for more than a month it's also been too difficult for me to find time to either offer or upload material for posting on this site. It is for these reasons alone that there have been very few new postings of blogs, lectures, kirtans, photos and videos.

By now, some devotees may have noticed that I generally set up a recorder before my classes, kirtans, or talks which are soon uploaded to the site. I have been trying my best to consistently do this for at least the past couple of years. However, now that I am traveling a lot more and also now that other obligations have increased once again, including my work as a GBC, it is becoming increasingly difficult for me to consistently record kirtans, talks, and lectures. I will certainly try my best. But the reality is that sometimes I cannot do it and neither can my secretary. One reason is that I cannot keep up with the constant demand for freshly charged batteries the recorder I use requires every time it is used.

From time to time other devotees have tried to help by providing audio recordings and I am grateful to them for their efforts. However, oftentimes these recordings were unacceptable for posting. For lectures, the recorded quality for both the speaker and the translator needs to be clear. For kirtans, not only the person leading has to be clear, but the devotees responding need to be clearly heard too. Generally a small mp3 recorder placed in front of the person speaking or leading the kirtan cannot record the quality required. As I have been told (by those who are more expert in these matters than I am), the recordings should be made in a "wave" format or better (and then converted to mp3), and the microphone (especially in a large room with sound amplification) has to be properly placed by someone who knows what they are doing.

I will look for alternatives for obtaining material required for this site. Meanwhile if devotees can be more conscientious of my need for quality material of lectures and other events (audio recordings, video recordings, photos, etc.) in the places I travel, and if they can make a point of handing this material on a DVD to either me or to my secretary before I leave either their city or their event, I will then personally see that as much of the material as possible is posted soon thereafter onto the site.

Fortunately, I was given some quality material from last week's Lithuania Festival. As soon I get access to a high-speed internet connection, I will see that it gets uploaded and posted.

Tomorrow I will be returning to Hungary for eight days. During this time, I will be focused exclusively on researching and writing a paper the GBC has requested from me. I may be able to write a blog or two—but certainly I will have no time at all for correspondence.

Hare Krsna

data.blurb:

Kaliningrad and Riga had to be cancelled primarily for the following reasons:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Here are some updates on my itinerary calendar:

Kaliningrad and Riga had to be cancelled primarily for the following reasons:

1) I was unable to get my Russian visa in New York on June 30th. The line was too long. After standing in line for some time, I observed that the rate at which people were being allowed to enter, I would have never been able to even enter the embassy before it closed-- what to speak of apply. One man in the front of the line told me that he had been waiting for three days. Since I had only one day in New York when I could apply, I'm now going to have to get my visa in Hungary, which means that I will have to stay in Hungary long enough to get the visa.

2) I still have a lot of work to do on a paper I'm supposed to write for a GBC committee. I will need at least a week to work on it and I must produce the first draft by mid-August. The first opportunity to work on it will come after the Lithuania Festival and the best place for me to work on it is in Hungary. Sivarama Swami and I will be able to collaborate there. I will also be undisturbed there.

Additionally, I was informed that many devotees from Kaliningrad will be in Poland during the time of my proposed visit.

I currently do not know when I will be able to reschedule visits to these two cities.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Where I am and What I've been Doing
data.blurb: I apologize to my blog readers for the long lapse of time since my last posting. The situation is simply this… I just haven't had the time.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I apologize to my blog readers for the long lapse of time since my last posting. The situation is simply this… I just haven't had the time.

Now that I'm traveling more, it's becoming increasingly difficult for me to balance my priorities. Madana-mohana dasa certainly helps to streamline my day so that I can keep more of my priorities in focus. Still, as I continue to travel, a lot also depends upon the number of new commitments that accummulate from one day to the next.

Moreover, when I'm in the United States, it's even more difficult. I'm more accessible to everyone here because everyone speaks English. When someone approaches, I can't say "Izvinitye. Mnye nuzhen perevodchik. Pogovoritye c' Madana-mohanom shtobi naznachit vstrechu." ["Sorry. I need a translator. Speak with Madana-mohan to schedule a meeting."] Of course, it would be nice if I didn't have to constantly say this in the CIS either. But since I have no choice, it does give me the option to at least organize my time a little bit better. [In this connection, some of you may be happy to know that just yesterday, I pulled about ten of my old Russian books and textbooks out of my closet here in Boston, hoping to take them with me so that I can start spending more time with them in the future. For now, it's just a hope, but taking the books with me is a good start.]

This last trip to Moscow and Lipetsk was wonderful for me. I was especially inspired by the mood of the 40th Anniversary celebration of Srila Prabhupada's visit to Moscow. I sincerely hope that similar events can be organized in the future. I will definitely attend. I could write more about my experiences in Moscow, but right now, time does not permit. If I can find time, I will write more about it in the future.

In fact, I don't even have much time to write more about where I am and what I've been doing. I will have to be very brief, though I'll try to fill in more detail in the future. I've had some very inspiring encounters.

From Moscow, I flew to Budapest for two days, rested, drove to Siofok to consult with my therapist, communicated with leaders from several countries, discussed details about the counselor system development in Hungary, and uploaded some of the material from the festival so that it could be posted here on the site.

I then flew to California, rested from the 15-hour flight, and then spent four very satisfying days in the association of my dear godbrother, Giriraja Swami, and many other devotees living nearby, including my godbrother Syamasundara Prabhu (who flew back to California from Moscow the same day that I flew to California from Budapest), my godbrother, Nrsimhananda Prabhu and his wife (whose name is now Nitya Manjari devi dasi), Sarvatma Prabhu and his wife, Divyananda dasi, and Bhakta Karl (Tamal Krsna Goswami's brother) along with his wife, Stella, and their daughter, Irene.

I then flew to Phoenix to spend one day with two very wonderful devotees I've known for many years. They formerly lived in Boston but reluctantly, they had to move almost three thousand miles away from the devotees they grew up with in Krsna consciousness.

Again, practically the whole day of June 28th was spent flying from Phoenix, through San Francisco and then on to New Jersey. I spent most of both flights reading Giriraja Swami's recently-published, revised version of "Watering the Seed."

I spent time with my godbrother, Guru Gauranga dasa, on June 29th. It just so happened that he flew to the United States from Brazil just days before my arrival on the East Coast, and he was flying out from New Jersey to Germany on the June 30th. Our flights were timed perfectly so that we could meet in New Jersey. I was so happy to be with such a dear godbrother that in order to avoid losing time from his association, I accompanied Syamakunda dasa to pick him up from Newark and to bring him back to Newark as well.

During his visit, Guru Gauranga Prabhu told a wonderful story about Srila Prabhupada that brought tears to everyone's eyes. But I'll have to tell the story later.

To be continued…

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Quote About Prayer
data.blurb:
Here is a wonderful quote by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura from which I spoke two days ago in Kishinev:

"3. How should we call the Supreme Lord?
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Here is a wonderful quote by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura from which I spoke two days ago in Kishinev:

"3. How should we call the Supreme Lord?

Śrī Gaurasundara taught us that in order to chant the Lord’s holy names, we must become lower than the straw in the street. Unless we consider ourselves insignificant, we cannot call upon another for help. Only when we pray for another’s help do we consider ourselves helpless. In such a state of mind we think that without another’s help we will be unable to do anything. We will feel it impossible to do that thing alone which is meant to be done by five people.

Śrī Gaurasundara has instructed us to chant the Lord’s names. We get this information from our spiritual master. To chant the Lord’s names means to take His help. data.title: What is Actual Independence?
data.blurb:
The following is another quote by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura from which I spoke on May 13th in Tiraspol:

"What is actual independence?
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is another quote by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura from which I spoke on May 13th in Tiraspol:

"What is actual independence?

To try to become God is nondevotional. The desire to become independent in this world means to become the servant of others. Material independence is simply a covered form of dependence. Complete independence is obtained by becoming dependent on the Lord, who is full of eternality, knowledge, and bliss, and desiring only to serve Him. As long as the living entities hold the rope of Lord’s mercy they are known as His servants. Those who think themselves self-dependent or independent should know that they are actually dependent on others. Only those who depend on the Supreme Lord are truly independent.

When we attain actual independence then the conception that we are eternally dependent on Śrī Hari becomes prominent. Any object that is a complete whole is transcendental. Service to or dependence on that transcendental Absolute Truth, Śrī Hari, is actual, joyful independence. Otherwise, the show of independence while identifying oneself as the doer or master brings only distress. It is nothing but subordination under Maya."

data.title: Coming to the End of my Ukraine Tour
data.blurb: With the additional responsibilities which come when I travel, it has been difficult for me to maintain the posting of blogs. I actually could say a lot about my travels during the past few weeks in Ukraine (and now in Moldova).
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
With the additional responsibilities which come when I travel, it has been difficult for me to maintain the posting of blogs. I actually could say a lot about my travels during the past few weeks in Ukraine (and now in Moldova). But for now, I will say that I've been very enlivened by this tour, primarily because it has been so long since I've been able to share my time with the smaller groups of devotees in cities throughout Ukraine (as opposed to the larger group found at the Evpatoriya Festival). It's been six years since I've been to some of these yatras! I'm really looking forward to more travels in Ukraine later this year.

Still, although I've been unable to post blogs, I have been trying my best to at least provide copies of the lectures I've been giving in the course of my travels. I hope that those of you who are more accustomed to stay connected with me from my blogs have been able to compensate for the lack of blogs by giving time to listen to some of those lectures. If time is an issue, then at least some of those lectures will hopefully be transcribed and posted in the near future.

Today and tomorrow there will be programs in Kishinev, Moldova, I will return to Kiev for two days, and then I am scheduled to return to Hungary for approximately two weeks, where some of the Hungarian devotees will be waiting for me to follow-up on Sridama Prabhu and Kisori devi dasi's visit there last week to help them with their developing counselor system.

Lately I started reading "Amrita Vani" again. It seems that whenever I open this book and start reading anywhere in it, I always discover some amazing jewels from the treasure-house of our revered Acarya, Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura.

Two days ago I spoke about dependence and independence and read from two quotes written by Srila Bhaktisiddhanta Sarasvati Thakura. I will be posting more of those quotes in future blogs, including another quote about "prayer" from which I might speak from today.

But for now, here is one of the quotes I spoke from two days ago:

"Should independence be renounced?

Those who are independent are proud, and those willing to subordinate themselves are humble. If after taking shelter of devotional service we become proud, and if after worshiping the Lord we neglect to serve His devotees and thus commit offenses at their feet, we will find ourselves facing inconveniences and then becoming detached from the Lord’s service. This human form of life is not meant for misfortune. Rather, it is meant to attain auspiciousness.

Why do we always forget this? Why do I forget that I am the most useless, insignificant wretch? To be tempted by Maya to become great or to enjoy is an insignificant and unnecessary occupation. If we really want to become humble, thus decreasing our hankering for greatness, then we should follow and associate with the Lord’s humble devotees, who are servants of the great."

As I mentioned in a previous post, I will be flying to Kiev from Budapest and I will remain in Ukraine until May 19th. The following is an approximate outline of what my schedule will be during my stay in Ukraine.

Although my flight to Kiev is scheduled to arrive tomorrow, April 18th, and my departure date from Ukraine is on May 19th, my travel dates within Ukraine are not fixed. They may vary by one or two days, depending upon the availability of flights. So everyone please take note that the exact dates of my arrival and departure in cities other than Kiev will be known only once all of our plane tickets have been purchased.

Kiev
April 18 – 28

Kharkov
April 28 – May 2

Kiev
May 2 – 5

Kishinev/Tiraspol
May 5 – 9

Kiev
May 9 – 13

Simferopol
May 13 – 16

Kiev
May 16 – 19

Please also take note of the following details:

During my visit to Kiev from April 18 – 28, although I will attend the morning programs according to my usual schedule, I will not give evening programs until Friday, April 22nd. Programs will probably be on Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. If there will be any other programs from April 24 – 27, they will be announced on Sunday, April 24th.

As much as I would like to attend the Vyasa Puja of His Holiness Bhaktivaibhava Swami in Kiev on April 22nd and 23rd, Maharaja has personally requested me to not attend, explaining that the event is for his sisyas only. I could have tried to convince him that I was also a sisya, but since I sensed that he was not going to accept my proposal, I did not push the matter any further with him. Therefore, the above-mentioned programs will be scheduled (unless Bhaktivaibhava Swami has a change of heart and tells me that I can come).

I have been requested by the GBC Committee I'm serving on to write a paper for the GBC body. I am scheduling time to begin work on that paper from April 19 – 22. I will therefore have very few personal meetings during that period of time, if any at all. Anyone requiring a meeting should first speak with Madana-mohana dasa, my secretary, and if meetings are scheduled, they will likely be scheduled during one of my shorter visits to Kiev—the dates of which are given above.

Throughout my entire stay in Ukraine, I will lecture no more than once a day, and other than Sundays, I will be lecturing only in the evenings. There may be very few exceptions, depending upon my flight schedules.

I am planning to visit Ukraine once again for the month of September and early October. If your city is not listed above, it's possible that it will be on my list for a visit this autumn.

data.title: My visit to Villagio Hare Krsna and an Update on Ladvamsi Prabhu
data.blurb: Thursday evening Trai Prabhu, Krsnaloka dd, Yasomatinandana dasa and I arrived at Villagio Hare Krsna in the northern part of Italy.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Thursday evening Trai Prabhu, Krsnaloka dd, Yasomatinandana dasa and I arrived at Villagio Hare Krsna in the northern part of Italy. After some delicious Ekadasi prasadam, we were taken on tour of the project by Anakadundubhi dasa, who showed us the temple, the village, and the other parts of the project. After the tour, we returned for the last arati and a beautiful darshan of Sri Sri Radha Ramana and Sri Gaura Nitai. Since about twenty-five devotees were present, we had kirtan with harmonium, mrdanga, and kartals, until the Deity curtain closed at 9:00 PM. Very shortly thereafter Yasomatinandana dasa had to return to his residence in order to take patients in his clinic the following morning.

The following morning at mangala arati, I was again very captivated by the beauty of Their Lordships Sri Sri Radha Ramana. But by the time I had my third darshan of Their Lordships during Deity greeting, I noticed that my mind was still becoming increasingly drawn by Their beauty.

At the beginning of Srimad Bhagavatam class, I couldn't restrain myself from expressing my appreciation to the pujaris and the other devotees serving Their Lordships for their wonderful service. The Deity outfits were just beautiful, Their ornaments were just beautiful, the altar was just so beautiful and clean, and when all that beauty was coupled with the beautiful features of the Deities, I just had to say something about Them to the devotees.

Unfortunately, I do not have a recording of the Srimad Bhagavatam class I gave at Villagio Hare Krsna. When I sat down to give class, I turned on the recorder, and almost immediately the batteries went dead. So rather than disrupting the class by getting new batteries, I just continued the class.

The verses were from the Third Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, describing the adverse fruitive activities of the conditioned souls, and specifically the verse which I was to speak on gave a graphic description of the soul's suffering even while on his journey to be punished in hell.

I decided to not focus on the descriptions of the actual punishments in hell, but instead I took the opportunity of the verse to explain how fruitive activities will always lead to suffering, wherever the soul will reside, and that the only relief from the sufferings of the reactions to fruitive work (as well as the only way to avoid punishment in hell from engaging in fruitive activities) was to render favorable devotional service to the Lord, free from the desire for fruitive gain and the desire for liberation from suffering.

Several devotees approached me after class to thank me, saying that my class was both very relevant and very helpful. After breakfast, I met with a few devotees, finished my rounds, shot a short video of the Deities (see below) and then I had my last lunch in Italy, prepared by my godsister Citra Rupini devi dasi. She prepared the most delicious ravioli I ever tasted. While honoring prasadam, I learned that many years ago Hrdayananda Goswami commented that Citra Rupini should be known as Raviolesvari devi dasi. We all laughed, but nonetheless after tasting the ravioli she prepared with so much love and devotion, I could understand why such a suggestion was made.

After lunch I was taken to Malpensa Airport. By Krsna's grace, there was no traffic at all, and I arrived an hour earlier than expected. I took the opportunity of extra available time prior to boarding to get the latest report on Ladvamsi Prabhu's condition. By Krsna's grace, I received the following report from Bhaktivedanta Hospital:

"Ladvamsi Prabhu is now stable. He was moved out of ICU (intensive care unit) on Sunday the 10th of April itself. His creatinine is now 5 which was 9.1 earlier. Apparently he does not need dialysis now and he is expected to recover gradually. In 15 days he will be fit to travel back out of the country."

Needless to say I was very relieved to hear this and I immediately contacted his mother, who I knew was also anxiously waiting to hear the latest report on his condition. He is not cured yet, but it does seem as though he is on the road to recovery.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Monday Night Program
data.blurb: On Monday Evening Krsnaloka dd invited a few local devotees to come to their home for an informal evening gathering consisting of bhajans, with questions and answers to come later.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On Monday Evening Krsnaloka dd invited a few local devotees to come to their home for an informal evening gathering consisting of bhajans, with questions and answers to come later. Despite being a weekday, about fifteen devotees made the thirty-five kilometer journey from Bologna to the village where we are staying, and an additional ten devotees drove an hour from Villa Vrndavana.

We started with a short kirtan, and then everyone very enthusiastically chanted "Ajna Tahal, Boro Sukher Khabor Gai, Bolo Hari Bolo" and "Bhajahu Re Mana." Two devotees brought a guitar and a bass guitar and accompanied us during the bhajans and kirtans. Actually, by the time the bhajans were over, because everyone was so enthusiastic I wanted to chant more so I asked what we should do, "More bhajans? Or questions and answers?" The answer I got was, "Both!," so I asked if anyone had any questions.

We had only enough time for two philosophical questions, but with the translation of my answers it took at least thirty minutes to answer the first question about what is the role of a siksa guru, and the second question concerning the benefit of adding austerities in our day-to-day life if we feel as though we are not sufficiently advancing. We then had one more kirtan, and after the kirtan while the prasadam was being served out, devotees who could speak English began asking me many questions about devotee care.

Before we knew it, it was 11:00 PM and nobody seemed interested to leave. I privately asked Trai Prabhu if we should continue, but as much as I wanted to associate with everyone more, without even hearing his answer, it became obvious that it was probably best to let everyone return to their homes.

The following photos taken by Krsnaloka devi dasi are from the preaching center program and from Monday evening's home program.

Hare Krsna

Yesterday afternoon I arrived in Bologna on a train from Milano. My godbrother, Trai Prabhu, met me at the train station and from there we went to the preaching center in the middle of the city for pizza, salad, and a very tasty apple pie (no sugar). What's a trip to Italy without pizza?

We spent time talking, catching up on each other's activities since my last visit in October, 2008, and then we drove about 25 kilometers outside the city where Trai Prabhu and his wife, Krsnaloka devi dasi, are living. In order to avoid the high cost of living in the city, they decided to live outside the city and make the sacrifice of driving to and from Bologna, almost every day, to conduct their preaching programs.

While chanting japa this morning, I looked out the window of my room and appreciated the beautiful, scenic countryside. Later in the morning, I pulled out a small video camera and shot a short video of the low-lying mountains and valleys just to the East of us. While listening to the chirping birds and taking note of the budding trees, vines and flowers, I could not help but think of Krsna's words to Arjuna, aham rtunam kusumakarah, "of seasons, I am flower-bearing spring."

Click on the photo below to see the beautiful landscape outside my window.

This evening Trai Prabhu and Krsnaloka organized a very nice Saturday night program at the preaching center in the city. With the help of five local devotees, Krsnaloka dd prepared an amazing feast of fried eggplant lasagna, salad, and lots of cake. So much prasadam was prepared that even though an unexpected total of 60 devotees, guests, and newcomers came for the bhajans, kirtan and lecture, almost a full tray of lasagna still remained after everyone had eaten to their full satisfaction. Everything looked so good that I was tempted to sample it. But knowing full well the consequences I would have to accept from honoring such a feast at 8:00 PM, I restrained myself and drank a small cup of lemonade instead.

The Bologna preaching center, organized by Trai Prabhu and Krsnaloka dd, is focused on introducing the local people to Krsna consciousness through cooking classes, kirtan-yoga classes, yoga classes, and Friday harinamas. Practically every evening of every week there is an event at the center. Since the aim of the Saturday evening program is primarily to give the newcomers an introduction to Krsna consciousness through chanting, Trai Prabhu asked me to speak on the topic of chanting as a means for internal satisfaction. Unfortunately the recorder I usually use for recording was unintentially turned off. But someone else who recorded it will give me his copy later this week.

Our next program is scheduled for Monday evening.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Please Say a Prayer for Ladvamsi Prabhu Today
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Devotees from Ukraine know my godbrother, Ladvamsi Prabhu, who has been living in Kiev now for almost eight years. For those of you who don't know him, Ladvamsi Prabhu and I grew up together in Krsna consciousness. We served in the Boston temple together about thirty-seven years ago, since the time he joined in early 1974. We distributed books together on traveling Sankirtan in the mid-1970's, and we shared many wonderful times together throughout the thirty-seven years that I've known him.

Today, April 9, 2011, Ladvamsi is being transferred from a hospital in Agra to the Bhaktivedanta Hospital. It will be a difficult journey for him but everyone agrees that it's best he gets moved to a facility where he they can take full charge of him in his present condition.

To make a long story short, Ladvamsi Prabhu had to begin a series of dialysis treatments in Agra. At this point, it's difficult for me to know the exact cause of his current condition. I've been told that the Agra doctors believe that he contracted something in India (typhoid was mentioned) and his kidneys were working at approximately 30% of their capacity.

Whether his current condition is life-threatening or not, is still too difficult to say. I've yet to receive a full diagnosis, it seems, because doctors still do not have one. He was taken to three hospitals before they were even able to determine that his kidneys were not functioning.

Please say a prayer today for Ladvamsi and give him your blessings to remain fixed upon the lotus feet of Sri Sri Radha Syamasundara during these difficult times.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Mayapura Temple Development
data.blurb: Having not been in Mayapura for six years, when I arrived in Mayapura on February 20th and saw the temple construction, I was assuming that the construction of the Temple of the Vedic Planetarium had been going on for several years.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Having not been in Mayapura for six years, when I arrived in Mayapura on February 20th and saw the temple construction, I was assuming that the construction of the Temple of the Vedic Planetarium had been going on for several years. However during the afternoon session of the GBC meetings, I learned that the work began only year ago. Considering the extent of the work which had already been done, I was very impressed. But what was even more impressive, was that Ambarisa Prabhu and his team gave a forecast that the main part of the construction could be completed within approximately three years.

What follows are photographs taken throughout 2010 as the temple construction began. The last photos in the set do not at all reflect what is existing there now. Before I left Mayapura work on the second floor of the project was already well underway. But these photos will give you a sense of the magnitude of the project.

These photos and a video which will soon be posted were given to me by Shrisha dasa, who currently is a member of the Temple of Vedic Planetarium Team. Shrisha dasa is in charge of 3D Modeling and Visualization. For more information and for the 2011 presentation, which was given to the GBC this year in Mayapura, please visit http://tovp.org/.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Travel Update
data.blurb: I've been asked for my travel plans. Here is a report of where I'm planning to go in the upcoming months, though unfortunately, it's not yet complete. Also none of my plans in June and July are confirmed.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I've been asked for my travel plans. Here is a report of where I'm planning to go in the upcoming months, though unfortunately, it's not yet complete. Also none of my plans in June and July are confirmed.

As I mentioned in my last blog, I arrived in Budapest on March 25th. I am regularly returning to Budapest for two reasons. 1) I still must continue to visit the therapist on a regular basis. She prefers I see her every two weeks, but because I have also resumed traveling, my visits now vary from once every two weeks to approximately once every month or sometimes even a little bit longer. I just saw her just two days ago and my next visit will be on April 16th. 2) Late last year Sivarama Swami asked if I would be able to help develop the counselor system in Hungary until he can become more actively involved in it's development and maintenance himself. I was happy to be of some service so that he could continue working on his new book. I therefore began closely working with the counselors here in January and will likely continue for at least another half-year.

On April 8th I will fly to Italy to visit my godbrother, Trai Prabhu, and to do some programs in his preaching center in Bologna. I will be in Bologna from April 8 – 13, together we'll then visit a devotee in Northern Italy on April 14th, and we'll then go to the Bergamo temple until the early afternoon of April 15th, at which time I will return to Budapest for my next therapist appointment.

My flight has not been booked yet, but I will likely fly to Kiev on April 17th. My Ukrainian visa expires on May 20th, so my plan is to remain in Ukraine until May 19th, at which time I will again return to Budapest for two therapist appointments, to renew my Ukrainian visa, and to continue my work with the counselor system.

My schedule for Ukraine is not fixed, although I have tentative plans to base myself in Kiev so that I can fly to different cities for Friday, Saturday and Sunday, returning to Kiev on Monday. Some of the cities I will visit in April/ May and other cities my hope is to visit in September/ October. Unfortunately I cannot say exactly which cities I will visit during April/ May, but I have tentatively planned to visit Kharkov, Kishinev, and Simferopol.

I will return to Budapest on May 19th and will stay until June 1st or 2nd, at which time I will transit Moscow, flying to Lipetsk until June 5th. I will return to Moscow on June 5th and will remain in Moscow until the day before my Russian visa expires, June 19th. I will write more about my Moscow visit in a later posting.

From Moscow I will again transit in Budapest from June 19th until June 22nd to see my therapist, and will then fly to the United States until July 21st or 22nd. Again, I have no fixed plan of which cities I will visit in North America for that month. My schedule for North America will be posted much later, probably some time in late May or early June.

I will return to Budapest on July 22nd, and plan to fly to Lithuania on July 24th, in order to take part in the Lithuania Festival from July 25th until July 31st. I also have tentative plans for August and September, but I will not post them now.

Hare Krsna

data.title: The Last Several Days
data.blurb: On March 20th, we had a wonderful Gaura Purnima celebration at the Taichung yoga center, consisting of kirtans, a morning lecture on Lord Caitanya, an abhiseka of Gaura Nitai, and then an initiation ceremony including an initiation lecture.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On March 20th, we had a wonderful Gaura Purnima celebration at the Taichung yoga center, consisting of kirtans, a morning lecture on Lord Caitanya, an abhiseka of Gaura Nitai, and then an initiation ceremony including an initiation lecture. In the evening we had a short talk and more kirtans with yoga students and outside guests. Many of those who attended the programs throughout the day were also relatively new to Krsna consciousness. We therefore tried our best to deliver lectures which could be understood by all those who attended. These audio and video lectures should be posted soon.

At 4:30 AM the following morning, Ekachakra and I drove two hours to Taipei so that I could catch my flight to Bangkok. I spent all day in the Bangkok Airport, though fortunately Thai Airlines gave me a free room and bath for six hours. I then flew to Mumbai, arriving in Mumbai late on the 21st night.

I rested all day on the 22nd, though I decided to chant bhajans with the devotees on the 22nd evening. The following day I drove together with Syama Gopal dasa, to the farm one hundred kilometers North of Mumbai, where I was given a five-hour tour of the project. Gauranga dasa, who is currently heading up the retreat center development, showed me the Retreat Center part of the project. The following morning I was shown the cow protection and agricultural aspects of the project by Sanat Kumar dasa. I also took part in churning some butter from the fresh milk that was taken that morning, and then watched while it was prepared into ghee. Some videos were taken of all of this and our tour which hopefully will be edited soon and uploaded to the site in the near future.

Yesterday, Syama Gopal and I drove to the Juhu temple, to meet Radhanath Swami. I also attended the wedding of two Radha Gopinath devotees who were getting married that day. Last night I flew a little more than eight hours from Mumbai to Vienna (where I am writing this brief update). I'll be boarding my flight to Budapest in 20 minutes so I will end here, though I should have time for more blogs once I'm settled in Budapest.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Preaching in Taiwan
data.blurb: I apologize if my silence since March 11th (my last blog posting) has caused any concerns to site users. I'm aware that the world is keeping a close eye on the news from Japan.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I apologize if my silence since March 11th (my last blog posting) has caused any concerns to site users. I'm aware that the world is keeping a close eye on the news from Japan. I have also been keeping my eye on the news, not so much because I'm concerned how all of us here in Taiwan could be affected, but because I'm concerned for those who live in Japan, especially the devotees. In fact, just two nights ago, I was finally able to contact Radhika Raman dasa, a devotee I've known for more than 25 years. He lives just outside of Tokyo. I had been trying many times to phone him since the time of the quake to find out how he, his wife, and his child were, but I was not able to get through. Finally, on Sunday evening, I spoke with him and learned that although he and his family were fine, the situation in Japan was such that all of them may have to leave there very soon even though they've been living there for more than nine years.

However, those who are concerned should know that other than sorrow for sufferings of the people of Japan, Taiwan has not been affected by the earthquake or the tsunami. There were no tremors here. There was no impact on the coastal areas here from the tsunami. There is a risk that if there are any major radiation leaks from the explosions at the nuclear plant in Japan, there could be some impact of that here in Taiwan. But, at this moment, there is no indication that anything like that has happened or will happen.

Meanwhile, we have been very busy preaching and I'm finding so many people receptive to the message I've been sharing with them. Since my arrival here in Taiwan five days ago, I've given three lectures to yoga students, including at least 1 – 1.5 hours of kirtan. Two of the programs were at "True Yoga" centers. You can find out more about "True Yoga" online. They are very popular yoga centers, probably one of the most popular in this part of the world.

On Sunday I gave the Sunday lecture at the Taipei preaching center. Approximately fifty devotees and guests took part in the program. They all danced very enthusiastically during the kirtan after the lecture. On Monday evening we did a program at the home of Mukesh, a very wonderful and humble devotee from India who has lived in Taipei with his family for many years. Although they invited people from the Indian community to his home program, an additional twenty-five devotees and guests from Taiwan also participated in the program. We spoke for about an hour about the importance of the holy name, we chanted a couple of bhajans, and then ended with a very enthusiastic kirtan.

Tonight's program at a yoga studio was especially ecstatic. Everyone chanted so enthusiastically and they were extremely appreciative of the experience they obtained from the chanting. When it came time to end the program, they were all begging for more kirtan. So we continued to chant for some time longer.

Tomorrow night, I will be speaking and chanting at the largest yoga center in all of Taipei, and then later this week we will relocate three hours South to Taichung for two more programs including the Gaura Purnima Festival on Sunday.

In case you're wondering why nothing has been posted in the audio or video section, it's because I have personally not recorded anything since arriving in Taiwan. One devotee, has been filming everything and has assured me that he will deliver first-class recordings of all the programs by the end of the week. Because he has to convert all of the video recordings, it's taking some extra time before he can provide me with the material. However, as soon as I have them, I will see that they get posted shortly thereafter.

Hare Krsna

data.title: From Mayapura To Taiwan
data.blurb: It was wonderful to be back in Mayapura after six years of separation from Lord Caitanya's transcendental abode. I could not go on parikrama, but I did take darshan of Sri Sri Pancha Tattva, Sri Sri Radha Madhava and the Asta Sakhis, and Lord Nrsimhadeva every morning.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
It was wonderful to be back in Mayapura after six years of separation from Lord Caitanya's transcendental abode. I could not go on parikrama, but I did take darshan of Sri Sri Pancha Tattva, Sri Sri Radha Madhava and the Asta Sakhis, and Lord Nrsimhadeva every morning. Although I'm unqualified to be engaged in Their service, I nonetheless prayed that some day They will consider me a worthy candidate for Their mercy. Without Srila Prabhupada's mercy, I would have not even been able to offer such prayers.

Twelve continuous days of morning and afternoon GBC meetings ended on March 3rd. As scheduled, my private meetings and evening programs began on March 5th. Considering my usual commitments in Mayapura along with my daily regimen of exercise and rest for my back, the addition of these personal meetings and evening programs kept me too busy to post blogs during the seventeen days I was there.

On March 4, I mostly rested and finished reading the last few chapters of "Miracle on Second Avenue," Mukunda Goswami's account of his early days with Srila Prabhupada in New York, San Francisco and London. I began reading this book about six days earlier, on a day when I was too sick with a stomach virus to attend the GBC meetings. After reading the first few chapters, I realized that I was not going to be able to put the book down. By the time evening arrived, I had devoured more than 300 pages of pure nectar. When the book becomes available for the public in June, I highly recommend anyone who can read English to get this book and to read all of it.

As an added encouragement, I'll share the few words I wrote to Mukunda Maharaja on March 3rd:

"I just wanted to thank you for the copy of 'Miracle on Second Avenue.' A few days ago I was sick and could not attend the meetings. I read about 300 pages of the book on that day. Today I heard a very nice talk by Dhanurdhara Swami about the relationships manifested in Govardhana. I've posted that talk below and it's available in both English and Russian. After the talk Dhanurdhara Swami, Ladvamsi Prabhu, my godbrother Apurva Prabhu, Ekatvam Prabhu, and I, along with a rather large group of devotees who came from Vrndavana, all set out to circumambulate this half of Govardhana Hill (the half where the Bhaktivedanta Sadhana Asrama is on). We all simply chanted, talked informally (some devotees were asking me questions) and we got many nice opportunities to remember the glorious pastimes which took place on Govardhana Hill.

This evening I was listening to, and chanting, prayers glorifying Govardhana Hill, written by Raghunath das Goswami, and beautifully chanted by my godbrother, Mukunda Datta Prabhu. I thought I would share the same experience by sharing the prayers both written and sung with all of you here.

Hare Krsna

Click Here to play Govardhana-vasa-prathana-dasaka

Sri Govardhana-vasa-prarthana-dasaka

Ten Appeals for Residence at Govardhana Hill

Raghunath das Goswami

(1)

nija-pati-bhuja-dandac-chatra-bhavam prapadya

pratihata-mada-dhrstoddanda-devendra-garva

atula-prthula-saila-sreni-bhupa priyam me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(2)

pramada-madana-lilah kandare kandare te

racayati nava-yunor dvandvam asminn amandam

iti kila kalanartham lagnakas tad-dvayor me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(3)

anupama-mani-vedi-ratna-simhasanorvi-

ruha-jhara-dara-sanu-droni-sanghesu rangaih

saha bala-sakhibhih sankhelayan sva-priyam me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(4)

rasa-nidhi-nava-yunoh saksinim dana-keler

dyuti-parimala-viddham syama-vedim prakasya

rasika-vara-kulanam modam asphalayan me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(5)

hari-dayitam apurvam radhika-kundam atma-

priya-sakham iha kanthe narmanalingya guptah

nava-yuva-yuga-khelas tatra pasyan raho me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(6)

sthala-jala-tala-saspair bhuruha-chayaya ca

pratipadam anukalam hanta samvardhayan gah

tri-jagati nija-gotram sarthakam khyapayan me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

Note: Govardhana means "that which nourishes (vardhana) the cows (go)."

(7)

surapati-krta-dirgha-drohato gostha-raksam

tava nava-grha-rupasyantare kurvataiva

agha-baka-ripunoccair datta-mana drutam me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(8)

giri-nrpa-hari-dasa-sreni-varyeti-nama-

mrtam idam uditam sri-radhika-vaktra-candrat

vraja-nava-tilakatve klpta-vedaih sphutam me

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(9)

nija-jana-yuta-radha-krsna-maitri-rasakta-

vraja-nara-pasu-paksi-vrata-saukhyaika-datah

aganita-karunatvan mam uri-krtya tantam

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(10)

nirupadhi-karunena sri-sacinandanena

tvayi kapati-satho 'pi tvat-priyenarpito 'smi

iti khalu mama yogyayogyatam mam agrhnan

nija-nikata-nivasam dehi govardhana tvam

(11)

rasada-dasakam asya srila-govardhanasya

ksitidhara-kula-bhartur yah prayatnad adhite

sa sapadi sukhade 'smin vasam asadya saksac

chubada-yugala-seva-ratnam apnoti turnam

1) O Govardhana, O king of all incomparable great mountains, O hill that became an umbrella with the arm of your own Lord as the handle and then destroyed the pride of the deva king madly attacking with raised weapons, please grant the residence near you that is so dear to me.

2) O Govardhana, please grant to me the residence near you that will guarantee the sight of the youthful divine couple as they enjoy passionate amorous pastimes in your caves.

3) O Govardhana, O hill where Lord Krsna happily plays with Balarama and His friends in the incomparable jeweled courtyards, jeweled lion-thrones, trees, waterfalls, mountain-brooks, caves, peaks, and valleys, please grant the residence near you that is so dear to me.

4) O Govardhana, O hill that provides the dark courtyard that witnesses the dana-keli pastime of the nectar-treasure youthful divine couple, O hill that brings great bliss to the best of they who relish transcendental nectar, please grant to me residence near you.

5) O Govardhana, O hill that, hiding as you playfully embrace the neck of your dear friend, Lord Hari's dear, unprecedented Radha-kunda, secretly gazes at the pastimes of the youthful divine couple, please grant to me residence near you.

6) O Govardhana, O hill that by nourishing the cows with its water, grass, and the shade of its trees declares to the three worlds the appropriateness of its own name, please grant to me residence near you.

7) O Govardhana, O hill that the enemy of Agha and Baka honored by transforming into a new house to give Vraja protection from the sustained fury of the sura king, please grant to me residence near you.

8) O Govardhana, O king of mountains, O hill whose nectar name "the best of Lord Hari's servants" flows from the moon of Sri Radha's mouth, O hill that the Vedas declare to be the tilaka marking of Vraja, please grant to me residence near you.

9) O Govardhana, O philanthropist that gives transcendental happiness to Vraja's people, animals, and birds, all anointed with the nectar of friendship for Sri Sri Radha-Krsna surrounded by Their friends, out of Your immeasurable mercy, please accept unhappy me and please grant me residence near you.

10) Although I am a cheater and a criminal, unlimitedly merciful Lord Sacinandana, who is very dear to you, has given me to you. O Govardhana, please do not consider whether I am acceptable or not, but simply grant me residence near you.

11) One who carefully reads these ten nectar verses describing Srila Govardhana, the king of mountains, will very soon reside near that blissful hill and quickly attain the precious jewel of the service to the handsome divine couple.

Body_raw.value:
When I was in Boston, I found a small packet of photos in my desk drawer, many of which were taken by an American TV associate producer in 1992 when she (I can't remember her name) and her crew were filming me for a television series called "Street Stories." As I later learned, the show, which focused mainly on social issues in the United States, was rated the #2 evening television show in the country for it's popularity.

I first met the entire crew at the Begovaya temple in Moscow. The producer was very courteous and she presented her purpose for wanting to film me along with the Russian devotees. She was particularly interested in me because, as she said, I was an American preaching in Russia and that would appeal to an American audience. She also did not hide the fact they had been filming other American missionaries from different traditions in Russia who would all be included in the same segment on "Street Stories." As she told me, the devotees were their last assignment in Russia.

After some discussion, it was decided that we would spend the next several days filming devotees and myself in the temple, on harinama at the Arbat, and then they wanted to relocate to Leningrad where they hoped to film me in our restaurant and especially with the children at our small gurukula.

According to plan, the producer, the TV correspondent, Peter Van Sant, and the camera crew took many hours of footage of the devotees in Moscow. From there we went separately to Leningrad. They flew on their private plane, I flew on Aeroflot and we met at a prearranged time and place to begin our first filming in Leningrad at the restaurant. After recording the affairs of the restaurant, including another short interview with me, we all jumped into a vehicle together to make our last and final stop on the tour to the Leningrad gurukula.

It was there in the gurukula when I began to notice that everyone began softening up and started to become a lot more friendly, especially towards me. We had prepared lunch for the entire crew and everyone honored prasadam with great enthusiasm, eating far more than the devotees expected them to eat. Moreover, now that our time together was coming to a close, they all started asking more personal questions about the devotees and about me, seriously wanting to learn more about our values and lifestyle. In particular, they began asking a lot of questions about what made me accept Krsna consciousness as a way of life.

Although they were scheduled to leave just after lunch, I recall that they stayed longer than they had initially planned. Filled with all kinds of Krsna prasadam, Peter Van Sant started confessing that he did not expect to find what he saw in the lives of Krsna's devotees. He was genuinely moved by their sincerity, and when he started talking about the children, he looked emotional and admitted that seeing the children brought tears to his eyes.

Gradually everyone else on the crew also began speaking about their experiences with the devotees, and described the children to be like "angels from heaven." If you look at them in some of the photos, you'll see that they were so happy being with the children.

As it turned out they really did not want to leave. But since it was their last day in Leningrad, they had no choice. Their flight back to Moscow on their private jet was that night. And from Moscow they were scheduled to catch their onward flight to New York in the morning.

We parted ways at the school, shaking hands and thanking each other for the experiences we shared together. However, unexpectedly, later that evening, we all met again at the airport. When they saw me coming into the departure area, they jumped up and all of them started moving quickly towards me. Again, totally unexpected, every one of them started to embrace me. It appeared that they were slightly intoxicated as apparently they were celebrating the last day of their assignment in Russia. In that state, they started to open up even more with me than before.

All of them revealed that from all the religious groups they filmed in Russia, none of them had any substance in comparison to what they saw in the lives of the Krsna devotees. I sensed that they were telling me this almost apologetically, giving me a slight indication (although I still did not suspect at that time) that maybe the TV show was not going to be as favorable as I had hoped.

The cameraman gave me his business card and told me that he was one of CBS network's top cameramen. He began listing the assignments he had been on all over the world. He said that from all of his assignments, his time with the devotees was one of the best experiences he ever had as a cameraman. He hugged me again and then said, "My home is your home. Please take this card and come visit me any time you're in the New York area." I sensed that he really meant it.

Then the producer spoke out next. She said, "We have a private jet taking us to Moscow tonight! Please, please, accept our invitation and fly with us to Moscow. We would be honored to travel with you." I apologized and told her that as much as I would like to accompany them to Moscow, I was booked on a flight to Minsk and couldn't disappoint the devotees there who were expecting me that night.

We exchanged many more pleasantries but soon it was time for me to board my flight to Minsk. We said our good-byes once again, but before I left, the producer asked if she could come and visit me in Boston the next time I would be in the United States. She said that she had taken some photographs of us in the school and she would like to deliver them to me personally. I thanked her for her offer and assured her that I would contact her the next time I would be in the United States. As it turned out, she did come and see me and she did bring the pictures—the same ones which I've posted here on the site.

By the time I reached the United States I found out that the "Street Stories" segment on "American missionaries in Russia" was not as favorable as I was hoping it would be. It appeared that, somewhere along the line, possibly the executive producers in New York, someone took the material and tried their best to cast each of the missionaries in an unfavorable light.

When I saw a recording of the show, I immediately remembered the apologetic tone of the television crew when they met me at the airport in Leningrad, and it started to become more clear why (in that slightly intoxicated state) they looked as if they were feeling a little bad.

I assumed (and it was confirmed when I met the associate producer again in Boston) it was because after filming the devotees, they honestly did not want the devotees to be cast in the same light as the other missionaries they interviewed in Russia. I recalled hearing several times in my conversations with the crew in Russia, how they were not at all impressed with the methodologies the American missionaries filmed before me, were using to convert the Russians to their faith. They even mentioned different tactics that were used to attract people, many of which were shown in the segment on "Street Stories."

Although the whole segment was not so favorable, in comparison to the other missionaries depicted, the devotees looked genuinely happy and were doing just what they should be doing. While other missionaries were dressing up as clowns and were making animals out of balloons to attract people on the street, and while they were resorting to apparently misleading tactics to win Russians over to their faith, the devotees were enthusiastically chanting Hare Krsna in a big kirtan. Although they obviously could not show partiality to us in the show, it seemed to me that either they could not, or intentionally did not, make us look as bad as the other missionaries they filmed. To this day, I still don't know which of the two reasons it was.

Still, I'm convinced that if we simply present Krsna consciousness as it is, without being pretentious, those who are sincere will be affected in a positive way. I have no doubt that the entire "Street Stories" crew were impressed by what they saw in the lives of the devotees. Srila Prabhupada has given us the perfect formula for spreading Krsna consciousness. "Chant Hare Krsna and Be Happy." If we do that, whatever conclusion someone wishes to draw about Hare Krsna devotees, we will have presented everything right.

Hare Krsna

It appeared that they were slightly intoxicated as apparently they were celebrating the last day of their assignment in Russia. In that state, they started to open up even more with me than before.

All of them revealed that from all the religious groups they filmed in Russia, none of them had any substance in comparison to what they saw in the lives of the Krsna devotees. I sensed that they were telling me this almost apologetically, giving me a slight indication (although I still did not suspect at that time) that maybe the TV show was not going to be as favorable as I had hoped.

The cameraman gave me his business card and told me that he was one of CBS network's top cameramen. He began listing the assignments he had been on all over the world. He said that from all of his assignments, his time with the devotees was one of the best experiences he ever had as a cameraman. He hugged me again and then said, "My home is your home. Please take this card and come visit me any time you're in the New York area." I sensed that he really meant it.

Then the producer spoke out next. She said, "We have a private jet taking us to Moscow tonight! Please, please, accept our invitation and fly with us to Moscow. We would be honored to travel with you." I apologized and told her that as much as I would like to accompany them to Moscow, I was booked on a flight to Minsk and couldn't disappoint the devotees there who were expecting me that night.

We exchanged many more pleasantries but soon it was time for me to board my flight to Minsk. We said our good-byes once again, but before I left, the producer asked if she could come and visit me in Boston the next time I would be in the United States. She said that she had taken some photographs of us in the school and she would like to deliver them to me personally. I thanked her for her offer and assured her that I would contact her the next time I would be in the United States. As it turned out, she did come and see me and she did bring the pictures—the same ones which I've posted here on the site.

By the time I reached the United States I found out that the "Street Stories" segment on "American missionaries in Russia" was not as favorable as I was hoping it would be. It appeared that, somewhere along the line, possibly the executive producers in New York, someone took the material and tried their best to cast each of the missionaries in an unfavorable light.

When I saw a recording of the show, I immediately remembered the apologetic tone of the television crew when they met me at the airport in Leningrad, and it started to become more clear why (in that slightly intoxicated state) they looked as if they were feeling a little bad.

I assumed (and it was confirmed when I met the associate producer again in Boston) it was because after filming the devotees, they honestly did not want the devotees to be cast in the same light as the other missionaries they interviewed in Russia. I recalled hearing several times in my conversations with the crew in Russia, how they were not at all impressed with the methodologies the American missionaries filmed before me, were using to convert the Russians to their faith. They even mentioned different tactics that were used to attract people, many of which were shown in the segment on "Street Stories."

Although the whole segment was not so favorable, in comparison to the other missionaries depicted, the devotees looked genuinely happy and were doing just what they should be doing. While other missionaries were dressing up as clowns and were making animals out of balloons to attract people on the street, and while they were resorting to apparently misleading tactics to win Russians over to their faith, the devotees were enthusiastically chanting Hare Krsna in a big kirtan. Although they obviously could not show partiality to us in the show, it seemed to me that either they could not, or intentionally did not, make us look as bad as the other missionaries they filmed. To this day, I still don't know which of the two reasons it was.

Still, I'm convinced that if we simply present Krsna consciousness as it is, without being pretentious, those who are sincere will be affected in a positive way. I have no doubt that the entire "Street Stories" crew were impressed by what they saw in the lives of the devotees. Srila Prabhupada has given us the perfect formula for spreading Krsna consciousness. "Chant Hare Krsna and Be Happy." If we do that, whatever conclusion someone wishes to draw about Hare Krsna devotees, we will have presented everything right.

Hare Krsna
