data.title: Travel Update and Plans
data.blurb: The following are my travel plans for the next two months. I'm posting them here to remain consistent with previous posts wherein I encouraged devotees to get the most accurate details of my travel plans here on this site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following are my travel plans for the next two months. I'm posting them here to remain consistent with previous posts wherein I encouraged devotees to get the most accurate details of my travel plans here on this site. I will also continue to explain what my priorities will be during my travels so that devotees do not travel to see me with false expectations.

I am scheduled to fly from Budapest to Mumbai on February 8th and will remain in Mumbai until February 13th. For the most part, the purpose of my visit to Mumbai is to be with H.H. Radhanath Swami, to visit the devotees of Radha Gopinath Mandir, and to follow through with some tests at Bhaktivedanta Hospital which I was unable to complete in November because of my unexpected departure to Moscow.

From Mumbai I will go to Govardhana until February 19th. Since, essentially, I will be in Govardhana for only five days, I plan to use this time for myself, for reading, parikrama and as much as possible, absorbing my thoughts in Govardhana. Moreover, since the Bhaktivedanta Sadhana Asrama is a monastary, I wish to comply with the rules of the monastary which is to not encourage guests to visit me there. I also made previous plans to spend time with H.H. Partha Sarathi das Goswami during this brief visit.

Bhaktivedanta Asrama is also publicly known as a monastary, an asrama inhabited only by men. The asrama, therefore, is under the close scrutiny of the local residents. Not wanting to bring disrepute to the asrama in the eyes of the dhama-vasis, the asrama management is careful to restrict the mixing of men and women within the asrama, as well as to control the frequency of women entering into the asrama. Devotees should be conscious of this.

If there are devotees who will be in Vrndavana or Govardhana during the days of my stay in Govardhana, and who wish to spend time with me, then the only opportunity for this will be on February 17th, which is the day I plan to chant and visit some holy places in Govardhana. There will be no discourses—only chanting. Devotees wishing to accompany me may do so, but on the condition that there are at least an equal number of men as there are women. It can not be otherwise.

From Govardhana my plan is to take a short darshan of Sri Sri Radha Syamasundara, Sri Sri Krsna Balarama, Sri Sri Gaura Nitai, and Srila Prabhupada on Feburary 19th. I will then relocate to Mayapura, arriving there on the morning of February 20th, the same day the GBC meetings are scheduled to begin.

During the days of the meetings, February 20 – March 3, I will follow the same schedule I generally follow wherever I travel. I will go to mangala arati, chant japa, and will leave to do my morning therapy either just before Guru-puja or just after the Guru-Puja kirtan, depending upon the intensity of the schedule I'll have in the GBC meetings. There will be no personal meetings during this time. Neither will I take part in any events other than the morning program, GBC meetings, and associating with my godbrothers.

After the GBC meetings I will remain in Mayapura until March 9th. This means that March 4th will be a day of complete rest, and then from March 5 – 9, I will have a restricted schedule for meeting and associating with devotees in Mayapura. I cannot yet say what that schedule will be and I probably won't be able to say what that schedule will be until the GBC meetings are finished.

On March 9th, I will depart from Kolkata to Taiwan, where I will remain until March 21st. During my visit to Taiwan I will do programs in Taipei and Taichung, and I will try to fulfill a commitment (lecturing in Taipei) which I was unable to fulfill the last time I was in Taiwan because of the state of my health.

On March 21st, I will fly all day, arriving in Mumbai late on the night of the same day. Provided immigration will allow my re-entry to India (because of a new law they introduced about one year ago) I will spend approximately three days in Mumbai. I am then scheduled to return to Budapest on the night of March 24th. I do have all the required documents for re-entry to India, but there's always the chance that I will meet an immigration officer who is unaware of the current details of the law. The law and it's recent revisions are quite new.

At present, I have no schedule planned beyond March 25th, except that I will need to spend some time in Hungary upon my return from India to follow up with the work I've begun during this visit. During this visit, upon the request of H.H. Sivarama Swami, I began helping the local devotees with their development of the counselor system in Hungary.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Being with Srila Prabhupada
data.blurb: The following is an edited transcript of a talk given on January 15, 2011 at the Yurlovo Brahmacari Asrama during the Installation of Srila Prabhupada’s Murti:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is an edited transcript of a talk given on January 15, 2011 at the Yurlovo Brahmacari Asrama during the Installation of Srila Prabhupada’s Murti:


I cannot stay here for a long time; I just want to say a few words. I’m trying to think of something relevant to today’s event that I can speak about; because I can understand that today you’re welcoming Srila Prabhupada here in Yurlovo, in your temple room, taking Him on tour to see the facilities here, and placing Him on the vyasasana where He will sit and overlook the activities going on here. Of course, He will more or less be here most of the time and many of His vyasasana pastimes will be manifested during His presence here on the vyasasana.

Srila Prabhupada had so many pastimes, not just on the vyasasana and to the degree you meditate upon Him, hear about Him, serve His instructions and read His books, to that degree Srila Prabhupada will become more and more manifested to you in your life. In other words, Srila Prabhupada is not simply a Deity sitting on the vyasasana, and the devotees who are welcoming Him here should display their realization of that by their dealings with Him, the way He is manifested here now.

Prabhupada, the times I saw Him sitting on the vyasasana, was always reciprocating with His disciples. In other words, although He was very conscious of Krsna’s presence on the altar, He was also very conscious of all the devotees who were present before Him. I never saw Srila Prabhupada chant His japa while He was being worshipped during the Guru-puja, for instance. He was never seen indifferent to the presence of His disciples. Srila Prabhupada would always sit there and participate ,playing the gong or the karatalas or chanting the Guru-puja kirtan. He would always look at everybody and everybody would have a sense that He was looking at them, but not only looking at them but looking much deeper than just at a physical form.

I had the experience once when Prabhupada was sitting and giving a Srimad-Bhagavatam class in Philadelphia. Many devotees came to see Him for that festival. I had to stay in some place far away because there was no place to stay near the temple. Therefore I, with a large group of devotees, arrived a little bit late and the temple room was already completely full when we got there. Many of us were trying to get into the temple room to see Srila Prabhupada. One devotee inside closed the door and many of us were left standing in the hall way. Prabhupada saw what was going on. He could see how crestfallen we were. The next thing we knew was that the door was opening again. Apparently Prabhupada pointed to that devotee to open the door and gestured for all of us to come in. Even though the temple was full, Srila Prabhupada was ready to defy the physical laws of this world and He invited us all to come and sit down.

Taking advantage of Srila Prabhupada’s invitation I walked toward the front to sit in front of Srila Prabhupada. I walked in, sat down and Prabhupada looked at me as I walked in, giving me his typical penetrating glance which went right through to the eyes, into the heart, and into the soul. I began to realize that Prabhupada knew me and my whole history simply by His glance. I would often stories about Prabhupada doing that to many other devotees.

In other words, Srila Prabhupada was never indifferent to the presence of the devotees who were there worshipping Him. He was always very conscious of our presence and at the same time fully Krsna-conscious. Therefore, I mentioned this because this is just one example that sometimes, if we are not careful,we may think that Prabhupada is just sitting on his vyasasana and chanting His japa while we are worshipping Him in the Guru-puja, but I never saw Him do that. Obviously Srila Prabhupada shouldn’t have His japa beads chanting His japa while we worship Him during Guru-puja.

This is just one example, there are many examples that we can use to help us feel more and more Srila Prabhupada’s presence and to be conscious of His presence in this world. For instance, just this morning during Guru-puja in “Dinamo” (this is just another example, and I’m using these examples to help emphasize the point I wish to make) we greeted the Deities and then we went to receive Srila Prabhupada for his Guru-puja. I was present many times when Srila Prabhupada would greet the Deities and would then sit on His vyasasana to accept Guru-puja, and therefore I always meditate on that during Deity greet and Guru-puja. In my mind and in my heart I’m just seeing Prabhupada offering His obeisances to the Deities and returning to His vyasasana to receive His flower garland, arati, flower petals.

I saw many times after the arati and after the devotees offered flower petals, Prabhupada would take the petals from His lotus feet and throw them at us. You can imagine what that did. Srila Prabhupada would create pandemonium in the temple room. He would take the flower petals, throw them at the devotees and the devotees would take the petals, put them on their heads and then would start throwing them at each other. Then more flower petals were placed at Prabhupada’s lotus feet so that Prabhupada could take more petals and throw them. This is another example how Prabhupada wasn’t indifferent to our presence. He wasn’t just sitting there thinking of something else.

Anyway, this morning Prabhupada sat on His vyasasana (generally, I immediately start leading the kirtan, because when Prabhupada sits on the vyasasana somebody should immediately start chanting), and the garland was sitting in the basket. One minute, two minutes, three minutes, four minutes passed and the garland was still sitting in the basket while I was chanting. If Prabhupada sat on the vyasasana, would the devotees wait to put on His garland? When I was with Prabhupada, every time He sat on the vjasasana, immediately there were devotees standing around who were waiting to put their garland on as soon as he sat down. One, sometimes two, three or five garlands were immediately put on Him. Sandalwood paste was put on His forehead, and then His servant would give Prabhupada either karatalas or a gong and Prabhupada would chant along.

However this morning Srila Prabhupada waited many minutes. No one put His garland on and I had to stop the kirtan to go put His garland on. Think about it. If Prabhupada sits on the vyasasana, will we make Him wait five minutes for the garland? No, immediately we will give Him his garland.

I can think of many examples. I don’t want to turn this into a chastisement for neglecting Srila Prabhupada. I just want to welcome you nto the world of being with Prabhupada. This is how you could be with Srila Prabhupada, to be very conscious that now He is coming to be with you and to just see that He is never indifferent towards us. Please never be indifferent towards Him.

Srila Prabhupada’s life was reciprocating with His disciples, and everything he did, constantly we always felt Prabhupada’s reciprocation. You can feel it too. Welcome Prabhupada and be with Him every day, not only in this form here on the vyasasana but by studying His books, hearing about His activities and pastimes and serving His instructions. In this way welcome Prabhupada not only in the temple, but more deeply into your heart and Prabhupada will be there to reciprocate.

data.title: A Newsletter Article from My Last Visit to Moscow
data.blurb: We are happy to announce that the Sevaka System in Moscow is continuing to develop. The number of Sevakas has increased since it's inception in October, 2010.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
We are happy to announce that the Sevaka System in Moscow is continuing to develop. The number of Sevakas has increased since it's inception in October, 2010. In addition to the first six Sevakas who were selected in October (Vatsala dasa, Nilakantha Priya devi dasi, Angira Muni dasa, Kaveri dd, Mukunda Murari dasa and Divya Sakti dd), thirteen more devotees have been added to the Sevaka System (Yaduraja dasa, Gopapatni dd, Kholaveca Sridhar dasa, Anubhava dd, Prabhupada dasa, Bhagavati dd, Radha Caran dasa, Bhaktin Natalya, Balarama dasa, Revati dd, Tungavidya Sakhi dd, Acala dasa, and Krsnadasa Kaviraja dasa).

Srila Prabhupada always emphasized unity in diversity. The Sevaka System is an attempt to create a unified vision of care, implemented by senior devotees in Moscow from amongst the many diverse methods for outreach and care. The primary responsibility of the Sevaka Board is to develop and implement a system of care, education and training so that devotees in the Moscow community can not only take part in Srila Prabhupada's mission of hearing ,chanting, and remembering the glories of the Lord for a part of their lives, but so that they can remain actively engaged in the pursuit of Krsna consciousness in the association of devotees throughout all of their lives.

Srila Prabhupada empasizes the point about unity and diversity so wonderfully in the following quote from a letter written to Kirtanananda on October 18, 1973:

"Material nature means dissension and disagreement, especially in this Kali yuga. But, for this Krsna consciousness movement its success will depend on agreement, even though there are varieties of engagements. In the material world there are varieties, but there is no agreement. In the spiritual world there are varieties, but there is agreement. That is the difference. The materialist without being able to adjust the varieties and the disagreements makes everything zero. They cannot come into agreement with varieties, but if we keep Krsna in the center, then there will be agreement in varieties. This is called unity in diversity. I am therefore suggesting that all our men meet in Mayapur every year during the birth anniversary of Lord Caitanya Mahaprabhu. data.title: A Very Auspicious Passing
data.blurb: Two days ago I received a letter from Acyuta Priya dasa, the Regional Secretary for Ukraine, which contained following information about the passing of Naimisaranya devi dasi:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Two days ago I received a letter from Acyuta Priya dasa, the Regional Secretary for Ukraine, which contained following information about the passing of Naimisaranya devi dasi:

"Your disciple Naimisaranya Mataji has left her body today, two hours ago. She was admitted in the hospital with a stroke, besides many other diseases, first of all kidney problems. She was in between life and death for one week. Today she felt better, and she took her beads and was able to chant. Devotees placed your picture in front of her, and whole day she was chanting, not talking to anybody. This way she left her body."

I replied:

"Dear Acyuta Priya,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

Thank you for the information. Actually the same information came in from several different sources all at around the same time. This was all very sudden. I did not know that Naimisaranya was in bad health. Still, for whatever reason, Krsna has taken her and she left us in a glorious way, by not allowing anything else to be on her lips on her last day except Krsna's holy names. Wonderful. This is inspiring.

Please, I would appreciate it if you could express my well-wishes to Titiksa dd, Devaprastha dasa, Svetadvipa dasa and Lalita and tell them that I share their loss with them.

Hoping this meets you in good health.

Your servant,

Niranjana Swami"

This morning I received the following from Acyuta Priya:

"The body was cremated today.

She was unconscious for three days. Then at last day she only chanted, nothing else, whole day she did not answer to anybody anything, she did not pay attention, only chanting. Besides holy names she said just one sentence: "O my Lord, how it is difficult!" She left in a very quiet way, just stopped breathing, and her daughter Lalita being in the same room did not even recognize the moment of her departure.

All relatives are feeling so inspired by the way she departed. They did not expect this, they thought such a glorious death only possible for highly elevated pure and glorious Vaisnavas, not for somebody who is "ordinary" and being among us whole life. It became such a nice example.

Your servant

Acyuta Priya das."

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Vyasa Puja Gift I Thought I Would Share
data.blurb: On Vyasa Puja I received two DVD's from Prema Vardana dasa with a message on the outside of the case. I thought I would share the contents of both with all of you here on the site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On Vyasa Puja I received two DVD's from Prema Vardana dasa with a message on the outside of the case. I thought I would share the contents of both with all of you here on the site.

You will find all of the videos from Prema Vardhana dasa posted on the home page of the site in the left-hand column entitled "Navadvipa 1996".

Here is his message:

Dear Maharaja,

Please accept my obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

A few words about these videos.

Last year one elderly Ukrainian devotee told me in India that he had a few 8mm videotapes from Navadwip and Vrindavan parikramas he participated in. He made most of the filming. But he told he could not find a proper video-camera to digitize these materials. He offered me to digitize them and I agreed. When I got the tapes and watched them I found there was a lot of footage of you together with youir Godbrothers and disciples. We thought it could be of some interest for you and your disciples, the more so because the devotee who filmed it told me it was most probably never digitized by anyone. The tapes were original. Kanjalocana Prabhu told that the classes recorded on these tapes were not in the archives.

Aspiring to become your servant,

Prema Vardhana dasa

I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Kanjalocana dasa, Lilanath dasa and Yasoda devi dasi, who have been major contributors of videos for this site.

Kanjalocana dasa maintains the "Tape Ministry Archive" found by clicking on the "Videos" link in the navigation menu on the left-side of the page.

Lilanath dasa and Yasoda devi dasi have been providing videos from the ISKCON International Archives regularly ever since this site was established more than two years ago.

My gratitude to all of them for their selfless service.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Update
data.blurb: As planned, I arrived in Budapest from New York on January 1st. However, it seems that somewhere along the way I picked up a virus. By the time evening arrived I was bedridden. My condition continued that way throughout the following day and night.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As planned, I arrived in Budapest from New York on January 1st. However, it seems that somewhere along the way I picked up a virus. By the time evening arrived I was bedridden. My condition continued that way throughout the following day and night. On the request of Sivarama Swami and other devotees who saw my condition, I decided to take an extra day in Budapest to recover before flying again. This morning I changed my ticket to Kiev from the 4th to the 5th night.

Regarding my plans for January, it became obvious to me during my tour in North America that I have been traveling too much these past several months. I have decided to slow down during the month of January and to try to resume the same level of commitment for my back as I kept during the earlier part of last year. Although I'm scheduled to remain in Kiev until January 12th, I will not do any programs in Kiev once the festival is over on the 8th.

I will also take this opportunity to mention that initiations, previously scheduled for January 8th, have been cancelled. My secretary, Radha Govinda dasa, posted an announcement in the disciple's conference approximately one month ago, requesting all candidates for initiation to send their recommendations to him as soon as possible. As of three days ago, only two people responded. Initiations have therefore been postponed until the Evpatoriya Festival. Anyone affected by this decision can find further details posted in the disciple's conference. The new schedule for Sunday, January 8th, has been posted there as well.

I am scheduled to visit Moscow from January 13 – 16. The primary purpose for my visit is to follow up on the seven days of intensive work I put into developing the Sevaka system in Moscow during my October visit. I will therefore be spending most of my time in Moscow to further develop the Sevaka System and I also hope to meet with other leaders on matters related to the care of devotees in the Moscow community. I will probably give one (or possibly two) lecture(s) in Moscow and that's all the lectures I will give during my visit, although I do plan to attend the morning program as I did in October.

Since, due to illness, I had to cancel my therapist appointment yesterday, I will return to Hungary on January 17th in order to visit the therapist at least twice before leaving for India. I will therefore remain in Hungary, probably in New Vraja Dhama, for at least three weeks, at which time I will focus on preparing myself to resume travels again in February.

Many devotees have asked me what my plans are for India this year. Although I had previously planned to leave for Mumbai on January 18th, those plans have been cancelled. I will likely not leave for India (in order to attend the GBC meetings) until just shortly before the GBC meetings begin. My plan is to be in Mayapura for the GBC meetings only. The meetings are scheduled to end on March 3rd. I will leave Mayapura one or two days after the meetings are over, although I have not yet fixed any schedule from March 3rd onwards.

For those of you who have been looking for new blogs, as you have noticed, my schedule did not allow me the time to do this during the month of December. I did more programs in Hartford and Boston than were posted on the site. Unfortunately several of them were not recorded so it may seem that I had more time for writing than I actually did. But between programs, travels, meetings, home visitations, and other commitments, I could not find the time to keep my blogs updated. I do plan to resume posting regular blogs by the middle of January. I also hope to post a few between now and then.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Don't Criticize
data.blurb: During the course of my travels, devotees asked if they could get the following quotes from Caitanya Bhagavata about which I spoke from time to time. For those interested in referring to them for further reference, here they are:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the course of my travels, devotees asked if they could get the following quotes from Caitanya Bhagavata about which I spoke from time to time. For those interested in referring to them for further reference, here they are:

Madhya Khanda , Chapter Five

abhyarcayitva pratimasu visnum
nindan jane sarva-gatam tam eva
 abhyarcya padau hi dvijasya murdhi
druhyannivajno narakam prayati

“Just as a foolish person who worships the feet of a brahmana and then beats him in the head goes to hell, one who worships the Deity form of Lord Visnu and then disrespects that same Lord who is situated in the hearts of all living entities also goes to hell.

In this regard one should discuss the Srimad Bhagavatam (3.29.21-24 and 11.5.14-15).

Text 140

Therefore, you should stay far away from persons whose talk harms the Vaisnavas and from persons who give pain to ordinary living entities.

Text 141

A person who gives pain to other living beings and then worships Lord Visnu, worships in vain. In death he suffers.

TEXT 140-141

vaisnava-himsara katha se thakuka dure
sahaja jivere ye adhama pida kare

visnu pujiya o ye prajara pida kare
puja o nisphale yaya, ara duhkhe mare

What to speak of being envious of the Vaisnavas, if one causes pain to ordinary living entities he is considered a fallen low-class person. Even after worshiping Lord Visnu, if a person gives trouble to other living entities, his worship becomes fruitless. Such a person suffers unlimited miseries.

COMMENTARY: If a person is knowingly or unknowingly envious of a Vaisnava who is engaged in the nonduplicitous service of Lord Hari, his degradation is inevitable. Of this there is no doubt. Apart from this, if even persons claiming to be devotees of Visnu are envious of ordinary living entities and give various troubles to them, they are actually far away from devotional service to Visnu and are not fit to be called human beings. Their worship of Visnu becomes the source of misery. Those endowed with an absense of jive-daya, or compassion for other living entities, and yet proudly consider themselves servants of Lord Visnu achieve the threefold miseries rather than the devotional service of the Lord.

Madhya Khanda, Chapter 19

207-Text 208

“Everyone please give your thoughts to Me. Please hear the truth I will now say. Anyone who neglects My servant and then worships Me is very lowly and degraded. Such a person cuts Me into pieces. His worship is like fire burning My body.

Text 209

“My holy name, which is a kalpa-vrksa tree, destroys anyone who once blasphemes My servant.

Text 210

“The living entities who live in the numberless universes are all My servants. Therefore any living entity who harms another living entity will perish.

Madhya Khanda, Chapter 20

Text 147

From Brahma down to the unmoving plants, every living being is Lord Krsna’s potency. Therefore all the scriptures say, “Anyone who blasphemes another angers Lord Krsna.”

Text 148

Lord Krsna delivers any person who is not a blasphemer and who once chants “Krsna!” That is the truth. It is the truth.

Text 149

If a person studies the four Vedas and then blasphemes others, he will fall into the hell called Kumbhipaka. There he will suffer birth after birth.

Text 212

“If a sannyasi blasphemes an innocent person, the sannyasi will fall down. All his piety will perish.”

Text 213

Raising His arms, fair Lord Caitanya declared to the entire world, “Renouncing criticism of others, everyone please chant Lord Krsna’s name.

Text 214

“I will personally deliver anyone who does not criticize others and who once chants `Krsna!’ That is the truth. It is the truth.”

Madhya Khanda, Chapter 10

Text 313

A person who never blasphemes anyone, and who chants, “Krsna! Krsna!”, easily conquers Lord Caitanya, who is never conquered by anyone.

Text 314

All the scriptures declare, “A person who blasphemes others will not attain the Lord.” Srimad-Bhagavatam teaches that one should respect everyone.

According to Srila Jiva Gosvami, since a kanistha-adhikari who cannot properly respect other devotees will certainly fail to offer respects to ordinary living entities who are not even devotees, a kanistha-adhikari is useless for practical preaching work unless he comes to a higher platform of understanding. Srila Jiva Gosvami says, iyam ca sraddha na sastrarthavadharana-jata. Because the kanistha-adhikari’s faith is not actually based on the statements of Vedic literature, he cannot understand the exalted position of the Supreme Personality of Godhead within everyone’s heart. Therefore he cannot actually manifest love of Godhead, nor can he understand the exalted position of the devotees of the Lord. Krsna is so glorious that Krsna’s intimate associates must also be glorious. But this is unknown to a kanistha-adhikari. Similarly, the essential qualification of a Vaisnava, which is to offer all respects to others (amanina manadena kirtaniyah sada harih [Cc. Adi 17.31] is also conspicuous by its absence in a kanistha-adhikari. If such a person, however, has faith in the Vedic literatures and tries to understand the statements of Bhagavad-gita and Srimad-Bhagavatam, he will gradually be elevated to the second—and first-class stages of devotional service. (from the purport to Srimad Bhagavatam 11.2.47)

data.blurb: The following is an article about Kazakhstan posted just three days ago on the BBC News website. I found it very interesting and a partial answer to the many questions I receive when I travel worldwide from devotees asking about the current situation in Kazakhstan.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is an article about Kazakhstan posted just three days ago on the BBC News website. I found it very interesting and a partial answer to the many questions I receive when I travel worldwide from devotees asking about the current situation in Kazakhstan.

Externally, the Kazakhstan government softened their manner of dealings with ISKCON both just prior to being voted as OSCE Chair-nation for 2010 as well as during the year 2010. However, they still have not resolved our issues, having failed to offer any fair compensation for the land which was taken over by the government. It will be interesting to see what they will do once 2010 is over and their status as Chair-nation is no longer important to them.

Kazakhstan seeks image boost from OSCE summit

30 November 2010 Last updated at 19:34 ET

By Rayhan Demytrie BBC News, Astana

Leaders and top diplomats from over 50 nations are in the Kazakh capital, Astana, for the biggest international event ever held in Central Asia.

Kazakhstan is hosting a summit for the international democracy and security body, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE).

This year the country has been chairing the organisation. Ever since assuming this role early in 2010 it has been lobbying to host this summit in its new capital.

Regional security, protracted conflicts and the war in Afghanistan are on the agenda. But critics say there has been no clarity on what exactly this summit is hoping to achieve.

A political analyst, Dosym Satpayev, compared the preparation for the event to a Kazakh wedding.

"All the local media has been reporting on the logistics of the event: which hotels the guests will be staying in, which cars will be transporting them, what's on the menu at the restaurants. But when it comes to saying what this event is about - they just mention it with one line," he said.

Critics say Kazakhstan is using the event primarily to boost its international image and that the country has gained little from its OSCE chairmanship.

But the authorities dismiss such claims.

"This summit and the chairmanship are the opportunity for Kazakhstan to contribute to global security," said Roman Vassilenko from the Kazakh Foreign Ministry.

"This is an opportunity to show that Kazakhstan is an equal, a decent and a worthy player and we have proven that we can manage a leadership role in such a major organisation."

Kazakhstan has managed to bring together many heads of state for the summit.

The participants include German Chancellor Angela Merkel, Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, and Russia's Dmitry Medvedev.

The US is represented by Secretary of State Hilary Clinton. Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg is attending for the UK.

One thing that has added zest to the event is the controversy sparked by Wikileaks' publication of US classified diplomatic documents.

Many of the politicians mentioned in the leaked files will be facing each other for the first time since the revelations put the United States into an awkward position.

'No reform'

The presence of so many top politicians from around the world is something that rights advocates have been hoping will attract attention to the region's poor human rights record.

International rights organisations and regional NGOs have been holding an alternative summit to discuss this issue.

"Kazakhstan has not made any progress in terms of democratic reforms, quite the opposite," said Ninel Fokina from the Helsinki Committee. "In many areas such as freedom of religion, freedom of speech, freedom of assembly and the right to a fair trial the situation got much worse."

In a statement published ahead of the OSCE summit the international group Human Rights Watch called on Kazakhstan's international partners not to give up on their engagement with the country and to push Kazakhstan towards the reforms it had been promising, particularly in the area of media freedom.

This was one of the promises made by Kazakhstan back in 2007 in Madrid when members elected the country to chair the OSCE - a first for a post-Soviet nation.

Along with media reforms, Kazakhstan also pledged to carry out electoral and judicial reforms, and to improve human rights.

But throughout Kazakhstan's chairmanship of the pro-democracy body the country has been criticised for doing very little to build democracy at home.

This June, Kazakhstan passed a new law rewarding the president with the title "leader of the nation".

The legislation gives President Nursultan Nazarbayev, who has ruled Kazakhstan since 1989, immunity from criminal prosecution and will allow him a continued role in decision-making if or when he steps down.

Prized partner

Observers say that since Kazakhstan has now achieved its main foreign policy goal - hosting the OSCE summit - it is no longer concerned with international criticism.

"The fact that European leaders are coming for the summit is a sign that the West no longer cares about Kazakhstan's democratisation. What's important for them is that the country remains their strategic partner," said political analyst Dosym Satpayev.

"This is globalisation," he adds. "Europe understands that if they do not strengthen their positions here, other powers such as Russia, China or Iran will - countries which are absolutely not interested in Kazakhstan's political orientation."

In the weeks before the summit an army of workers, drivers and caterers have been helping to prepare for the event: sweeping the snow and scraping the ice. They have been making sure that Astana looks immaculate and ready to impress every new guest.

The streets are decorated with hundreds of white and blue OSCE flags.

For many ordinary citizens Kazakhstan's chairmanship of the OSCE has not brought any personal gains.

Many find it difficult even to explain what the OSCE stands for. But they feel proud that the country is hosting such an event.

"Our president knows why it is important. Everybody is just doing their job," said one street cleaner.

data.title: Travel Update
data.blurb: Due to the intensity of my recent travels, other responsibilities associated with traveling, and increased GBC responsibilities which came as a result of my attendance of the Mumbai GBC meetings, it has been difficult for me to write blogs with the same frequency as when I was not traveling.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Due to the intensity of my recent travels, other responsibilities associated with traveling, and increased GBC responsibilities which came as a result of my attendance of the Mumbai GBC meetings, it has been difficult for me to write blogs with the same frequency as when I was not traveling. Only time will tell if I will be able to resume posting blogs as before, but I remain hopeful.

Last night I arrived in the United States on a flight from Budapest – Zurich – New York. I was hoping to catch up on some sleep on the flight from Zurich to New York (an eight-hour flight) so that I could work on the revision of "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume 1" today, but Krsna had a different plan for me. Located in the same row I was seated, was a baby, approximately 1-2 years old, with very strong vocal chords. He didn't talk yet, but he sure knew how to shriek. I can't remember seeing so many passengers wearing headsets all at the same time— even those who didn't seem interested in watching the movie. Whether we wanted it or not, non-stop entertainment continued from take-off to landing, even after the flight attendants collected the headsets. Needless to say, even my noise-cancelling headphones, which I was able to wear after all other headsets were collected, could not block out the charming sound coming from this child's mouth.

This brings to mind the following verse from Caitanya Caritamrita, Madhya 21.144:

"The vibration of His flute is just like a bird that creates a nest within the ears of the gopis and always remains prominent there, not allowing any other sound to enter their ears. Indeed, the gopis cannot hear anything else, nor are they able to concentrate on anything else, not even to give a suitable reply. Such are the effects of the vibration of Lord Krsna's flute."

This seems to be a solution much better than noise-cancelling headphones. When on when will that day be mine!

Although I tried to avoid it, I had no choice but to make up for lost sleep today. This morning I slept three hours after breakfast. This afternoon I slept almost another three hours after lunch. It's already evening and I've reviewed only one chapter with five more chapters to go. But now that I'll probably be up for most of the night, hopefully I'll get through a lot more reviewing before morning.

The following is probably how my travels will look for the month of December and early January:

Hartford – December 3 - 7
Visit to mother and sister – December 8 – 9
Hartford – December 10 – 13
Boston – December 13 – 22
Driving to Ottawa – December 23
Ottawa – December 24 – 26
Driving to Hartford – December 26
Hartford – December 27 – 28
New Jersey/New York – December 28 – 31
Departure to Budapest – December 31
Budapest – January 1 – 4
Arrival in Kiev – January 4

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Update and Minsk Schedule
data.blurb: I returned to Budapest from Moscow on Friday night, November 12th. Since my previous Belarussian visa is no longer valid, I had to re-apply for a new visa. Budapest is the most convenient place for me to do this.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I returned to Budapest from Moscow on Friday night, November 12th. Since my previous Belarussian visa is no longer valid, I had to re-apply for a new visa. Budapest is the most convenient place for me to do this. Providing there are no problems with my application, I've been told that my visa will be ready on November 22nd.

While here in Budapest, I visited Yasomatinandana dasa on Monday so he could review the results of my tests taken at Bhaktivedanta Hospital. Yesterday, Tuesday, I visited my therapist in Siofok, approximately 1.5 hours from Budapest, and was given my next set of exercises for the following two weeks (until my next visit).

I will be devoting the bulk of my remaining time in Budapest in reviewing more than thirty files which Sri Radha devi dasi sent for review. This material will form the basis for the next volume of "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume 3."

I had previously planned to work on this material in Mumbai from November 5th to November 12th, once the GBC meetings were completed, but because I decided to fly back to Moscow immediately upon receiving news of H.H. Purnacandra Goswami's departure, I had to cancel those plans. Considering that there is only five days remaining between now and my departure to Minsk (essentially only four days because I am attending a full-day conference here in Budapest on November 18th), I will be focusing practically all of my time on this work.

The following will be my schedule in Minsk:

I will arrive late in the afternoon on Tuesday, November 23rd. Nothing will be scheduled for that day. Madana-mohana dasa is currently working on scheduling meetings for Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, (November 24, 25, and 26). Depending how far I will be staying from the temple, I hope to follow a schedule similar to that which I followed in Moscow. I will not give morning or evening lectures on Wednesday or Thursday, although I hope to attend the morning program until the end of Guru Puja kirtan, at which time I will return to wherever I will be staying to do my morning exercises. It is presently unclear whether or not I will be able to give a lecture on Friday evening. It will depend upon a few factors which are impossible to predict in advance.

On Saturday, November 27th, I will do an evening program at the temple. On Sunday, depending upon when the Sunday Feast lecture will be scheduled, I am hoping to have a general meeting for disciples on Sunday late morning, and I will also take part in the full Sunday Feast Program.

My flight departs Minsk on Monday, November 29th, at which time I will return to Budapest for one day. For reasons which should be obvious, only those devotees assigned to pick me up at the airport on Tuesday, November 23rd, and drop me off at the airport on the following Monday, November 29th, should be at the airport for my arrival and departure. I humbly request everyone's cooperation in this regard.

My flight to the United States is scheduled to depart on December 1st. I will be in North America from December 1st until December 31st. I am currently working on my schedule for North America and will post it as soon as all dates are confirmed.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Bhaktin Veronika Shares Her Realizations
data.blurb: While standing in the registration line at the airport, just prior to my departure from Moscow, I requested Bhaktin Veronika to share some of her realizations from the ceremony commemorating His Holiness Purnacandra Goswami's departure.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
While standing in the registration line at the airport, just prior to my departure from Moscow, I requested Bhaktin Veronika to share some of her realizations from the ceremony commemorating His Holiness Purnacandra Goswami's departure. I told her that I would post what she wrote as a blog on my site.

Here is what she wrote:

I attended the farewell ceremony of a wonderful vaisnava—His Holiness Purnacandra Goswami Maharaja. This day happened to coincide with the Disappearance Day of our Founder-Acarya of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness—His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada. During the morning Srimad Bhagavatam class, Krishnananda Prabhu inspired everybody by explaining from a philosophical point of view, how to correctly understand the departure of great personalities.

Then there was an abhisheka ceremony of Srila Prabhupada’s Murti. Guru Maharaja took part in the abhisheka along with many other devotees.

The farewell ceremony for His Holiness Srila Purnacandra Goswami Maharaja began a bit later. Accompanied by kirtan, devotees carried Maharaja's body three times around the temple, escorted by all the Vaisnavas present.

Then the farewell ceremony moved to the pandal. It is impossible to describe the pain of separation the devotees experienced, displayed by the continuous flood of tears streaming from their eyes. The kirtan led by Guru Maharaja went to the innermost core of everyone’s heart, forcing the soul to tremble. An incredible desire of reciprocal love united all the devotees present.

Guru Maharaja expressed confidence that Srila Purnacandra Maharaja, because of his very strong desire to achieve eternal service to the Supreme Personality of Godhead, would continue to be engaged in that service in the future.

His Grace Yadunandana Prabhu read a message from His Holiness Bhakti Vijnana Goswami Maharaja, in which he expressed his gratitude to Purnacandra Maharaja for having helped the Russian devotees to become deeper in their spiritual life, to avoid superficiality, and to comprehend the beauty of Krishna consciousness.

His Grace Jaya Madhava Prabhu shared his memories about his acquaintance with Purnacandra Maharaja. He spoke about Maharaja's amazing qualities-- his genuine humility, his ability to listen and take to to heart the problems of others. He also urged all devotees to follow Maharaja's example in Krishna consciousness and thus to express gratitude to Purnacandra Goswami for that example.

His Grace Medini Pati Prabhu described how Purnacandra Goswami was always thinking how to help devotees, how to increase their faith, and how to bring them nearer to Srila Prabhupada.

His Holiness Nitai Caitanya Goswami spoke about Purnacandra Maharaja's important qualities of truthfulness and his generous desire to share his love. He underlined Purnacandra Maharaja's contribution to Vaisnava education.

The program continued with a pushpanjali ceremony accompanied by an incredibly moving kirtan led by Mataji Gauri devi dasi. The flower petals, like tears, streaming from the hearts of the assembled devotees, became the last gift offered to Purnacandra Maharaja. Those unable to leave Purnacandra Maharaja followed the hearse to the crematorium.

The most amazing thing for me was that, though Guru Maharaja felt pain himself, nevertheless feeling empathy towards everyone else, he sincerely helped support everyone else as much as possible.

Thank you very much, dear Guru Maharaja, that you were with us during this heaviest moment. I’m in a huge debt before you and this debt grows every time I associate with you.

data.title: My Memories of Purnacandra Goswami
data.blurb: The following is a partially-edited transcript of a short talk I gave during the memorial service for Purnacandra Goswami in Moscow on November, 9, 2010.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is a partially-edited transcript of a short talk I gave during the memorial service for Purnacandra Goswami in Moscow on November, 9, 2010.

I will not speak long because there are other devotees who will speak a little bit today. We should not go too long because it gets dark early and it's best to finish this function during the daylight. We adjusted the schedule a little bit to accommodate the need to finish everything before sunset.

We are gathered here to pay our respects to His Holiness Purnacandra Goswami. For those of you who know him, you know that he is a person of substance. I often speak about this topic --substance versus form. If there is substance then everything else will eventually follow.

For the life of a Vaisnava this substance is his Krsna Consciousness, the activities which are performed by him in Krsna Consciousness, and the ability to share that Krsna Consciousness with others. That is the essence of our Krsna Consciousness Movement. And that substance is the heart of a Vaisnava. A Vaisnava is one who fully dedicates his life in service to the Supreme Lord. He feels compassion for the suffering of others.

Purnacandra Maharaja was such a Vaisnava. He was not interested in the external affairs of this world. I know that because of my personal association with him. I'm sure that we'll hear more confirmation of this from others today-- that Maharaja was more interested in sharing substance and less concerned about structure or form. That is one quality of Purnacandra Maharaja I've always appreciated.

Purnacandra Maharaja would oftentimes keep his firm commitment to substance even at the risk of being unpopular. He was not at all interested in winning some popularity contest. He was interested in preserving that which was passed on to him by his spiritual master.

data.title: Another Great Loss
data.blurb: I'm presently sitting in the Mumbai Airport. Yesterday was the last day of GBC meetings in Mumbai. I was supposed to stay at Radha Gopinath Temple for an additional week just after today's checkup at Bhaktivedanta Hospital, but…
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm presently sitting in the Mumbai Airport. Yesterday was the last day of GBC meetings in Mumbai. I was supposed to stay at Radha Gopinath Temple for an additional week just after today's checkup at Bhaktivedanta Hospital, but…

Last night at approximately 2:00 AM I received a phone call from Moscow. You'll find the essence of that call in the following message which Bhakti Vijnana Goswami wrote when I called to give him the same information I received from the 2:00 AM call.

"Dear Maharajas and Prabhus,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

With great sadness in the heart we inform you that on auspicious Karttika Amavasya tithi, 4th of November, 22:25 PM Moscow time Sripad Purnacandra Goswami entered samadhi.

On October 15th he was hospitalized with internal bleeding, and from September 19th he was in coma. Despite deep coma he manifested some signs of consciousness every time when devotees would come to him to chant the holy name.

Sripad Purnacandra Maharaja joined Srila Prabhupada's movement when he was 17 years old. For more than 38 years he served the movement with great dedication. His knowledge of sastra was vast and profound. For many years he was teaching Bhakti-sastri course and many other courses to the devotees. He had very deep attachment to Sri Vrindavana-dhama. He divided his preaching time between Russia and Balkans, but Karttik he would always spend in Vrindavan. Over the last few years he was writing a book dedicated to Lord Krishna's pastimes in Vrindavana. He was always deeply absorbed in the holy names. The concentration and intensity with which he would chant the holy name every day was incomparable.

It is a great loss for our society.

Please offer your prayers, hold the kirtans in his honour, and help his dedicated disciples in this difficult time.

Your servant,

Bhakti Vijnana Goswami"

Just after receiving the phone call from Moscow I decided to cancel my plans in India. My flight to Budapest leaves in less than an hour. From Budapest I'll fly to Moscow on Monday morning at which time I'll do whatever I can to render service to this wonderful Vaisnava.

Hare Krsna

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last Friday I was informed that His Holiness Purnacandra Goswami was in the hospital in Moscow, unconscious, and on life support. Upon arriving in Moscow on Saturday evening, I immediately arranged to meet with the devotees who were overseeing his treatment the next day.

At this time, there are not too many details I can give about his present condition other than he is intensive care, he is not conscious, there is some internal bleeding, and it appears that his present condition is connected to the ongoing detioration of his health due to hepatitis C.

I have posted a talk in the audio section which I gave to his all of his disciples here in Moscow the night before last. Please listen to it.

Devotees have begun kirtan for Purnacandra Maharaja every evening in the Moscow temple. Friday evening there will be a maha kirtan which will be attended by devotees from the whole Moscow community. If you're in Moscow, please come.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Belarus Visit Postponed
data.blurb: During the last six weeks, I've had the flu twice, three colds, and now I'm having bronchial issues that won't go away. Yesterday morning I decided to postpone my trip to Belarus so that I can hopefully rest and recover in Kiev.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the last six weeks, I've had the flu twice, three colds, and now I'm having bronchial issues that won't go away. Yesterday morning I decided to postpone my trip to Belarus so that I can hopefully rest and recover in Kiev.

If my health improves, I will continue with the rest of my previously-posted schedule, beginning with Moscow on October 16th.

I am tentatively rescheduling my Belarus visit for around the third week of November. The exact date will depend upon how long it will take to get a new Belarus visa once I return to Budapest from India on November 12th. It will likely take at least a week to get a visa, and the earliest I'll be able to apply will be November 15th.

While in Kiev, my plan is to simply rest.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Plans
data.blurb: As expected, my schedule does not allow me so many opportunities to write for my blog. Hopefully, in time, I will be able to strike the right balance between writing and other duties which come when I travel.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As expected, my schedule does not allow me so many opportunities to write for my blog. Hopefully, in time, I will be able to strike the right balance between writing and other duties which come when I travel. I can foresee opportunities arising in the not-too-distant future, but probably not on any kind of regular basis until I've returned to Europe from India.

Meanwhile, I wish to post a few details about my visit to Minsk and Moscow in order to avoid any confusion about those visits.

I've given a proposed schedule to Madana-mohana dasa for both Minsk and Moscow, but it's possible that he has not been able to forward it to the leaders in both places yet because he has no internet connection where he's staying right now. But these details will soon be submitted to the leaders in the form of proposals for my visit. I suspect that my plans will be finalized, hopefully within the next day or two.

I will give evening programs in Minsk only on October 14th and 15th. Both October 12th and October 13th are being reserved for meetings which will be coordinated by Madana-mohana dasa in consultation with the local leaders.

My plan for Moscow (though it is still unconfirmed) is that I will give general programs ONLY on October 17th, October 23rd, and October 24th. I will not give evening programs during the week, although I do hope to be at the temple for Damodarastakam and an evening kirtan for most weekdays. I am also hoping (though this also still needs to be coordinated) to be able to attend the temple morning program most mornings during the week up until Guru Puja and the following kirtan. I will not give morning classes however. After Guru Puja kirtan I will return to my residence to perform my first set of exercises for the day.

My meetings for Moscow will be coordinated between Madana-mohana dasa, Bhakti Vijnana Goswami and myself. A good portion of my Moscow visit will be dedicated to discussions with community leaders.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Update
data.blurb: There is a lot I could write about my visit to Almaty, the Evpatoriya Festival, and now my visit to New Vraja Dhama. There is also a lot of material which needs to be uploaded and eventually posted.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
There is a lot I could write about my visit to Almaty, the Evpatoriya Festival, and now my visit to New Vraja Dhama. There is also a lot of material which needs to be uploaded and eventually posted. Between other commitments here in New Vraja Dhama and the time required to recover from some kind of flu which I came down with four days ago, unfortunately, I am able to do neither.

Meanwhile, I am trying to become healthy enough to resume the next series of travel plans between now and the middle of November. I cannot throw caution to the wind and just assume that if I survived the past few months of travel without any major health setback that the next few months will be the same. I am constantly being cautioned about this by my well-wishers.

Still, as long as I have no lung infection or potential infection (something which often appears when I get the flu) I will likely follow through with my next set of plans:

September 24 – 29 Kiev

September 29 – October 2 Dnepropetrovsk

October 2 – 4 Donetsk

October 6 – 9 Odessa (National Council Meetings October 6 - 8)

October 10 – 11 Kiev

October 11 – 16 Minsk

October 16 – 25 Moscow

October 25 – 28 Budapest

October 28 – November 12 Mumbai (GBC Meetings and visit to Radha Gopinath Mandir)

November 12 - Budapest

I will be getting my lungs checked today or tomorrow. If there is excess fluid or infection, I will not travel anywhere until I've fully recovered.

I should probably wait and not post this blog until after my examination, but since I will probably not have enough time to post anything later today, tomorrow, or even the next day, I will just post this blog as it is and will then post an update as soon as it will be possible.

Regarding my visits to Ukraine, Minsk and Moscow, in Ukraine I will be traveling together with His Holiness Devamrita Swami. The plan is that he will give most of the classes and I will likely give only a few.

Madana-mohana dasa will be traveling everywhere with me as my secretary and will be responsible for scheduling meetings. Meetings with me and classes by me in all cities (Kiev, Dnepropetrovsk, Donetsk, Odessa, Minsk, and Moscow) will be VERY limited.

I am very grateful that wherever I have traveled these past few months, devotees have been very sensitive to the fact that I must maintain a balanced schedule which allows me the much needed time for both resting and exercising several times a day, every day. Anticipating that the same sensitivity will be there in Ukraine, Minsk and Moscow, I wish to thank everyone in advance for their kind understanding.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Evpatoriya Festival Journal (September 11, 2010)
data.blurb: The Bhakti Sangama festival has begun! This morning's mangala aarti was unbelievable! Thousands of devotees gathered in front of Jagannath, Baladeva, Subhadra Maharani and Gaura Nitai who are benevolently smiling over the assembled devotees.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The Bhakti Sangama festival has begun! This morning's mangala aarti was unbelievable! Thousands of devotees gathered in front of Jagannath, Baladeva, Subhadra Maharani and Gaura Nitai who are benevolently smiling over the assembled devotees.

The full morning program is followed here starting with mangala aarti at 5am, followed by tulasi puja, japa period, deity greetings, Guru puja and Srimad Bhagavatam class. However, it's definitely a challenge to see Srimati Tulasi devi, what to speak of watering her, with the number of devotees present! The atmosphere is surcharged with so much love and enthusiasm and smiles are abundant.

Today's Srimad Bhagavatam class was given by HH Candramauli Swami. Maharaja spoke on SB. 7.9.41- Prayers by Prahalad Maharaja. Maharaja highlighted how the vaisnava is never happy with their own Krsna conscious liberation and always wants to help others who are suffering. Glancing around the almost overflowing pandal, one of the qualities that really strikes me about the devotees here is how much they are eager to hear. They are so attentive and and their gratitude for being here is clearly etched upon their faces.

One thing I didn't take into consideration is how little time one has during the day! After Bhagavatam class, breakfast is served at 9am and the first session begins at 10:45am. Each session is one hour and fifteen minutes long so after two sessions in the morning lunch is served at 2pm. Afternoon sessions begin at 4pm, end by 6:45pm and then there is kirtan until 10pm! Its a transcendental marathon that leaves one feeling blissfully exhausted and eager for more!

The topics and speakers for all the sessions are so interesting . Four sessions run in parallel at all times making me wish That I could find a way to expand myself into four persons so that I can attend all of them simultaneously! Since that's not possible, I've decided to attend the following: HH Bhaktivaibhava Swami's sessions on Jaiva Dharma, HH Devamrta Swami's sessions on "The Nectar of Attachment and Detachment", HH Niranjana Swami's sessions on "Preaching with Compassion", and finally HH Giriraja Swami's talks on "Srila Prabhupada and the Holy Name."

All the speakers have taken so much care and effort in putting together their presentations. Their love for the devotees is also so transparent in how they are always ensuring translations are being heard clearly and that the devotees are comfortable.

After a day filled with hearing about Krsna and the devotees, the evening began with a bang as the official opening ceremonies commenced. Over 25 devotees took to the stage where HH Niranjana Swami personally welcomed and honored all the senior devotees and speakers who are attending this year's festival. Maharaja is so personal and so genuinely grateful to have the association of all his god brothers and god sisters. Just watching and hearing those sweet interactions and loving exchanges has already become one my highlights for the festival although today is only the first day!

Following the welcoming talks, an incredible kirtan filled the huge pandal which could surely be heard for miles away. HG Aditi Dukaha Prabhu, HH BB Govinda Swami and Madhava Prabhu overflowed the hearts of the devotees with the holy names. The ecstasy was so palatable and the holy names penetrated every single cell of every living entity present there. With so much mercy already pouring down, I can't even imagine what the following days will bring.

data.title: Evpatoriya Festival
data.blurb: I am much too busy to write any blogs during the Evpatoriya Festival. I've therefore requested Vrndavana Vinodini devi dasi to share some of her experiences of the festival. Here is her first intallment:
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I am much too busy to write any blogs during the Evpatoriya Festival. I've therefore requested Vrndavana Vinodini devi dasi to share some of her experiences of the festival. Here is her first intallment:

Today is the "official arrival day." Devotees all over Ukraine, parts of Russia and the rest of the world are descending upon the city village of Evpatoriya for what has become commonly known as the Ukraine festival. Evpatoriya borders the Black Sea and is in the Crimea region of Ukraine. Coming for the first time, I am already overwhelmed and awestruck by the grandeur and sweet mood.

We flew from Kiev and arrived in the nearby town of Simferopol in the wee cold hours of the early morning to what can only laughingly be called an airport. Hence the fitting mane- Bhakti Sangama

I can't even imagine what the next few days will bring if the mercy is already pouring down upon us. I think I speak on behalf of everyone here that we can't wait for tomorrow!

data.title: My Vyasa Puja Offering - 2010
data.blurb:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Srila Prabhupada,

Please accept my prostrated obeisances in the dust of your lotus feet. All glories to Your Divine Grace.

I've recently found myself reflecting on verses from your "Vrndavana Bhajana", written by you in 1958, the year before you formerly accepted sannyasa. Needless to say, I found every verse impregnated with deep meaning, as is every word which emanates from your lotus mouth.

In this connection I am reminded about your answer to the following question I read just yesterday in a beautiful account of your transcendental lilas in Britain, authored by your beloved disciple, Ranchor dasa. These few words spoken by you in 1972 in response to a journalist's query, also made a deep impression on me, an impression whose full impact is still yet to be realized.

"Do you know everything?" one of them [the journalists] asked with a hint of sarcasm. Prabhupada took his time to answer.

"Yes. Perhaps it is true, since everything I say is from Krishna."

As soon as read this I began to more deeply contemplate our eternal connection. Although it doesn't make any difference to me whether you know everything or not, I am convinced that you know whatever Krishna wants you to know. You do whatever Krishna wants you to do. Among the many services you render to the Divine Couple, Krishna wants you to be merciful to those who have become fully dependent upon you.

Even Krishna depends upon you, desiring your mercy!

"Although the Supreme Personality of Godhead is self-sufficient, He becomes dependent on His devotees." (SB 4.31.22)

"With the dust of My devotees' lotus feet I desire to purify the material worlds, which are situated within Me. Thus, I always follow the footsteps of My pure devotees, who are free from all personal desire, rapt in thought of My pastimes, peaceful, without any feelings of enmity, and of equal disposition everywhere." (SB 11.14.16)

When you say you know "everything", you must mean that you know Krishna's heart.

"The pure devotee is always within the core of My heart, and I am always in the heart of the pure devotee. My devotees do not know anything else but Me, and I do not know anyone else but them. (SB 9.4.68)

Krishna has given His heart to you because your only desire is His pleasure.

"I am completely under the control of My devotees. Indeed, I am not at all independent. Because My devotees are completely devoid of material desires, I sit only within the cores of their hearts. What to speak of My devotee, even those who are devotees of My devotee are very dear to Me. (SB 9.4.63)

Please, therefore, I beg you to also take my heart and make me your fully surrendered devotee. Among all that you do know, certainly you must know that is my desire.

I will never be able to fully comprehend all that lies in the depths of your merciful heart. Along with these words I offer to you today, therefore, I also offer to you the rest of my life, hoping that this will help me to more fully realize the full depths of compassion, love, and deep attachment to Krsna's service that lies within the core of your heart. It is my desire to always act according to your desire. Please, therefore, penetrate the internal region of my heart and allow me to some day more fully realize the deepest meaning of every word spoken by you. Until then, I also beg you to please accept that which I am able to offer you now.

Since a few stanzas from "Vrndavana Bhajana" seem to be more fixed into my memory than the whole composition, I'd like to reflect on those lines and conclude with the reason why they mean so much to me.

"I am sitting alone in Vrndavana-dhama
In this mood I am getting many realizations."

There you were in Vrndavana, sixty-two years of your life in this world had already passed, and already four years had passed since you left all of your family connections. Every Vaisnava hankers to live and devote the remainder of his life in the Holy Dhama. Vrndavana, therefore, seemed to be the most natural place for you to pass the rest of your life, a life already replete with all realizations necessary for dedicating your mind, body and words in full service to and remembrance of Krishna. Why would you leave?

Your answer:

“I left the peaceful life in Vrindavan to take on so much burden and anxiety for Krishna.” (Srila Prabhupada, 1974).

Full service to and remembrance of Krishna, for you, meant giving Krishna to the world and to all of us.

"Always preach! From jiva's door to door
Your life will be successful as a result of your preaching."

You left Vrndavana to preach all over the whole world, because that was the order you received from your spiritual master, an order apparently still unfulfilled at the time this was written.

"Sri Dayita dasa prabhu gave this instruction
"'Chant Hare Krsna loudly, this is my initiation:'"

You made it clear that your connection (initiation) with your own spiritual master was only through serving his order—Chant Hare Krsna loudly and "loudly" for you, meant that Krsna's name must be heard "all over the world."

I am reminded of an event which took place in 1959, the same day you accepted sannyasa. Your beloved godbrother and friend, Krsnadas Babaji Maharaja, many years later related this story to a group of your disciples. He told them that during the yajna, his chanting distracted others also taking part in the yajna. But Babaji Maharaja would always be chanting, no matter where he was. One Vaisnava requested Babaji Maharaja to chant softer so that the mantras being chanted for the yajna could be heard. You then turned to your dear godbrother and appealed to him, "Chant louder! Chant louder!" Babaji Maharaja told your disciples that it was right at that moment that he realized that you had such complete faith in the loud chanting of the holy name that you would surely be the one empowered to spread the glories of the holy name all over the world.

"Come out of your cage, stop making objection
Everything belongs to Sri Hari and Sri Hari belongs to everyone."

While others in Vrndavana were thinking that Krishna was only for them, seeing every living being as an eternal servant of Krishna, and being empowered by the full mercy of Mahaprabhu, you were convinced that Krishna and His devotional service was for everyone. Or, as Krsnadas Kaviraj Goswami proclaimed in Caitanya Caritamrita, "Not considering who asked for it and who did not, nor who was fit and who unfit to receive it, Caitanya Mahaprabhu distributed the fruit of devotional service." You embodied exactly this same mood.

"Chant the Hare Krsna mantra loudly
By the performance of such sankirtana there will come remembrance automatically
Then there will be nirjana bhajana manifested in the heart spontaneously."

It is this conclusion, Srila Prabhupada, which inspires me with great hope. How will I ever truly enter Vrndavana unless I have dedicated the rest of my life serving the same mission you left Vrndavana to fulfill?

In your Srimad Bhagavatam purport you have written:

"In conclusion, if a disciple is very serious to execute the mission of the spiritual master, he immediately associates with the Supreme Personality of Godhead by vani or vapuh. This is the only secret of success in seeing the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Instead of being eager to see the Lord in some bush of Vrndavana while at the same time engaging in sense gratification, if one instead sticks to the principle of following the words of the spiritual master, he will see the Supreme Lord without difficulty."

Narottama das Thakur also writes:

gauranga-gunete jhure, nitya-lila tare sphure,
se jana bhakati-adhikari
gaura-prema-rasarnave, se tarange jeba dube,
se radha-madhava-antaranga

"That person who feelingly appreciates the movement of Lord Gauranga gets the adhikara to enter into Radha-Krsna’s nitya-lila. Anyone who takes pleasure sporting within the waves of the ocean of Lord Caitanya's distribution of love of God immediately becomes a confidential devotee of Sri Sri Radha-Madhava."

Dear Srila Prabhupada, your example, mercy, and compassion, are my only hope for progress towards this goal in my life. Without them, I am truly a very lost soul.

Although I am unqualified to address you as such, I pray that you will some day accept me as,

Your eternal servant,

Niranjana Swami

data.title: Almaty Festival
data.blurb: There's a nice festival going on here at the Sri Vrndavana Dhama just outside Almaty, Kazakhstan. Devotees have arrived from all over the region and there are daily classes being given by Govinda Maharaja, Bhakti Vidya Purna Swami, Giriraja Swami, and myself.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
There's a nice festival going on here at the Sri Vrndavana Dhama just outside Almaty, Kazakhstan. Devotees have arrived from all over the region and there are daily classes being given by Govinda Maharaja, Bhakti Vidya Purna Swami, Giriraja Swami, and myself. I believe there are also other local devotees speaking during the day, but unfortunately, since I am commuting each day between the city and the farm, I cannot say who they are. Every evening, however, Giriraja Swami is giving his class and then there is kirtan until at least 10:00 PM. Last night the kirtan went until 10:30, I left the farm at 11:00 PM, and arrived back in the city shortly after midnight.

One of the unfortunate circumstances from the events of the past (the bulldozing of so many devotee houses in the village where Sri Vrndavana Dhama is located) is that along with a large number of devotee homes, practically all of the guest facilities which Govinda Maharaja worked so hard to arrange for all of the visiting devotees to Sri Vrndavana Dhama were also destroyed. It is for that reason that I am staying in the city. Yesterday I had to go back and forth between the farm and the city twice, which meant that I was in the car for more than four hours. During traffic time it can take as long as 80 minutes to get to the farm. Fortunately, however, I don't have to do that every day. Usually it is only one trip a day.

Despite the hostility of local government officials in their efforts to remove the devotees from Sri Vrndavana Dhama, the spirit of the devotees living there is very high. Those who faithfully endured the austerities which were forced upon them appear to have been very resilient to the government's aggression. Govinda Maharaja has several times spoken about this in his introductory talks to the assembled devotees and has been often heard praising and thanking the Sri Vrndavana Dhama devotees for their determination to worship the deities and to maintain the project.

Based upon my discussions with Govinda Maharaja about the future of the Sri Vrndavana Dhama project, it appears that now that the dust has settled and the hostile actions of the government have desisted, there is some ray of hope that what's presently left of Sri Vrndavana Dhama will remain. It's probably too early to give a forecast of how that will take shape until negotiations with the government have been completed. Negotiations are going on, but unfortunately they do not move so quickly in this part of the world.

Meanwhile we are preparing for tomorrow's Janmastami celebration and Srila Prabhupada's Vyasa Puja the day after. I will be returning to the farm shortly to give my afternoon lecture to the assembled devotees and will stay throughout the evening program as well.

Many lectures and kirtans, both audio and video, have been recorded, but unfortunately there is still no sign of a suitable internet connection so that these files can be uploaded. The devotees with whom I am staying are definitely trying their best to get a connection installed for this purpose. But due to circumstances beyond their control, there is some delay.

Hopefully, we will have that connection either later today or tomorrow and then gradually some of these files will appear on the site.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Short Update
data.blurb: I arrived in Almaty very early on the 25th morning. There are a few stories to tell, since the situation became somewhat of an adventure. But it may take awhile before I will post them to my blog for reasons which should become clear once they are posted.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I arrived in Almaty very early on the 25th morning. There are a few stories to tell, since the situation became somewhat of an adventure. But it may take awhile before I will post them to my blog for reasons which should become clear once they are posted.

Unfortunately, I still don't have a very reliable internet connection which makes it difficult to post new blogs onto the site. Also, it may take some time before we can find a way to upload large files from the festival. So everyone will have to be patient.

The festival will not start until the 28th evening, although I've been told that Bhakti Vidya Purna Swami has been giving daily seminars to all of the local devotees. Unfortunately I have not been able to attend any of Maharaja's classes since arriving, however, because I got sick on the flight and also developed an infection which requires attention and rest.

If this short blog gets posted, you should know that it took a lot more time than usual to do it. So I will end here until I can get a better connection.

Hare Krsna
