data.title: A Slight Glimpse of New Vraja Dhama
data.blurb: As much as I'm inclined to share photos and videos of different events on this site, I am not so inclined to take pictures or shoot videos. So from time to time I just ask somebody if they would be willing to take pictures or shoot videos for posting on this site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As much as I'm inclined to share photos and videos of different events on this site, I am not so inclined to take pictures or shoot videos. So from time to time I just ask somebody if they would be willing to take pictures or shoot videos for posting on this site.

About a week and a half ago, I made a similar request to Nama Ruci dasa in New Vraja Dhama. Nama Ruci likes to take photos, and in fact, many of the earlier photos found on this site from either Budapest Rathayatra or from different events in New Vraja Dhama were taken by him with his camera. However, knowing that Nama Ruci likes fresh challenges, this time I asked him if he would take some video shots of New Vraja Dhama. At first, Nama Ruci was a little bewildered by my request. He didn't quite know what I was looking for. But then again, neither did I. I told him, "Just take the camera and shoot whatever you see in New Vraja Dhama. It's all transcendental anyway." So that's what he did.

It just so happened the next day, August 10th, the day when Nama Ruci did all of his shooting, there were sixty devotees visiting New Vraja Dhama from the Dubai yatra. They were on a tour of several temples in Europe and New Vraja Dhama was one of the main pilgimage sites they wanted to see. So the bus filled with these devotees arrived in New Vraja Dhama late on the night of August 9th.

Several hours before they arrived, Sivarama Maharaja came to my room and asked me if I would give Srimad Bhagavatam class to them the following morning, a request from him which I could not refuse. So when I showed up for Deity Greeting, Guru Puja and class, it didn't take too long before I learned that their bus arrived in New Vraja Dhama "very" late the previous night. It all became clear to me as soon as I started to speak. As I was apologetically told after class, even though they all arrived at about one in the morning, they were all at mangala arati, japa, Guru Puja and class. So you may be able to imagine what it was like speaking to sixty devotees who all slept no more than two hours the previous night. Fortunately, Nama Ruci didn't focus on that with the camera, and neither did I with my class.

After class Nama Ruci dasa went about fulfilling the mission I had given to him and the following day the camera was delivered back to me by Nilamani Cakravarti devi dasi, his wife. Nama Ruci dasa had to leave New Vraja Dhama for several days and by the time he got back, I was preparing to leave New Vraja Dhama so that I could get to the Kazakh Embassy on the last day it would be opened before my departure to Almaty. It was then, when the camera was handed back to me, that I realized that the suggestion I had also made on the day I gave Nama Ruci the camera, to work together to edit the videos, was not going to take place.

I originally proposed to Nama Ruci that we edit the video "together," because I didn't know if he knew anything about video editing. Certainly I didn't. Having never done it before I thought that between the two of us we might have a better chance of producing something worthwhile. I should have also considered the fact that Nama Ruci dasa doesn't speak English and neither do I speak Hungarian.

After looking at some of the clips it appeared that Nama Ruci must have spent quite a few hours shooting the videos I asked him to shoot. Not wanting his efforts to go in vain, yesterday I decided to load all the clips into iMovie and this morning I put them together. I'm no film editor and that will become clear by what you'll see in the 30-minute clip of "A Slight Glimpse of New Vraja Dhama."

Like Lilasuka dasa (mentioned in my August 17th blog) just as his time is much better spent by focusing on the preaching in Budapest rather than developing his videography skills, my time will be much better spent chanting, writing, reading, (I also now have to exercise every 30-60 minutes a day) and communicating with devotees all over the world rather than on editing video clips in iMovie.

The bottom line is that I could have spent more time on editing, but I didn't. I did manage though, to add a really nice soundtrack, a few beautiful photos of the Deities which were posted here on the site two years ago, and I tried my best to meditate on Radhe Syama in the process.

Hare Krsna

data.title: In Defense of Lilasuka Dasa
data.blurb: I ended my blog yesterday diminishing Lilasuka dasa's skills in videography. Unfortunately, the impression I had of his video-shooting talents was based upon a cursory exploration of the video's first several minutes.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I ended my blog yesterday diminishing Lilasuka dasa's skills in videography. Unfortunately, the impression I had of his video-shooting talents was based upon a cursory exploration of the video's first several minutes. After watching more of the video (some time after I wrote the blog), I discovered that Lilasuka gradually got a better feel of the camera and was able to capture a lot of the mood left in my memory after Sunday's event.

Instead of removing my closing comments from yesterday's blog, I'll take them back here and I'll give him an "A" for effort (an "A" according to U.S. standards is equal to 90-100%). Given the chance, he'd probably become as good of a videographer as he is a Temple President. But then again, for the sake of the Budapest yatra, it's probably best he continues to focus on the preaching in Budapest.

You can find his slightly-edited video in the "Recent Videos" block on the home page.

Hare Krsna

data.title: A Community Gathering in New Vraja Dhama
data.blurb: Yesterday evening Kesava Bharati Maharaja and I were invited to participate in a community gathering here in New Vraja Dhama, held outside a recently-renovated building which houses four householder couples.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Yesterday evening Kesava Bharati Maharaja and I were invited to participate in a community gathering here in New Vraja Dhama, held outside a recently-renovated building which houses four householder couples. Before we arrived, Govardhana Lal had been taken on procession with kirtan from the temple, throughout the community, and He was then brought to preside over the event. By the time we arrived, most of the devotees, including Sivarama Maharaja, had already taken a tour of the building and they were sitting on the grass having kirtan.

Upon entering the building, and while being shown each of the rooms, I was fascinated to see that each householder apartment was one room, simply but tastefully furnished, with a small sink, a small four-burner stove and an adjoining bathroom. The rooms were immaculately clean, as is everything in New Vraja Dhama, and all the walls were freshly painted. I was greatly appreciating the simplicity of New Vraja Dhama householder life, and I was also imagining how difficult it would be for many householders to live in such a simple environment.

I attributed the success of their lifestyle to the fact that most New Vraja Dhama devotees spend most of their waking hours actively serving within the community. All of New Vraja Dhama is their home, service to Radha Syamasundara is their life, and their humble dwelling is simply where they rest for the night, where they may take a short rest or read during the day, or possibly where they would recuperate if they should fall sick. Other than that, they are either busy in the temple, in kirtan, on the altar, in the Deities' kitchen, in the fields, in the gardens, with Krsna's cows, with administration, or taking guests on tours.

After getting our tour of the building, we were invited to sit next to Sivarama Maharaja, who shortly thereafter gave a short talk in Hungarian about life in New Vraja Dhama. I did not come with the intention to speak, and therefore I simply asked Lilasuka dasa, the Budapest Temple President, if he would translate Sivarama Maharaja's talk for me. After his talk, Sivarama Maharaja then asked Kesava Bharati Maharaja, who was sitting immediately next to him if he would say something. He spoke briefly, (his talk is posted on www.sivaramaswami.com) and then, caught by surprise, Maharaja turned to me and asked if I wanted to say something. I asked him, "Do you want me to say something?" He nodded with approval.

After seeing where some of the devotees present were living and hearing the talks of both Maharajas, what immediately came to my mind is what has been posted in the audio section below. I assume that it will soon be translated into Russian for those who do not understand English.

After I spoke, there was kirtan again, Govardhana Lal was brought back to the temple in procession, and the remaining devotees were served a nice evening snack of home-made potato chips with cream sauce, along with maha-prasadam.

I brought a small video camera with me, thinking that I would ask somebody to film the event so that it could be posted some time later on the site. But, since there was no time or opportunity to ask somebody to take a video for me, I waited until after the talks and then asked Lilasuka dasa if he would shoot some video for me.

My impression is that Lilasuka Prabhu is a much better Temple President than a videographer. From what I've seen of the video so far, it appears that a lot of the shooting was more of the sky than what was below. Of course, it's possible he saw something in the sky that I wasn't able to see. But since Sivarama Maharaja had the same impression as I did, I'll assume that after some simple editing, hopefully there will be something which can be posted in the video section soon.

Hare Krsna

data.title: New "Gauranga Press" Mailorder Departments and Site
data.blurb: Through the efforts of many devotees, especially Yugala Piriti devi dasi and Visnu dasa, a mailorder site has been established for purchasing "Gauranga Press" books online, both in English and in Russian, from within the CIS countries.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Through the efforts of many devotees, especially Yugala Piriti devi dasi and Visnu dasa, a mailorder site has been established for purchasing "Gauranga Press" books online, both in English and in Russian, from within the CIS countries. These books are now available online at http://www.niranjanaswami.com/ruorder/.

All orders from within Ukraine and Moldova will be shipped from within Ukraine, thus dramatically reducing the cost of each book as well as postage costs. All orders from other CIS countries will be shipped from Moscow.

Regarding future publications, the Gauranga Press staff is currently working on a fully revised edition, both in English and in Russian, of "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume One." Also, "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume Three", is in progress, and will be available in both English and in Russian. LFD-3 will be published next after the LFD-1 revision is published.

Other earlier publications which are out of print are also being reprinted. Some are already available online and the others will be available soon. The "Gauranga Press" staff is also gearing up to produce even more new titles once all this has been accomplished.

The United States "Gauranga Press" mailorder department will continue to service orders from countries of the Western Hemisphere and Western Europe. These books are available at the following two links:

http://www.niranjanaswami.com/Niranjana_Swami/Mailorder.html

http://nrs.iskconboston.org/books

Hare Krsna

data.title: Update and Travel Plans
data.blurb: Last night I returned to Budapest from my 12-day visit to Lithuania. I was very happy to be in the association of the devotees from the Baltic countries once again. It had been two years since my last visit. I had also not seen H.H. Bhakti Caitanya Swami since my last Baltics visit.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Last night I returned to Budapest from my 12-day visit to Lithuania. I was very happy to be in the association of the devotees from the Baltic countries once again. It had been two years since my last visit. I had also not seen H.H. Bhakti Caitanya Swami since my last Baltics visit. So getting his association once again was also very refreshing.

I now must return to my daily exercise regimen. Although I was strict in Lithuania, unfortunately I was not strict enough. There were some setbacks. But it appears to me that they are not too serious. Hopefully the therapist will agree with me. I have an appointment with her tomorrow morning, at which time I should have a more clear picture of where everything stands. Assuming that she will not reintroduce severe restrictions on me again, I am already prepared to publish the dates and places for my next trip from Hungary.

The next two weeks I will stay in New Vraja Dhama. Actually, because I had to stay in Budapest for five months in order to take treatment in the clinic, I have not stayed for more than a week in New Vraja Dhama since last December. So I am very much looking forward to being once again in Radha Syamasundara's Holy Dhama and to obtain the opportunity to chant Their glories in the association of Their surrendered servants, especially His Holiness Sivarama Maharaja.

Tomorrow I am also applying for my visa to Kazakhstan so that I can fulfill my commitment to His Holiness B.B. Govinda Maharaja that I would take part in their festival from August 28th – September 4th. I presently have a booking to depart from Budapest on August 26th to Almaty, but I am also wait-listed on the 22nd, 23rd, and 25th. If a seat should clear for me on one of those earlier dates, I will leave for Almaty earlier so that I can settle down there and rest before the festival begins. As I have been told, attending that festival will be H.H. B.B. Govinda Maharaja, H.H. Indradyumna Maharaja, H.H. Bhakti Vidya Purna Maharaja, and H.H. Giriraja Maharaja. So I am definitely looking forward to some nice kirtans and hari katha for that week in Almaty.

From Almaty, I am planning to fly to Kiev on September 7th, at which time I will greet some of my invited guests who will be taking part in this year's Evpatoriya Festival. From Kiev I am booked to fly to Evpatoriya on the evening of September 9th, so that I can also settle in there and rest in time for the first day of the festival on September 11th.

As per tradition, I will not hold any personal meetings during the Evpatoriya Festival, especially since I will be hosting many new visitors to this year's festival. However, my return flight to Kiev is booked for the evening of September 16th. If necessary, it may be possible to schedule a few meetings during the early afternoon of September 16th. Madana-mohana dasa will be my secretary in Evpatoriya. Devotees can contact him there, and only then will I be able to confirm whether or not a few meetings will be possible on the 16th. I will not confirm any meetings until a day or two before the 16th.

On September 17th, I am scheduled to fly to Budapest and from the airport I will go directly to New Vraja Dhama to celebrate Radhastami with the devotees of New Vraja Dhama on September 19th. At present, my plan is to remain in New Vraja Dhama for approximately one week in order to fulfill some commitments I made with several of my godbrothers, including Purusartha dasa, a godbrother who joined in Boston not long after I did and with whom I associated very closely for many years subsequent to that. Both he and his wife, Tulasi dasi, who I have also known for 30 years, will be attending the Evpatoriya Festival and we will be traveling together to Hungary on September 17th.

I have more travel plans after that visit to New Vraja Dhama, but since my plans seem a bit ambitious for somebody who is still not supposed to be traveling much, I will stop here for now and as time passes I will hopefully be able to better ascertain whether or not I will be able to follow through with those plans.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Transcription of a short talk by Aindra Prabhu, given in Mayapura, Gaura Purnima Festival, 2010
data.blurb: The following is a transcription of a talk given during the Gaura Purnima Festival by Aindra Prabhu in Mayapura, 2010.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is a transcription of a talk given during the Gaura Purnima Festival by Aindra Prabhu in Mayapura, 2010.

Please remember and I beseech you again and again. Please remember: world-wide, ISKCON, grass-roots, nama-sankirtan revolution. Revolution means revolution. It means we have to shed pounds and gallons and gallons of blood to get the job done. We have to turn this movement inside out, upside down, whatever we have to do, but we have to put nama-sankirtan back into it's rightful place of dignity in the forefront of our movement. It's absolutely essential for the proper growth of our movement. Those who understood this are awake to the need of the hour. And those who have not understood it are still sleeping. It's time to wake up and understand what is the responsibility of every man, woman and child in this movement; to take seriously that dharma which Lord Caitanya Himself inaugurated for the deliverance of all the fallen conditioned souls for the rest of this Kali Yuga.

There's another 427,000 years left to Kali Yuga. The yuga dharma doesn't change. The next yuga is Satya Yuga and for them contemplative, peaceful meditation is where it's at. But in Kali Yuga you got to get fired up; every one of you, fired up— chanting, dancing from the heart like you really mean it—like you really want Lord Caitanya's mercy. So that you can even think, you can even hope, to go back home, back to Godhead in this one lifetime. It's not a joke. It's the real thing. So stand up and do what's right. Do the real thing. Perform nama-sankirtan daily, every day, for as many hours as possible and you'll get there. I guarantee it. Not that I guarantee it. Lord Caitanya has guaranteed it. And help others to understand the need to augment the performance of nama-sankirtan; to increase the performance of nama-sankirtan on a regular, daily basis in every major city all over the world.

That's what has to happen to make this ISKCON movement grow properly. Otherwise what happens is that you get a deformed child due to undernourishment. You understand this? Can you understand it? The way to feed the child in Kali Yuga— you have to water the creeper of devotion. And you have to give the creeeper of devotion proper nourishment. It doesn't just mean a few snik, snik, rama ramas as a token gesture on the side. That's not going to get you back home, back to Godhead. You may take another 700 lifetimes to get home, back to Godhead, that way. It means getting fired up and doing the real thing—the yuga dharma, harinama sankirtan. There's no other yuga dharma for anyone of us. And there's no way that you are going to get Krsna prema in this Kali Yuga if you don't do the Kali Yuga dharma. That's the way to do it.

Trnad api sunicena, that's what it means to be humble. Humble enough to recognize that you're one of the fallen creatures that has to take advantage of the opportunity to perform nama-sankirtan while you have the opportunity. Who knows what kind of condtion the demons are going to impose on us in some future date? Global tyranny is on it's way. Don't think otherwise. You don't know what's going to happen in the future. But right now we can take the opportunity. Right now we have the facility to congregate and dance and chant. Hare Krsna Hare Krsna Krsna Krsna Hare Hare/ Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare.

And especially in Vrndavana where you get a thousand times the benefit of chanting Hare Krsna Hare Krsna Krsna Krsna Hare Hare/ Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare.

Taror iva sahisnuna means to stand up and do what's right against all odds. If your temple authorities tell you not to perform the yuga dharma, not to perform sankirtan, then I'm sorry, they are not your authorities. If your guru tells you not to perform nama-sankirtan, then I'm sorry, he is not your guru, because he's not representing adi-guru, Nityananda, who created the Nama-Hatta, the marketplace of the holy name, by loudly propagating nama-sankirtan. And if the guru is not satisfied by our performance of nama-sankirtan, then he's not our guru.

Caitya-guru is satisfied and the proper representative will manifest in due course to encourage you to do the right thing against all odds, taror iva sahisnuna amaninena. What does amaninena mean? It simply means not to expect to be regarded, not to expect to be regarded as having the fitness for any other dharma in this age. The soul has to go back back to Godhead, and the way that's going to happen is if the soul agrees to engage all of his psychophysical energies and his whole heart in the performance of sneha samyukta harinama sankirtan. Sneha means with affection. Samyukta means complete engagement. Full on! Fired up! And back home, back to Godhead in this one lifetime. Don't let anyone tell you that it can't be done.

Why did Srila Prabhupada stress book distribution? Book distribution is for the purpose of philosophically convincing others to join Lord Caitanya's harinama sankirtan party. If they come and they see that there's no practical demonstration of the life of all transcendental knowledge in the books, for them to participate in, be a part of, then no wonder devotees are leaving and going hither and thither to look for the higher taste. Because they are not getting the higher taste. They are not getting harinama ruci. They are not geting suddha-nama ruci, because they are not doing that activity which actually helps us to get suddha-nama ruci. The most powerful process for getting suddha-nama ruci is the loud congregational chanting of the holy name Much more so that nama-japa. Nama-japa is like taking tablets. And nama-sankirtan is like an injection when you really need it bad. Because you're sick. And if you think you're not sick, you're in illusion. So you need to take the medicine. And medicine means proper dosage and proper frequency. Not just a little token lip service, a little makeshow, to kind of like... and then anthropologically study about it in the scriptures. That, "Oh that was back in Lord Caitanya's time."

So, anyway, on that note, I humbly request all of you; it's very important that we understand this philosophy. We have to understand the philosophy. If you're chanting and dancing in Lord Caitanya's sankirtan movement, then basically you've understood the philosophy. And if you're not chanting and dancing in Lord Caitanya's sankirtan, then it means that you simply have not understood the philosophy. Hari Bol.

data.title: A Great Loss
data.blurb: Just minutes ago I read the shocking news that my godbrother, Aindra dasa, unexpectedly left this world last night in Sri Vrndavana Dh
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Just minutes ago I read the shocking news that my godbrother, Aindra dasa, unexpectedly left this world last night in Sri Vrndavana Dhama. I'm too devastated to write anything long in this connection. The constant tears flowing from my eyes make it too hard to write and even as I write these few words, my thoughts of him only increase their flow. The world will suffer this tremendous loss of a great soul whose heart and soul was to expand the full glories of Sri Nama.

My only solace at this moment is the memory I have of him last year when he came to see me while I was staying in Giriraja Maharaja's house in Vrndavana. Aindra Prabhu heard that I had injured my back but came anyway to request me to try and come to Krsna Balarama Mandir to chant during the boat festival on Gaura Purnima. Due to the intensity of his appeal, I did not want to disappoint him by telling him that it was impossible for me to attend. Rather than immediately telling him this, I simply looked at him right in the eyes and said to him, "Aindra Prabhu, from the core of my heart I wish to thank you for your complete dedication to the Holy Name. Not only myself, but I can see that the whole world is influenced by your dedication to Sri Nama." Aindra Prabhu was completely taken aback by my interuption to his appeal. He looked back at me, also right into my eyes, but stumbled in his attempt to accept my appreciation. He thanked me for my kind words, but he looked so humble and child-like at that moment, that I sensed he was momentarily displaying another identity—possibly the one for which he constantly hankered for in the core of his heart. I have no doubt in my heart that he is now serving Radha and Krsna in this fully manifested form.

Devotees throughout the world should celebrate the life of this great soul by gathering together to chant Hare Krsna and by appreciating what Aindra Prabhu has done for anyone and everyone who has ever come in contact with him.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Update
data.blurb: After consulting with my therapist last week and then after a few more days of deliberation, I decided that I will attend the Lithuania Festival from July 26, 2010 until August 1, 2010.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
After consulting with my therapist last week and then after a few more days of deliberation, I decided that I will attend the Lithuania Festival from July 26, 2010 until August 1, 2010.

I am still not clear to what degree I will participate in the festival. Based upon my experience in Moscow and Kiev, I have to be prepared to cancel a program, even at the last minute, should the pain in my back become too severe. I had to cancel my participation in one program in Moscow and one program in Kiev for this reason. Since there are no simultaneous programs at the Lithuania Festival, I will have to figure out a way that somebody else can speak in my place should I have to cancel. In this regard, I am in the process of working something out with Doyal Govinda dasa and hopefully we will come up with a satisfactory solution.

I plan to arrive in Vilnius on July 24th, but I will not participate in any public events until the first day of the festival. I also plan to remain in Lithuania until August 4th, at which time, I will return to Budapest. I am not making any commitments from August 1-4, but will wait until I see how my health is once the festival is over. If devotees need to make their plans in advance, they should assume that I will be resting from August 1-4 unless they hear otherwise at the end of the festival.

In previous years, I used to go to Belarus from Lithuania upon completion of the Lithuania Festival. However, because I have been requested to take only one trip a month for the next few months, I have decided that I will not visit Belarus at that time. Instead, this year I am planning to visit Belarus some time in October.

Hare Krsna

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Sivarama Maharaja contacted me yesterday morning and asked if I would replace him as the speaker at Bhaktivedanta College. I was happy to be of some service.

Minutes later I received a text message from Maharani dasi with the topic for today's talk, "What is our [Vaisnavism's] connection with other world religions?" With no time to prepare and considering that there were quite a few students who were not devotees, the first thing which came to my mind was to speak about Rev. Oleksandr Ovcherenko's commentary in the following article which was given to me during my recent visit to Kiev.

The audio file of that talk has been posted below in the audio section. Hopefully, the talk will be either dubbed in Russian, or transcribed and translated into Russian in the near future.

It's possible the article may be translated into Russian in the near future too, but if not, at least we will get Reverend Oleksandr Ovcherenko's commentary translated.

To read in this window click on "Fullscreen" below.

To read on KyivWeekly's site click HERE, but you will exit this site.

Hare Krsna

data.title: My Visit to Kiev and Moscow
data.blurb: I arrived back in Budapest yesterday evening. Today I spent most of the day recuperating from yesterday's trip.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I arrived back in Budapest yesterday evening. Today I spent most of the day recuperating from yesterday's trip. We also scheduled an appointment with the therapist for Thursday afternoon, at which time I hope to get her opinion about what I will and will not be able to do in the immediate future.

Meanwhile, I'd like to say a few words about this last trip before I retire for the night.

As always, it was very satisfying to be in H.H. Radhanath Swami's association once again. Although I could see that, physically, he was very tired, when it comes time to speaking Hari Katha or to chanting, you would never suspect it.

Due to circumstances beyond our control, although we speak from time to time on the phone, Radhanath Maharaja and I have not been together for almost two years. Since next month Maharaja will begin a four-month tour in the United States to launch his book "The Journey Home", I was very eager to see him now before he returns to the U.S., just in case I won't be able to visit the United States during the time that he's there. As I mentioned in Kiev, Krsna fulfilled this desire for me.

Krsna also fulfilled my desire to visit Moscow. I've been to Kiev already five times during the last year. But this was my first visit to Moscow in over two years. For me, this visit to Moscow was one of the best visits I can remember for many years. In particular, I was very inspired to observe all the efforts devotees were making in the background to accommodate all the visiting devotees. I'm fully aware that in a city like Moscow, it is not an easy thing to organize any event. There are always so many obstacles, even to travel from one place to the other in the city-- what to speak of so many unexpected disruptions to plans. But this time it seemed to me that Krsna was removing these impediments (although I'm sure there were many that I did not see), in order to reciprocate with the devotees' desire to serve the visiting Vaisnavas. I pray that all the visiting devotees were satisfied by the efforts of the local devotees and if, by some misfortune, someone was not received or accommodated nicely, that they will forgive the devotees involved since I'm sure that was not their intention.

Naturally I also noticed that so much organization was there in the background for making Radhanath Maharaja's and my stay in Moscow as comfortable as possible. It would be irresponsible of me to not mention this. But, if I am to be honest, I am even more satisfied when I see others besides myself being served nicely.

I would therefore like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all the devotees (names witheld since it's better to not name anyone than to leave someone out by an oversight) for making it the successful festival that it was.

I would also like to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to all of the devotees who took responsibilities for organizing the festival in Kiev. Everything I said above about Moscow also applies to the festival in Kiev.

To everyone, please continue to serve the Vaisnavas in this spirit and Krsna will bless you for taking nice care of His devotees.

Hare Krsna

The therapist was so pleased with the progress I've made during the past two weeks that when I asked her opinion about taking a ten day international trip at the end of this month, returning to Hungary by July 5th, she immediately smiled and said, "Yes, as long as you do your exercises every day, three times a day, you may certainly go."

I have already booked tickets from Budapest to Kiev to Moscow and then returning to Budapest. Assuming that I will have my Russian visa on June 23rd, the day the Russian Embassy told me that my passport and visa should be ready, I will fly to Kiev on June 25th. My flight is booked to Moscow for June 29th late evening. I will depart Moscow on July 5th, returning to Budapest. I have arranged my visit to coincide with His Holiness Radhanath Swami's visit to Kiev (June 23 – June 29), and his visit to Moscow (June 30 – July 7).

I will be very restrained during these ten days. My participation in daily events will have to be fully in line with the doctor and therapist's recommendations. But I am very much looking forward to seeing everyone chanting and dancing together in kirtan.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Travel
data.blurb: My computer has been repaired, but during the past few days I've been traveling back and forth between embassies in an effort to acquire Ukraine and Russian visas.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
My computer has been repaired, but during the past few days I've been traveling back and forth between embassies in an effort to acquire Ukraine and Russian visas. In fact right at this moment I'm typing this on my mobile phone while standing at the back of a long line of people waiting to get in to the Russian Embassy. Yesterday we fought through traffic all morning to come here only to be told that they were not accepting visa applications yesterday. It was a little disappointing because the Danube River is partially flooded in Budapest, closing many roads and creating a lot of traffic. What normally takes 30 minutes can take 2 hours. Anyway, we managed to get here today within a reasonable time.

So while we are on the subject of visas, I should reveal what is happening in this connection. I am getting my visas now only because I am relocating to New Vraja Dhama next week and I wanted to get my visas before leaving Budapest. I still have no immediate plans to travel anywhere. I will explain why.

According to my therapist, I am making good progress right now. I feel the same as well. But during my last appointment with her she told me that this will be a very crucial month. As the saying goes, in this month I could "make it or break it". If I can continue to make progress this month then further progress could be rapid. But if I travel, or overendeavor physically in any way, I run the risk of falling back to where I was at the beginning. In consultation with many devotees I am hearing again and again that the risks of losing progress are just too great. Therefore at this point in time I am still not making any plans to travel. The only plans I am making at this time are to visit Kazakhstan at the end of August and to attend the Evpatoriya Festival after that. My thoughts are that those two events are far enough away to make plans for. Anything before that, is still too early for me to predict.

It's not easy standing in line and blogging at the same time. I don't know how so many people do it these days. So I will stop here.

Hare Krsna.

Body_raw.value:
This is a short message written from my mobile phone. My computer is presently under repair. Hopefully I will have it back and working properly within the next 1-2 days.

Meanwhile I am taking the opportunity to do some extra reading. This afternoon I finished reading "When the Sun Shines", a beautiful account of the Krsna Consciousness Movement in Great Britain, and Srila Prabhupada's personal involvement in it's step by step development. A truly wonderful book expertly documented by my godbrother, Ranchor dasa.

I also read about half of H.H. Chandramauli Swami's new book entitled "Holy Jail", which is a well documented book of the "ISKCON Prison Ministry" and how so many people's lives were reformed by reading Srila Prabhupada's books and chanting Krsna's names while serving time in prison. Chandramauli Swami gave me a copy of his new book last week and requested me to read it and critique it. So far I've read some very moving testimonies on Krsna consciousness saved these inmates from the darkest depths of despair.

I'll write more once I have a working computer again. 

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Update
data.blurb: In less than an hour I will be leaving for my next visit to the therapist which is a little more than half the way from Budapest to New Vraja Dhama. After the therapist, I will continue to New Vraja Dhama for tomorrow's Nrsimha Caturdasi Festival and Sivarama Maharaja's Vyasa Puja on Sunday.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
In less than an hour I will be leaving for my next visit to the therapist which is a little more than half the way from Budapest to New Vraja Dhama. After the therapist, I will continue to New Vraja Dhama for tomorrow's Nrsimha Caturdasi Festival and Sivarama Maharaja's Vyasa Puja on Sunday. I am very much looking forward to the opportunity to visit New Vraja Dhama once again, to get the darshan of Radha Syamasundara, and to be in the association of Sivarama Swami, several other visiting godbrothers (Kesava Bharati das Goswami, B.B. Govinda Swami, and Chandramauli Swami) and all the residents and guests of New Vraja Dhama.

I will try to get material to post here on the site throughout the weekend, but at this point in time, whether or not I'll get something remains questionable.

Although I'm staying in Hungary, the last time I was in New Vraja Dhama was at the end of December. As I reported in earlier blogs, I've been staying in Budapest for more than four months in order to be close to the clinic which I visited several times a week. I just finished with the clinic about a week and a half ago. Now I am moving in the next phase of physical therapy. The therapist estimates approximately two more months for that. My estimate may differ, but for now, I'm keeping silent and will continue to cooperate.

I apologize for my inability to maintain regular blogs for the last couple of weeks. I've been dealing with many other immediate issues, while still trying to put time in for working on "Lectures from a Disciple", Volume Three. Although there is tangible improvement with my back, I still need to follow the same daily routine, going through cycles of sitting, standing, walking and lying down, which has its impact on how much time I can spend writing. My hope is that as my back continues to improve, so will my ability to maintain regular blogs along with everything else I need to take care of while being physically absent from the temples I usually visit each year. Still, I hope to be able to post at least once again this weekend.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Sridama and Kisori's Visit to Hungary
data.blurb: During this past week, Sridama and Kisori from Radha Gopinath Mandir have been here in Hungary giving seminars on devotee care. This morning they left for Kiev, where they will spend approximately 10 days before returning to Mumbai.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During this past week, Sridama and Kisori from Radha Gopinath Mandir have been here in Hungary giving seminars on devotee care. This morning they left for Kiev, where they will spend approximately 10 days before returning to Mumbai.

I attended some of their presentations while they were here. I also spent time with them getting updated on the service they rendered as members of the GBC Devotee Care Committee as well as all the places they visited since we met last year.

In connection with Sridama and Kisori's visit, yesterday in Budapest there was a "Bhakta Sanga" program held for the Hungarian Yatra. The program was held in a large hall, usually rented for these events.

After kirtan, Candrodaya dasa rendered a dramatic reading from "Nava Vraja Mahima," the book Sivarama Swami is currently writing. Devotees played beautiful music in the background, just suitable for the mood of the reading, while slides of the art work for the new book were projected on a large screen behind Sivarama Swami and Candrodaya dasa.

As expected, after getting a slight glimpse of what's to come in this book (projected to be 4,300 pages), I observed how excited the devotees were at the prospect of soon having these books in their hands to bathe their minds and hearts with the nectarian topics connected with New Vraja Dhama and the pastimes of Radha Syamasundara. However, when we heard all the work that still needs to be done and the timeline for it's projected completion we had no choice but to readjust our expectations. Although three-quarters of the book is already written, still much more time is required for editing, proofreading, artwork, layout and design. The dates Sivarama Maharaja gave for its expected completion were spring, 2012 for English and spring, 2013 for Hungarian.

After the reading, Sivarama Maharaja gave an introductory talk in Hungarian (a transcription of the English translation will soon be available) requesting the devotees assembled to cooperate with the implementation of the counselor system in Hungary. Then Radha Krsna dasa interviewed Sridama, Kisori, Candramauli Swami and myself, asking all of us relevant questions about the counselor system and our experiences with it elsewhere. The English/ Hungarian recording of that interview will be soon posted in the audio section on the front page.

A nice lunch was then served to everyone, although Candramauli Swami and I returned to the temple for a much simpler lunch.

A little later in the evening, Sivarama Swami, Candramauli Swami, I, and a small group of the local leaders gathered in the temple conference room to express our appreciation for all that Sridama and Kisori shared during their visit. What ensued was a very sweet exchange between all of us. You will also find the recording of that gathering in the audio section below.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Letter from Srutakirti Prabhu
data.blurb:
Dear Maharaja,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Dear Maharaja,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

I hope all is well and your not suffering too much. Below is my offering to my wife. Somehow two weeks have already gone by. If you like please pass it on so that it can be put on your website. I hope to see you in September, as the song goes. We will see what happens. If there is anything I can do for you let me know. I will probably spend part of June with my daughter who is about to have her first child the end of this month. From there we will see what unfolds. I am doing okay, all things considered, and eager to see what Krishna has in store for me next.

your servant, Srutakirti das

A tribute to Amekhala devi dasi by Srutakirti das

It has been two weeks since my wife left this world under the protection of Srila Prabhuapda. I have wanted to write my offering, my homage to her, but I haven’t been able to do it. I haven’t been able to think very clearly. My entire life was turned upside down in a moment. I was so busy taking care of her for the last 18 months I never had time to contemplate on what was happening right in front of my eyes.

Feelings of emptiness embrace me at every moment. Besides her leaving I’ve had to deal with more than a few devotees telling me she has visited them since her departure. Many would be skeptical, some may not. I have always been a skeptic myself. I have never felt mystical experiences, "beings" around me or anything like that. I don’t doubt it could happen, that someone might see her silhouette, hear her speak, or feel her presence. I know that anything is possible. Once, Srila Prabhupada was asked if there were any ghosts around. He answered, “wall to wall.” I even believe she did visit these fortunate devotees but that makes me more upset. What about me, your husband, who has taken care of you and nursed you 24 hours a day. I know I’m dull headed but damn. I have been talking to her and pleading for a dream, a voice or a breeze next to me. Anything! I have been so lonely.

On Tuesday, May 4th I left our home in the UK. I spent the next 3 days at my sister’s home visiting my eighty-seven year old mother. I wanted her to know I was okay and going to survive this trauma. She lost her husband at 30 and had to raise three of us on her own. She remained unmarried and never wavered in her duties since then. She drives to church every morning, still.

This morning at 4:30 a.m. I left my family and drove to JFK airport in New York. When I put my bags in the car I felt like it was a new life in front of me, but had no idea what it was. I was on my own now. I thought at least the time of the day was auspicious. I thought I am being forced to have complete faith in Guru and Krishna. It was a 100 mile drive from my mother’s house. I was taking my next flight to a quiet place to chant and hopefully write. I was going to be staying with devotee friends there for the next few weeks. While driving, every now and then I talked to Amekhala, out loud. This is not my style, but everything has changed. I prayed to her, to please give me some sign she was still with me. I really believed it was possible she could comfort me. I have just been thinking that I don’t deserve it because of my many sinful activities and offenses to devotees in this life.

The flight was at 8:45 a.m. Amekhala and I always left early for the airport, rather than rushing and being in anxiety about not being on time. I dropped off the Hertz one-way rental and asked a few people to help me find my way onto the train that whizzes around to the eight different terminals. I don’t know my way around JFK at all. I know Heathrow Airport in England very well. I checked my bags at Jetblue Airways. With plenty of time I went through security and then stepped onto the moving aisles headed to the main departure area. With my rolling hand luggage I stepped off the moving ramp and walked a few steps. I looked up. There was a large triangular shaped center area with three levels, some cushions and outlets where you can plug in your computer. It was the hub to all 30 gates. I thought that was great. I'll plug in my computer and try to find a wireless signal. I took a few more steps and looked straight into her youngest son’s bright blue eyes. It was Vrinny! We couldn’t believe it. Impossible! It was a real live miracle for both of us. Since the day before I left the UK we hadn’t spoken a word. He was not in the house the morning I left the UK. Neither of us had any idea where or when the other was going. The day before he missed his connecting flight to Florida because it arrived late from Heathrow so he had to stay in New York an extra day and leave this morning. How cheeky of Amekhala to arrange it for us. It was my miracle, at last! We hugged and laughed both knowing this was no accident. Out of all airports we both could have been in and in one of the biggest airports in the world I walked right up to him. Ten minutes later it would not have happened. If I were him I would have already been at the gate because his flight was leaving in 45 minutes. He said he always waits to the last minute to get on the plane. I’m the exact opposite. I got there early and wanted to be on my flight first, but because I had plenty of time I didn’t walk to the gate.

We both knew it was special. Not a blade of grass moves without the sanction of the Supreme Lord. We talked for almost an hour. We both knew Amekhala was with us laughing and smiling. I told Vrinny how much his mom had protected me over the last seven years and how since she left she has become my "guardian angel." I know she will always help me. From the beginning of our relationship she has been what I wanted and needed. Vrinny also now understood she will always be there for him as well. We were both so happy and both needed this so much. I still can’t get over walking right into him. That "little" sign gave me so much.

Separation is not the same as lamentation. That one moment will carry me for a long time. I know there will be others. Every moment I make a choice to see Krishna or not see Him. He is always there. Amekhala will also be there with her look of approval, or disapproval. At this moment I am happy. Right now on my flight the seat next to me is empty but I don’t see it that way. I have to learn how to relish separation. That’s the purpose of this human life--to develop love for our Guru and Krishna, and in our separation, to want nothing else except to render devotional service and go back home, back to Godhead. There we will be together with all of Srila Prabhupada’s followers.

While I was taking care of Amekhala many devotees would tell me what a wonderful service I was doing and ask me if I was okay. I could only think of her condition. She was disintegrating before my eyes. She never complained about it and simply accepted it as her karma. She never wanted anyone to feel sorry for her. She said that she felt sorry for everyone else because she was almost finished with her suffering, but others would still have to go through it. That made her sad. Her strength and conviction always amazed me. This never changed throughout her painful ordeal. It was one of her most attractive qualities. She always remained positive in her life despite many very difficult circumstances. She used that experience to try and help others with their own hardships in the most caring way.

On January 20, 2010 she developed septicemia (an infection in the blood). Because of the chemotherapy session her immune system was extremely poor. Her temperature went up to 107 degrees F (42 degrees C). She was in a very blissful state at the time, in and out of consciousness. She kept telling me that the trick was to realize that we are not the doers. She kept emphasizing that Krishna was in control. Once she said, “But I am stubborn.” She said she understood that Krishna loves us because if He didn’t He wouldn’t put so much effort into trying to help us.

At that time she saw Srila Prabhuapda with a dozen beautiful gardenia garlands around his neck, looking very regal. She said she always thought he was disgusted with her, but now she knew he loved her. She was worthy of being loved. Twice she saw Mayaypur dhama. Each time she saw a very young boy she thought was Lord Caitanya. Each time He ran away laughing saying it wasn’t her time yet. Then she saw a little blue boy who also laughed and ran away. She said, “I have relevance! I deserve, only because Krishna loves me.” Then she said, “I am nothing and I don’t want anyone to think I am anything.” Then in her typically positive fashion said, “The cancer is not going to kill us. We are going to kill the cancer. Krishna has more power.”

She ended by saying with pride that even with a temperature of 107 degrees she still recognized everyone around her. At the time, over fifty devotees had rushed over to the house to see her because we thought she was in her final hours. Even in such a physical state, she gave all of her love and a blissful smile to every one of them. She stayed with us for nine more weeks, barely eating or drinking during that time.

Srila Prabhupada exhibited unalloyed love for Krishna. Amekhala exhibited to me her unalloyed love for Srila Prabhupada. She showed me the same undeviating love in our relationship. She wouldn’t settle for anything less for herself. She taught me so much in a short time. As the months passed by I realized she wasn’t my wife. She belonged to Krishna and was Srila Prabhupada’s daughter. I was being offered the opportunity to serve her. As the cancer progressed throughout her body she became weaker and the pain increased dramatically. I had to take care of all her needs. My only focus was to try and relieve her suffering. I was engaged in devotional service. I had no choice. I loved her.

I have been given more mercy than I deserve in this life. I want to learn to be grateful. I don’t want to spend my days filled with lamentation over "my" loss. I want to appreciate all I have been given. I had over seven wonderful years with Amekhala and have had forty years of association with devotees. I know I will be on a roller coaster of emotions for quite a while. However, I am happy knowing Amekhala devi dasi passed her final test and has given me tools to help me pass mine.

A tribute to Amekhala devi dasi by Srutakirti das

It has been two weeks since my wife left this world under the protection of Srila Prabhuapda. I have wanted to write my offering, my homage to her, but I haven’t been able to do it. I haven’t been able to think very clearly. My entire life was turned upside down in a moment. I was so busy taking care of her for the last 18 months I never had time to contemplate on what was happening right in front of my eyes.

Feelings of emptiness embrace me at every moment. Besides her leaving I’ve had to deal with more than a few devotees telling me she has visited them since her departure. Many would be skeptical, some may not. I have always been a skeptic myself. I have never felt mystical experiences, "beings" around me or anything like that. I don’t doubt it could happen, that someone might see her silhouette, hear her speak, or feel her presence. I know that anything is possible. Once, Srila Prabhupada was asked if there were any ghosts around. He answered, “wall to wall.” I even believe she did visit these fortunate devotees but that makes me more upset. What about me, your husband, who has taken care of you and nursed you 24 hours a day. I know I’m dull headed but damn. I have been talking to her and pleading for a dream, a voice or a breeze next to me. Anything! I have been so lonely.

On Tuesday, May 4th I left our home in the UK. I spent the next 3 days at my sister’s home visiting my eighty-seven year old mother. I wanted her to know I was okay and going to survive this trauma. She lost her husband at 30 and had to raise three of us on her own. She remained unmarried and never wavered in her duties since then. She drives to church every morning, still.

This morning at 4:30 a.m. I left my family and drove to JFK airport in New York. When I put my bags in the car I felt like it was a new life in front of me, but had no idea what it was. I was on my own now. I thought at least the time of the day was auspicious. I thought I am being forced to have complete faith in Guru and Krishna. It was a 100 mile drive from my mother’s house. I was taking my next flight to a quiet place to chant and hopefully write. I was going to be staying with devotee friends there for the next few weeks. While driving, every now and then I talked to Amekhala, out loud. This is not my style, but everything has changed. I prayed to her, to please give me some sign she was still with me. I really believed it was possible she could comfort me. I have just been thinking that I don’t deserve it because of my many sinful activities and offenses to devotees in this life.

The flight was at 8:45 a.m. Amekhala and I always left early for the airport, rather than rushing and being in anxiety about not being on time. I dropped off the Hertz one-way rental and asked a few people to help me find my way onto the train that whizzes around to the eight different terminals. I don’t know my way around JFK at all. I know Heathrow Airport in England very well. I checked my bags at Jetblue Airways. With plenty of time I went through security and then stepped onto the moving aisles headed to the main departure area. With my rolling hand luggage I stepped off the moving ramp and walked a few steps. I looked up. There was a large triangular shaped center area with three levels, some cushions and outlets where you can plug in your computer. It was the hub to all 30 gates. I thought that was great. I'll plug in my computer and try to find a wireless signal. I took a few more steps and looked straight into her youngest son’s bright blue eyes. It was Vrinny! We couldn’t believe it. Impossible! It was a real live miracle for both of us. Since the day before I left the UK we hadn’t spoken a word. He was not in the house the morning I left the UK. Neither of us had any idea where or when the other was going. The day before he missed his connecting flight to Florida because it arrived late from Heathrow so he had to stay in New York an extra day and leave this morning. How cheeky of Amekhala to arrange it for us. It was my miracle, at last! We hugged and laughed both knowing this was no accident. Out of all airports we both could have been in and in one of the biggest airports in the world I walked right up to him. Ten minutes later it would not have happened. If I were him I would have already been at the gate because his flight was leaving in 45 minutes. He said he always waits to the last minute to get on the plane. I’m the exact opposite. I got there early and wanted to be on my flight first, but because I had plenty of time I didn’t walk to the gate.

We both knew it was special. Not a blade of grass moves without the sanction of the Supreme Lord. We talked for almost an hour. We both knew Amekhala was with us laughing and smiling. I told Vrinny how much his mom had protected me over the last seven years and how since she left she has become my "guardian angel." I know she will always help me. From the beginning of our relationship she has been what I wanted and needed. Vrinny also now understood she will always be there for him as well. We were both so happy and both needed this so much. I still can’t get over walking right into him. That "little" sign gave me so much.

Separation is not the same as lamentation. That one moment will carry me for a long time. I know there will be others. Every moment I make a choice to see Krishna or not see Him. He is always there. Amekhala will also be there with her look of approval, or disapproval. At this moment I am happy. Right now on my flight the seat next to me is empty but I don’t see it that way. I have to learn how to relish separation. That’s the purpose of this human life--to develop love for our Guru and Krishna, and in our separation, to want nothing else except to render devotional service and go back home, back to Godhead. There we will be together with all of Srila Prabhupada’s followers.

While I was taking care of Amekhala many devotees would tell me what a wonderful service I was doing and ask me if I was okay. I could only think of her condition. She was disintegrating before my eyes. She never complained about it and simply accepted it as her karma. She never wanted anyone to feel sorry for her. She said that she felt sorry for everyone else because she was almost finished with her suffering, but others would still have to go through it. That made her sad. Her strength and conviction always amazed me. This never changed throughout her painful ordeal. It was one of her most attractive qualities. She always remained positive in her life despite many very difficult circumstances. She used that experience to try and help others with their own hardships in the most caring way.

On January 20, 2010 she developed septicemia (an infection in the blood). Because of the chemotherapy session her immune system was extremely poor. Her temperature went up to 107 degrees F (42 degrees C). She was in a very blissful state at the time, in and out of consciousness. She kept telling me that the trick was to realize that we are not the doers. She kept emphasizing that Krishna was in control. Once she said, “But I am stubborn.” She said she understood that Krishna loves us because if He didn’t He wouldn’t put so much effort into trying to help us.

At that time she saw Srila Prabhuapda with a dozen beautiful gardenia garlands around his neck, looking very regal. She said she always thought he was disgusted with her, but now she knew he loved her. She was worthy of being loved. Twice she saw Mayaypur dhama. Each time she saw a very young boy she thought was Lord Caitanya. Each time He ran away laughing saying it wasn’t her time yet. Then she saw a little blue boy who also laughed and ran away. She said, “I have relevance! I deserve, only because Krishna loves me.” Then she said, “I am nothing and I don’t want anyone to think I am anything.” Then in her typically positive fashion said, “The cancer is not going to kill us. We are going to kill the cancer. Krishna has more power.”

She ended by saying with pride that even with a temperature of 107 degrees she still recognized everyone around her. At the time, over fifty devotees had rushed over to the house to see her because we thought she was in her final hours. Even in such a physical state, she gave all of her love and a blissful smile to every one of them. She stayed with us for nine more weeks, barely eating or drinking during that time.

Srila Prabhupada exhibited unalloyed love for Krishna. Amekhala exhibited to me her unalloyed love for Srila Prabhupada. She showed me the same undeviating love in our relationship. She wouldn’t settle for anything less for herself. She taught me so much in a short time. As the months passed by I realized she wasn’t my wife. She belonged to Krishna and was Srila Prabhupada’s daughter. I was being offered the opportunity to serve her. As the cancer progressed throughout her body she became weaker and the pain increased dramatically. I had to take care of all her needs. My only focus was to try and relieve her suffering. I was engaged in devotional service. I had no choice. I loved her.

I have been given more mercy than I deserve in this life. I want to learn to be grateful. I don’t want to spend my days filled with lamentation over "my" loss. I want to appreciate all I have been given. I had over seven wonderful years with Amekhala and have had forty years of association with devotees. I know I will be on a roller coaster of emotions for quite a while. However, I am happy knowing Amekhala devi dasi passed her final test and has given me tools to help me pass mine.

All glories to Srila Prabhupada! All glories to Amekhala who freely gave her loving care to so many devotees for forty years. Her example will be appreciated by so many for the rest of their lives. I am one of them.

Your servant,

Srutakirti das

data.blurb: As many of you have probably noticed, this past week I fell behind with my blogs. I had four sessions at the clinic and with the therapist. I had to write and then revise my Vyasa Puja offering to Srila Prabhupada for publishing in "both" of this year's Vyasa Puja books.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
As many of you have probably noticed, this past week I fell behind with my blogs. I had four sessions at the clinic and with the therapist. I had to write and then revise my Vyasa Puja offering to Srila Prabhupada for publishing in "both" of this year's Vyasa Puja books. Beginning this year there will be two Vyasa Puja books offered to Srila Prabhupada— the usual publication from ISKCON leaders and projects, and the new book which will publish offerings from any disciple of Srila Prabhupada.

I also spent no less than 3-4 hours a day this past week on the phone, mainly with godbrothers who had matters they wished to discuss with me, but also with many other devotees, most of whom are leaders in responsible positions.

I am also currently working on a new book, "Lectures from a Disciple," Volume 3. And I am working with the Gauranga Press editors, English division, making a major revision of "Lectures from a Disciple," Volume 1. A lot of material which needs to be proofread by me for that revision came to me during this past week. I will still need to give that even more immediate attention during the upcoming week.

I also did some work on reviving the Russian division of Gauranga Press, preparing ground for reprinting all books published in Russian so that they can be available in the CIS countries as well as through mailorder online. And once the editing of "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume 3 is finished and is proofread, work will also begin with the translation and prepress work for that new publication in Russian.

Also during this past week, I was in regular contact with devotees in the United States helping them set up a mailorder department, mainly for English publications. But until a mailorder department for Russian books can be set up in the CIS, the U.S. mailorder department will also be handling Russian publications and will ship them internationally at the lowest possible cost per book.

Additionally, this past week I was dealing with matters related to the development of another website, www.niranjanaswami.com. The main purpose of this new site is to make Gauranga Press publications available to those who are not registered users of http://nrs.iskconboston.org. It will also serve as a referral site for those who may be looking for this site but cannot find it because it's password protected and set up only for registered users. There will also be access on that site to a small amount of material which is not available on this site. The site is already in both English and Russian, though the Russian mailorder section will not be set up until more Russian books are available.

This other site was established a few years ago by Hrsikesa dasa, a devotee in the New York area, before Gangambupada Prabhu set up http://nrs.iskconboston.org. He intended to host podcasts of mine and other material. But because http://nrs.iskconboston.org started to become more popular, the site became inactive and was eventually even closed down by the company which hosted it. Working together with Hrsikesa dasa and other devotees in Kiev over the past week, we managed to get something set up once again so that it can be used in the above-mentioned ways.

It is not at all my intention to suggest any shift of material from this site to the new site. The new site will, for the most part, be a static site for displaying books and CD's as they become available for online ordering. Still, I wanted to make devotees aware of the existence of this new site, mainly so that you will not be confused if you should land there and begin wondering what the site will be used for. This site, http://nrs.iskconboston.org, will continue hosting everything that it has hosted up until now, and hopefully, including my blogs, as I start writing them once again.

Now that May has arrived, I'm sure that many of you must be wondering when the next health update will appear. I've been wondering the same myself. Hopefully, I should be able to post something about that soon.

Hare Krsna

Please accept my humble obeisances _/\ò_. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

Srutakirti prabhu has requested me to post the following appreciation of his recently departed wife Smt. Amekhala dasi written by Sriman Patita Pavan prabhu, which I am very happy to do. I am also attaching a photo provided by Srutakirti prabhu.

Your humble servant,
Hari-sauri dasa

Amekhala Dasi Goes Back to Godhead
by Patita Pavana das Adhikary

Our longtime friend and Godsister Amekhala Dasi left this world on 23 April 2010 in London apparently from the effects of cancer. She was surrounded by her devotee friends including her husband Shrutakirti das. Hundreds of devotees had visited her in her last days. From the language of astrology we can see just how special she was to Lord Krishna.

In January, she asked Srutakirti to write to us to decide whether the painful treatments modern medicine prescribes would be worthwhile. Abhaya Mudra Dasi and I looked at the stars and advised her not to bother but to only shelter in Krishna’s name. Thinking of her a few days back, I wrote her a letter, and twelve hours after I sent it, she left her body. Since we are getting older now, the end is drawing near for the first generation of the Hare Krishna Movement as the next able generation has accepted this mantle of responsibility. I would like to share our letter with the devotees.

My dear Amekhala devi dasi,

Please accept my humble obeisances. I am so happy at your wonderful good fortune. By Srila Prabhupada's divine mercy, Lord Sri Krishna, the Supreme Personality of Godhead is inviting you Back to Home, Back to Godhead during His favorite month, Purushottama. The Sun is in Uttarayana as well.

No one can know you but your spiritual master and Shri Kishna. Others will go their own way, only the Guru Maharaja knows the heart of the disciple. Now your material sojourn is behind you and you are on your way to join Krishna in Vrindavana.

So now, please just forget about everything here because you are going there too. Have no fear and no attachment for this world. Remember us only as your eternal friends in the Spiritual Sky and we will all join you there very soon, soon enough. Please let go of all material attachment. We are all spirit souls, parts and parcels of Lord Shri Krishna, His eternal servants sheltered by the divine power of His Holy Names.

You are a kind, compassionate and good person at heart and Shri Krishna knows your heart. Now please make up your mind only to go to Him, through the divine loving grace of Shrila Prabhupada.

See you soon enough, sister,
Patita Pavana das

After Amekhala departed, Srutakirti Prabhu wrote me with the details, and a portion of Srutakirti’s letter is given hereunder:

Dear Patita Pavana Prabhu,

Please accept my humble obeisances.i

She has had hundreds of devotees pass through the hospice in the last few days she was there.

Of course she wanted that her leaving in the UK be a reason for everyone to come to the Manor to glorify Srila Prabhupada, a way to bring the community together. Something that was very important to her.

She took her last breath at 5:56 a.m. It was without any strain. If you blinked you would have missed it.

There was no gasping for a last breath and no pushing from her last breath. It was simple, profound and ladylike. We were happy that Radhanatha Maharaja made it here in time to visit her and speak about her in class on Friday evening.

With affection your servant and friend,

Srutakirti das

Now let us have a look at the stars under which Amekhala left our limited vision. As stated, she departed during the Uttarayana or “northern path of the Sun”. Bhishma, the great warrior and mahajana, had to rest on a painful bed of arrows for over a month in order to leave during Uttarayana. Amekhala met all criteria for liberation--as per Krishna’s instructions to Arjuna--and then much, much more. Not only was the Moon in the auspicious shukla-paksha phase, or waxing fortnight, but Amekhala left on the auspicious dashami day preceding holy Padmini Ekadashi, the day of Lord Hari.

As noted above, the month, still running, is the rare intercalary Purushottama-masa, Lord Vishnu’s favorite which occurs once in three years. She left this world exactly at the juncture between Brahma muhurta and Sunrise with the Sun in his northern progress, or daytime of the demi-gods.

In Vedic astrology, the Sun is called the atmakaraka, or “planet of the soul”. Lord Surya Narayana, who appeared in the lagna or “house of self” in the chart or kundali of her disappearance, is only one degree from the highest point of exaltation, which is 10º Aries, Mesha rashi.

The phenomenon of the Sun occupying at or near his point of extreme elevation at sunrise--atmakaraka in the atmastan--occurs only for a few hours in a solar year. Who but the self-realized could depart under such conditions?

The bright kundali is decorated with several other telling details, such as Budha in ucchamsa in conjunction with the Sun, but are too technical for a general explanation.

Who can describe the glories of leaving this Earth under such rare stars and exalted muhurta? Even great yogis are denied leaving this world during such conditions. The final statement is the most profound. Only the rarest of souls would be allowed to leave at such a moment because such a fortunate mahatma is certainly granted the eternal shelter of Shri Krishna.

As Shrutakirti Prabhu pointed out, Amekhala wanted her departure to be an example for us, her Godbrothers and -sisters languishing behind in the world of birth and death. In that our Godsister has succeeded beyond the powers of all imagination.

Amekhala’s life and transition to the next world forces us to ask ourselves about the spiritual identities of those who follow Shrila Prabhupada. Prabhupada often said that his disciples--his “nice boys and girls”--are “not ordinary mahatmas, but they are sudurlabha mahatmas”. In fact, Prabhupada, who appeared to the average man as a mere householder-turned-Indian-Swami, was not even an ordinary Jagat Guru. Shrila Prabhupada was the Acharya of World Acharyas. The closer we disciples and ISKCON members can co-operate with one another, the sooner history will verify his position as a shaktyavesh avatara and personal direct associate of Lord Chaitanya’s sankirtan.

Therefore it follows that understanding the most exalted position of our spiritual master means understanding the position of those who serve His Divine Grace with every breath, even their last one. For me, this is the parting message of our beloved and rare Godsister, Shrimati Amhekala devi dasi, beloved daughter of His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada.

Only the rarest of souls would be allowed to leave at such a moment because such a fortunate mahatma is certainly granted the eternal shelter of Shri Krishna.

As Shrutakirti Prabhu pointed out, Amekhala wanted her departure to be an example for us, her Godbrothers and -sisters languishing behind in the world of birth and death. In that our Godsister has succeeded beyond the powers of all imagination.

Amekhala’s life and transition to the next world forces us to ask ourselves about the spiritual identities of those who follow Shrila Prabhupada. Prabhupada often said that his disciples--his “nice boys and girls”--are “not ordinary mahatmas, but they are sudurlabha mahatmas”. In fact, Prabhupada, who appeared to the average man as a mere householder-turned-Indian-Swami, was not even an ordinary Jagat Guru. Shrila Prabhupada was the Acharya of World Acharyas. The closer we disciples and ISKCON members can co-operate with one another, the sooner history will verify his position as a shaktyavesh avatara and personal direct associate of Lord Chaitanya’s sankirtan.

Therefore it follows that understanding the most exalted position of our spiritual master means understanding the position of those who serve His Divine Grace with every breath, even their last one. For me, this is the parting message of our beloved and rare Godsister, Shrimati Amhekala devi dasi, beloved daughter of His Divine Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada.
