data.title: Some Memories from Preaching in Boston
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
In the past week I've narrated, more than once, an interesting recollection to devotees here in Budapest about a college preaching engagement I did in the early 1980's when I was Temple President in Boston. Since this, and other similar memories have been churning in my mind these past couple of days, I thought I would share this story here in my blog. For me, this experience has served as a thoughtful reminder that even in an apparent unfavorable situation, if we have faith and conviction about what we are doing, Krsna can reverse that situation into something favorable.

During the years 1979 – 1983, I was the Temple President of Boston. During the first year or two of my tenure, I was a bit more embroiled in management than I would have preferred, especially when I had to deal with the sale of the five-story building next to our temple building on Commonwealth Avenue, which happened to be one of the most up-and-coming and prestigious areas in all of the United States. On top of that, I also had to deal with the purchase and management of another property for householder residency 30 miles outside of the city, a 28-room, residential building on a large plot of land, and which was an annex to the Boston temple.

After these matters were settled and once I was more stably situated in my service, I began looking for outside preaching opportunities which would nicely complement my service as President. I did not want to be managing in the temple all day, and Boston was (and still is) a literal treasure house of preaching opportunities in the more than one hundred colleges and universities spread out through the entire metropolitan area of Boston. From September to May of each year, even back in those days, there were at least 250,000 college students in Boston at any given time.

Srila Prabhupada personally preached in several of Boston's internationally renowned universities such as Harvard University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Brandeis University, and so many others. He also spoke about, and many times wrote about, including in letters to my former Temple President, Trai Prabhu, the importance of preaching in the colleges and universities in Boston. Here is one of many samples of Srila Prabhupada's interest in Boston's universities in a letter dated August 19, 1968, to Sacisuta dasa:

"The Boston center is also very important, because there are many students and Boston is educational center, especially there are so many universities so if you concentrate your energy and can organize the student community to understand our philosophy it will be a great service."

Since our temple is located right in the heart of Boston, it was not uncommon to receive phone calls and letters from professors requesting if a speaker from the temple could come and give a presentation about Krsna consciousness to their students. This means that even without much extra effort, there were occasional classroom engagements, maybe one or even two a week, towards the end of each semester, which I could do. It was also even more common to receive an entire class of students, along with their teacher, who would come to the temple on a prearranged day, to hear an introductory talk on Krsna consciousness, to see the arati ceremony, and to sample a little prasadam.

However, since I was looking for more outside preaching engagements and since the opportunity to lecture to students was becoming more of my focus, we decided to print up a brochure, listing several available speakers on various religious, philosophical, and social topics. We called ourselves the "ISKCON Speakers Guild", and we mailed out the brochures, with a cover letter, to the heads of the philosophy, sociology, religious, anthropology, and similar departments in many of the major universities throughout Boston, offering our services to lecture to their students on any one or more of these topics.

One day the temple received a phone call from a student at "Boston State Teacher's College," who told us that she was making a presentation about us in her "Health Education" class and that her professor gave her permission to invite me to observe her presentation and to be there to answer questions about our philosophy and lifestyle. She gave me the time and place to meet her at the college and I agreed to come, telling her what she could expect from my presentation.

Generally, whenever I would give a classroom presentation, I would bring at least one, but usually a few devotees with me. I would begin the presentation with a short explanation about chanting, we would have a short kirtan, and I would then give my introductory presentation about Krsna consciousness. We would always bring some prasadam to distribute to the students after the presentation. Usually the prasadam would be distributed by the devotees who accompanied me while I continued taking questions from the students after the presentation. So I explained all of this to this student and she seemed satisfied with what we could offer.

On the scheduled day of the engagement, my godbrother, Mukta Vandya dasa, and I prepared all of the paraphernalia and prasadam for our usual presentation, and we then proceeded to the college—not far from the temple— to meet the student in front of the building at the prearranged time. When we arrived, the student was there waiting and she told us that everyone was upstairs in the classroom, including her professor, and they were all waiting for us. We proceeded up the stairs to the classroom, expecting the usual-- a warm welcome, an introduction to the students of who we were and why we were there, and then a request by the professor to his/her students to listen attentively to our presentation since it was typically relevant to the course they were taking.

However, upon entering the classroom, I was surprised to see that at the front of the class was a low platform, upon which stood a row of about four or five desks with four students sitting behind them. Something else which was a little unusual, was that the professor, although present at the back of the class when we walked in, never acknowledged our presence. Mukta Vandya Prabhu and I were escorted to the front row of the class where we were given seats and we were told that the students would be speaking first and then I could speak later. The student who met us then proceeded to sit behind one of the desks on the platform, the professor told them to begin, and then the first student began giving his presentation.

Without even acknowledging our presence, the first student began by summarizing the theme of his talk— "The Dangers of Cults"— and then proceeded to give a detailed account from his research, including as much statistics as he could find, on the many different cults which were in existence in the United States at that time. After he spoke, each subsequent speaker from the five-member panel (among them, our host) covered a different aspect about the dangers of cults, including methods of recruitment, indoctrination, rituals, historical background of each cult, the typical behavior of a brainwashed member, and specifically why cults were so dangerous in mainstream America at that time. Needless to say, to sit and listen to all of this was a little bit intimidating. Mukta Vandya Prabhu and I would exchange glances from time to time, reading each others' mind, and wondering if we should tolerate all of this or just leave. But assuming that I was going to be given a chance to speak at the end of their presentation, I tolerated it until the end.

Finally, I was introduced to the class, and I was told that the next phase of their presentation would be to allow the students to ask me questions related to the findings of the five-member panel. I was then invited to stand in front of the class to field questions from the students. Of course, by then I had fully realized that we had been tricked, that I was not invited to give a presentation, but rather I had been invited as a "cult specimen" to dissect in front of the classroom after hearing how dangerous I was both to society and to all of them. But I already knew what I was going to speak about, since I had plenty of time to mentally prepare my talk while the panel members were delivering their findings.

Accepting the invitation, I immediately stood up and began speaking, "Before we can take any questions on today's topic, first I must explain, according to the evidence I have from academic circles, what is the difference between a cult and a religion!" No sooner had these words come out of my mouth, immediately the professor, who all of this time had been sitting in the back of the class, briskly stood up and protested, "We have not invited you here for your presentation! You are here to answer the students' questions and nothing else. Now please take the first question."

I didn't listen to him. I continued speaking, trying as much as possible to reason to the intelligence of the students that they were being misled by not having been given any clear explanation, neither within the context of the previous presentation, nor within the context of their classroom studies (slightly alluding to the deviant tutelage of their professor), of what is the difference between a cult and a religion. The professor continued to object to my speaking. By this time he was raising his voice and was even turning a little bit red in the face, angered by my resistance to submit to his will. I simply continued my presentation. I specifically remember praying to Srila Prabhupada to give me the words to make these people hear his pure message.

By this time the professor seemed ready to have me physically removed from the front of the class, but all of a sudden one student sitting on the left side of the class, stood up, turned to the back of the classroom, pounded her hand on the desk, and loudly, but respectfully, said to her teacher, "I object to the way you are treating this gentleman! Isn't there some way he can be allowed to continue to speak?" I stopped and waited for his response. Nothing. Instead, however, another student stood up, faced the professor, and he also objected to the way I was being treated. Without saying another word, within the next 30 seconds, at least ten other students were out of their seats, some even raising their voices in protest, and again and again I was hearing, "Let him speak! Since this, and other similar memories have been churning in my mind these past couple of days, I thought I would share this story here in my blog. For me, this experience has served as a thoughtful reminder that even in an apparent unfavorable situation, if we have faith and conviction about what we are doing, Krsna can reverse that situation into something favorable.

During the years 1979 – 1983, I was the Temple President of Boston. During the first year or two of my tenure, I was a bit more embroiled in management than I would have preferred, especially when I had to deal with the sale of the five-story building next to our temple building on Commonwealth Avenue, which happened to be one of the most up-and-coming and prestigious areas in all of the United States. On top of that, I also had to deal with the purchase and management of another property for householder residency 30 miles outside of the city, a 28-room, residential building on a large plot of land, and which was an annex to the Boston temple.

After these matters were settled and once I was more stably situated in my service, I began looking for outside preaching opportunities which would nicely complement my service as President. I did not want to be managing in the temple all day, and Boston was (and still is) a literal treasure house of preaching opportunities in the more than one hundred colleges and universities spread out through the entire metropolitan area of Boston. "The Boston center is also very important, because there are many students and Boston is educational center, especially there are so many universities so if you concentrate your energy and can organize the student community to understand our philosophy it will be a great service."

data.title: Good Ol' Days
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
My godbrother, Purusartha dasa, sent me this photo some time ago by email with the subject title, "Good ol' days." I'm trying to remember what year this photo was taken but for some reason I can't remember. It was probably some time between the mid-to-late 1980's.

Harinama was always a regular event for the Boston temple. As far back as I can remember, even when I first joined, we used to go out and chant at this same spot on the Boston Common, the biggest park right in the center of downtown Boston. During the spring, summer, and autumn months we would go there for harinama every day of the week.

Thousands of people used to walk by, or at least very near to, this spot every day. Facing us, directly behind the back of Purusartha Prabhu, the devotee who took this photograph, was a large fountain with benches all around it, where, every weekday, especially during the hours of 11:30 AM to 1:30 PM, many local office workers, businessmen and women, would come to sit and take their lunch. Many of the same people would come to that spot every day. Some would even come just to listen to the chanting. We'd often receive words of appreciation from these people for the nice atmosphere our harinama created and for our lovely "music." Purusartha Prabhu always made sure that the instruments were nicely mixed and the sound was first-class. He designed and made the sound system himself.

We also displayed Srila Prabhupada's books on a table nearby. At least one devotee would stand by the table, would distribute prasadam to the passers-by, and would answer everyone's questions. Everyone loved the prasadam. Many people would take books. Some would visit the temple for our evening "dinner program", and some even became full-time devotees who are still actively serving Srila Prabhupada's mission today.

This daily harinama party was also one of Boston's attractions for thousands of tourists who would visit Boston for it's historical attractions. In fact, there used to be a multimedia presentation produced by the city of Boston, which the tourists would pay to go and see, and a picture of our harinama was included in the presentation.

I'm very happy to say that even today, my godbrother Purusartha Prabhu goes out on harinama several days a week on the University of Florida campus in Gainesville, Florida, USA. There, he has also arranged a first-class harinama, similar to the one he arranged in Boston, where hundreds of university students sit right nearby to take sumptuous lunch prasadam every day of the week organized by "Krishna House" in Gainesville (see http://www.krishnalunch.com). After and even during lunch, many of the students sit and chant together with the harinama party.

Param Vijayate Sri-Krsna-Sankirtanam!

Hare Krsna.

Body_raw.value:
Here are three short articles I recently found which lend support to my previous post about "Email vs Letter Writing." Of course, email is not quite the same as "Social Networking." But there are many similarities which can bind one into a network of emailing much the same way as "Social Networking" does.

Everything below are the articles as they were posted. All comments in the articles are those of the authors and not mine.

Article #1

350 million people are suffering from Facebook Addiction Disorder [FAD]
Posted on January 28, 2010


Facebook Addiction Disorder (FAD) is a term introduced by US phychologists for those who are addicted to facebook and their life is really effected by their uncontrolled activities on Facebook. According to US psychologists the number of patients suffering from FAD are increasing.

Not only US but also millions of South Africans may also be at risk as they search for long-lost friends and relatives, share photo albums and stay abreast of gossip.

Lynlee Howard-Payne, a psychology lecturer at the University of the Witwatersrand, said: “While there are no official statistics available regarding South Africans who have been diagnosed as having or being treated for FAD, based on the large number of universities, schools and companies blocking access to Facebook … there could very well be an uncontrolled dependence.”

Howard-Payne added: “Universities, schools and companies are forced to limit accessibility to Facebook because some people seem to be unable to perform other tasks if they have access to this online social network. While Facebook is often a great way of maintaining both social and professional relationships, it seems to take on a destructive force with certain personalities.”

After US psychologists began their probe into FAD, millions of Facebook users – there are an estimated 350 million around the world – have admitted to being addicted.

More than 500 groups for addicts have been created on Facebook, where members joke about their dependence on the site.

Howard-Payne said if addicts chose to join a support group, it should not be on Facebook.

She said: “Addictive use of the Internet is a new phenomenon which many practitioners are unaware of and, subsequently, unprepared to treat. Use of Facebook is often a legitimate way of social networking, so abstinence may not be seen as a practical intervention thus it is recommended that there be moderation and controlled use.”

Article #2

Online Community Strategist

Are your most active members suffering from depression?
(Febrary 2, 2010)

Have you ever wondered how some members of your online community (or any community for that matter) can get so overwhelmingly caught up in online drama with people they hardly know? I know I have. Well, there could be a real, clinical reason behind it, according to a new study, that goes beyond them needing to “get a life.”

Psychologists from Leeds University say they’ve found “striking” evidence that some avid internet users develop compulsive habits in which they replace real-life social interaction with online chat rooms and social networking sites.

The lead author of the study wrote in the the journal of Psychopathology that the study “reinforces the public speculation that over-engaging in websites that serve to replace normal social function might be linked to psychological disorders like depression and addiction.”

WOW, THAT EXPLAINS A LOT.

What the study didn’t glean is which comes first: excessive internet use or depression. In other words… are depressed people drawn to the internet or does the internet cause depression?”

Here is one more interesting quote I just have to share:

“While many of us use the internet to pay bills, shop and send emails, there is a small subset of the population who find it hard to control how much time they spend online, to the point where it interferes with their daily activities.”

This is a really interesting study. Read more about it here in Science Daily, and come back and tell me what you think.Oh, you can also read the complete abstract with methodology and other pertinent information at Psychopathology.

Article #3

Science Daily (Feb. 4, 2010)

People who spend a lot of time browsing the Internet are more likely to show depressive symptoms, according to the first large-scale study of its kind in the West by University of Leeds psychologists.

Researchers found striking evidence that some users have developed a compulsive internet habit, whereby they replace real-life social interaction with online chat rooms and social networking sites. The results suggest that this type of addictive surfing can have a serious impact on mental health.

Lead author Dr Catriona Morrison, from the University of Leeds, said: "The internet now plays a huge part in modern life, but its benefits are accompanied by a darker side.

"While many of us use the internet to pay bills, shop and send emails, there is a small subset of the population who find it hard to control how much time they spend online, to the point where it interferes with their daily activities."

These 'internet addicts' spent proportionately more time browsing sexually gratifying websites, online gaming sites and online communities. They also had a higher incidence of moderate to severe depression than non-addicted users.

"Our research indicates that excessive internet use is associated with depression, but what we don't know is which comes first -- are depressed people drawn to the internet or does the internet cause depression?

"What is clear, is that for a small subset of people, excessive use of the internet could be a warning signal for depressive tendencies."

Incidents such as the spate of suicides among teenagers in the Welsh town of Bridgend in 2008 led many to question the extent to which social networking sites can contribute to depressive thoughts in vulnerable teenagers. In the Leeds study, young people were more likely to be internet addicted than middle-aged users, with the average age of the addicted group standing at 21 years.

"This study reinforces the public speculation that over-engaging in websites that serve to replace normal social function might be linked to psychological disorders like depression and addiction," added Dr Morrison. "We now need to consider the wider societal implications of this relationship and establish clearly the effects of excessive internet use on mental health."

This was the first large-scale study of Western young people to consider the relationship between internet addiction and depression. The internet use and depression levels of 1,319 people aged 16-51 were evaluated for the study, and of these, 1.2% were classed as being internet addicted. While small, this is larger than the incidence of gambling in the UK, which stands at 0.6%. The research will be published in the journal Psychopathology on 10th February.

Incidents such as the spate of suicides among teenagers in the Welsh town of Bridgend in 2008 led many to question the extent to which social networking sites can contribute to depressive thoughts in vulnerable teenagers. In the Leeds study, young people were more likely to be internet addicted than middle-aged users, with the average age of the addicted group standing at 21 years.

"This study reinforces the public speculation that over-engaging in websites that serve to replace normal social function might be linked to psychological disorders like depression and addiction," added Dr Morrison. "We now need to consider the wider societal implications of this relationship and establish clearly the effects of excessive internet use on mental health."

This was the first large-scale study of Western young people to consider the relationship between internet addiction and depression. The internet use and depression levels of 1,319 people aged 16-51 were evaluated for the study, and of these, 1.2% were classed as being internet addicted. While small, this is larger than the incidence of gambling in the UK, which stands at 0.6%. The research will be published in the journal Psychopathology on 10th February.

Please bless the Kharkov devotees so that they may now attract more and more local people to Their Lordship's new home. We pray that they everyone who gets Their darshan and hears Their glories from those who intensely desire to distribute Their mercy, will gain full shelter under the shade of Their beautiful lotus feet.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Some comments on an article entitled "Email vs Letter"
data.blurb: The following article is not my own. But the author's sentiments on the topic of email versus paper mail nicely resonate with some of my own thoughts about writing letters and sending them by post.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following article is not my own. But the author's sentiments on the topic of email versus paper mail nicely resonate with some of my own thoughts about writing letters and sending them by post.

In fact, one of the reasons why I haven't written so many blogs lately is because I have been writing quite a few paper letters over the past week to devotees in North America, some of whom I have not communicated with for many years.

Well, actually I'm not exactly following the traditions of the past. There was a time, though it was probably somewhere between 40-50 years ago, when I would sit down with a pen and paper, write a letter, then rewrite the letter without the crossed-out words, fold the letter into an envelope, write the address and return address on the envelope, put a stamp on the envelope, and then finally take it to the closest mailbox to deposit it for the postman.

In fact, ironically, about a month ago I was speaking with my mother. She just recently moved and while she was packing all of her things in preparation for the move, she found an old box of letters I had sent her about 50 years ago. She decided to go through all of them. She told me that she couldn't wait until I could visit her again so that she could show me what I had written to her.

The letters I wrote last week, however, were not hand-written. Of course, neither were they typewritten. They were typed on the computer, but I did not print them out. Instead, I uploaded them to a postal service in the United States which prints out the letters and then gives them to the post office for mailing. Sure, it costs more money than an email, but surprisingly not much more than the cost of the postage stamp itself. It also takes more time before it gets to the recipient. But when I think of the reaction people will hopefully have from receiving a printed letter from me in their mailbox (not a virtual mailbox but the one at their front door), instead of seeing only a pile of junk mail, which is practically all that anyone gets in the mail these days in the United States, it was well worth the extra cost. There's even a picture of Srila Prabhupada which can be seen through the see-through panel of the envelope so that the letter can not be mistaken as junk mail.

Like the author of the following article, it is also my conclusion that I will not be able to get away from email. I know I must continue to respond to email, and I will, though unfortunately it will still have to continue at a very slow pace.

Hare Krsna

Here is the article:

EMAIL VS LETTER WRITING

Dear Mum and Dad, I hope you are both well ... was the way the hand written letters used to start. I was at boarding school at the time and once a week we were given letter writing lessons which included a one hour "practical" when we were required to send at least one letter home.

The letter writing format was formal and the outgoing address always had to be positioned neatly in the top right hand corner of the page with the date set dead central in the middle of the page. The sign off (considering it was to the parents) was also formal and finished yours faithfully.

My parents paid a fortune for the privilege of having a son who could string a sentence together in neat, legible and hand written English. They would go as far as complaining to the headmaster if their weekly "update" letter didn’t arrive promptly each week from their son.

Perhaps I am old fashioned but I do enjoy receiving hand written letters from friends and family, although over the years the amount of these has diminished in number to almost zero, barring Christmas cards and birthday letters, and email appears to be the number one form of communication.

These days I receive email and lots of it. When I take a week off work I am guaranteed to come back to the office to find at least four or five hundred emails (excluding spam) that need my attention and responses. The world has gone mad for it.

On an average day when I return home I will visit my letter box and feel lucky to find anything other than the unwanted junk mail and bills which are the only regularly visitors to said letter box. I can often go a whole week without bothering to check as I know that these days’ people just don’t consider letter writing as an effective form of communication.

So, on returning home having bypassed the letter box and gone through the pleasantries of greeting my wife I will make a cup of coffee, sit in the lounge, open my laptop and spend almost an hour, firstly sifting through unwanted junk email and trying to get through the ever increasing titles of; "Your long lost Nigerian Uncle has left you $10 million we just need your bank details to transfer the funds!!" and then looking through the reams of both wanted and unwanted email, responding to which take up a good portion of my spare time.

Which is better; Letter writing or email?

I have on occasion been misinterpreted via email and dependent upon an individual’s mood at the time of receipt, various different shades of light are cast upon the interpretation of what has been said. I believe this is not so with a hand written letter.

Letter writing in itself used to be an art form, you could sense a person’s personality and mood just by examining how hard they pressed upon the paper or the sweeping of the tails on individual letters. Obviously, letter writing is a time consuming past time and therefore one can understand the need in this busy world in which we live, for a more effective form of communication to be adopted. Letters go missing in the post and can take weeks, even with today’s modern postal services, to reach their destination. But I always get a sense that those who have taken the time to write a letter generally have thought their comments through making it in my mind a more sincere mode of communication.

Alas, these days letter writing appears to be an almost distant memory, except when the season dictates for something more personal. Even last year I noted that many Christmas cards came in a typed format with a prepaid envelope, I therefore fear that even this universal and age long tradition may soon pass us by.

Email started off as a wondrous new innovation, one might almost say it revolutionised modern day communications, but I wonder more and more these days whether the very technology invented to make us more efficient, has in fact made us less efficient due to the ease of pressing the word "SEND" without giving due consideration to a message.

I have earned the unenviable title of being the biggest single hoarder of email within my business with files only reaching back 18 months but extending to almost 30,000 email. The resource to keep on my "stockpile" of communications alone would probably light up a village for a week! Unfortunately, as I keep stating to the I.T. team at my place of work, if I am to be challenged on any decision, I must continue to have the resource to defend my position or in fact challenge others, and this is where the system falls down.

With email today one feels duty bound to read each individual correspondence and quite often obliged to reply. Subjects not on an agenda can overnight become the centre of an all too busy diary due to comments made and communicated half way across the world in an unrelated and misinterpreted email conversation that occurred moments ago. There appears to be no limits to the level of destruction one can cause simply by getting an opinion registered in the correct inbox at an inappropriate time, and they regularly put the proverbial "spanner" in my all too busy works.

The title of this post is email vs letter writing, they each have their use, but I am inclined to say that if the same thought processes associated with traditional letter writing could be applied and enforced upon those let loose with a keyboard and email address then perhaps a reasonable balance could be struck.

Unfortunately, this is highly unlikely to happen and my life and career could not continue to function at the same pace without the benefits of an email system, yet, even with that knowledge, I remain deeply in favour of a return to ink and paper.

data.blurb:
Somebody just sent me the links to the following five videos:

These videos were taken on Radhastami, 1998, in the kitchen of a rented hall in St. Petersburg. There are five short video clips which will play one after the other.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Somebody just sent me the links to the following five videos:

These videos were taken on Radhastami, 1998, in the kitchen of a rented hall in St. Petersburg. There are five short video clips which will play one after the other.

I have very fond memories of this Radhastami. Although the circumstances under which we were forced to cook in this kitchen were not pleasant, nonetheless in the association of these wonderful devotees, somehow we managed to cook a feast for over 300 devotees in a small kitchen with a few electric stove burners.

The main organizer of the feast was His Holiness B.B. Govinda Maharaja. He calculated all the ingredients required, made up the shopping list, organized the kitchen, and made most of the preparations himself. I can't remember how many preparations were prepared in that little kitchen, but I do remember that every one of the preparations tasted like they had been prepared by Srimati Radharani Herself, Krsna had then eaten all of them to His full satisfaction, and the remnants were somehow, by some inconceivable mercy, left for all of the assembled Vaisnavas to honor to their full satisfaction.

I remember that His Holiness Radhanath Maharaja took full responsibility for organizing the preparation of the samosas. He made the samosa filling himself, he also made the dough, and he showed everyone how to roll out the dough, fill the samosas, and how to properly twist and press the edges so that they would not open up while they were cooking in the ghee. He told us stories how he used to make samosas in the early days of New Vrndavana.

As the samosas were being filled, I specifically remember that Radhanath Maharaja was standing by the stove waiting and waiting for the ghee to get hot enough so that he could begin deep-frying the samosas. It was a very primitive electric stove and the pot full of ghee was so huge we all began to think that the ghee would never get hot enough to prepare the samosas. Every once in awhile Radhanath Maharaja would drop a little piece of dough into the ghee to see if it would cook. But every time he tried, the dough would just drop down to the bottom of the pot.

After waiting a long time, all four of us, Govinda Maharaja, Radhanath Maharaja, Bhakti Vijnana Goswami Maharaja [then Vaidyanath dasa] and myself, stood around the pot with our arms around each other and began loudly chanting "tapta-kancana-gaurangi, radhe vrndavanesvari/ vrsabhanu-sute devi, pranamami hari-priye," over and over again. We desperately wanted to offer samosas for Radharani's pleasure and knew of no other way to do so other than to pray for Her mercy to allow us to prepare them for Her pleasure. Within minutes after completing our prayers, Radhanath Maharaja again dropped a piece of dough into the ghee. It stayed on the surface and quickly became cooked. He then tried a full samosa. As we all stood around the pot and watched the samosa drop deep down into the ghee, we held our breaths. We then watched it slowly rise to the surface, and then gradually turn brown while Radhanath Maharaja carefully nursed it turning it over and over. Finally it was cooked!

But there were hundreds of samosas to cook! Maharaja decided to throw a full batch of samosas into the ghee, and as we all looked on in amazement, every single one of the samosas gradually rose to the surface and gradually became cooked. It was a miracle which astonished everyone present. It was inconceivable how such a huge pot of ghee could become hot enough to cook all of those samosas on such an inadequate burner. But from that moment on, every samosa got cooked.

I also remember cooking a very large pot of halavah—probably the largest pot of halavah I ever cooked. I used to regularly cook halavah for the Sunday Feasts in Boston back in the early 1970's, so that was one preparation I felt confident enough to make. But when it came time to melt down the butter so that the grains could be cooked, I was shocked to see how many kilos of butter Govinda Maharaja threw into the pot for me to cook all the grains in. It was probably almost twice the amount of butter that I was accustomed to using. Still, he was the master chef and I was simply there to assist him. Following his request I stood and cooked the grains for a very long time, carefully stirring them so that not a single grain would get burned. But there was so much butter in there that the grains almost seemed like they were all effortlessly swimming around in the butter themselves without me having to worry too much about them. Meanwhile, I prepared another huge pot of water with sugar along with the other ingredients to be cooked within the halavah. After quite some time, the grains were added to the boiling water, and after a lot of stirring, and a little help from Govinda Maharaja, every grain looked perfect. I honestly think it was the best halavah I ever made in my life.

For some reason I cannot remember what preparation Bhakti Vijnana Goswami cooked, but I do remember that he was there in the kitchen cooking along with us the whole time.

After Radhanath Maharaja, Bhakti Vijnana Maharaja and I finished our assignments, Govinda Maharaja suggested that we go up to the hall and start a kirtan while he worked on the finishing touches of the feast. We had a wonderful kirtan, Govinda Maharaja then appeared and then we all gave talks on Srimati Radharani. To be honest, I was a little reluctant to speak about Radharani in presence of such exalted Vaisnavas. But neither Radhanath Maharaja nor Govinda Maharaja were going to allow me to not speak. So I also gave a talk after they both spoke. We then had an arati, kirtan and then we all sat down for the most amazing feast I ever tasted.

Radharani ki jaya! Maharani ki jaya!

Hare Krsna.

data.title: We are Servant of the Servant
data.blurb: Recently I acquired a device which allows me to lie down on my back to read, rather than sitting in a chair.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Recently I acquired a device which allows me to lie down on my back to read, rather than sitting in a chair. The result is that I'm getting an opportunity to read transcriptions of many lectures which previously could only be read from the computer (something I still cannot do for so long) or, in some cases, from a book too difficult to read from while lying down.

Last week I read all the lectures which were given during the festival in Mayapura. After reading those lectures, I felt as though I was given an opportunity to be in Mayapura in the association of so many GBC godbrothers with whom I've not been able to associate now for quite a few years. Some of the lectures were very inspiring, especially those describing the reasons for Lord Caitanya's sannyasa.

These things will be clearly exhibited.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: A Report from Vraja Kumara dasa on Grahila Prabhu's Passing
data.blurb: Yesterday evening we went to Grahila Prabhu's apartment to chant kirtan for about 1-1.5 hours.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Yesterday evening we went to Grahila Prabhu's apartment to chant kirtan for about 1-1.5 hours. Grahila Prabhu's condition was much worse than the day before. We followed your request to stay with him through the night and have a kirtan.

Despite the fact that his condition was declining, Grahila Prabhu was smiling a lot and his mind was very clear and sharp.

At 8 pm Bhakti Brhat Bhagavata Maharaja came and he discussed with Grahila Prabhu some of Krishna's pastimes. At the end when Maharaja was speaking about Madhumangala, Grahila Prabhu was laughing a lot. Maharaja requested for Grahila Prabhu to call him any time if Grahila Prabhu would start to feel worse.

After Maharaja left we continued the kirtan. I asked Grahila Prabhu what he would prefer to listen to, Srila Prabhupada's recordings or kirtan.

He smiled and said that it is difficult for him to choose because he likes both. So we continued our kirtan.

Guru Seva went to take some rest, but I was concerned that she will not be able to get any sleep because of the kirtan in the apartment. She said that she is absolutely happy when kirtan is going on and will not have any problems to take proper rest.

Grahila Prabhu could not sleep for the last few days. Last night was no different. I could see that he was trying to absorb his mind on chanting.

Around 1.30 AM, when other devotees came to replace those who were chanting, I went into Grahila Prabhu's room and noticed that he was breathing more often. He told me that he cannot control his breathing and cannot relax. Also he told me that he was feeling that Srila Prabhupada would come very soon. I went and woke up Guru Seva and at the same time we called Bhakti Brhat Bhagavata Maharaj.

It was obvious that Grahila Prabhu was going to be departing soon. Sometimes he would feel a lot of heat inside the body and sometimes he was feeling cold. Also he started to feel more pain. But despite this, he was keeping his mind concentrated on kirtan and he was trying to chant. At one moment he requested Guru Seva to come closer and he started to give her instructions in spiritual life. I did not hear everything but two things were clearly said by him. He said that she should continue the process (devotional service) and chanting.

At 3 AM, Bhakti Brhat Bhagavata Maharaja came and started to arrange everything in a very nice and expert way, preparing the whole atmosphere for Grahila Prabhu's departure. He requested all the devotees to go into Grahila Prabhu's room and then started to chant very softly and slowly (without harmonium and mridanga, only karatals) so that Grahila Prabhu could follow. It was an amazing kirtan. The melody was very simple but I could feel that this melody easily invoked in my mind memories of different places in Mayapura and Vrindavana.

After some time he requested Trivikrama to lead the kirtan and he moved closer to Grahila Prabhu and took his hand. He started to talk to him directing his consciousness on remembrance about Srila Prabhupada, Gauranga Mahaprabhu and Radha-Madhava. Although Grahila Prabhu practically could not talk, suddenly he started loudly chanting together with us, sometimes folding his hands in pranam and sometimes raising them up. Maharaj asked Grahila Prabhu few times if he is ready to go and his answer was, "Yes".

It was the most amazing thing. Despite all the pain and troubles which he was experiencing from his body his mind was like an ice breaker ship which despite all the obstacles, moves in right direction. Grahila Prabhu was like a real warrior who did not want to retreat despite all injuries.

At 4 AM, Jananivas Prabhu came and warmly embraced Grahila Prabhu. After mangala-arati more devotees started to come and join the kirtan. We were tired after chanting for a while and decided to go to take some rest for couple hours. Other devotees started to lead the kirtan. Approximately at 7.30 am Grahila Prabhu started breathing slowly and slowly. At one moment he took Guru Seva's hand and looking at Sri Sri Radha-Madhava's photo left the body very peacefully.

Guru Seva was crying a bit at the time when Grahila Prabhu passed away but at the same time she was very happy that he left the body in a such wonderful way at auspicious day and time [Ekadasi].

After that I did not see any sorrow in her eyes. She was very happy for Grahila Prabhu how he gloriously ended his life.

Cremation took place at 3 PM on the banks of the Ganges. Many devotees came to say goodbye to Grahila Prabhu who showed by his own example how one should pass his last exam and achieve highest destination.

Your humble servant,
Vraja Kumara dasa

data.title: The Passing of Grahila Prabhu
data.blurb: This morning at 7:47 AM in Mayapur, a very wonderful devotee and dear godbrother, Grahila Prabhu, departed this world to continue his service to Srila Prabhupada wherever Prabhupada wants Grahila to assist him. Of this I have absolutely no doubt.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This morning at 7:47 AM in Mayapur, a very wonderful devotee and dear godbrother, Grahila Prabhu, departed this world to continue his service to Srila Prabhupada wherever Prabhupada wants Grahila to assist him. Of this I have absolutely no doubt.

Yesterday, in a phone conversation with Grahila Prabhu, I was amazed to hear how joyful, satisfied, and Krsna conscious he was, just hours before his departure from this world. During my conversation with him, I mentioned that there was no need to speak about anything in the past other than the fact that he was so fortunate to have come in contact with Srila Prabhupada in this life. When I told him that now was the time to think only about the future, and the future opportunities for service which Grahila Prabhu would be given as a result of Srila Prabhupada's blessings, it immediately became clear to me that he was already completely fixed in that mindset. I sensed that there was no fear in his heart at all.

Grahila Prabhu then went on to tell me that he could not possibly describe how fortunate he was in all respects. He said that his constant meditation and prayer to Srila Prabhupada and Krsna was that They would engage him in Their service eternally. He spoke in such a humble, but confident way, that I felt uplifted and confident myself that this special soul was being protected from all fear of death because of his firm faith in Srila Prabhupada.

Continuing in a very humble mood, Grahila Prabhu then went on to confess that he couldn't understand how such a sinful person as he was being given the opportunity to leave this world to go back to Godhead while somebody like me had to stay here. Naturally, I couldn't tolerate it that he described himself as being sinful, and had to immediately respond that even if there were sins committed before that because he was offering himself completely in service to Srila Prabhupada and Krsna with body, mind, and words, that there could not possibly be any trace of sin left in him. I told him that he was not sinful, but sinless. He joyfully accepted defeat.

We spoke for some time longer, but mainly Grahila Prabhu did most of the talking, thanking me for my support and expressing his preparedness for his next journey. I told him that I would call him again today, but that if Krsna arranged it otherwise, I would simply hanker for his association again in the future.

This morning I received the following notice from Vraja Kumara dasa:

"Today at 7.47 am Grahila Prabhu left his body. From yesterday evening we stayed with him through the night chanting kirtan and it was extremely glorious departure. He was in a very good spirit and consciousness."

I wrote back: "I was just speaking with Sivarama Maharaja yesterday. He was telling me how privileged he felt to spend time with Grahila when he was in Mayapur."

Vraja Kumara dasa's reply was:

"It was a good lesson for all of us how one should leave the body remembering Krishna and Srila Prabhupada. His body was creating so many inconveniences for him but he made it through and was able to chant and remember about Krishna like a warrior."

Grahila Prabhu ki jaya!!!

Hare Krsna.

data.title: "This Much You Have to Do"
data.blurb: The other day I was reading the following quote from a talk Srila Prabhupada gave in 1969. While answering a letter today, I thought of this quote because it was relevant to the topic being discussed in the letter.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The other day I was reading the following quote from a talk Srila Prabhupada gave in 1969. While answering a letter today, I thought of this quote because it was relevant to the topic being discussed in the letter. Since it's relevant to all of us, I decided I would share the quote with all of you too. This quote is a classic Srila Prabhupada quote:

"So our whole program is that Krsna is very kind, always kind upon us, but we have to become little willing to take Krsna's favor. That... What is the example? My Guru Maharaja used to give a very nice example. I remember. Just like here is a well. Somebody has fallen down; he's crying, "Please get me out! Get me out! Get me out!" Now, if somebody drops a, a, I mean to, tight, strong rope and asks him, "All right, you catch this rope tightly. I'll get you out," and if he says, "No, that I cannot do," then how he'll be saved? That much endeavor he must have, to catch the rope. Then he'll be lifted immediately. Similarly, Krsna says that sarva-dharman parityajya mam ekam saranam vraja [Bg. 18.66]. So we have to do that. Simply to surrender unto... Then everything is there. That is the only. Because... Now the rope is there. Now we have to capture. Now, if you don't use your independence to catch it, then how can you expect to be lifted? That much you have to do. Because you have got... You are living. You are not a dead stone. You have got the independence. Therefore you have to capture, and Krsna will do everything. Then Krsna will do everything. Simply you have to capture, that "Krsna, from this day I am Yours. Whatever You like, You do." (Srimad-Bhagavatam 1.5.18 -- New Vrindaban, June 22, 1969)

Hare Krsna

data.title: Devotees Get Their Fulfillment From a Place Beyond Their Day-to-day Social Dealings
data.blurb: Because I have not posted any policies about questions and answers on this site, I will respond to an inquiry about my previous blog here in this blog. But, in principle, I have no immediate plans for using this site as a forum for regular questions and answers.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Because I have not posted any policies about questions and answers on this site, I will respond to an inquiry about my previous blog here in this blog. But, in principle, I have no immediate plans for using this site as a forum for regular questions and answers.

Moreover, I am still very limited in my ability to sit down for too long. Just yesterday I was speaking with Sivarama Swami (who is in India) on a video call. Thirty minutes into our conversation, he cut off the conversation and asked, "Why are you still sitting down?! It's been more than 30 minutes!" He knows I'm not supposed to be sitting for so long.

So the question was, "How can a devotee be happy without social relations?"

First, I'm not sure how the word "day-to-day" was translated into Russian. But an English definition of day-to-day is "ordinary" or "routine". I was therefore referring specifically to ordinary social dealings. I was not referring to any of the principle angas of bhakti, especially sadhu-sanga, hearing Srimad Bhagavatam, or congregational chanting of the Lord's holy names, etc. These are not ordinary social dealings.

Nonetheless, as long as one has a material body, devotees still must engage in social dealings. But they know that these affairs do not give them internal satisfaction. The body needs to be maintained if we want to use it for hearing and chanting. Devotees therefore need to discuss or deal with these matters in a minimal way so that the real purpose of maintaining the body is not forgotten.

Although the word "social" is not used within the context of the following verse and excerpt from the purport of Srimad Bhagavatam, 1.2.5, nonetheless what follows is an example of what I meant by day-to-day social dealings:

munayah sadhu prsto 'ham
bhavadbhir loka-mangalam
yat krtah krsna-samprasno
yenatma suprasidati

"O sages, I have been justly questioned by you. Your questions are worthy because they relate to Lord Krsna and so are of relevance to the world's welfare. Only questions of this sort are capable of completely satisfying the self."

[…]The whole world is full of questions and answers. The birds, beasts and men are all busy in the matter of perpetual questions and answers. In the morning the birds in the nest become busy with questions and answers, and in the evening also the same birds come back and again become busy with questions and answers. The human being, unless he is fast asleep at night, is busy with questions and answers. The businessmen in the market are busy with questions and answers, and so also the lawyers in the court and the students in the schools and colleges. The legislators in the parliament are also busy with questions and answers, and the politicians and the press representatives are all busy with questions and answers. Although they go on making such questions and answers for their whole lives, they are not at all satisfied. Satisfaction of the soul can only be obtained by questions and answers on the subject of Krsna.[…][end of quote]

Hare Krsna.

First, I'm not sure how the word "day-to-day" was translated into Russian. But an English definition of day-to-day is "ordinary" or "routine". I was therefore referring specifically to ordinary social dealings. I was not referring to any of the principle angas of bhakti, especially sadhu-sanga, hearing Srimad Bhagavatam, or congregational chanting of the Lord's holy names, etc. These are not ordinary social dealings.

Nonetheless, as long as one has a material body, devotees still must engage in social dealings. But they know that these affairs do not give them internal satisfaction. The body needs to be maintained if we want to use it for hearing and chanting. Devotees therefore need to discuss or deal with these matters in a minimal way so that the real purpose of maintaining the body is not forgotten.

Although the word "social" is not used within the context of the following verse and excerpt from the purport of Srimad Bhagavatam, 1.2.5, nonetheless what follows is an example of what I meant by day-to-day social dealings:

munayah sadhu prsto 'ham
bhavadbhir loka-mangalam
yat krtah krsna-samprasno
yenatma suprasidati

"O sages, I have been justly questioned by you. Your questions are worthy because they relate to Lord Krsna and so are of relevance to the world's welfare. Only questions of this sort are capable of completely satisfying the self."

[…]The whole world is full of questions and answers. The birds, beasts and men are all busy in the matter of perpetual questions and answers. In the morning the birds in the nest become busy with questions and answers, and in the evening also the same birds come back and again become busy with questions and answers. The human being, unless he is fast asleep at night, is busy with questions and answers. The businessmen in the market are busy with questions and answers, and so also the lawyers in the court and the students in the schools and colleges. The legislators in the parliament are also busy with questions and answers, and the politicians and the press representatives are all busy with questions and answers. Although they go on making such questions and answers for their whole lives, they are not at all satisfied. Satisfaction of the soul can only be obtained by questions and answers on the subject of Krsna.[…][end of quote]

Hare Krsna.

data.title: One Way to Deal with the Fear of Rejection
data.blurb: From time to time I hear from devotees, weakened by the wrong association, excessive enjoyment, or by contemplation of other attachments, and to the point where they can no longer strictly follow all the principles of Krsna consciousness, that they they do not associate with stricter devotees out
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
From time to time I hear from devotees, weakened by the wrong association, excessive enjoyment, or by contemplation of other attachments, and to the point where they can no longer strictly follow all the principles of Krsna consciousness, that they they do not associate with stricter devotees out of fear of being rejected. The following is part of a response I recently sent to a devotee who mentioned this fear to me:

"I can understand why you have concerns about being rejected. In mundane society, to reject an associate or friend for their failure to live up to their own expectations is very common among co-workers, friends, politicians, partners, and even family members. Accepting and rejecting is the business of a mind driven by personal ambition and that means that accepting and rejecting relationships is no exception for one who possesses such a mentality.

But generally, devotees, even those who are not yet fully mature in their devotion, are more merciful and kind than mundaners.

Of course, it's true that materialists can appear a lot more kind than devotees. As long as your association with them will benefit them by helping them to move forward in their personal or collective goals, they will generally be nice to you and also accommodating. Krsna describes this mentality in His conversation with the gopis:

'So-called friends who show affection for each other only to benefit themselves are actually selfish. They have no true friendship, nor are they following, the true principles of religion. Indeed, if they did not expect benefit for themselves, they would not reciprocate.' (SB 10.32.17)

In the commentary before that verse, Visvanath Chakravarti Thakur rephrases part of the gopis' question to Krsna to which He gave the above answer:

'There are some people who only respect those who respect them. Their respect is conditional. They give respect expecting something, and if they do not get that, then they no longer give respect. This is conditional love.'

In other words (or to put it more bluntly) if someone finds out that you're no longer interested in feeding their egos or their wallets, then they generally will take measures to reject you.

Of course there are philanthropically inclined people who are more pious. But they also have their limits within the realm of their philanthropically motivated goals.

Devotees have no personal investment in their dealings-- at least serious devotees. They get their fulfillment from a place beyond their day-to-day social dealings. Giving without expectation of return is the platform from which serious devotees operate. And even if you don't meet their expectations, they will not reject you. They know the power of the illusory energy. And they know how a spiritually weak, but non-offensive devotee can fall victim to her powerful influence.

Please remember this and be assured that due to weakness, which is also influenced by mundane association, you will not be rejected by devotees for not living up to their expectations of you. As long as there is the slightest spark, or desire, for Krsna consciousness (and in your case there is a lot more than a spark) serious devotees will always be there to encourage you, though they generally will not try to force you."

Hare Krsna

data.title: About "Srila Prabhupada's Quote of the Day"
data.blurb: I thought I should clarify the following comment which was posted recently about the "Srila Prabhupada's Quote of the Day" section on the front page of this site.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I thought I should clarify the following comment which was posted recently about the "Srila Prabhupada's Quote of the Day" section on the front page of this site.

"Dear Guru Maharaja, I would like to thank you for Srila Prabhupada's quotes. This is very nice idea. I didn't expect that they inspired me so much. They have double sweetness. They are not only Srila Prabhupada's words, they are also your words because you select these quotes, therefore they have double sweetness and double power. Thank you very much." [end of quote]

It's true that it was my idea to have these quotes posted on the website daily. But I got the idea from a calendar, containing the exact same quotes, which is sitting on a cabinet in my room in Kiev. Unfortunately I do not know who put this calendar together, though I do recall that my godsister, Daivi Sakti devi dasi, gave me this calendar in Mumbai several years ago during the Cross Maidan Festival. I also seem to recall that when she gave me the calendar, she told me that she compiled the quotes herself. I could be wrong about that. But I'm quite sure that the calendar was produced by devotees in Vrndavana.

So I did not select these quotes. I am simply taking the honey that was already collected by the bee-like devotees in Vrndavana who were eager to collect all this nectar emanating from the lotus lips of our beloved Srila Prabhupada.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Following Srila Prabhupada
data.blurb: Following Srila Prabhupada
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Following Srila Prabhupada

About a week and a half ago I received in the mail the final two DVD's from the "Following Srila Prabhupada" series produced by Yadubara Prabhu. Since they've arrived, every day while taking prasadam, I watch some of the DVD and listen to the remembrances given by devotees who were present with Srila Prabhupada during each particular lila. It's been the most relishable part of my day.

Yesterday I finished (or at least "thought" I finished) the entire DVD series. DVD #11 ended by showing Srila Prabhupada's last visit to Vrndavana in 1977. When the credits and special thanks were shown, as they were shown at the end of every previous DVD, I assumed that the DVD was finished. But when the DVD returned to the main menu, I saw a menu item entitled "Final Pastimes."I clicked on it and realized that there was more to watch on the DVD. I decided to save the last part for today.

After watching part of "Final Pastimes," I began to realize why Yadubara Prabhu set the DVD up in this way. My conclusion is that he left it up to the viewer to decide whether or not he/she wants to watch Srila Prabhupada's final pastimes. To watch and listen to the devotees speak about Srila Prabhupada's tirobhava was heart wrenching.

I know that Srila Prabhupada gave his permission for his tirobhava pastimes to be filmed. He had his reason for allowing all of his followers to see the way he departed. But it became too difficult for me to watch. I lost my appetite and became too emotional to do anything other than put my coat on, grab my japa beads, and leave for a long walk. There was nothing else I could think of doing at that moment but take shelter of the Holy Name and pray that some day I will be able to sincerely follow in the footsteps of my beloved spiritual master.

Hare Krsna

data.title: Travel Update
data.blurb: Although nobody is putting any pressure on me to travel, I thought I should share this information so that everyone will know what to expect for the immediate future with regards to my travels.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Although nobody is putting any pressure on me to travel, I thought I should share this information so that everyone will know what to expect for the immediate future with regards to my travels.

This week I received two pieces of information which has a direct bearing on my future travel plans. I also received relevant information from a third source, but that came about two weeks ago.

All of this information is coming from sources independent of each other. Two of them are from doctors and the other is from the therapist. All of them are currently treating me. The therapist has no connection with either of the other two doctors.

1) About two weeks ago I visited the therapist who prescribes my daily therapy and monitors my progress. The first question she asked me was, "Are you going to stay in one place now?" I replied that I would stay in Hungary until she released me. I answered that way because she had previously expressed some frustration with the fact that whenever I made a little progress, soon after I traveled. But this time, she seemed satisfied with my answer and immediately fixed her mind on my present condition. She said that she did not want me to travel again for at least three more months and then started my therapy from the very beginning again for the third time.

2) Before I left for Kiev on January 3rd, the understanding I had from my primary physician, Yasomatinandana dasa, was that he also wanted me to stop traveling completely for a few more months, though the impression I had from him was that I could plan to travel again by the end of March. However, four days ago Sivarama Swami was exchanging text messages with Yasomatinandana (who is currently in Italy until the end of the week). The following morning Maharaja forwarded part of the text message he received from Yasomatinandana to me. In it Yasomatinandana wrote, "Niranjana Maharaja's back is improving but he should not think about going anywhere again for at least another few months. He should stay in Hungary and relax until at least April or May."

3) Two days ago I made my fifth visit to the doctor of Oriental medicine who is treating me with acupuncture and another form of treatment aimed to improve the circulation of blood in the spinal area and then into the limbs. This treatment also releases a substantial excess of toxic blood which has accummulated in the spinal area as a result of all the disc hernias. During this visit she described my condition in more detail than she had in the past and said that in my present state one of the worst things I could do would be to fly in an airplane. She further explained how cabin pressure in an airplane adversely affects the lymphatic system. Without soliciting a statement from her about future traveling, she told me that after completing at least twelve treatments from her, I must not travel anywhere for an additional three months. She said that the earliest I should even consider going anywhere outside of Hungary would be some time in May.

I believe that the above report speaks for itself. It's taking me a little while to digest all of this since I had previously hoped to begin traveling again by the end of next month. But I'm trying my best to see Krsna's hand in all of this and I will also do my best to follow what I'm asked to do by the doctors since that's what everyone seems to be telling me what I should do.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Update from Srutakirti Prabhu
data.blurb:
Hare Krishna,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Hare Krishna,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada!

Today is the most auspicious appearance day of Lord Nityananda Prabhu. It is also Amekhala's birthday. Amekhala came home two days ago after five days in the hospital. She is still taking some antibiotics but her health is good and she is feeling stronger every day. This morning when she awoke she said her mind felt completely clear for the first time since getting the chemo 20 days ago. She is walking around the room and hallway, sometimes without help and all of her bodily functions are gradually returning to normal.

Her digestion is good and she is eating small meals three times a day. She is also taking a number of herbal tonics etc. for strength of body and immune system. For the next few weeks she will continue to eat an anticancer diet and taking supplements and when her strength is back to 'normal' we will decide what to do next. She is not inclined to continue with chemotherapy.

I have been reading letters from the devotees every day, many of them from her well wishers in the Ukraine who are very attached to her. She is overwhelmed by the kindness and love of all the devotees and it brings tears to her eyes. It is giving her the strength to continue to fight her disease. She has been through alot but she is very positive due to the mercy of the devotees. She sends her love and gratitude to everyone.

your servant, Srutakirti das

data.title: The Festival of the Soul
data.blurb: During the summer of last year I posted a blog describing a little bit about the Kiev Sunday Feast program, especially about how many new people were coming every Sunday. In fact, during the last Sunday Program I attended in November, there were 56 people attending for the first time.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the summer of last year I posted a blog describing a little bit about the Kiev Sunday Feast program, especially about how many new people were coming every Sunday. In fact, during the last Sunday Program I attended in November, there were 56 people attending for the first time.

Inspired to see so many new faces every week I asked if some of the local devotees could put together a video about the Kiev Sunday Program, or as it is called in the video, "The Festival of the Soul."

I simply put in my request and left it up to local devotees to do the rest of the work. It took some time to bring all the elements of the project together, but during the festival in Kiev two weeks ago I was given a DVD of the video as a birthday present. Although I've been told that there is still more work which will be done on it in the future, I decided that I would share what's been done so far here on the site.

I would like to take this opportunity to thank Gaura Purnima dasa, Nama Cintamani devi dasi, Brijabasi dasa, Sarvatma dasa, Dmitry Litvinov, Denis Postupnoi, Visnu dasa, Ivan Gubanov, Vilen Gubanov, Vladislav Sirenko, Aleksandr Gaidar, Abhimanyu dasa and Igor Scherba for their input into the project.

The video has been narrated in both English and Russian. The version with the Russian narration will be posted very soon.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: An Update from Srutakirti Prabhu about Amekhala Devi Dasi
data.blurb: The following is the text of a message which I received from Srutakirti Prabhu this afternoon. Again, if anyone wishes to write to Amekhala devi dasi, please post a comment to this blog, I will have it translated (if it's in Russian) and it will be forwarded to Srutakirti Prabhu.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is the text of a message which I received from Srutakirti Prabhu this afternoon. Again, if anyone wishes to write to Amekhala devi dasi, please post a comment to this blog, I will have it translated (if it's in Russian) and it will be forwarded to Srutakirti Prabhu.

Hare Krsna


This is going to many different addresses. Please forgive any lack of etiquette.

Hare Krishna everyone,
I couldn't write until now because I didn't have anything positive to report. Much has happened since Amekhala's chemo treatment 12 days ago. It has been very difficult. She was discharged home three days after but must have picked up a stomach bug while in hospital. She got bad diarrhea and vomiting and had to be re-hospitalised for 48 hours for rehydration etc. and then discharged.
On coming home she still felt sick and would not keep anything down and started getting severely dehydrated. It became more severe each day. Yesterday, Jan. 19 she had a fever of 40 C. 102 F. We spent all day yesterday trying to convince her to be readmitted for more rehydration because we knew it was a temporary hitch to a potentially curable problem. She had septicemia.
She did not want to go back to the hospital. She was ready to leave her body and would have within the next 24 hours. She was very peaceful and just wanted to have kirtan at the house. Over 50 devotees came from the surrounding area from 5 p.m. onwards. One doctor made a house call at 4:00 and advised her to go to the hospital but she refused.
Throughout the afternoon and evening she spoke with everyone, smiling brightly and was more and more peaceful. She had different visions or dreams. Each one allowing her to be more peaceful. All her fear had gone. She hadn't had any food or drink for days and was just sucking on ice cubes. It was the only thing that didn't come back up.
At 10:00 a very wonderful and sensitive doctor again came and tried. Again she said she was ready to die and despite all that he said it didn't change. Finally two of her sons and I managed to convince her to go back in just to get the IV's for antibiotics and electrolytes. She agreed and we arrived there in an ambulance at midnight after more coaxing when they arrived at the door.

data.title: Please Pray for Amekhala devi dasi
data.blurb: Those of you who have regularly attended the Southern Ukraine Festival and especially most of you who live in Ukraine probably know Srutakirti Prabhu and his wife, Amekhala devi dasi.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Those of you who have regularly attended the Southern Ukraine Festival and especially most of you who live in Ukraine probably know Srutakirti Prabhu and his wife, Amekhala devi dasi.

During the festival in Kiev I received word from Srutakirti Prabhu that Amekhala devi dasi was diagnosed as having a diffuse large B-Cell lymphoma which surrounded her left pelvis and had encased her kidneys. It was very serious and complete kidney failure was not very far off.

The doctors had to immediately begin chemotherapy for five days and said that they must continue chemotherapy once every three weeks for four months more.

I was unable to stay in daily communication with Srutakirti Prabhu because of my intense schedule in Kiev. However, two days ago I received the following update:

"Dear family and friends,

It was a good day today. She came home this afternoon. Her creatinine levels in her kidneys dropped another 15 points from 150 to 135 and she was told her tumor has reduced as there was softness in her left side which was very firm just a few days ago. So we are happy for our small blessings and ready to start giving her lots of nice food, drinks and prayers at home. It is just the beginning of the battle but at least we know what we are fighting. I won't write so often now unless there is something new to report. Thank you again for your support and prayers.

with love and affection,

Sruta" [end of quote]

This morning I immediately wrote to Srutakirti Prabhu to explain the reason behind my lapse in communication and to request him to continue to update me so that I can keep everyone informed about Amekhala dd's progress on my website.

His reply was as follows:

"Dear Maharaja,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

No need to beg forgiveness Maharaja. I understand and so does Amekhala. I am sure your disciple was in a good place mentality by your assistance and I know how caring you must have been.

Amekhala's situation is serious. She had her first chemo treatment 6 days ago and there are some positive signs, shrinkage of the tumour and a drop in the toxins in the kidneys but it is going to be a difficult and painful way back. I will keep in touch with you when I can. She doesn't want to go back into the hospital. The remainder can be done as an outpatient. We just have to pray that things improve along the way so that she is optimistic to continue the therapy.

I am happy to hear from you and know that your prayers and that of the devotees in the CIS will be a great help to both of us. Thank you.

your servant, Srutakirti das" [end of quote]

Let us pray that Krsna will protect Amekhala devi dasi and that He will allow us to continue to have her association for many more Ukraine Festival to come.

If anyone would like to send a few words to Amekhala devi dasi, you can post a comment here and I will forward it to Srutakirti Prabhu.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Now that the Festival is Over
data.blurb: In case some of you are wondering why no material has been posted on the site, it's because I did not have time to write any blogs while I was in Kiev.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
In case some of you are wondering why no material has been posted on the site, it's because I did not have time to write any blogs while I was in Kiev.

All the recordings of the lectures and talks during the past week in Kiev are still being put together by devotees in Kiev and should be posted by today or tomorrow. Also a lot of photos were gathered just yesterday and we hope they will be gradually posted in upcoming days.

Finally we are waiting for the ISKCON International Archives, whom we requested to video as much of the festival as possible, to digitize all the videos which were taken at the festival so that they can be available for streaming online and for downloading. We hope that these videos will be available soon, but as soon as they are available, they will be posted.

I returned to Budapest last night. I will be resuming treatment tomorrow and will gradually start posting blogs again within the next couple of days.

Hare Krsna.
