data.title: Srila Prabhupada's Mission
data.blurb: During the past week I've been trying to budget my sitting time to dedicate as much time as possible for reviewing material which is being prepared for my next book, "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume 3." This is probably one of the main reasons why I haven't posted a blog for over a week.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
During the past week I've been trying to budget my sitting time to dedicate as much time as possible for reviewing material which is being prepared for my next book, "Lectures from a Disciple, Volume 3." This is probably one of the main reasons why I haven't posted a blog for over a week.

This morning I was reviewing the following short talk which I gave on September 16, 2006, in Boston on the anniversary day of Srila Prabhupada's arrival in America at Commonwealth Pier. I generally do not post transcriptions from old lectures into my blogs, but because this was a short talk and since a blog from me is long overdue, I decided to use this for today's post.

After harinama to Commonwealth Pier, there was a seminar given at the temple to discuss some of the important principles found in Srila Prabhupada's "Markine Bhagavata-dharma." I arrived a little late for the seminar and was asked at the end if I had any comments I would like to make regarding the topic. The following were my closing comments:

This talk is also available here on the site in an audio file. The talk is in English only. You can find this audio file by going to the following link:

Fileshare / Lectures / Audio / 2006

Hare Krsna

If I am going to speak for a few minutes, then I should speak about substance, rather then form. And substance goes back to the quote that was pulled out from Prabhupada’s Markine Bhagavata-dharma, specifically quoting Prabhupada saying, “I can simply repeat your message. So if you like, you can make my power of speaking suitable for their understanding”. Prabhupada is here expressing his deep, utter helplessness and dependence on Krsna’s will. It’s like the story which is told about how Prabhupada used to go to Advaita Acharya’s in Santipur. Before Prabhupada began the movement, Srila Prabhupada used to go there regularly, and he would simply sit at the back and the pujari used to see Prabhupada. This was before ISKCON, before anything. And the pujari would see Prabhupada just sitting there chanting for a long period of time. He came a few times, and the pujari never spoke to him. And then there was a long period of time when Prabhupada wasn’t there, and then when the pujari saw Prabhupada again, he approached him. Prabhupada had been sitting there for a very long time, just chanting and chanting and tears were coming from his eyes. The pujari asked Srila Prabhupada: “What are you doing?”

Prabhupada said: “I have been given an order to go to the West” (and it was just before Prabhupada had left on the Jaladuta). And he said: “I’ve come here to this sacred place and I am simply praying very intensely, very deeply on how I can fulfill this order”. That was his total meditation. That’s what he carried with him on the Jaladuta. That’s what he carried with him to Commonwealth Pier when he wrote Markine Bhagavata-dharma. Prabhupada carried very deep conviction, compassion and substance. And he brought with him the desire to fulfill the higher order, coming down through the disciplic succession. That in of itself was sufficient, but Prabhupada was also filled with an overwhelming sense of compassion and Krsna consciousness. But it’s not just that he was carrying out an order; although he was carrying out blindly as we see here. Blindly in the sense that he had such firm faith in the order and in the Holy Name. But it was not just that he was carrying out an order.

Sometimes when we hear, “He was just doing it out of duty,” then it loses its immediacy, it loses its sense of compassion—“probably because it’s just something done out of duty.”

Just like when somebody preaches to somebody and if he’s just saying, “Well, I’m just doing it out of duty,” then the other person feels like, “Oh, that’s all you can get out of it to talk to me.” But Prabhupada was carrying more then just the duty to execute the order. He was carrying a deep desire to give Krsna and to make Krsna accessible to others. He didn’t only want to make them understand. He wanted to awaken their faith, sraddha, and by his own example, he wanted to build that faith from sraddha all the way to prema.

When the pure devotee’s message enters the heart, as he quotes Bhagavatam, then what does it do? It creates a revolution in the heart of that person—that that person actually gets darsan. Just as it says in the Bhagavatam:

“What is the value of a prolonged life which is wasted, inexperienced by years in this world? Better a moment of full consciousness, because that gives one a start in searching after his supreme interest.” (SB 2.1.12)

Prabhupada wanted to give that moment of full consciousness to everyone, because when one gets a glimpse of Krsna, then everything else is pale.

“My dear Vyäsa, even though a devotee of Lord Kåñëa sometimes falls down somehow or other, he certainly does not undergo material existence like others [fruitive workers, etc.] because a person who has once relished the taste of the lotus feet of the Lord can do nothing but remember that ecstasy again and again.” (SB 1.5.19)

Prabhupada was giving darsan with Krsna.

I was here in the early seventies, and I can tell you what drove everybody mad to spread Krsna consciousness. It was the darsan of Krsna that Srila Prabhupada was giving in our hearts. That’s what drove us mad. And we became so mad that having once tasted it, we wanted to taste it more and more. And what gave us the impetus? It was Prabhupada’s smile. Prabhupada’s pleasure gave us the impetus. We knew that by pleasing Prabhupada, we were pleasing Krsna. That’s substance.

Just like Gurudas Prabhu was just at the Odessa festival. I was supposed to be there, but I couldn’t go there because of my health. But I was doing a video broadcast with the devotees in Odessa just a few days ago. We (myself and Radhanath Maharaj) did it over the internet. I was speaking to 2,500 devotees. And Gurudas was there. I had invited him this year. And he tells so many stories.

I was there in Pune when he, Syamasundar and Malati were together telling stories of the early days and of the sacrifices and of the desire to please Prabhupada and the desire to give Krsna to others because they knew it was pleasing to Prabhupada. They were ready to do anything and to make any personal sacrifice, because they were driven by that unmotivated desire. There was no agenda. That purity, that sense of purpose, that sense of mission was inculcated in the hearts of Prabhupada’s followers, because Prabhupada wanted so much for us to get that darsan of Krsna so that we will be ready to keep on making those sacrifices and do whatever is necessary to see Krsna face-to-face.

That’s the value of the association of the devotee. Therefore even a moment’s association… one moment can give that person to search after his ultimate interest. And if we lose that sense of urgency, we will become complacent and forget that actually that’s our goal. That goal is achieved by pleasing Krsna’s pure devotee who has no other desire in his heart than to please the Lord. That’s how it is accomplished. No other way. Krsna has already established that that’s His method for purifying the planet. He says:

“With the dust of My devotees' lotus feet I desire to purify the material worlds, which are situated within Me. Thus, I always follow the footsteps of My pure devotees, who are free from all personal desire, rapt in thought of My pastimes, peaceful, without any feelings of enmity, and of equal disposition everywhere.” (SB 11.14.16)

Krsna says: “I follow in their footsteps, taking their dust.” That’s Prabhupada’s mission. That’s what he did. He taught us by his example. We saw in Prabhupada somebody who is ready to sacrifice everything. Now, are we prepared to do that to make people Krsna conscious? We can make all the trappings we want to try to attract people, but where are we going bring them once we have captured them? Have we accomplished our mission by getting followers? We’ve not accomplished our mission by getting followers. We’ve accomplished our mission by giving Krsna consciousness to others and awakening the desire in their hearts to become a pure devotee in this life.

That’s what Prabhupada’s mission is. We cannot change it to something else.

Therefore, when I read this this verse from Markine Bhagavata-dharma, I always try to look at the essence of Prahupada’s mood and just how much he is feeling himself helplessly dependent upon Krsna. And therefore because he is feeling so helplessly dependent on Krsna, Krsna is embracing Prabhupada in His arms, and impregnating Prabhupada’s words with such a deep sense of desire. When I listen to those lectures from 1966 in New York, Prabhupada is so animated! So animated! His heart is bubbling, just like a caring father, wanting so much.

In those lectures in 1966, he was speaking right from Caitanya Caritamrta about mother Yasoda, Nanda Maharaja, the cowherd boys and Vrndavana. He was bubbling with the desire to make people Krsna conscious. We never experienced anything else in Prabhupada’s presence than that bubbling desire to give Krsna. And that’s what captured our hearts, and that’s what makes us want to make this life successful by doing something to make Prabhupada smile. And if some day we can become so blessed to be able to do that which he wants us to do, then that’s the only reason why we live in this world. There is nothing else.

That’s what I see as the essence of Markine Bhagavata and because you’ve asked me to speak, I felt it was more essential to emphasize this point, rather than anything else.

Thank you.

Hare Krsna.

That’s the value of the association of the devotee. Therefore even a moment’s association… one moment can give that person to search after his ultimate interest. And if we lose that sense of urgency, we will become complacent and forget that actually that’s our goal. That goal is achieved by pleasing Krsna’s pure devotee who has no other desire in his heart than to please the Lord. That’s how it is accomplished. No other way. Krsna has already established that that’s His method for purifying the planet. He says:

“With the dust of My devotees' lotus feet I desire to purify the material worlds, which are situated within Me. Thus, I always follow the footsteps of My pure devotees, who are free from all personal desire, rapt in thought of My pastimes, peaceful, without any feelings of enmity, and of equal disposition everywhere.” (SB 11.14.16)

Krsna says: “I follow in their footsteps, taking their dust.” That’s Prabhupada’s mission. That’s what he did. He taught us by his example. We saw in Prabhupada somebody who is ready to sacrifice everything. Now, are we prepared to do that to make people Krsna conscious? We can make all the trappings we want to try to attract people, but where are we going bring them once we have captured them? Have we accomplished our mission by getting followers? We’ve not accomplished our mission by getting followers. We’ve accomplished our mission by giving Krsna consciousness to others and awakening the desire in their hearts to become a pure devotee in this life.

That’s what Prabhupada’s mission is. We cannot change it to something else.

Therefore, when I read this this verse from Markine Bhagavata-dharma, I always try to look at the essence of Prahupada’s mood and just how much he is feeling himself helplessly dependent upon Krsna. And therefore because he is feeling so helplessly dependent on Krsna, Krsna is embracing Prabhupada in His arms, and impregnating Prabhupada’s words with such a deep sense of desire. When I listen to those lectures from 1966 in New York, Prabhupada is so animated! So animated! His heart is bubbling, just like a caring father, wanting so much.

In those lectures in 1966, he was speaking right from Caitanya Caritamrta about mother Yasoda, Nanda Maharaja, the cowherd boys and Vrndavana. He was bubbling with the desire to make people Krsna conscious. We never experienced anything else in Prabhupada’s presence than that bubbling desire to give Krsna. And that’s what captured our hearts, and that’s what makes us want to make this life successful by doing something to make Prabhupada smile. And if some day we can become so blessed to be able to do that which he wants us to do, then that’s the only reason why we live in this world. There is nothing else.

That’s what I see as the essence of Markine Bhagavata and because you’ve asked me to speak, I felt it was more essential to emphasize this point, rather than anything else.

Thank you.

Hare Krsna.

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I'm hearing from many sources (phone, email, chats, and Vyasa Puja offerings) that devotees, inspired from hearing or reading my lectures about the Prabhupada Marathon, are making extra efforts to give Krsna consciousness to others this month in the form of Srila Prabhupada's books and Krsna's Holy Names.

As I am sitting here in my room in snowy and very cold New Vraja Dhama, I am thinking about all of these devotees and the many more devotees from whom I have not heard any news yet. I am wishing that I could be among all of you, preaching in the front lines, tasting the austerities which come, in a very natural way, from attempting to induce non-devotees to voluntarily surrender the fruits of their labor to purchase one of Srila Prabhupada's books.

Srila Prabhupada is pleased by these efforts, of this I am sure. There is no need for any other consideration in this endeavor. Simply think of Srila Prabhupada's pleasure when you approach someone to engage them in taking a book. Everything else will come. Realizations, mercy, a glimpse of a sweet taste, humility, and the desire to do more to please Krsna's devotee— all the characteristics of devotional service described in Lord Krsna's concluding statements to Narada Muni in the first part of Brhad Bhagavatamrta—will naturally come. Do not be discouraged if they don't come right away. They will come according to the degree of our surrender.

Here is a sample from one of the many different pieces of news I received during this past week:

"I am not doing much Guru Maharaja, hardly 10 books a day. I am sometimes standing on the street without speaking to anyone, sometimes I feel like crying, sometimes I feel extremely cold and sometimes completely exhausted. But for the first time of my life, I don’t care so much about all those discomforts. I am experiencing a new feeling that I never experienced before. This new feeling of being ready to tolerate rain, wind, cold for your pleasure Guru Maharaja.  This feeling that even though I am not very good at it I feel that I am doing the right thing. Knowing that effort can please you and please Srila Prabhupada give me a satisfaction and a desire to do more. Srila Prabhupada explain how it doesn’t matter to live in hell or in heaven when our mission is to distribute books. And for the first time I understand a little more the meaning of it. 
  
Going on books seems to be like going on an adventure with Krsna, The Supreme Personality of Godhead. It help me to realize the personal relationship with Krsna. Sometimes He encourages us, sometime He is testing our determination. Sometime He shows us His Supreme power and His inconceivable mercy and all the time He demonstrate His Supreme control. It is a very powerful way to understand how insignificant I am and to practice to become His instrument. 
  
I don’t understand why it took me so long to start this and taste that special nectar. 
  
Going out on books shows a visual aspect of Srimad Bhagavatam, how Kali yuga is filled with so much suffering. I become more convince how Srila Prabhupada’s books and the Holy Names are the only remedy for the suffering of this world. Slowly I feel more compassion and a stronger desire to distribute books arises in my heart.
  
Srila Prabhupada’s books seems now to become more alive. Verses have another dimension that I never experienced before. A certain sweetness that I never had. This experience of book distribution really helps me to focus on taking shelter of Krsna’s Holy Names. In certain situations that we can face in the street it becomes clear  how there is no other shelter than His Holy Names." [end of quote]

Today is December 19th. There are six days left between now and Christmas Eve. If you haven't attempted to distribute some of Srila Prabhupada's books yet, or if you don't have a Sankirtan story or realization to share with me or with other devotees yet, there is still time left to do this. Even a few books distributed will be pleasing to Srila Prabhupada.

In this connection Srila Prabhupada wrote and it has so many times been quoted, "I remember that my Guru Maharaja would often send young boys out to sell literature of Krishna Consciousness, and if they would come back having sold only a few issues, Guru Maharaja was very, very pleased. [Srila Prabhupada's letter to Subala, July 31, 1969]

I wish to take this opportunity to thank all the devotees who have made an increased effort this month to distribute Krsna consciousness. I pray that you will experience Srila Prabhupada's mercy being showered upon you in the form of deep, spiritual realizations which will carry you forward on your journey back home, back to Godhead.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Harinama in Kolkata
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On December 10th I communicated with godbrothers and disciples in Mayapura. During the discussion I was told about a harinama in Kolkata which devotees organized a little more than two weeks ago. At that time I was not fully aware that the idea for bringing a harinama party to Kolkata like this was inspired by devotees wishing to offer the harinama as a present to me for my birthday.

That same day, I received a video file of the harinama, watched it, and was so filled with happiness to see how the people of Kolkata were so joyful to witness all these Russian-speaking devotees chanting, dancing, and distributing, books, prasadam and flyers. By the end of the video, the fruit of the sacrifice was that the observers were all loudly and enthusiastically chanting Hare Krsna. It was so nice to see that I must have watched the video at least 3-4 consecutive times.

A few days later I received a letter from a disciple living in Mayapura. The following is a small excerpt from her letter:

"I am grateful to Mahaprabhu for every moment in Mayapur and trying to remember to not take it for granted. He is so responsive to my prayers. For instance, the last biggest sweetness happened during your disciples' meeting about organizing Your Vyasapuja. I offered the idea to organize a Harinam and book distribution in Kolkata as a birthday gift for You. Everybody liked it. We had two weeks to prepare. […]

[…] I saw a miracle!!! I saw people of Kolkata with different eyes: they ARE Mahaprabhu's people! It was endless bliss! Everything went so smoothly and easy. Devotees were so cooperative and united. There were no complaints, nor any dislikes. Everyone shared money for the expenses." [End of quote]

I felt so grateful that all these devotees cooperated to bring Lord Caitanya's mercy to Kolkata on that day. But after seeing this video and reading this letter, I couldn't help thinking, "Why only on my birthday?" Would it be possible to distribute this mercy more often than that?"

Of course, I know that it will not be so easy to organize harinamas like this often. It took two weeks to prepare for this one. Moreover, a lot of time and expense is involved to go all the way to Kolkata from Mayapura regularly. But just now when I showed the video to Sivarama Maharaja, he said that if Kolkata is too far, then why not go to Navadvipa and Krishnanagar?

Just some food for thought…not only for devotees living in Mayapura, but for anyone who visits Mayapura during the non-festival time.

My thanks to all the devotees who organized and took part in this harinama, and to Vanamali Nrsimha dasa, for the very nice video production. More! More!

Hare Krsna.

Chanting in Kolkata from NRS on Vimeo.

data.title: Vyasa Puja Offerings
data.blurb: On December 10th I received many Vyasa Puja offerings from disciples all over. Moreover, I was also informed that more offerings were posted at http://vyasapuja.com.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
On December 10th I received many Vyasa Puja offerings from disciples all over. Moreover, I was also informed that more offerings were posted at http://vyasapuja.com.

I began reading some of the homages posted on that site. However very soon thereafter I began to wonder, "If I read all of these homages now, then what is going to happen from 10:45 to 13:15 on January 9th? Will different homages be offered to me then?"

Without an answer to this question, I decided that I would wait until I receive further clarification.

As far as I understand, the Vyasa Puja organizers allocated 2.5 hours on January 9th so that as many devotees who wanted to read their homage directly to me could be given the opportunity to do so. It seems to me that if somebody wishes to offer an homage to me in person, the content of their offering should be spontaneous and fresh and I shouldn't spoil it for them by having already read it.

Meanwhile, for those who sent me offerings from outside the CIS either directly to my email or through someone who has my email, I'm assuming that you will not be present in Kiev on January 9th. I have already read those offerings and I wish to thank all of you for sharing your innermost thoughts with me about how my service to Srila Prabhupada and to all of you has impacted your life. In my heart I know that I am unworthy of your praise and my knowledge of that makes it difficult for me to read all of this. However, I am also convinced that if I accept your homages and offer them to Srila Prabhupada, it will be pleasing to him and beneficial for you. It is for this reason that I will read each and every homage that has been written to me.

I also wish to assure everyone who has already written an offering that's been posted on the http://vyasapuja.com site that I will read your offering just as soon as I know which ones to read now and which ones I should wait to read either on or after January 9th.

For those of you who will write something later and will hand it to me or to my secretary in Kiev (something which inevitably happens) I will certainly read your offerings too, provided that they have been translated into English for me.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: More Power Point Presentations on Book Distribution
data.blurb: This morning I received these recently produced Power Point presentations on book distribution from Vaisesika Prabhu. They are available as attached files at the end of this blog.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
This morning I received these recently produced Power Point presentations on book distribution from Vaisesika Prabhu. They are available as attached files at the end of this blog.

These presentations are very useful tools to inspire devotees to go out and distribute Srila Prabhupada's books, especially now while the Prabhupada Marathon is still going on. 

Anyone who carefully studies each slide in the "How to Sell a Gita" presentation will feel more equipped with the knowledge required to introduce a book into somebody's hands, to engage them in a meaningful conversation, and to inspire them to give a donation to cover the cost of the book. This presentation can also build confidence in the "Art of Book Distribution."

"I like also your programme of sending out your best men to teach the others. That is the actual process of Krishna Consciousness. To train others continue this programme so that in the future every devotee in our movement will know the art of distributing books. This is approved by me." ( a quote from Srila Prabhupada in a letter to Ramesvara, dated August 3rd, 1973).

The other presentations are also inspirational and give novel ways to introduce Srila Prabhupada's books for those who are inclined to a more passive approach.

Unfortunately, however, because these presentations are fresh , they are only in English. If anyone knows how to use "Power Point" or "Keynote" and can translate the slides into Russian, it would be a much appreciated service for the Russian-speaking devotees.

Leave a comment if you know someone who has the time and knowledge how to translate them and then once they are translated, an arrangement can be made for a place to upload them.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Srila Prabhupada is Calling
data.blurb: The following is the part of Srila Prabhupada's talk which I listened to this morning while honoring breakfast prasadam. While listening to this talk, I was strongly moved by Srila Prabhupada's call for "everyone to go back home, back to Godhead."
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following is the part of Srila Prabhupada's talk which I listened to this morning while honoring breakfast prasadam. While listening to this talk, I was strongly moved by Srila Prabhupada's call for "everyone to go back home, back to Godhead."

Ladies and gentlemen, I thank you very much for your coming here to participate in this Krsna consciousness movement. We are calling everyone to go back to home, back to Godhead. This is our movement, Krsna consciousness movement. Just now we described the place where we intend to go. That is Goloka Vrndavana. There the Supreme Personality of Godhead is residing with His consort Radharani. Radha-Madhava. Krsna is the husband -- not exactly husband, but friend. The same mellow. As you try to enjoy here, boy and girlfriend, not married, but an extra ecstasy without being married, conjugal love, the ideal conjugal love is there, Krsna and Radha. Here the same thing is present, but in a perverted sense. The origin is there. Jaya radha-madhava kunja-vihari. Radha and Krsna, They are always engaged in loving affairs in the kunja, in the bushes of Vrndavana. Jaya radha-madhava kunja-vihari, gopijana-vallabha. He is very dear to the gopis and the gopas. Gopas means the cowherd men and the cowherd boys.

durasaya ye bahir-artha-maninah
andha yathandhair upaniyamanas
te 'pisa-tantryam uru-damni-baddhah

They do now know what is the ultimate goal of life, our self-interest. Everyone must be self-interested, but we do not know what is self-interest. There is no education what is the ultimate goal of life. Na te viduh. They are trying to satisfy themselves to become happy and prosperous by adjusting this material nature. Bahir-artha-maninah. Bahir-artha-maninah means giving more importance to this materialistic way of life. That is called bahir-artha-maninah. God has got many energies. Parasya saktir vividhaiva sruyate [Cc. Madhya 13.65, purport]. In the Vedas we understand that the Supreme Lord has manifold energies, and whatever we see, that is the activities of His energy. Just like electric energy. The energy is coming out from the powerhouse, and by utilizing that electric energy, we are working in so many ways: heater, cooler, this microphone, tape recorder, so many things. But the energy is coming from that powerhouse. Similarly, whatever you are seeing, wonderful action of the material action and reaction, they are simply interaction of different energies of the Lord, heat and light. Any scientist will understand that this whole cosmic manifestation is creation of heat and light, two energies. The two energies are coming from the sun, and the material world is creation of the sunshine, heat and light. Similarly there are two energies of God, heat and light. So one is called material energy, another is called spiritual energy, although both of them coming from the supreme spirit, exactly like heat and light is coming from the sun. But heat is not light; light is not heat. There is distinction. This is called inconceivable one and difference simultaneously. Acintya-bhedabheda tattva. This is our philosophy. Nothing is different from God, but not that everything is God. Simultaneous one and different.

So two energies are working, material and spiritual. The spiritual energy is called superior, and the material energy is called inferior. Just like matter. Material energy means earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intelligence, ego, and spiritual energy means spiritual force, the living force. So every one of us, combination of two energies, spiritual energy and material energy. You can understand it. As soon as the spiritual energy is off from the combination of this material energy, it is simply lump of matter. It cannot move. That is stated in the Bhagavad-gita: yaya idam dharyate jagat. The whole world is moving by the combination of material and spiritual energy, and both of them coming from one source, exactly like that, that both heat and light is coming from the sun. But they are working differently or working combinedly.

So this world, this material world, although it is not different from God, but still, it is not God. So we have to transfer ourself from this material energy to the spiritual energy. That is the business.

Hare Krsna.

Body_raw.value:
I should have mentioned in my last "Health Update" that when consulting the therapist during my last visit, I explained to her that I had already made a prior commitment to travel one more time in January because I had assumed that my six month commitment for recuperation in Hungary would be finished at the end of December. I began treatment in early July. She said that, quite likely, if I didn't travel in September, October, and November, my assumption would have been correct.

Still, she agreed to the trip when I assured her of the following:

1) It would be the only exception.

2) It would be only a one-hour flight.

3) I would bring somebody with me to carry all of my hand-baggage.

4) I would continue my therapy without interuption.

5) I would limit my activity to stay within the guidelines she had given me.

She told me that she would see me before I leave for Ukraine, she would give me exercises for traveling, and that she would re-evaluate my progress and adjust my therapy accordingly until I returned to Hungary.

To fulfill this commitment to my therapist, to my doctor, and to all of you, (to strictly stick with the therapy and treatment for at least three more months) I would like to state a few additional points so that I can hopefully finish this topic and move on to other topics for future blogs.

1) Nobody should come to Kiev expecting a personal meeting (hopefully the reasons for this will be obvious and I will not need to explain any further).

2) The festival dates are January 8 – 10. Although I plan to arrive in Kiev a few days before the 8th and I plan to remain in Kiev a few days after the festival is over, I have no plans to conduct programs or meetings either before or after the festival.

3) If I make a spontaneous exception to the previous statement, I ask everyone in advance for forgiveness if my decision was not pleasing to them.

4) It's possible that Giriraja Maharaja may speak at the temple once or twice before and after the festival, but his schedule will not be decided until he arrives in Kiev. He has already agreed to speak on the 8th evening and also again on the 10th.

5) The actual day of Vyasa Puja, January 9th, will be an obvious exception to my strict daily routine, but it will be the only exception. Still I will find the time for two therapy sessions on that day.

6) Devotees should avoid discussing my health between themselves and with me during the entire festival. Let us instead try to focus on topics more relevant to the reasons why we will be gathering, to focus on Srila Prabhupada, and especially to focus on the sweet Names of Lord Krsna, which I'm hoping will be a major part of this event.

7) Nobody should spontaneously assume the role of my "security guard." I will have a personal servant and a personal secretary/translator and that should be sufficient. I do not appreciate it when I see people mistreat others in the name of protecting me. I shouldn’t have to say this but since it continues to happen, I decided to make it known that it disturbs me.

8) If you bring letters you wish to deliver to me (or to my secretary) by hand, please make sure they are in English before hand-delivering them. Please do not expect my secretary to translate them for you and please do not expect that I will read your letter before the end of the festival.

I would like to end by saying that, as always, I am very eager to see all of you and to be given another opportunity to serve all of you by, in some way, encouraging you in Krsna consciousness. By setting these guidelines, it will provide me with the hope to get more opportunities for this in the future.

Hare Krsna.

P.S. You can download this blog as an attached file. If you know someone who may be interested to read the content of this blog but who may not be frequenting this site, please download the file and either forward it to them or print it out and give it to them.

data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
The following report was written by Guruttama dasa. I requested him to write on this subject because he hears everything from the doctor and physiotherapist. Although he is a good translator, naturally I do not always hear all the details of the conversation. Here is his report:

My name is Guruttama dasa. Niranjana Swami Maharaja asked me, to write about his present health condition. He asked me, since I usually go with and translate for him when he has his doctor’s appointments, therefore I can give an authentic report in regards to presenting what the doctors are saying.

Niranjana Maharaja is suffering from cervical and back hernias. (Hernia simply is, when there is overload or overweight on the spine, the vertebrae are pushing on the discs, so the circular outer fibers of the discs are broken, and the gel-like material from the inside is coming out and pushing on the nerves, giving much pain and can cause serious problems.) He has been going through treatment for the past couple months. He has also been visiting a physiotherapist, who has prescribed several exercises for him. The idea is to get weight of the spine so the vertebrae are not pushing on the discs, so the hernias can draw back. After the hernias are gone, the muscles have to be strengthened, making sure they do not flare up again in the future. For this 6 months is needed (3 months to clean off the hernias and another 3 months for the strengthening of muscles).

Maharaja was doing pretty good and made significant progress with the exercises until Govardhana Puja. Since then, he has been travelling and having meetings, which was too much for him according to present health status, and his back condition was set back noticeably. It started to give much pain again to him, and other symptoms like numbness and tingling sensations started to appear, which are not good signs also.

Last week we visited the physiotherapist, who was talking about what can happen in the future. If the hernias get any worse than the present state, only operation can help. If not operated, the hernias will push on the nerves and the spinal marrow to the extent, that can cause permanent paralysis in the limbs. The problem with operation is, that there are many hernias. The doctors would probably choose one maximum two, but it does not solve the problem. Also when they cut off the hernia during surgery there are always scars, which usually push on the nerves as well. Also some hernias in Maharaja’s back come out in more directions, to the sides and to the middle also, so it would be difficult to operate them. After surgery, rehabilitation takes one to two years, and recovery is never hundred percent.

The other option is to take exercises and certain guidelines very seriously. They are helping to take weight off from Maharaja’s back, stretching the spine and can make the hernias go away.

First of all, Maharaja has to do series of exercises in every hour in the first week, than every second hour in the second week, etc. The exercises are only working, if he is not sitting or standing for more than 30 minutes continuously, not lifting more than 3 kilograms weight, not turning his spine sideways at all, not bending down at all and not travelling.

Even if he is doing the exercises, but not being able to follow these rules, his health condition will just get worse. He needs minimum of three months in a row for making permanent progress. This means he is not allowed to travel, have meetings, give classes, play harmonium for the next three months. He has to do exercises and take much rest for that three month period.

To all those who are concerned about Niranjana Maharaja, please continue to be patient with him and give him the time he needs to recover.

Your servant,

Guruttama dasa

Body_raw.value:
In response to a request made here on this site to clarify statements I've made in Minsk and in Kiev about my future aspirations for serving the devotees in my capacity as GBC, I will explain here what I've said, what were my intentions, and what some of my plans are for the future.

In Kiev I gave a a talk to the leaders present in the National Council meeting and then answered everyone's questions. The essence of my talk was that I wish to withdraw from direct management within Ukraine and Moldova and I wish to leave the managerial decisions up to the National Council with Acyuta Priya remaining as Regional Secretary. I explained the history of the new issues which surfaced with my health earlier this year, and to some degree, I touched upon the issues of the past few years. I also gave reference to the cummulative effect that dealing with conflicts between leaders has had on my health.

When I spoke about my dealings with conflicts in that meeting, I was referring to conflicts with which I've had to deal within the jurisdiction of my entire GBC zone, which includes Ukraine, Moldova, Belarus, Kaliningrad, Lithuania, Moscow, Moscow Central Region, St. Petersburg Region and Northeast United States, and I was not speaking exclusively about Ukraine and Moldova. Some time ago I had to deal with leadership conflicts in the United States which went on for several months and which took a serious toll on my health. And then more recently I had to deal with conflicts elsewhere, though fortunately, because my health seems to be gradually improving, it did not affect my health as much as it has been affected by conflicts before.

Nonetheless my statements in the Ukraine National Council Meeting about withdrawing from management were specifically directed to the leaders within Ukraine and Moldova, and not elsewhere, because in that region there is a working National Council and there is Acyuta Priya dasa, who is a responsible and experienced Regional Secretary who has already been serving in that capacity for many years.

In that meeting I expressed my desire for the Ukraine/Moldova leaders to mature further in their roles as leaders and to learn to resolve their conflicts amongst themselves. This statement was not at all something new. This was exactly the same theme which both H.H. Bhaktivaibhava Swami and I discussed with the same leaders during the last National Council Meeting that we both attended together in September, 2008, during the the time of the Evpatoriya Festival. In fact, Bhaktivaibhava Swami explained this point to the leaders with much greater emphasis at that time than I did. I have since better understood why.

However, I thought I made it clear in last week's National Council Meeting that I have no plans for withdrawing my active participation in the affairs of the Ukraine/ Moldova region. On the contrary, I told everyone present that my plan was to spend a good portion of my time next year in Ukraine (though I hope to visit other areas outside Ukraine as well), that I would base myself in one place in Ukraine, and that it was my hope to gradually visit most of the major cities next year in Ukraine, not only to spend time with the devotees in general, but especially to associate with the leaders and senior devotees, to personally encourage them, to advise them about their own spiritual lives, and to give whatever guidance I could about their lives as sadhakas and as managerial leaders. To that degree, I am planning to continue to manage. I would also like to assist the managers by preaching a unified vision for developing their yatras, placing special emphasis on taking care of devotees. I will also take part in some National Council meetings, whenever I can, to observe and to give advice if required.

A similar point was also expressed in the following quote from my blog two days ago:

"In general, I wanted to be present as much as possible to observe the retreat, though naturally, I also wanted to contribute to the retreat by speaking each day and by leading some kirtans. As I mentioned in my interview, I am definitely satisfied by observing the direction this system of care has been moving in Ukraine and Moldova, especially seeing that there now seems to be an increased awareness of the need for a developed system of caring for devotees in general. But there is still a lot of work that needs to be done before the system includes more senior devotees who can feel sheltered, wanted, and needed for participating within this system. If Krsna allows me, it is my desire to personally give attention to this aspect of its development next year."

So, again, we see this same point. If my health will allow it, I would like to resume traveling in Ukraine to give classes, lead kirtans, and to focus on associating with and encouraging senior devotees to become more active in their own Krsna consciousness, in community affairs, and to do whatever I can to help them individually so that they can share their experiences and realizations with the younger generation of devotees through counseling. I feel that would be the best use of the limited time and energy I still have left with respect to Ukraine and Moldova, rather than having to focus on conflicts when I visit each center.

It is my wish, and with my full support, that Acyuta Priya dasa will continue to emphasize the need for developing the counseling system throughout the Ukraine/ Moldova region. He will also continue to attend the GBC Deputy meetings in Mayapura each year and hopefully, to some degree, the GBC meetings, so that he can represent GBC discussions and decisions to the Ukrainian yatra.

This is pretty much the essence of what I spoke about at the Ukraine National Council Meeting last week, although I have elaborated upon the same points a little more here.

This is by no means a complete account of what my responsibilities and plans for the future are for the other areas within my GBC jurisdiction. Each region is unique and has different contributing factors, such as more active co-GBC's, less active co-GBC's, no co-GBC, no Regional Secretaries or National Councils, and also the existence of a Regional mangerial body to which each temple is accountable, such as the the way the situation exists in North America. It is not possible to give an exhaustive explanation of how I will participate in each of these areas in the immediate and long-range future within the context of this blog.

I am therefore specifically addressing the issues here which I discussed in Kiev with reference only to Ukraine and Moldova.

But there is also another side to my future, which is my accountability to the GBC body and my participation in GBC meetings. Due to health reasons I have not been able to attend a GBC meeting since March, 2005. And though I have been planning to attend next year's meetings in February, I am again being cautioned by the medical practitioners who are presently overseeing my immediate health issues that I need to stay in one place for "at least" another three months and remain focused on health improvement or run the risk of further irreversible consequences. Therefore whatever plans I have for continuing with my GBC duties, in whatever capacity I plan to fulfill them, must be confirmed and sanctioned by the GBC Body, and/or the GBC Executive Committee.

Considering the point mentioned above, between now and February 6th, the day when the International GBC meetings will begin in Mayapura, I plan to discuss these plans with other GBC members and to get the blessings from the GBC Body or the GBC Executive Committee to serve in the capacity which I have described, in case I will not be able to attend the GBC meetings next year.

I hope this explanation answers the question which was posted on this site regarding the statements I made last week in Kiev during the National Council Meeting.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Update and Kiev Counselor Retreat
data.blurb: I returned to Budapest on the evening of November 18th from one week in Kiev.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I returned to Budapest on the evening of November 18th from one week in Kiev. I have to admit, that after my Belarus trip, Holy Name Weekend in New Vraja Dhama, and then one week in Kiev participating in temple programs, fully participating in the National Counselor Retreat, the National Council Meeting on Monday, and then many hours of personal meetings on Tuesday and Wednesday, right up until the time of my departure to Boryspil Airport, by the time I arrived in Budapest I needed a lot of rest.

In a phone conversation with my therapist two days ago, after she heard the details of what's going on with my back and the shooting pains I'm getting elsewhere, she insisted that I completely stop all travel again for three more months. I asked her to please re-evaluate the time required for further recovery after she can directly observe my condition, something she hasn't been able to do for almost two months.

My therapist gave birth approximately six weeks ago and is on maternity leave for at least two months, but she said that she will make an exception for me and will see me next week. I will also see Yasomatinandana dasa, my doctor, on Monday, November 23rd.

Whatever both of them say, or whatever you may hear from other reports, I just want to assure everyone that I have no intentions of canceling or postponing Vyasa Puja in Kiev from January 8 – 10. Other than that trip, however, I have no immediate plans to travel anywhere other than to New Vraja Dhama.

I would also like to take this opportunity to mention that my godbrother, H.H. Giriraja Maharaja, has already booked his tickets to Kiev in order to spend time with me there and he very much wants to take part in the festival from January 8 – 10. He will arrive in Kiev on January 5th and will depart from Kiev on January 13th. I requested him, and he has already agreed, to give at least two classes during the three-day festival, specifically to pour Srila Prabhupada katha upon everyone attending the festival.

Giriraja Maharaja is an ocean of Srila Prabhupada katha, having spent so much time with Prabhupada, especially in India. Whenever I stay with him in America, and whenever we sit and talk, he almost always has something new to say about his experiences with Srila Prabhupada. His wisdom is deep, having both observed and imbibed Srila Prabhupada's mood and manner of dealing with his disciples, godbrothers, and all living entities in general. He also received many personal instructions from Srila Prabhupada and is eager to share the realizations he gets from those instructions. His presence in Kiev will be a blessing for all who attend.

It is not at all clear what Giriraja Maharaja's (and my) schedule will be in Kiev before and after the festival. It is very likely that we will spend our days together outside the city at least two days before the festival begins and possibly even two days after the festival is over, though it is possible that Giriraja Maharaja may give an evening class or two at the temple before and after the festival. These details will not be worked out until we meet each other on January 6th, the day after his arrival in Kiev.

Bhakti Visrambha Madhava Maharaja, whom all of you should already know, has also assured me that he will attend the festival. I am not sure what date he will be arriving in Kiev, but we have tentatively planned to also spend some time together after the festival. I'm sure that, as usual, he will be bubbling with enthusiam for Hari Katha and for sharing slokas with anyone and everyone who comes within hearing range of his ever-flowing stream of verses from sastra.

I would like to go back a little to my recent Kiev visit…

On Tuesday, two days after the Kiev Counselor Retreat, I was interviewed for "Dom Prabhupadi", the Kiev community newsletter, and was asked several questions about my impressions of the retreat, my vision for further development of spiritual counseling in Ukraine and Moldova, and several other questions related to the system of care for both junior and senior devotees in Ukraine and Moldova. I felt that the answers I gave to these questions were relevant for devotees elsewhere and not only in Ukraine and Moldova. Unfortunately, however, I neglected to record that interview. I therefore do not have anything to post here from that interview on the site. Meanwhile I will try to get a copy of it, at least in Russian, though I'm not sure at this time if we will be able to get an English version. I've been told that the Russian transcription will be available by Tuesday or Wednesday of next week.

In general, I wanted to be present as much as possible to observe the retreat, though naturally, I also wanted to contribute to the retreat by speaking each day and by leading some kirtans. As I mentioned in my interview, I am definitely satisfied by observing the direction this system of care has been moving in Ukraine and Moldova, especially seeing that there now seems to be an increased awareness of the need for a developed system of caring for devotees in general. But there is still a lot of work that needs to be done before the system includes more senior devotees who can feel sheltered, wanted, and needed for participating within this system. If Krsna allows me, it is my desire to personally give attention to this aspect of its development next year.

The retreat was thought-provoking. The format was good in that it stimulated dialogue and participation from practically everyone who attended. I was very happy to see that. Presentations were given by senior devotees who have experience with many different aspects of care, from counseling, caring for the terminally ill, education, training, and engaging congregational members. Also much time was given for presentations on how to bring guests and new devotees into the system, to see that they are inspired to engage in the temple services, and especially to insure that their service does not compromise the development of their faith in practicing sadhana and in the process of hearing and chanting about Krsna in the association of more experienced devotees. These are all important areas which will always require attention and will need to be further developed throughout the whole region.

I felt, however, that it would have been nice if some of the speakers would have had more time for their presentations and for questions and answers regarding the particular subject of their presentation. This is a small point, but something to be considered by the organizers for future retreats.

In particular, I was very enlivened by Acyuta Priya dasa's explanation as to why so much time was spent on the second day of the retreat by putting the participants together into four separate groups and requesting them to spontaneously organize, within one and a half hours, two short dramas and two short operas depicting four different lilas of the Lord (1- Krsna's lifting of Govardhana Hill, 2- Krsna and Balarama leaving Vrndavana for Mathura, 3- The chastisement of the Kaliya serpent, and 4- The killing of the Aghasura demon).

I was impressed by the devotees' resourcefulness to employ whatever they could find and whatever they could make, within such a short period of time, to use as props for their dramas. I was also impressed by the composition and the scripts they were able to put together so quickly. It was also nice to see the cooperation and genuine happiness many of the devotees appeared to experience by using their talents in a devotional way.

In the beginning of the afternoon session, Acyuta Priya Prabhu summarized this part of the event nicely by emphasizing that devotees need to fill the need for a possible cultural vacuum by spontaneously and joyfully using their talents to express themselves within a Krsna conscious context. Otherwise devotees run to risk of needing to look elsewhere to fill that need.

On Sunday, after the morning strategy session for reviewing what was accomplished within Ukraine and Moldova for developing the system of care in 2009, and for making short and long-range plans for 2010, the Sunday Feast program began shortly thereafter. Before beginning my lecture, I asked how many people were present for the program for the first time. Again, I saw so many hands go up. But I also felt the need to speak about the Prabhupada Marathon since it was my last public lecture for all the congregational devotees from Kiev and especially all those who had assembled from throughout Ukraine for the retreat. So I tried my best to present my talk in such a way that both audiences could derive some benefit from the presentation.

After the lecture, and just before the kirtan began, I noticed that there was simply not enough room in the temple room and on the balcony for everyone to participate in the kirtan. Some of the devotees had to leave for other parts of the temple. Again, another indication that we must hope that the Kiev temple room construction and expansion project can continue as quickly as possible.

After the kirtan, according to tradition, all the new guests (it seemed that it was at least 30, but probably more) were enthusiastically received with a garland, mahaprasadam, and some warm words. Usually there is a long line of garlands for each new guest, but as each new guest was received it started to become apparent that there were not going to be enough garlands for all the new guests. An apology was made to those who did not receive garlands, but within a short time I saw that gradually more and more garlands were coming out of the pujari room for the new guests who had not received one yet. When I left the temple room after the announcements, I noticed that Mahamana devi dasi was quickly stringing more garlands in the pujari room so that nobody would be left without one.

Also, Sunday happened to be the exact day of the 50th wedding anniversary of Sandipani Muni dasa and Prema Sagara devi dasi—long time residents and very active participants in devotee care from Kharkov. An announcement was made, words of appreciation were spoken by several devotees who knew them well, gifts and garland were offered to them, and then both spoke a few humble words, expressing their gratitude for the association of each other and for the association of devotees in general. It was a very nice ending for the Sunday announcements and was greatly appreciated by everyone, including myself, by seeing how a householder couple can stay together and selflessly serve the community of Vaisnavas as householders for so many years.

After the feast Sadacara dasa and his drama troupe from Dnepropetrovsk put on a very nice drama about the life of Haridasa Thakur. As usual, it was a very impressive performance and was greatly appreciated (judging by the extent of the applaud at the end) by everyone who attended.

Approximately 800 – 900 pictures have been posted of the retreat, Sunday Program, and the drama in the Photo Gallery on this site. You can immediately go to all of them by clicking on the following link. If you wish to see them as a slide show, you can click on "View Slideshow" at the bottom of the page, and the pictures will be shown consecutively from one photo to the next in the form of a slideshow.

Photos in Gallery Link

Hare Krsna.

When I left the temple room after the announcements, I noticed that Mahamana devi dasi was quickly stringing more garlands in the pujari room so that nobody would be left without one.

Also, Sunday happened to be the exact day of the 50th wedding anniversary of Sandipani Muni dasa and Prema Sagara devi dasi—long time residents and very active participants in devotee care from Kharkov. An announcement was made, words of appreciation were spoken by several devotees who knew them well, gifts and garland were offered to them, and then both spoke a few humble words, expressing their gratitude for the association of each other and for the association of devotees in general. It was a very nice ending for the Sunday announcements and was greatly appreciated by everyone, including myself, by seeing how a householder couple can stay together and selflessly serve the community of Vaisnavas as householders for so many years.

After the feast Sadacara dasa and his drama troupe from Dnepropetrovsk put on a very nice drama about the life of Haridasa Thakur. As usual, it was a very impressive performance and was greatly appreciated (judging by the extent of the applaud at the end) by everyone who attended.

Approximately 800 – 900 pictures have been posted of the retreat, Sunday Program, and the drama in the Photo Gallery on this site. You can immediately go to all of them by clicking on the following link. If you wish to see them as a slide show, you can click on "View Slideshow" at the bottom of the page, and the pictures will be shown consecutively from one photo to the next in the form of a slideshow.

Photos in Gallery Link

Hare Krsna.

data.title: Holy Name Weekend
data.blurb: Several hundred devotees assembled in New Vraja Dhama this past weekend for Holy Name Weekend on November 7 – 8.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
Several hundred devotees assembled in New Vraja Dhama this past weekend for Holy Name Weekend on November 7 – 8. Many devotees came from England and Wales, and naturally devotees from all over Hungary also participated in this annual event – kirtan all day long from 7:00 AM to 10:00 PM with a short one-hour break for lunch.

Madhava dasa also came from Switzerland and led some very wonderful kirtans. And of course, Sivarama Maharaja led many intense kirtans, Kesava Bharati Maharaja led, and I was also asked to lead some of the kirtans as well.

Unfortunately, because of my late flight arrival on Friday, I was unable to arrive in New Vraja Dhama until 11:00 AM Saturday morning and I missed all the kirtans up until then. For this reason and also because I was not able to stay in the temple room all day long on both days, I was unable to get recordings of all of the kirtans. Most of the kirtans I took part in, I recorded myself and those are the kirtans which are posted here on the site. And since I had to leave New Vraja Dhama early Monday morning in order to return to Budapest, I was unable to get any of the other recordings before I left

To go immediately to the page where all these kirtans were posted, CLICK HERE.

After Holy Name Weekend all the devotees in New Vraja Dhama begin their Prabhupada Marathon. Although the official marathon is from November 23rd until December 24th, the devotees in New Vraja Dhama have a two-week pre-marathon to get warmed up for the actual marathon. So as I was leaving New Vraja Dhama, I could see that gradually the farm was emptying out as everyone was packing their vehicles to relocate to other cities in Hungary and to many cities throughout Europe to get settled for beginning their two-week pre-marathon. There is a very strong marathon spirit here in Hungary. It's very pleasing to see everyone taking the Prabhupada Marathon so seriously.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: About November 5th Talk in Minsk
data.blurb: (Нажмите русский флаг, чтобы читать текст на русскoм языке.)
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
(Нажмите русский флаг, чтобы читать текст на русскoм языке.)

Towards the beginning of the November 5th talk in Minsk, (available in audio and video on this site and in both English and Russian) I asked everyone attending, "How many of you have ever taken part in a Prabhupada Marathon?" When I saw that only about 30% of all those attending put up their hands I decided to speak about the "Prabhupada Marathon", explaining why and how the marathon started back in the early 1970's. The main purpose of my talk was to encourage everyone to take part in the Prabhupada Marathon, and for those who had never participated in a marathon to "at least" once in their life taste the sweetness of distributing Srila Prabhupada's books.

I will not repeat the points I made in that talk here because the entire talk will soon be transcribed and will be available for reading in an upcoming blog.

After the talk, one of the Minsk temple book distributors brought into the temple room about 25 copies of the "Sankirtan" magazine, a very elaborate, colorful, and high-quality magazine published in Russian to inspire book distribution. All of the copies were sold to the devotees and guests within a matter of minutes. I also signed each magazine before they were taken. When we found out that there were not going to be enough copies available for everyone who wanted one, at least another 30 copies were brought into the temple room, some of them older issues. Much to my pleasure, all of these were also signed and purchased until there were no issues left. It was very pleasing to see how much enthusiasm the devotees and guests displayed, wanting to learn more about this transcendental book distribution.

I also mentioned during part of my talk about my godbrother, Vaisesika Prabhu, and how he inspires book distribution in many places throughout America and other countries throughout the world. Vaisesika Prabhu oversees preaching and book distribution in Northern California and inspires the entire congregation of the San Jose, California devotee community to regularly go out on weekend marathons to distribute Srila Prabhupada's books. During my last visit to San Jose earlier this year, Vaisesika Prabhu told me that approximately 240 devotees went out for the Srila Bhaktivinode Thakur Weekend Marathon and thousands of books were distributed exclusively by congregational devotees.

In order to give the devotees a vision on how to distribute books and especially how to become qualified to distribute Srila Prabhupada's books, Vaisesika Prabhu has put together different "Power Point" presentations which he has used to inspire the San Jose devotee community. One of those presentations is as follows.

Please go through each slide of this 81-slide presentation and hopefully you'll find some deeper insights which could inspire you to either catch up or rekindle some enthusiasm to experience for yourself the pleasure found in pleasing Srila Prabhupada through the distribution of his books.

To move the presentation forward, move the cursor to the right side of the frame and a hand pointing right will appear. Just click and each frame will move forward one at a time. To go back, move the cursor to the left side of the frame and a hand pointing left will appear. Click and the frame will move back one at a time.

Hare Krsna.

data.title: A report on what I have been doing and will be doing in the near future
data.blurb: I returned to Budapest last Friday. Unfortunately, due to the intensity of my schedule during the period just before Govardhana Puja, during Govardhana Puja, and a for a few days after Govardhana Puja, I've experienced setbacks with my back.
data.author: Niranjana Swami

Body_raw.value:
I returned to Budapest last Friday. Unfortunately, due to the intensity of my schedule during the period just before Govardhana Puja, during Govardhana Puja, and a for a few days after Govardhana Puja, I've experienced setbacks with my back. My back had been much better a few weeks prior to Govardhana Puja, to the point where I was able to take long japa walks, almost effortlessly, and sometimes 4-5 miles every day. Moreover, the doctor did not see the need to give me any injections for the past several weeks. After Govardhana Puja, however, and especially after sitting in many meetings, two days ago the doctor said the the inflammation in the lower spine had substantially increased once again. He had to give me six injections that day and he has to come and see me again early tomorrow morning here at the temple because he is very concerned about an upcoming trip I am planning to Belarus (more about that trip later).

Moreover, due to inflammation and the other consequences of that inflammation, the therapist had to change my therapy to once every two hours, no sitting for more than 30 minutes, no walking for more than 30 minutes, and mandated that I lie down more frequently.

So all that has affected my daily activity. I have been writing a lot more letters than usual these past several days, but still I have to get up frequently from the chair. I haven't been able to figure out a way to stand and type yet, but that may come in the future.

My correspondence these past few days, other than writing many important letters connected to my GBC responsibilities, has especially been centered on refining the system Amsumati devi dasi and I have set up for dealing with both old and new correspondence that she translates for me.

Other than correspondence which comes through Amsumati dd, I get many letters from five other sources:

1) Direct email (a lot more than probably most of you think that I get)
2) Hand-delivered
3) From Sarva Laksmi dd
4) Contained with counselor reports from Sarva Laksmi dd
5) Postal mail

These past several days I've also had to deal with correspondence concerning this website and how the layout and translations into Russian can be improved in the future. I'm also trying my best to produce a blog on a regular basis and I also try to make sure that the website gets updated as frequently as possible with some kind of new material.

Once GBC issues get a little more sorted out and less of my time is required to deal with these issues, my desire is to gradually start posting more blogs on my readings and on what I am hearing from Srila Prabhupada's lectures while I'm exercising.

I've also resumed watching the "Following Srila Prabhupada" series by Yadubara Prabhu over the course of the last few weeks. Every day that I watch them I get ever-fresh realizations on the depth of Srila Prabhupada's compassion. Just the other day I wrote the following in a letter to Yadubara Prabhu:

"It took a little while for #9 to catch up to me because I haven't been in the States since February. Since Sivarama Swami is at the farm right now and I'm staying in Budapest to meet my doctors' appointments, I'm watching #9 every day while I take lunch. Such nectar! I can't tell you how moved I am when I hear these stories and see Krsna's perfect representative before my eyes. As I've told devotees in the past, watching this "Following Srila Prabhupada" series is like doing bhajan. For me, it is total absorption. I can't help but think about Krsna when I meditate on Prabhupada by the process you've so expertly given for us to meditate upon him. Thank you so much! I can't wait for #10 and #11!!!"

Other than writing, I've also been averaging at least four international phone calls a day, some lasting as long as two hours, dealing with both personal matters and GBC matters. I also speak regularly with many godbrothers, who either call me or I call them.

Yesterday, among the several phone conversations I had, I spoke for quite some time with my godbrother Mukta Vandya Prabhu, who unfortunately just recently suffered from his second heart attack. I found out about his heart attack when a scanned letter from him arrived in my email from the Temple President of Boston. His handwriting was shaky because it was a very serious heart attack. So the Temple President of Boston also typed out his message to me and it was as follows:

"Dear Niranjana Swami,

Please accept my humble obeisances. All glories to Srila Prabhupada.

You might have heard that I had a 2nd heart attack. I didn’t think I would live thru it in this body.

I wanted to tell you I love you & I could never repay you for all you did for me over the years. I thank you for what you’ve done for me & so many others. I hope to see you again. I’ll be in Boston for at least 2 more weeks if you want to write, after that I’ll be in Gita Nagari.

Yours in the service of Prabhupada,

Mukta"

I've known Mukta Vandya Prabhu for more than 36 years. He is a wonderful devotee and I've spoken publicly about him on several occasions when he had his first heart attack two years ago. But this time, his situation is much more serious. The doctors told him that right now his heart is working at only a 35% capacity, and that there was permanent damage to part of his heart too. Still the doctors say that the 35% could increase if he follows their recommendations.

Mukta Vandya repeatedly refers to Krsna's will whenever we talk about his situation. But it seemed that he now also knows a lot better that he has a role to play in that outcome as well, and it's time for him to change the way that he lives.

I therefore had to request him to put his sister Kathy on the phone so that I could talk with her too. She is very friendly, kind, she loves her younger brother, and she knows very well that I love him too. I spoke with her for quite some time. I wanted to assure her that if she needed help convincing Mukta Vandya to change his lifestyle, I was ready to help her. She was very grateful, but she assured me that after this second heart attack, Mukta Vandya finally got the message that he has to stop working so hard.

Mukta Vandya lives in the Gita Nagari Farm in U.S.A, in the corner of the basement of the temple building. He has a business in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania which means that before his second heart attack not only was he working all day with his business, but he had to drive back and forth from the farm for more than one hour each way every day. This business requires a good amount of physical work too, but since his business supports a lot of projects on the farm and many devotees on the farm too, he didn't want to give it up. He hardly ever takes anything from the business for himself. He has been doing this for many years and is an ideal example of a very selfless devotee.

Yesterday I also spent some time before my late lunch talking with Karunamayi devi dasi and her husband Mahateja dasa who happened to be passing through Budapest. She did not know that I was here when they arrived in Budapest two days ago, but when I heard that she was downstairs, I went down to speak with both of them for awhile while they were taking prasadam.

Then yesterday I decided to spend more time with both of them because I have not had the opportunity to spend much time in person with them since the time Karunamayi was in the automobile accident five years ago which, despite many surgeries and treatments since then, has left her still unable to walk.

So yesterday the three of us drove a short distance to the banks of the nearby Danube River. We walked and we talked for quite some time along the paved path next to the river, while her husband pushed her briskly along in her wheelchair. After walking a good 1-2 kilometers, we then stopped and while Mahateja and I sat on a bench, Karunamayi enthusiastically continued to share with me the many realizations she's had over the past several years. I was very happy to just hear the many realizations both she and her husband wanted to share with me. Maybe some day, if she's inclined, I may ask her to share them with all of you. But for now, I will say that I could see that she is getting a lot of mercy because she is sincerely trying her best to surrender to Krsna's will.

Also, this afternoon, Sridama, Kisori, and their daughter, Radharani, are scheduled to arrive in Budapest to conduct seminars here on the counseling system and on the grhastha asrama for the upcoming week. Sridama and I have been in regular correspondence about this visit, and as always, I know that they will hope that I will spend some time with them, separately, as well as during their presentations to the Hungarian devotees.

My original plan was to spend the whole week as much as possible with them between Budapest and the farm, especially because Sivarama Maharaja had a prior commitment which will take him out of Hungary on Saturday morning. But over the course of the past couple of weeks I felt the need to fulfill my GBC duties in Belarus since I have not been there for more than fourteen months. I applied for my Belarussian visa a few days ago, and I will fly to Belarus on November 2nd arriving in the early to mid-afternoon, and will then leave Minsk for Budapest on the 6th shortly after noon.

For those of you who are in Belarus, or who might be thinking to visit Belarus during my visit, I will quote the following relevant points from letters written to devotees in Belarus which will hopefully make it clear what should be expected from me during this visit:

"There will be no program on November 2nd evening. I will do [short] programs in Minsk on November 3rd evening and November 4th evening. I will try, if my body is still holding up, to go to Vitebsk for a program on November 5th evening, returning to Minsk on the 6th morning. But the trip to Vitebsk will really depend upon the degree of pain in my back on the 5th. Therefore, if there are any devotees from Vitebsk who want to attend programs and are assuming that I will be in Vitebsk on the 5th, they should be told that my trip to Vitebsk is not definite and to visit Minsk would be a safer option.

There should be a discussion between Yuga Avatara dasa, Vrikodara dasa and Acyuta Priya dasa on the 2nd morning to make a schedule for my meetings for the 2nd (5 PM - 7 PM), 3rd (11:00 AM to 2:00 PM) and 4th (11:00 AM - 2:00 PM). [The meetings on these three days will be related to GBC matters only and only those invited by the assigned secretary for this trip, Acyuta Priya dasa, will be allowed to attend]

[There may be time on the 5th morning from 10:00 – 12:00 for a few short personal meetings, but my secretary will make the decisions of who and when. Nobody should approach me for a personal meeting.]

I cannot say for sure whether there will be a general disciple meeting during this visit or not. […] Disciples should [therefore] be warned ahead of time that there may not be time for a general disciple's meeting [during this visit]."

Hare Krsna.

I applied for my Belarussian visa a few days ago, and I will fly to Belarus on November 2nd arriving in the early to mid-afternoon, and will then leave Minsk for Budapest on the 6th shortly after noon.

"There will be no program on November 2nd evening. I will do [short] programs in Minsk on November 3rd evening and November 4th evening. I will try, if my body is still holding up, to go to Vitebsk for a program on November 5th evening, returning to Minsk on the 6th morning. But the trip to Vitebsk will really depend upon the degree of pain in my back on the 5th.
